%BASO:
Description: Basophils are granulated white blood cells that are increased with parasitic, neoplastic, and allergic conditions.

 

Increased Basophils    

 

  • Parasitic infection
  • Hypersensitivity responses
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic
    • Chronic basophilic leukemia  

  

Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Basophils

 

  • Parasitic infection
    • CBC:
      • Variable anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Skin scrapings to assess for ectoparasites
    • Fecal Dx antigen tests and/or fecal ova and parasites test positive with intestinal parasites.
    • Positive heartworm testing (serology for antigen or antibody, microfilaria testing)
  • Hypersenstivity responses
    • Asthma 
      • Bronchial pattern on thoracic radiographs
      • Eosinophilic and neutrophilic inflammation found on transtracheal or endotracheal wash
    • Eosinophilic granuloma complex
      • Histopathology supportive of eosinophilic granuloma complex
    • Allergic dermatitis/atopy
      • Abnormalities on skin allergy testing
      • Positive reactions on serum allergy testing
      • Histopathology supportive of allergic dermatitis
    • Food allergies/eosinophilic gastroenteritis 
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies showing eosinophilic inflammation
      • Gastric and/or intestinal wall thickening found on abdominal ultrasound
      • Abnormal serum folate and cobalamin
    • Allergic rhinitis/sinusitis
      • Lymphoplasmacytic or eosinophilic inflammation on nasal biopsies
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
    • Most comon in middle-aged female, domestic shorthair cats and Rottweiler dogs
    • CBC:
      • Variable mild nonregenerative anemia
      • Marked mature eosinophilia (typically >20,000 cells/ul)
    • Histopathology or cytology of any affected organs or masses - eosinophilic infiltration
    • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy to discriminate from eosinophilic leukemia 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic:
      • Cytology or histopathology - consistent with mast cell neoplasia, lymphoma, carcinoma, pulmonary lymphomatoid granulomatosis, polycythemia vera or essential thrombocythemia
    • Chronic basophilic leukemia
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Variably increased platelets
        • Marked basophilia with orderly left shift

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Basophils are typically present in low numbers in mammals.
  • Basophils originate in the bone marrow, circulate briefly, then marginate to tissues.
  • The granules of basophils are round and stain metachromatically (purple) although the intensity varies by species.
    • Mature basophils in cats have very lightly staining granules.
    • Granules are abundant in most species except for the dog.
  • The most prominent constituents of basophil granules are histamine and heparin, substances that promote hypersenstivity reactions and attract eosinophils.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The basophil percentage (or relative basophil count) is the number of basophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute basophil count is calculated by multiplying the basophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
       

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
%EOS:
Description: Eosinophils are white blood cells that are specialized to combat parasites and other infectious diseases. They are also involved in allergic responses.

 

Decreased Eosinophils   

  • Normal (Some reference intervals include zero.)
  • Corticosteroid-induced eosinopenia
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress   
  • Acute inflammation
  • Decreased bone marrow production   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Eosinophils

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced eosinopenia
    • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    • CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • Absence of a left shift
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased lymphocytes
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 
    • Assess for recent history of glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests 
      • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
          
     

Increased Eosinophils
   

  • Hypersensitivity responses (allergy)
  • Infection
    • Parasitic
    • Fungal
    • Pythium
    • FeLV (rare)
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome
  • Endocrine
    • Hyopadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
  • Eosinophilic bronchopneumopathy
  • Eosinophilic leukemia 
 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Eosinophils 

 

  • Hypersensitivity responses
    • Asthma
      • Bronchial pattern on thoracic radiographs
      • Eosinophilic and neutrophilic inflammation found on transtrachael or endotracheal wash
    • Eosinophilic granuloma complex
      • Histopathology supportive of eosinophilic granuloma complex
    • Allergic dermatitis/atopy
      • Abnormalities on skin allergy testing
      • Positive reactions on serum allergy testing
      • Histopathology supportive of allergic dermatitis
    • Food allergies/eosinophilic gastroenteritis 
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies showing eosinophilic inflammation
      • Gastric and/or intestinal wall thickening found on abdominal ultrasound
      • Abnormal serum folate and cobalamin
    • Allergic rhinitis/sinusitis
      • Lymphoplasmacytic or eosinophilic inflammation on nasal biopsies
  • Infection
    • CBC:
      • Variable anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Variable basophilia with parastic infections
    • Skin scrapings to assess for ectoparasites
    • Fecal Dx antigen tests and/or fecal ova and parasite tests positive with intestinal parasites
    • Serology, PCR or antigen tests positive for other infectious causes (e.g. systemic fungal, heartworm, pythiosis, FeLV) 
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
    • Most comon in middle-aged female, domestic shorthair cats and Rottweiler dogs
    • CBC:
      • Variable mild nonregenerative anemia
      • Marked mature eosinophilia (typically >20,000 cells/ul)
      • Basophilia
    • Histopathology or cytology of any affected organs or masses - eosinophilic infiltration
    • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy to discriminate from eosinophilic leukemia 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic:
      • Cytology or histopathology - consistent with mast cell neoplasia, lymphoma, carcinoma or thymoma
    • Eosinophilic leukemia
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia (often severe)
        • Variable thrombocytopenia and neutropenia
        • Immature myelogenous precursors often present
      • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy - eosinophilic leukemia with immature forms and disorderly maturation
  • Endocrine
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
      • CBC:
        • Mild nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium 
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol 
        • Abnormal ACTH stimulation 
    • Hyperthyroidism
      • CBC - mild erythryocytosis
      • Chemistry - increased ALT, ALP, glucose and phosphorus
      • Total T4, Free T4 concentrations increased
  • Eosinophilic bronchopneumopathy
    • Reported in dogs, especially Siberian huskies
    • CBC:
      • Deceased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Thoracic radiographs - bronchointerstitial pattern and air trapping, with occasional lobar consolidation or miliary patterns
    • Heartworm, Fecal Dx antigen and fecal ova and parasite testing -  all negative 
    • Transtracheal or endotracheal wash cytology - increased eosinophils

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Eosinophil granules stain variably eosinophilic (pink) depending on the species, and their shape is species specific.
    • The granules are large, round, and uniform in the horse, and rod-shaped and less bright in the cat.
    • Dogs can have varying numbers and sizes of granules.
    • The granules contain lysozymes and other substances that are important to their protective function.
  • Eosinophils are active in killing of helminths and also in the regulation of mast cells.
  • Eosinophils are most commonly found in the skin, lung, gastrointestinal tract and endometrium.

  

Diagnostic Methodology 

 
  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The eosinophil percentage (or relative eosinophil count) is the number of eosinophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute eosinophil count is calculated by multiplying the eosinophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.

  

References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
%LYM:
Description:  Lymphocytes are white blood cells which are derived from lymphoid tissues including the lymph nodes, spleen and thymus.  Lymphocytes play a role in cell-mediated and humoral immune responses.

 

Decreased Lymphocytes 

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Acute systemic infection
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
    • Chylous effusions
  • Immunosuppressive therapy
  • Infiltrative lymphatic disease
  • Hereditary immunodeficiency
       

     Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Lymphocytes

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    • CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • Absence of a left shift
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased eosinophils 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 
    • Assess for recent history of glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests 
      • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Acute systemic infection
    • Lymphopenia most commonly seen with sepsis, endotoxemia or early viral infections
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic change +/- band neutrophils
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils 
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of systemic infection:
      • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (esp.viral)
      • Blood culture or urine culture to assess for systemic bacterial infections
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin and globulin
        • Decreased cholesterol
        • Decreased total calcium
      • GI panel:
        • Folate variably decreased (if proximal infiltrative intestinal disease) or increased (with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)
        • Cobalamin decreased (if distal infiltrative intestinal disease)
        • Spec cPL or fPL test - variably increased with secondary pancreatic inflammation
      • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - confirms gastrointestinal protein loss
      • Ultrasound to assess for thickened intestinal walls, loss of wall layering and/or enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies to evaluate for lymphangiectasia and infiltrative disease (lymphoma, severe inflammatory bowel disease)
    • Chylous effusions
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin
      • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for body cavity effusions
      • Cytology of effusion consistent with chylous effusion
      • Effusion triglycerides and cholesterol:
        • Fluid triglycerides higher than serum triglycerides
        • Fluid cholesterol lower than serum cholesterol
        • Effusion cholesterol: triglyceride ratio <1
      • Next steps to assess for underlying causes:
        • Cardiopet proBNP test:
          • Increased with cardiomyopathy
          • Variably decreased with significant pericardial effusion
        • Heartworm antigen serology for antigen or antibody testing, microfilaria testing
        • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound, echocardiogram) to evaluate for cardiac disease, cranial mediastinal mass, or venous obstruction

 

  Increased Lymphocytes   

 

  • Physiologic lymphocytosis (epinephrine effect)
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • Chronic infection
    • Post-vaccination
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • Lymphocytic leukemia, acute and chronic
    • Leukemic phase of lymphoma
    • Thymoma

   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Lymphocytes

 

  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia
      • Larger and/or reactive lymphocytes 
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - variably increased
    • Assess for recent vaccination (especially serial vaccinations).
    • Next steps to assess for chronic infection:
      • Positive serology, PCR or antigen tests for infectious diseases (esp. ehrlichiosis)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Mild nonregenerative anemia 
      • Normal to increased eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium 
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol 
      • Abnormal ACTH stimulation test 
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia common
      • Variable leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
      • Lymphoid blasts present with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and the leukemic phase of lymphoma
      • Mature lymphocytosis with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL); may be reactive
    • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound) to help differentiate between leukemic stage lymphoma and ALL
    • Serology, PCR and antigen tests:
      • Negative for tick-borne diseases and other infectious causes of reactive lymphocytosis 
      • FeLV positive common as predisposing cause of leukemia and lymphoma in cats
    • Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on whole blood - confirms leukemia/leukemic phase vs reactive lymphocytosis
    • Cytology or histopathology of enlarged lymph nodes or lymphoid organs - consistent with lymphoma
    • Bone marrow cytology or histopathology:
      • ALL - blast cells present, may require immunocytochemical stains to differentiate
      • CLL - infiltration with mature lymphocytes
    • Lymphoma PCR (PCR for antigen receptor rearrangement [PARR]) - confirms lymphoma/leukemia and determines B-cell vs T-cell for specimen with equivocal cytology (whole blood, bone marrow, lymph node or splenic aspirate)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Mature lymphocytes are approximately 1-1.5 times the size of a red blood cell, with scant bluish cytoplasm, round to oval nuclei, and aggregated or clumped chromatin.
  • Lymphocytes differ from other leukocytes in that after leaving the vascular system, they can recirculate and have a relatively long half-life (months to years).
  • Their primary function is humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

  

   Diagnostic  Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The lymphocyte percentage (or relative lymphocyte count) is the number of lymphocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute lymphocyte count is calculated by multiplying the lymphocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of lymphocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
%MONO:
Description: Monocytes are white blood cells that are responsible for phagocytosis, antigen presentation, and production of cytokines.

Increased Monocytes 

  •   Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced monocytosis
  • Chronic or acute monocytic/myelomonocytic leukemia
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia  

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Monocytes

  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs- positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
     Corticosteroid-induced monocytosis
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils
      • Absence of a left shift 
      • +/-increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Monocytes are the largest cells (typically 15-20 µm in diameter) present in normal peripheral blood.
  • They have abundant blue-gray cytoplasm, often with multiple, variably-sized clear vacuoles.  Their nuclei may be oval, kidney bean-shaped, or convoluted.  The nuclear chromatin is finely granular to lacy, with only a few clumped areas.
  • Monocytes arise in the bone marrow, circulate, then differentiate into tissue macrophages after they leave the peripheral blood vasculature.  They do not recirculate.
  • Their main functions include phagocytosis of infectious agents and particulate matter, production of mediators that promote blood cell production (hemopoiesis), and release of inflammatory mediators.
  • They produce cytokines important for immunoregulation and present foreign substances to immunocompetent lymphocytes.
  • Monocytes also differentiate into many types of tissue macrophages (e.g. Kupffer cells in the liver).
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The monocyte percentage (or relative monocyte count) is the number of monocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute monocyte count is calculated by multiplying the monocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of monocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

  

References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Reagan WJ, Irizarry Rovira AR, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology Atlas of Common Domestic and Non-Domestic Species, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Wiley-Blackwell; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
%NEU:
Description: Segmented neutrophils are the most abundant type of white blood cell (WBC). They respond quickly to inflammation and stress, are capable of phagocytosis, and have antimicrobial properties.

 

Decreased Neutrophils

  • Decreased neutrophil production (bone marrow suppression)
    • Infection
    • Drugs/toxins
    • Immune-mediated destruction (targeting neutrophil precursors)
    • Bone marrow disease
    • Cyclic hemopoiesis - Grey Collie Syndrome
    • Neutropenia of Giant Schnauzers (secondary to vitamin B12 malabsorption)
    • Idiopathic
  • Excessive tissue demand and/or destruction of neutrophils
    • Endotoxemia/sepsis
    • Inflammation
    • Bacterial infection  
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Neutrophils

 

  • Decreased neutrophil production
    • CBC may show decreases in other cell lines:
      • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Thrombocytopenia
    • Assess for history or possibility of exposure to drugs that may suppress bone marrow, e.g.: 
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Azathioprine
      • Chloramphenicol
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Methimazole
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy shows decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of myeloid cell line or other changes.
    • Next steps to evaluate for infectious causes:
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Blood film review - toxic neutrophils, band neutrophils or reactive lymphocytes may be seen 
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Positive serology or PCR tests for infectious diseases (e.g. parvovirus, panleukopenia, FeLV, FIV, ehrlichiosis)
    • Idiopathic neutropenia is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Excessive tissue demand (and destruction) of neutrophils
    • Migration into tissues in response to endotoxin, inflammation or infection where the rate of migration exceeds the rate of replacement from the bone marrow.
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review:
        • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils, toxic neutrophils may be seen 
        • Red blood cell fragments (e.g. schistocytes, poikilocytes) may be seen with secondary disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP) 
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for effusion, localized inflammation or infection where neutrophils may be sequestered
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
      • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria

 

Increased Neutrophils 

  

  • Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia (stress leukogram)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • Granulocytic leukemia 
    • Chronic myeloid leukemia
    • Acute myeloid leukemia
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic neutrophilia
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Neutrophils

 

  • Evaluate for the presence of immature neutrophils (bands):
    • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) may show a band indictator.
    • Comparison of patient WBC dot plot to species-specific normals may show pattern changes consistent with the presence of bands. 
      • For example, in the IDEXX ProCyte Dx, the WBC dot plot shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population if bands are present.
    • Blood film review
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophils have toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Increased monocytes and neutrophils
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile -variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases: 
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia:
        • Non-myeloid neoplasia can result in neutrophilia in response to secondary inflammation or as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with release of G-CSF.
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Increased monocytes 
      • Absence of a left shift 
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response 
    • CBC:
      • Increased lymphocytes and neutrophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Segmented neutrophils are the mature neutrophils that form the largest portion of the WBC count in domestic animals.
  • Neutrophils are only in the peripheral blood for approximately ten hours before exiting the vascular system, either from normal cell death or in response to chemotactic factors.
  • Neutrophils are quickly activated and increase in number in response to a myriad of stimuli, such as infecting agents (viral, bacterial, fungal, parasitic, etc), foreign substances, tissue damage, necrosis, and cancers.
  • Neutrophils exist in two main pools in the peripheral blood: those freely floating in circulation (circulating neutrophil pool or CNP) and those adhered to the endothelium (marginated neutrophil pool or MNP); only the neutrophils in the CNP are measured on a CBC.
  • Neutrophils can be recruited from the MNP within minutes (e.g. in response to stress) and will then increase the neutrophil count
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The segmented neutrophil percentage (or relative segmented neutrophil count) is the number of segmented neutrophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute neutrophil count is calculated by multiplying the neutrophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) show a band indicator when bands may be present, indicating the need to evaluate the WBC dot plot and/or perform a blood film review.
  • Evaluation of the WBC dot plot can provide valuable information about the presence of immature neutrophils (bands), platelet clumping or morphologic abnormalities which may impact the automated white blood cell differential. 
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of neutrophil abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).
      

   References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Reagan WJ, Irizarry Rovira AR, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology Atlas of Common Domestic and Non-Domestic Species, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Wiley-Blackwell; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
     

Last updated 7/1/2018
%RETIC:
Description: Reticulocytes are immature red blood cells that do not have a nucleus.  Their presence in circulation is used to differentiate regenerative from nonregenerative anemia. Reticulocytosis in the absence of anemia can be an indication of significant underlying disease accompanied by RBC loss or destruction with an adequate regenerative response (compensated anemia). Reticulocytes should be evaluated along with the reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) for early detection of blood loss and inflammatory conditions prior to the development of anemia.

 

Increased Reticulocytes

 

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Blood loss
      • Hemorrhage
      • Parasitism
    • Immune-mediated hemolysis
      • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
      • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
        • Heinz body anemia
          • Toxins
          • Drugs
          • Dietary
        • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
          • Vasculitis
          • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
          • Hemangiosarcoma
          • Heartworm infection
        • Metabolic
        • Hereditary
        • Envenomation
  • Reticulocytosis in the absence of anemia
    • Physiologic reticulocytosis - splenic contraction
      • Excitement
      • Exercise
      • Drugs: epinephrine
    • Compensated anemia
      • Blood loss
      • Hemolysis
    • Absolute erythrocytosis
      • Endocrine
      • Secondary polycythemia
      • Polycythemia vera

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Reticulocytes

 

  • Regenerative Anemia:
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, MCHC, MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses) 
  • Reticulocytosis in absence of anemia
    • Physiologic reticulocytosis - most often due to splenic contraction (dogs only)
      • CBC:
        • Normal RBC, hematocrit, MCV and RDW
        • Reticulocytosis is generally mild
    • Compensated anemia - regeneration of RBCs is keeping up with RBC loss or destruction
      • CBC:
        • RBC and hematocrit at low end of normal
        • MCV and RDW increased
        • Decreased MCH and MCHC
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Absolute erythrocytosis
      • CBC:
        • High normal to increased RBC and hematocrit
        • +/- increased nucleated RBCs 
      • Endocrine
        • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
        • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
          • Hyperthyroidism
          • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
          • Acromegaly
      • Secondary polycythemia
        • CBC - marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Erythropoietin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal
        • Systemic hypoxia:
          • Thoracic imaging for evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
          • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
          • Decreased PA02 and Sa02
          • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
        • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
          • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneoplastic syndrome
          • Abdominal imaging for evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia (e.g. hepatoma)
      • Polycythemia vera
        • CBC:
          • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
          • Platelets - variably increased
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
        • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney abnormalities or neoplasia
        • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion

 

Normal Reticulocytes

  • Normal reticulocytes with anemia
    • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Chronic inflammatory disease
        • Infection
        • Immune-mediated
        • Neoplasia
      • Chronic blood loss
        •  Parasitism
        • Hemorrhage
      • Decreased erythropoietin production
        • Chronic kidney disease
        • Hypothyroidism
        • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
      • Bone marrow suppression
        • Drugs/toxins
        • Bone marrow disease
      • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
        • Pure red cell aplasia
      • Nutritional deficiences
        • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
        • Folate
    • Acute pre-regenerative anemia
      • Acute blood loss
      • Acute hemolytic anemia
  • Normal reticulocytes in absence of anemia
    • Normal - a non-anemic patient typically has low numbers of circulating reticulocytes

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Anemia without Reticulocytosis

 

  • Non-regenerative anemia
    • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • +/- microcytosis
        • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Iron Panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
        • Increased serum ferritin
      • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
        • Immune-mediated diseases:
          • CBC:
            • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
            • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
            • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
          • Coombs - positive if IMHA
          • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
          • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
        • Systemic infection:
          • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
        • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
          • Pancreatitis:
            • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
            • Amylase and lipase variably increased
          • Pyelonephritis:
            • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
            • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
            • Urine culture - positive
        • Neoplasia:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
    • Chronic blood Loss - causing iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Decreased erythropoietin production
      • CBC:
        • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
        • Decreased RBC and hematocrit
        • Normal RDW
      • Evaluate for underlying causes:
        • Chronic kidney disease:
          • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
          • Urinalysis:
            • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
            • +/- proteinuria
          • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
          • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
        • Hypothyroidism:
          • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
          • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
        • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
          • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
            • Variably increased potassium and calcium
            • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
            • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
          • Adrenal function tests:
            • Decreased resting serum cortisol
            • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
    • Bone marrow suppression:
      • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
        • Chemotherapy
        • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
        • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
        • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
        • Griseofulvin (cats)
      • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
        • Thrombocytopenia
        • Leukopenia
        • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
      • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
    • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with PSS
        • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acathocytes
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased (or decreased) ALT, ALP
        • Variably increased bilirubin (not seen with PSS)
        • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol, glucose
      • Urinalysis:
        • Urine specific gravity is variable, may be inappropriate (USG < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats) due to altered thirst and/or low BUN
        • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
        • Bilirubinuria (not seen with PSS)
      • Increased bile acids
      • Increased ammonia
    • Acute pre-regenerative anemia
      • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator
      • Acute blood loss
        • Chemistry - low serum total protein
        • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
      • Hemolytic disease
        • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
        • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
        • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
        • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Reticulocytes are immature red blood cells that do not have a nucleus. Reticulocytes have stainable cytoplasmic RNA which differentiates them from mature red blood cells.
  • Reticulocytes are released into circulation as part of a regenerative response to anemia (except in the horse).
  • Circulating reticulocytes have a 2-3 day life span in dogs.  Reticulocyte life span is more variable in cats.
    • In dogs with an acute anemia, reticulocytosis is noted in about 3-4 days, peak reticulocyte production occurs at about 7 days
    • In cats, peak reticulocyte production is expected 7-14 days after an acute anemia
  • For all species except the horse, anemia can be classified as non-regenerative or regenerative based on the bone marrow response assessed by the number of reticulocytes in circulation. Reticulocytes are rare in the horse.
    • Non-regenerative anemias have low reticulocyte counts.
      • Note that some non-regenerative anemias may be pre-regenerative (the anemia has developed too recently for the regenerative response to have started; typically <3-4 days).
    • Regenerative anemias have increased reticulocyte counts.
  • Reticulocytosis can be found in non-anemic animals due to either splenic contraction or a compensated anemia (the RBC production is greater than RBC loss or destruction)
    • Splenic contraction usually results in a mild reticulocytosis. Moderate to severe reticulcytosis is concerning for signficant underlying disease with compensated anemia.
    • Monitoring CBCs over time can help to determine if the reticulocytosis is persistent and progressive.
    • Concurrent decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) suggests compensated anemia

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Incubation of RBCs with new methylene blue causes the stain to precipitate and allows detection of the RNA and mitochondria on the blood film.
  • Some reticulocytes can be seen on a Wright-stained blood film.  The cells have a blue tinge (polychromatophils) to them but if there is not enough RNA in the cell it may not be detected by this method.
  • Cats have two types of reticulocytes (punctate and aggregate) that can be detected when evaluating reticulocytes on a new methylene blue stained blood film.
    • Aggregate reticulocytes have large aggregates of RNA and are a better indicator of active marrow release
    • Punctate reticulocytes have 2-6 small granules
  • Reticulocytes can be expressed as a reticulocyte concentration or reticulocyte percentage
    • Absolute reticulocyte count (reticulocyte concentration) – the number of reticulocytes per µL.  This is the preferred method for reporting reticulocytes
    • Reticulocyte percentage- the percent RBC that are reticulocytes.  For example – if you have 5 reticulocytes per 1000 RBC, the reticulocyte percentage would be 0.5%
  • Reticulocytes can be evaluated by two techniques
    • Manual – A new methylene blue stained blood smear is evaluated – the number of reticulocytes per 1000 nonnucleated RBCs is evaluated
    • Automated – CBC analyzers either use a light scatter method or florescence detection to identify reticulocytes.

 

   References

 

  • Fuchs J, Moritz A, et al. Reticulocytosis in non-anaemic cats and dogs. J Small An Practice2019 in press.
  • Harvey JW. Atlas of Veterinary Hematology: Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals. Philadelphia, PA: WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
﻿Description:  The Anaplasma antibody test uses a species-specific synthetic peptide that detects IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both Anaplasma phagocytophilum and A. platys. A. phagocytophilum is the causative agent of granulocytotrophic anaplasmosis in dogs, cats, horses, humans and ruminants. A. platys is the causative agent of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia in dogs.

Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Active infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
  • Residual or declining antibody response from a previously cleared/treated infection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is clinical evidence of anaplasmosis with supportive history and physical exam findings.
  • CBC:
    • Thrombocytopenia, normocytic, normochromic nonregenerative anemia
    • Neutrophilia (occasionally neutropenia) and monocytosis
    • Variable eosinopenia and lymphopenia
    • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (A. phagocytophilium) may be seen on blood film evaluation early in infection (usually prior to seroconversion).
    • Morulae inclusions within platelets (A. platys) may been seen on blood film evaluation.
  • Chemistry:
    • Decreased albumin
    • Increased globulin, ALP, ALT
  • Urinalysis - variable increased protein
  • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased
  • Infectious disease testing:
    • For dogs presenting with clinical signs consistent with a vector-borne disease, using serology and PCR together improves ability to make a complete and accurate diagnosis.
    • PCR-positive for Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
      • Negative PCR result after treatment can indicate a reduction in pathogen load
      • Vector-borne disease PCR panel may identify co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Bartonella spp., Ehrlichia spp.)
    • IFA
      • Positive for Anaplasma spp. organism
        • Separate IFA tests are available for A. phagocytophilum and A. platys.
        • IFA can be subjective and may cross react with other species of Anaplasma and Ehrlichia
  • Joint cytology - findings may include increased mononuclear cell and neutrophil counts
  • CSF - findings may include neutrophilic pleocytosis

Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody concentration below the limit of detection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • In a dog with history, clinical signs and clinical pathology consistent with canine granulocytic anaplasmosis or infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia, consider:
    • Blood film evaluation for morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (may be seen prior to seroconversion)
    • Vector-borne disease PCR panel to detect early infection prior to seroconversion and to evaluate for co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Ehrlichia spp., Bartonella spp.)

Additional Information

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of tick/vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide
  • View the Anaplasma Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/anaplasma-next-steps.
  • Access additional vector borne disease resources at www.idexx.com/4Dx-plus-resources.

Physiology

  • Anaplasma phagocytophilum (transmitted by Ixodes spp ticks) is the cause of canine granulocytic anaplasmosis in dogs (a.k.a. granulocytrophic anaplasmosis).
    • Transmission of A. phagocytophilum occurs with a minimum feeding time of 24 hours, and may take up to 48 hours of tick attachment.
    • Anaplasma phagocytophilum has a worldwide distribution and disease is commonly diagnosed in temperate zones of the northern hemisphere. In the United States, disease prevalence is highest in areas associated with the primary tick vector, specifically the northeastern, mid-Atlantic and upper Midwest (Ixodes scapularis) and the west coast (Ixodes pacificus).
    • In the United States, seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the dog ranges from 0-68% depending on location of the study.
    • In Europe, seroprevalence in dogs ranges from 5-71%.
      • Seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the cat population has been reported as 1.8%, however there is no specific data regarding rate of active infection in cats.
    • Clinical signs of dogs infected with A. phagocytophilum (canine granulocytic anaplasmosis) include fever, lethargy, and polyarthritis. Occasionally these signs are accompanied by lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and rarely neurologic signs. Clinical signs are typically only present during the acute, rickettsemic phases when the organism is circulating in the blood.
  • Anaplasma platys (transmitted by Rhipacephalus sanguineus and Dermacentor spp.) is the cause of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • Anaplasma platys is the only intracellular infectious agent known to specifically infect the platelets of animals.
    • After the organism is innoculated into the host and appears in circulating platelets, severe thrombocytopenia (i.e. typically <20,000/uL) results with 8-14 days.
    • Platelet counts usually remain below 20,000/uL for one or two days.
    • The organisms then disappear rapidly from the peripheral blood, and platelet counts rise quickly, reaching a normal value in three or four days.
    • Subsequently, organisms will reappear at one-to two-week intervals, and the process repeats, resulting in a cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • The percentage of parasitized platelets and the severity of the thrombocytopenic episodes decrease with subsequent cycles of parasitemia.
    • A tick vector for A. platys infection has not been conclusively determined. Since the DNA of A. platys has been amplified in Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) and Dermacentor spp. ticks, these are the suspected tick vectors for infection with this organism. Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) is present throughout the continental United States and is one of the most widely distributed ticks in the world.
    • In one study in Arizona, in a location with frequent infestations of dogs with Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick), A. platys DNA was detected in 4.5-8.3% of dogs. Most dogs infected with A. platys have mild clinical disease. Occasionally, signs of petecchial hemorrhage, epistaxis, fever, lethargy, pale mucous membranes and/or lymphadenopathy can occur.
  • Co-infection with other vector-borne diseases (Borrelia burgdorferi, Ehrilichia spp., Babesia microti, Bartonella spp.) is common and the clinical signs can be difficult to distinguish between the co-infections. Co-infection may lead to complex presentations, more severe clinical signs and slower response to therapy.

Diagnostic Methodology

  • ELISA technology is used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both A. phagocytophilum and A. platys. Results are reported as positive or negative.
  • Anaplasma antibody tests will typically be positive for Anapasma spp. 14-30 days after infection with A. phagocytophilum or A. platys. 
  • A positive Anaplasma antibody result generally correlates with an ﻿Anaplasma﻿ spp. IFA titer of 1:100 or higher.

References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Eberts MD, Dinez PPVP, Beall MJ, et al. Typical and atypical manifestations of Anaplasma phagocytophilum infection in dogs. JAAHA 2011; 47:6.
  • Sainz A, Roura R, et al. Guidelines for veterinary practitioners on canine ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis in Europe. Parasites & Vectors. 2015; 8:75.
  • Mazepa AW, Kidd LB, et al. Clinical presentation of 26 Anaplasma phagocytophilum-seropositive dogs residing in an endemic area. JAAHA Nov/Dec 2010; Vol. 46.

Last Updated:  12/1/2018
ALB:
Description:   Albumin is an important regulator of osmotic equilibrium in the body and is also a carrier for highly protein-bound substances (e.g. calcium, thyroxine, fatty acids, and some drugs).

 

Decreased Albumin

 

  • Decreased production
    • Liver disease
      • Chronic severe liver disease with loss of function
      • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Maldigestion/malabsorption (e.g. small intestinal disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency)
    • Malnutrition
      • Decreased intake
      • Severe intestinal parasitism
    • Inflammation (negative acute phase reactant)
    • Compensatory (with hyperglobulinemia)
    • Neonates
    • Pregnancy, lactation
  • Increased loss
    • Protein-losing nephropathy (PLN) 
    • Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE)/lymphangiectasia
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Blood loss
    • Protein-losing dematopathy
    • High protein effusions (e.g. pancreatitis, peritonitis, vasculitis, pleuritis)
  • Hemodilution
    • Excess administraion of intravenous fluids
    • Edema disorders (e.g. congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome)
    • Concurrent hypovolemia and increased total body water
      • Fluid accumulation in third space
      • Fluid accumulation in the GI tract
    • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

 

   Next Steps and Related findings for Decreased Albumin

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, variable reticulocytes
      • Microcytic (decreased MCV), hypochromic (decreased MCHC) anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT) may initially be increased, but with loss of functional hepatic mass may be normal to decreased
      • Bilirubin variably increased
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, glucose, cholesterol and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably decreased total protein
      • Globulins usually normal
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably decreased total protein
      • Globulins usually normal
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Gastrointestinal disease (maldigestion/malabsorption, protein-losing enteropathy)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Possible megaloblastic, hypochromic RBCs (especially with folate deficiency)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased BUN, cholesterol, total protein and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Cobalamin and folate may be abnormal with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
    • Trypsin-like immunoreactivity - decreased with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
    • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - increased with protein-losing enteropathy
    • Abdominal ultrasound - evidence of thickened intestines with small intestinal disease; abdominal effusion may be present with severe protein-losing enteropathy
  • Malnutrition
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein, globulin and cholesterol
      • Variably decreased BUN
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Evaluation for possible causes of malnutrition:
      • Assess for history of excessive calorie restriction or very low protein diet
      • Fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen - positive with intestinal parasites
  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Protein-losing nephropathy
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoetin)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variable globulins - normal to increased
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Proteinuria 
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

Increased Albumin
     

  • Dehydration (with hemoconcentration)
  • Absolute hyperalbuminemia is rare and of doubtful significance.
  • Artifact: depending on testing methodology, increases may be seen with:
    • Lipemia
    • Hemolysis
    • Icterus
    • Use of heparinized plasma (interference due to fibrinogen)
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Albumin

  •  Dehydration
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, albumin and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)
    • Urinalysis - increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • In addition to being an important osmotic regulator and carrier for highly protein bound substances albumin is a negative acute phase reactant.  This means that hypoalbuminemia often develops in acute inflammation and acute tissue injury.
  • It is manufactured exclusively by the liver.

 

   References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer LS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine, Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
ALB/GLOB:
Description:  The albumin: globulin ratio is the amount of albumin in the serum divided by the globulins.  The ratio is used to try to identify causes of change in total serum protein.

 

Decreased Albumin: Globulin Ratio
  

  • Decreased albumin (without decrease in globulins)
    • Decreased production
      • Liver disease
        • Chronic severe liver disease with loss of function
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • Inflammation (negative acute phase protein)
      • Compensatory (with hyperglobulinemia)
      • Neonates
      • Maldigestion/malabsorption (e.g. small intestinal disease, exocrine pancreatic insuffiency)
      • Malnutrition
        • Decreased intake
        • Severe intestinal parasitism
    • Increased loss
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (PLN)
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
      • Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE)
      • Protein-losing dermatopathy
  • Increased globulins (without increase in albumin)
    • Inflammation
      • Chronic inflammatory or immune-mediated disease (e.g. stomatitis)
      • Infection (e.g. feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], ehrlichiosis, chronic pyoderma, ectoparasites, heartworm infection)
    • Neoplasia
      • Multiple myeloma
      • Extra medullary plasma cell tumor
      • Some lymphomas (especially B-cell lymphoma)
    • Near-term pregnancy
    • Lactation

  

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Albumin: Globulin Ratio

  •  Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, varaible reticulocytes
      • Microcytic (decreased MCV), hypochromic (decreased MCHC) anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT) may initially be increased, but with loss of functional hepatic mass may be normal to decreased
      • Bilirubin variably increased
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, glucose, cholesterol and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Globulins usually normal
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and albumin: globulin ratio
      • Globulins usually normal
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate stable nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased globulins
      • Albumin variably decreased (negative acute phase protein)
      • Albumin: globulin ratio decreased
    • Serum protein electrophoresis:
      • Polyclonal gammopathy
      • Increased alpha globulins (acute phase proteins, i.e. fibrinogen)
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Coombs or anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive with immune-mediated diseases
      • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation with polyarthritis
      • Spec cPL/fPL tests - increased with chronic pancreatitis
      • Consider PCR, serology or antigen tests for infectious diseases (heartworm, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], Bartonella, ehrlichiosis, Lyme, toxoplasmosis, Leishmania, etc.)
  • Protein-losing nephropathy
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoetin)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variable globulins - normal to increased
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Proteinuria 
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Globulin usually normal
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Neoplasia (multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, some lymphomas)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Variable hypercalcemia
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Albumin often decreased (compensatory)
    • Urinalysis - urine protein variably positive
