    • Bence Jones urine protein test - variably positive (especially with multiple myeloma or plasma cell tumor)
    • Serum or urine protein electrophoresis - monoclonal gammopathy with multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumors; rarely seen with lymphoma
    • Diagnostic imaging:
      • Radiographs - lytic bone lesions with multiple myeloma
      • Ultrasound - enlarged lymph nodes, spleen, liver or other masses with lymphoma or plasma cell tumor
    • Bone marrow cytology or fine needle aspirate of affected organs, lymph nodes or masses - consistent with neoplasia
    • Lymphoma:
      • Positive PCR for lymphocyte clonal receptor rearrangement (PARR)
      • Clonal expansion on immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on blood or lymph nodes

Increased Albumin: Globulin Ratio
   

  • Artifact:  hemolysis resulting in increased albumin with some methodologies
  • Decreased globulin (without decrease in albumin)
    • Immunodeficiency
      • Failure of passive transfer of colostrum (neonates)
      • Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) - esp. Arabian foals
      • Agammaglobulinemia (horses)
    • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia
  • Increased albumin
    • Dehydration with hemoconcentration (rare without concurrent increase in globulins)

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Albumin: Globulin Ratio

  •  Immunodeficiency
    • Quantitative immunoglobulins decreased

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • The albumin: globulin ratio is a calculated value.
  • The albumin: globulin ratio is used to try to identify causes of change in total serum protein. It will go out of the normal range if one component increases or decreases relative to the other. Hence it is important to look at changes in the individual components (albumin and globulins) as well as the ratio.
  • The albumin: globulin ratio remains constant (in the normal range) if both protein components of the blood change together.  This occurs with:
    • Loss of both albumin and globulin
      • Acute blood loss
      • Exudative skin disease
      • Gastrointestinal disease
      • Acute vasculitis or third space loss
    • Dehydration (increased albumin and globulin)
    • Hemodilution (decreased albumin and globulin)

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
ALKP:
Description: Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is primarily an indicator of cholestatic liver disease.  It also increases with severe bone destruction and with steroid induction (corticosteroid-induced isoenzyme). Physiologic increases in ALP are seen in growing puppies, and possibly other young animals, due to increased osteoblast activity (bone isoenzyme)

 

Increased ALP

 

  • Liver disease with intrahepatic cholestasis
    • Infectious (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. mycotoxins, ragwort, alsike clover)
    • Vascular anomaly (usually mild elevations in ALP if any)
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis to liver
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited 
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
      • Degenerative vacuolar hepatopathy in Scottish terriers
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy and/or steroid induction
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hepatic lipdosis
  • Induction by drugs (e.g. corticosteroids, phenobarbital, thyroxine)
  • Increased osteoblastic activity in bone (particularly dogs)
    • Young animals (increases up to 3-4 times the level in mature dogs)
    • Bone cancer (e.g. osteosarcoma) or metastasis to bone (e.g. mammary tumors)
    • Fracture repair
    • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Benign familial hyperphophatasemia (Siberian huskies, Scottish terriers)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased ALP

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets - mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Elevated ALT, AST, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubinuria, bilirubin or ammonium urate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract.
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP > GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased (unless concurrent inflammatory disease)
      • Increased bilirubin
      • BUN decreased
      • Variable cholesterol and albumin
    • Urinalysis:
      • Variable; often inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.035)
      • Variable bilirubinuria (follows increased serum bilirubin)
    • Bile acids - may be increased with severe disease; not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be increased with severe disease
    • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
    • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
    • Liver cytology or biopsy - severe vacuolar hepatopathy
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
      • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
      • History of stress or household changes

Decreased ALP

 

  • Not clinically significant
  • Artifact
    • Hemolysis or EDTA contamination may decrease ALP significantly

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Alkaline phosphatase refers to a group of enzymes that catalyze hydrolysis of phosphate esters in an alkaline environment in vitro.
  • Cellular function is poorly described, but these are membrane-bound enzymes present in most tissues.
  • High activities are present in liver, bone, intestine, kidney, and placenta.
  • Serum half-life in dogs is approximately 66 hours.
  • Serum half-life in cats is 6 hours, therefore, even mild elevations are considered significant.
  • Changes in the serum level of ALP are attributed primarily to hepatic (L-ALP) and bone (B-ALP) isoenzymes since intestinal, renal, and placental isoenzymes have extremely short half lives.
  • Hepatic ALP is found mainly in liver canalicular cell membranes and increases with biliary disease, especially with cholestasis.
  • In dogs, glucocorticoids (endogenous or exogenous) induce an isoenzyme in the liver (C-ALP) that contributes to serum increases
  • In cats, the hepatic isoenzyme has such a short half life that even minor increases are considered significant.
  • In horses, serum ALP levels are highly variable, and are of limited diagnostic use

 

   References

 

  • Center SA. Degenerative vacuolar hepatopathy and hetocellular carcinoma in Scottish terriers. Proceedings of the 23rd ECVIM Congress, 2013.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Gallagher AE, Panciera DL, Panciera RJ.  Hyperphosphatasemia in Scottish terriers:  7 cases.  JVIM 2006; 20(2):  418-421.
  • Nestor DN, Holan KM, Johnson CA et al. Serum alkaline phosphatase activity in Scottish Terriers versus dogs of other breeds. JAVMA 2006; 228(2): 222-228
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Washabau RJ, Day MH, eds. Canine and Feline Gastroenterology. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2013.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
     

Last Updated 9/1/2024
ALT:
Description: Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) is a cellular enzyme released in response to injury of liver cells.  ALT can also increase mildly with muscular injury and gastrointestinal disease.

 

Increased ALT

  

  • Liver disease
    • Infectious (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, methimazole, mushrooms, sago palm)
    • Vascular anomaly (usually mild elevations in ALT if any)
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis to liver
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited 
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
  • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hepatic lipdosis
  • Skeletal myopathy (severe)
    • Ischemic myopathy (cat)
    • Muscular dystrophy (dog)
    • Trauma

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased ALT

 

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase- increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably increased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably increased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP > GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased (unless concurrent inflammatory disease)
      • Increased bilirubin
      • BUN decreased
      • Variable cholesterol and albumin
    • Urinalysis:
      • Variable; often inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.035)
      • Variable bilirubinuria (follows increased serum bilirubin)
    • Bile acids - may be increased with severe disease; not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be increased with severe disease
    • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
    • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
    • Liver cytology or biopsy - severe vacuolar hepatopathy
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
      • History of stress or household changes

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • ALT is a hepatocellular enzyme
  • ALT is also known as serum glutamic-pyruvic transaminase (SGPT)
  • The enzyme is almost exclusively found within hepatocytes, so serum increases are highly specific for hepatocellular injury in dogs and cats (there is only a minor contribution from skeletal muscle and red blood cells).
  • The magnitude of increase is related to the number of hepatocytes affected, but does not necessarily reflect severity of liver damage nor predict reversibility.
  • The serum half life is 2-3 days for dogs; reductions occur over 1-2 weeks with cessation of hepatic damage.
  • The serum half life is 3.5 hours in cats, therefore minor elevations are significant in this species.
  • The hepatocellular level of ALT in horses is very low, hence ALT is of limited value in this species.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Lattimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
AMYL:
Description:  Amylase is an enzyme produced primarily in the pancreas to digest dietary carbohydrates in the intestine. Note: due to its variability in cats, amylase is an unreliable marker for pancreatitis in this species.

 

Increased Amylase
   

  • Pancreatic acinar cell damage
    • Pancreatitis (acute or chronic)
    • Pancreatic inflammation secondary to other primary disease
    • Subclinical pancreatitis (if clinical signs are absent)
    • Pancreatic neoplasia (rare)
  • Decreased clearance through the kidneys (any condition that reduces glomerular filtration rate [GFR])
    • Kidney disease
    • Pre-renal
    • Post-renal   
  • Gastrointestinal disease
  • Hepatobiliary disease
  • Macroamylasemia
    • Amylase is complexed to immunoglobulins/other proteins too large to pass through the glomerulus, extending the half life of amylase in the circulation

 

  Next Steps and Related findings for Increased Amylase

 

  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP and bilirubin
      • Variably increased lipase, cholesterol. triglycerides and glucose
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Decreased clearance by the kidneys (decreased GFR)
    • Amylase usually only 2-3X increased above reference interval
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - normal, unless secondary pancreatic inflammation is present
    • Kidney disease
      • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
      • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Chemistry: 
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
      • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
      • Increased blood pressure
      • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
      • Investigate for underlying causes:
        • Toxic insult:
          • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
          • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
        • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
          • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
          • Chemistry:
            • Decreased albumin
            • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
        • Infectious kidney diseases:
          • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
            • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
            • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
      • Assess for confounding conditions:
        • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
    • Pre-renal
      • Dehydration:
        • Urinalysis: increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horses
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased serum proteins
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA
          • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
        • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
      • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration and shock
        • CBC:
          • Nonregenerative anemia
          • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA due to secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation (diagnostic test)
      • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
        • Decreased blood pressure
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
        • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
        • Abnormal echocardiogram
    • Post-renal
      • Urinary obstruction occurring in the kidneys, ureter, bladder or urethra
      • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
      • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
        • Increased potassium with complete urinary tract obstruction or leakage
      • Uroabdomen - abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentration than serum
      • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies, or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones) or rupture.
  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • Moderate increases in amylase may be seen in a variety of intestinal diseases.
    • CBC:
      • Non-regenerative anemia and decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with chronic disease
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased lipase
      • Decreased albumin, cholesterol and total protein with more severe disease
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - normal or may be increased with secondary pancreatic inflammation
    • Decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with diffuse small intestinal disease
    • Abdominal imaging (radiographs or ultrasoun) - abnormalities consistent with intestinal disease, obstruction or rupture.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Amylase is a cytoplasmic enzyme produced by the pancreas that catalyzes the hydrolysis of complex starches in the intestine.
  • Although one of the main sources of amylase is the pancreas, it is produced from many other tissues in the body, making it a relatively nonspecific indication of pancreatic inflammation.
  • Sources of amylase activity in blood include pancreas, intestine, macroamylases (protein complexes containing amylase bound to other proteins), and possibly liver.
  • Serum amylase activity peaks at 12-48 hours and can return to the reference interval within 8-14 days after a single pancreatic insult.
  • The kidneys excrete or inactivate amylase.  Conditions that reduce GFR usually do not result in more than a 2-3X increase in serum amylase activity.
  • In dogs, the higher the serum amylase activity (3 to 4-fold increase), the more likely the presence of pancreatic disease.  Serum amylase activity can be increased 7 to 10 fold above the reference interval with pancreatic disease in this species.
    • In more recent studies, serum amylase was the least sensitive test in the diagnosis of mild to severe pancreatitis in dogs.
  • Serum amylase is not clinically useful in the diagnosis of pancreatitis in cats; it can even be decreased in cats with pancreatitis.
  • In horses serum amylase activity is not diagnostically useful.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Assays measure amylase activity through substrate consumption, not the quantity of circulating amylase.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote, E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Tams, TR.  Handbook of Small Animal Gastroenterology, 2nd ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2003.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
AP_spp:
﻿Description:  The Anaplasma antibody test uses a species-specific synthetic peptide that detects IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both Anaplasma phagocytophilum and A. platys. A. phagocytophilum is the causative agent of granulocytotrophic anaplasmosis in dogs, cats, horses, humans and ruminants. A. platys is the causative agent of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia in dogs.

Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Active infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
  • Residual or declining antibody response from a previously cleared/treated infection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is clinical evidence of anaplasmosis with supportive history and physical exam findings.
  • CBC:
    • Thrombocytopenia, normocytic, normochromic nonregenerative anemia
    • Neutrophilia (occasionally neutropenia) and monocytosis
    • Variable eosinopenia and lymphopenia
    • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (A. phagocytophilium) may be seen on blood film evaluation early in infection (usually prior to seroconversion).
    • Morulae inclusions within platelets (A. platys) may been seen on blood film evaluation.
  • Chemistry:
    • Decreased albumin
    • Increased globulin, ALP, ALT
  • Urinalysis - variable increased protein
  • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased
  • Infectious disease testing:
    • For dogs presenting with clinical signs consistent with a vector-borne disease, using serology and PCR together improves ability to make a complete and accurate diagnosis.
    • PCR-positive for Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
      • Negative PCR result after treatment can indicate a reduction in pathogen load
      • Vector-borne disease PCR panel may identify co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Bartonella spp., Ehrlichia spp.)
    • IFA
      • Positive for Anaplasma spp. organism
        • Separate IFA tests are available for A. phagocytophilum and A. platys.
        • IFA can be subjective and may cross react with other species of Anaplasma and Ehrlichia
  • Joint cytology - findings may include increased mononuclear cell and neutrophil counts
  • CSF - findings may include neutrophilic pleocytosis

Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody concentration below the limit of detection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • In a dog with history, clinical signs and clinical pathology consistent with canine granulocytic anaplasmosis or infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia, consider:
    • Blood film evaluation for morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (may be seen prior to seroconversion)
    • Vector-borne disease PCR panel to detect early infection prior to seroconversion and to evaluate for co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Ehrlichia spp., Bartonella spp.)

Additional Information

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of tick/vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide
  • View the Anaplasma Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/anaplasma-next-steps.
  • Access additional vector borne disease resources at www.idexx.com/4Dx-plus-resources.

Physiology

  • Anaplasma phagocytophilum (transmitted by Ixodes spp ticks) is the cause of canine granulocytic anaplasmosis in dogs (a.k.a. granulocytrophic anaplasmosis).
    • Transmission of A. phagocytophilum occurs with a minimum feeding time of 24 hours, and may take up to 48 hours of tick attachment.
    • Anaplasma phagocytophilum has a worldwide distribution and disease is commonly diagnosed in temperate zones of the northern hemisphere. In the United States, disease prevalence is highest in areas associated with the primary tick vector, specifically the northeastern, mid-Atlantic and upper Midwest (Ixodes scapularis) and the west coast (Ixodes pacificus).
    • In the United States, seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the dog ranges from 0-68% depending on location of the study.
    • In Europe, seroprevalence in dogs ranges from 5-71%.
      • Seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the cat population has been reported as 1.8%, however there is no specific data regarding rate of active infection in cats.
    • Clinical signs of dogs infected with A. phagocytophilum (canine granulocytic anaplasmosis) include fever, lethargy, and polyarthritis. Occasionally these signs are accompanied by lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and rarely neurologic signs. Clinical signs are typically only present during the acute, rickettsemic phases when the organism is circulating in the blood.
  • Anaplasma platys (transmitted by Rhipacephalus sanguineus and Dermacentor spp.) is the cause of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • Anaplasma platys is the only intracellular infectious agent known to specifically infect the platelets of animals.
    • After the organism is innoculated into the host and appears in circulating platelets, severe thrombocytopenia (i.e. typically <20,000/uL) results with 8-14 days.
    • Platelet counts usually remain below 20,000/uL for one or two days.
    • The organisms then disappear rapidly from the peripheral blood, and platelet counts rise quickly, reaching a normal value in three or four days.
    • Subsequently, organisms will reappear at one-to two-week intervals, and the process repeats, resulting in a cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • The percentage of parasitized platelets and the severity of the thrombocytopenic episodes decrease with subsequent cycles of parasitemia.
    • A tick vector for A. platys infection has not been conclusively determined. Since the DNA of A. platys has been amplified in Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) and Dermacentor spp. ticks, these are the suspected tick vectors for infection with this organism. Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) is present throughout the continental United States and is one of the most widely distributed ticks in the world.
    • In one study in Arizona, in a location with frequent infestations of dogs with Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick), A. platys DNA was detected in 4.5-8.3% of dogs. Most dogs infected with A. platys have mild clinical disease. Occasionally, signs of petecchial hemorrhage, epistaxis, fever, lethargy, pale mucous membranes and/or lymphadenopathy can occur.
  • Co-infection with other vector-borne diseases (Borrelia burgdorferi, Ehrilichia spp., Babesia microti, Bartonella spp.) is common and the clinical signs can be difficult to distinguish between the co-infections. Co-infection may lead to complex presentations, more severe clinical signs and slower response to therapy.

Diagnostic Methodology

  • ELISA technology is used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both A. phagocytophilum and A. platys. Results are reported as positive or negative.
  • Anaplasma antibody tests will typically be positive for Anapasma spp. 14-30 days after infection with A. phagocytophilum or A. platys. 
  • A positive Anaplasma antibody result generally correlates with an ﻿Anaplasma﻿ spp. IFA titer of 1:100 or higher.

References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Eberts MD, Dinez PPVP, Beall MJ, et al. Typical and atypical manifestations of Anaplasma phagocytophilum infection in dogs. JAAHA 2011; 47:6.
  • Sainz A, Roura R, et al. Guidelines for veterinary practitioners on canine ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis in Europe. Parasites & Vectors. 2015; 8:75.
  • Mazepa AW, Kidd LB, et al. Clinical presentation of 26 Anaplasma phagocytophilum-seropositive dogs residing in an endemic area. JAAHA Nov/Dec 2010; Vol. 46.

Last Updated:  12/1/2018
﻿Description:  The Anaplasma antibody test uses a species-specific synthetic peptide that detects IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both Anaplasma phagocytophilum and A. platys. A. phagocytophilum is the causative agent of granulocytotrophic anaplasmosis in dogs, cats, horses, humans and ruminants. A. platys is the causative agent of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia in dogs.

Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Active infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
  • Residual or declining antibody response from a previously cleared/treated infection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is clinical evidence of anaplasmosis with supportive history and physical exam findings.
  • CBC:
    • Thrombocytopenia, normocytic, normochromic nonregenerative anemia
    • Neutrophilia (occasionally neutropenia) and monocytosis
    • Variable eosinopenia and lymphopenia
    • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (A. phagocytophilium) may be seen on blood film evaluation early in infection (usually prior to seroconversion).
    • Morulae inclusions within platelets (A. platys) may been seen on blood film evaluation.
  • Chemistry:
    • Decreased albumin
    • Increased globulin, ALP, ALT
  • Urinalysis - variable increased protein
  • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased
  • Infectious disease testing:
    • For dogs presenting with clinical signs consistent with a vector-borne disease, using serology and PCR together improves ability to make a complete and accurate diagnosis.
    • PCR-positive for Anaplasma phagocytophilum and/or Anaplasma platys
      • Negative PCR result after treatment can indicate a reduction in pathogen load
      • Vector-borne disease PCR panel may identify co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Bartonella spp., Ehrlichia spp.)
    • IFA
      • Positive for Anaplasma spp. organism
        • Separate IFA tests are available for A. phagocytophilum and A. platys.
        • IFA can be subjective and may cross react with other species of Anaplasma and Ehrlichia
  • Joint cytology - findings may include increased mononuclear cell and neutrophil counts
  • CSF - findings may include neutrophilic pleocytosis

Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody concentration below the limit of detection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Anaplasma Antibody Test

  • In a dog with history, clinical signs and clinical pathology consistent with canine granulocytic anaplasmosis or infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia, consider:
    • Blood film evaluation for morulae inclusions within neutrophils and/or eosinophils (may be seen prior to seroconversion)
    • Vector-borne disease PCR panel to detect early infection prior to seroconversion and to evaluate for co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Ehrlichia spp., Bartonella spp.)

Additional Information

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of tick/vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide
  • View the Anaplasma Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/anaplasma-next-steps.
  • Access additional vector borne disease resources at www.idexx.com/4Dx-plus-resources.

Physiology

  • Anaplasma phagocytophilum (transmitted by Ixodes spp ticks) is the cause of canine granulocytic anaplasmosis in dogs (a.k.a. granulocytrophic anaplasmosis).
    • Transmission of A. phagocytophilum occurs with a minimum feeding time of 24 hours, and may take up to 48 hours of tick attachment.
    • Anaplasma phagocytophilum has a worldwide distribution and disease is commonly diagnosed in temperate zones of the northern hemisphere. In the United States, disease prevalence is highest in areas associated with the primary tick vector, specifically the northeastern, mid-Atlantic and upper Midwest (Ixodes scapularis) and the west coast (Ixodes pacificus).
    • In the United States, seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the dog ranges from 0-68% depending on location of the study.
    • In Europe, seroprevalence in dogs ranges from 5-71%.
      • Seroprevalence for A. phagocytophilum antibodies in the cat population has been reported as 1.8%, however there is no specific data regarding rate of active infection in cats.
    • Clinical signs of dogs infected with A. phagocytophilum (canine granulocytic anaplasmosis) include fever, lethargy, and polyarthritis. Occasionally these signs are accompanied by lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and rarely neurologic signs. Clinical signs are typically only present during the acute, rickettsemic phases when the organism is circulating in the blood.
  • Anaplasma platys (transmitted by Rhipacephalus sanguineus and Dermacentor spp.) is the cause of infectious cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • Anaplasma platys is the only intracellular infectious agent known to specifically infect the platelets of animals.
    • After the organism is innoculated into the host and appears in circulating platelets, severe thrombocytopenia (i.e. typically <20,000/uL) results with 8-14 days.
    • Platelet counts usually remain below 20,000/uL for one or two days.
    • The organisms then disappear rapidly from the peripheral blood, and platelet counts rise quickly, reaching a normal value in three or four days.
    • Subsequently, organisms will reappear at one-to two-week intervals, and the process repeats, resulting in a cyclic thrombocytopenia.
    • The percentage of parasitized platelets and the severity of the thrombocytopenic episodes decrease with subsequent cycles of parasitemia.
    • A tick vector for A. platys infection has not been conclusively determined. Since the DNA of A. platys has been amplified in Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) and Dermacentor spp. ticks, these are the suspected tick vectors for infection with this organism. Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) is present throughout the continental United States and is one of the most widely distributed ticks in the world.
    • In one study in Arizona, in a location with frequent infestations of dogs with Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick), A. platys DNA was detected in 4.5-8.3% of dogs. Most dogs infected with A. platys have mild clinical disease. Occasionally, signs of petecchial hemorrhage, epistaxis, fever, lethargy, pale mucous membranes and/or lymphadenopathy can occur.
  • Co-infection with other vector-borne diseases (Borrelia burgdorferi, Ehrilichia spp., Babesia microti, Bartonella spp.) is common and the clinical signs can be difficult to distinguish between the co-infections. Co-infection may lead to complex presentations, more severe clinical signs and slower response to therapy.

Diagnostic Methodology

  • ELISA technology is used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies to the p44/MSP2 region of the outer membrane of both A. phagocytophilum and A. platys. Results are reported as positive or negative.
  • Anaplasma antibody tests will typically be positive for Anapasma spp. 14-30 days after infection with A. phagocytophilum or A. platys. 
  • A positive Anaplasma antibody result generally correlates with an ﻿Anaplasma﻿ spp. IFA titer of 1:100 or higher.

References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Eberts MD, Dinez PPVP, Beall MJ, et al. Typical and atypical manifestations of Anaplasma phagocytophilum infection in dogs. JAAHA 2011; 47:6.
  • Sainz A, Roura R, et al. Guidelines for veterinary practitioners on canine ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis in Europe. Parasites & Vectors. 2015; 8:75.
  • Mazepa AW, Kidd LB, et al. Clinical presentation of 26 Anaplasma phagocytophilum-seropositive dogs residing in an endemic area. JAAHA Nov/Dec 2010; Vol. 46.
