AST:
Description:  Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is a cellular enzyme that primarily increases due to liver and muscle damage.

 

Increased AST

  • Liver disease
    • Infectious (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, methimazole, mushrooms, sago palm)
    • Vascular anomaly (usually mild elevations in AST if any)
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis to liver
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited 
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
  • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy (usually mild elevations in AST if any)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hepatic lipdosis
  • Skeletal myopathy (severe)
    • Trauma
    • Ischemic myopathy (cat)
    • Muscular dystrophy (dog)
    • Exertional disorders
    • Hypokalemic myopathy

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased AST

 

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably increased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP > GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased (unless concurrent inflammatory disease)
      • Increased bilirubin
      • BUN decreased
      • Variable cholesterol and albumin
    • Urinalysis:
      • Variable; often inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.035)
      • Variable bilirubinuria (follows increased serum bilirubin)
    • Bile acids - may be increased with severe disease; not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be increased with severe disease
    • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
    • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
    • Liver cytology or biopsy - severe vacuolar hepatopathy
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Spec fPL test or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase - increased with pancreatitis
      • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
      • History of stress or household changes
  • Skeletal muscle disease or injury
    • CBC- variable depending on cause and chronicity
    • Chemistry:
      • AST increased greater than ALT
      • ALP, GGT, bilirubin typically normal to only mildly increased
      • CK increased
      • Hypokalemic myopathy may have increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and decreased potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • May be normal
      • Myoglobinuria (with severe muscle damage) may result in tubular necrosis with casts on urine sediment
      • Decreased urine concentration may be seen with hypokalemic myopathy.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • AST is present in the cytosol and mitochondria of many cell types but increased activity primarily reflects liver and muscle disease, with less specificity than ALT (liver) or CK (striated muscle), respectively.
  • AST is also known as serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase (SGOT).
  • Significant damage to hepatocytes must occur before AST activity increases so it is less sensitive for liver disease than is ALT.
  • The plasma half life of AST is short (dogs 5 hours, cats 1.5 hours).
  • In large animals, AST is used to detect liver disease despite its lack of specificity.  Clinical signs and concurrent CK activity help discriminate between hepatic and other diseases.
  • Plasma half life of AST is longer than that of CK; concurrent measurement of AST and CK may help assess the course of muscle disorders.  In horses, AST activity peaks 12-24 hours after liver or muscle injury and remains increased for 5-6 days.
  • Erythrocytes are an important source of AST, so hemolyzed samples have mild to moderate increases in AST activity; lipemia may also interfere.

 

   References

 

  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders: 2004. 
  • Washabau RJ, Day MJ, eds. Canine and Feline Gastroenterology. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2013.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
AnGap:
Description: The anion gap is the calculated difference between measured cations (Na+, K+) and anions (Cl-, HCO3-).  The anion gap is used to help identify the cause of metabolic acidosis.

 

Decreased Anion Gap

  

  • Decreased albumin
    • Negative charges of albumin are major contributors to normal anion gap 
  • Artifact
    • Potassium bromide therapy resulting in falsely increased chloride
  • Increased unmeasured cations
    • Increased calcium (minor effect)
    • Increased magnesium (minor effect)
    • Multiple myeloma/plasma cell myeloma

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Anion Gap

 

  • Evaluate for history of bromide administration
  • Multiple myeloma/plasma cell myeloma
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Variable hypercalcemia
      • Increased globulins
      • Decreased albumin: globulin ratio
      • Variable decreased albumin (compensatory)
    • Urinalysis - urine protein variably positive 
    • Urine protein: creatinine ration - variably increased
    • Bence Jone protein test - variably positive
    • Serum or urine protein electrophoresis - monoclonal gammopathy
    • Diagnostic imaging:
      • Radiographs of bone often show lytic bone lesions (dogs, not cats) with multiple myeloma
      • Enlarged spleen, liver or other masses with plasma cell tumor
    • Bone marrow cytology or fine needle aspirate of masses/enlarged organs diagnostic for neoplasia

 

Increased Anion Gap

 

  • Metabolic acidosis
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Kidney failure
    • Toxins/medications
      • Antifreeze (ethylene glycol, methanol)
      • Snail and slug bait (metaldehyde)
      • Penicillin (high doses)
      • Salicylates (aspirin, Pepto-Bismol)
      • Paraldehyde
    • Lactic acidosis (e.g shock, hypoxia)
  • Hyperalbuminemia (minor changes)
  • Severe rhabdomyolysis
  • Artifact due to prolonged exposure of sample to air

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Anion Gap

 

  • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate) and calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
      • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
    • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
    • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Anion Gap (AG) = ([Na+] + [K+]) - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]).
  • The anion gap can help clarify mixed acid-base disorders (concurrent metabolic acidosis and alkalosis).
  • Most changes in anion gap occur because of changes in unmeasured anions (organic acids, inorganic phosphate, albumin, and exogenous toxins).
  • Albumin is an important contributor to the anion gap.
  • Because the anion gap is calculated, the value may be erroneous if inaccurate electrolyte concentrations are used.

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
BA:
﻿Description:﻿ Bile acids are produced in the liver, stored in the gall bladder and released into the intestinal tract where they aid in lipid digestion. Bile acids are recirculated to the liver via the portal vein. Bile acids are primarily used to evaluate for portosystemic shunt or loss of liver function, but can also be elevated with cholestatic diseases causing bile retention.

Increased Bile Acids

  • Liver disease with loss of function or cholestasis
    • Infection (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, methimazole, mushrooms, sago palm)
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
    • Vascular anomaly
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Pancreatitis
      • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
    • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Hepatic lipidosis
    • Breed-related increases (Maltese dogs)
    • Artifact
      • Lipemia (depending on methodology)
      • Hemolysis (depending on methodology)
      • Icterus (depending on methodology)
      • Ursodiol administration

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Bile Acids

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • ALT normal to mildly elevated
      • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol and glucose
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variable, but often inappropriate in light of hydration status (<1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
      • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
    • CBC - usually normal
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
      • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
    • Urinalysis - usually normal
    • Bile acids - variably increased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
    • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
    • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
    • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets - mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Elevated ALT, AST, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubinuria, bilirubin or ammonium urate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Spec cPL/fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract.
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.

 

Additional Information

  • ﻿View the Bile Acids Diagnostic Algorithm

   Physiology

  • Patients with significant liver disease can have normal bile acids if sufficient functional hepatic mass remains.
  • Bile acids are molecules produced exclusively in the liver, secreted from the gallbladder and undergo enterohepatic circulation.
    • Feeding induces gallbladder contraction, releasing a bolus of bile into the intestines.
    • There is also a "bellows-like flutter" of the gall bladder during the time between meals, resulting in a constant (small) bile flow.
    • Almost all bile acids released into the intestines are reabsorbed in the ileum.
    • After reabsorption, bile acids are transported back to the liver via the portal vein for re-uptake and re-circulation.
  • Evaluation of paired (pre-prandial and two hour post-prandial) bile acids increases the sensitivity for detection of liver dysfunction.
    • Post-prandial bile acids are generally more likely to be increased than pre-prandial and are more sensitivie for detection of liver dysfunction.
      • Spontaneous contraction of the gall bladder may result in a higher fasting bile acids.
      • Incomplete gall bladder contraction following the meal may reduce the degree of post-prandial increase.
      • Enteric diseases (especially those affecting the ileum) and changes in gastric and/or intestinal motility may interfere with the bile acids test, making it less sensitive.
  • Clinically, if bilirubin concentration is increased or the animal is icteric, there is little additional value in performing a bile acids test.
  • Bile acids can be useful in differentiating steroid induction from significant liver damage in patients on phenobarbital or corticosteroids, or with hyperadrenocorticism.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Measurement of bile acids is performed using either spectrophotometric assays, enzyme immunoassays or radioimmunoassays.
  • When utilizing the spectrophotometric methodology, hemolysis, lipemia and icterus can have variable effects depending on the assay type.
    • Catalyst bile acids results can be artifactually increased by hemolysis or icterus. Lipemia has no effect on Catalyst bile acids.
    • In other spectrophotometric bile acids methods, hemolysis may artifactually decrease results, and lipemia may artifactually increase results.

  References

  • Center SA. Changing perspective on the pathobiology of bile acids - background, physiology and diagnostic use. 2017 ACVIM Forum Proceedings, National Harbor, MD
  • Johnston AN, Webster CRL. Portal vein hypoplasia (microvascular dysplasia). In: Bonagura JD, Twedt DC, eds. Kirk's Current Veterinary Therapy XV. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Watson PJ. Hepatobiliary diseases in the dog. In: Nelson RW and Couto CG, eds. Small Animal Internal Medicine, 5th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Weisse C, Berent AC. Hepatic vascular anomalies. In: Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 5th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2012.

﻿Description:﻿ Bile acids are produced in the liver, stored in the gall bladder and released into the intestinal tract where they aid in lipid digestion. Increased Bile Acids

  • Liver disease with loss of function or cholestasis
    • Infection (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)

      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, methimazole, mushrooms, sago palm)
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
    • Vascular anomaly
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Pancreatitis
      • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
    • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Hepatic lipidosis
    • Breed-related increases (Maltese dogs)
    • Artifact
      • Lipemia (depending on methodology)
      • Hemolysis (depending on methodology)
      • Icterus (depending on methodology)
      • Ursodiol administration

          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)

  • Willard MD, Tvedten H. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 5th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2012.

BA03:
﻿Description:﻿ Bile acids are produced in the liver, stored in the gall bladder and released into the intestinal tract where they aid in lipid digestion. Bile acids are recirculated to the liver via the portal vein. Bile acids are primarily used to evaluate for portosystemic shunt or loss of liver function, but can also be elevated with cholestatic diseases causing bile retention.

Increased Bile Acids

  • Liver disease with loss of function or cholestasis
    • Infection (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, methimazole, mushrooms, sago palm)
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
    • Vascular anomaly
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Pancreatitis
      • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
    • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Hepatic lipidosis
    • Breed-related increases (Maltese dogs)
    • Artifact
      • Lipemia (depending on methodology)
      • Hemolysis (depending on methodology)
      • Icterus (depending on methodology)
      • Ursodiol administration

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Bile Acids

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • ALT normal to mildly elevated
      • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol and glucose
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variable, but often inappropriate in light of hydration status (<1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
      • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
    • CBC - usually normal
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
      • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
    • Urinalysis - usually normal
    • Bile acids - variably increased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
    • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
    • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
    • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets - mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Elevated ALT, AST, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubinuria, bilirubin or ammonium urate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Spec cPL/fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract.
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.

 

Additional Information

  • ﻿View the Bile Acids Diagnostic Algorithm

   Physiology

  • Patients with significant liver disease can have normal bile acids if sufficient functional hepatic mass remains.
  • Bile acids are molecules produced exclusively in the liver, secreted from the gallbladder and undergo enterohepatic circulation.
    • Feeding induces gallbladder contraction, releasing a bolus of bile into the intestines.
    • There is also a "bellows-like flutter" of the gall bladder during the time between meals, resulting in a constant (small) bile flow.
    • Almost all bile acids released into the intestines are reabsorbed in the ileum.
    • After reabsorption, bile acids are transported back to the liver via the portal vein for re-uptake and re-circulation.
  • Evaluation of paired (pre-prandial and two hour post-prandial) bile acids increases the sensitivity for detection of liver dysfunction.
    • Post-prandial bile acids are generally more likely to be increased than pre-prandial and are more sensitivie for detection of liver dysfunction.
      • Spontaneous contraction of the gall bladder may result in a higher fasting bile acids.
      • Incomplete gall bladder contraction following the meal may reduce the degree of post-prandial increase.
      • Enteric diseases (especially those affecting the ileum) and changes in gastric and/or intestinal motility may interfere with the bile acids test, making it less sensitive.
  • Clinically, if bilirubin concentration is increased or the animal is icteric, there is little additional value in performing a bile acids test.
  • Bile acids can be useful in differentiating steroid induction from significant liver damage in patients on phenobarbital or corticosteroids, or with hyperadrenocorticism.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Measurement of bile acids is performed using either spectrophotometric assays, enzyme immunoassays or radioimmunoassays.
  • When utilizing the spectrophotometric methodology, hemolysis, lipemia and icterus can have variable effects depending on the assay type.
    • Catalyst bile acids results can be artifactually increased by hemolysis or icterus. Lipemia has no effect on Catalyst bile acids.
    • In other spectrophotometric bile acids methods, hemolysis may artifactually decrease results, and lipemia may artifactually increase results.

  References

  • Center SA. Changing perspective on the pathobiology of bile acids - background, physiology and diagnostic use. 2017 ACVIM Forum Proceedings, National Harbor, MD
  • Johnston AN, Webster CRL. Portal vein hypoplasia (microvascular dysplasia). In: Bonagura JD, Twedt DC, eds. Kirk's Current Veterinary Therapy XV. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Watson PJ. Hepatobiliary diseases in the dog. In: Nelson RW and Couto CG, eds. Small Animal Internal Medicine, 5th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Weisse C, Berent AC. Hepatic vascular anomalies. In: Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 5th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2012.

BACc:
Description:  Bacteria in the urine most commonly indicate urinary tract infection.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm. 

Images represent (from left to right) cocci and cocci in chains.

     

To view additional SediVue Dx reference images, visit www.idexx.com/BacteriaImages.

Learn more about the diagnosis and management of urinary tract infections in dogs and cats at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria.

 

Increased Bacteria
   

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Bacterial cystitis
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Prostatitis
  • Subclinical bacteriuria (confirmed bacteriuria with no history of clinical signs)
  • Vaginitis (voided sample)
  • Urine sample contamination – particularly in catheterized or voided samples

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Bacteria

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.205 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Variable crystalluria:
        • Struvite crystals may form secondary to urinary tract infection
        • Other crystal types may also be present reflecting underlying metabolic diseases predisposing to urolithiasis and/or urinary tract infection.
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive
    • Next steps to localize infection:
      • Bacterial cystitis
        • CBC- often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
        • Chemistry - typically normal
        • Abdominal imaging:
          • Abdominal radiographs- variable urinary calculi
          • Abdominal ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Pyelonephritis:
        • CBC:
          • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Urinary casts
          • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria
        • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
        • Urine culture - may be negative if infection is isolated to kidneys
        • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
      • Prostatitis
        • CBC:
          • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Chemistry:
          • May be normal
          • Increases in SDMA, creatinine, BUN and potassium with secondary urethral obstruction
        • Abdominal imaging:
          • Abdominal radiographs - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization
          • Abdominal ultrasound - abnormal or enlarged prostate
        • Cytology/biopsy collected by traumatic catheterization or fine needle aspirate consistent with prostatitis

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Urine is normally sterile only from the kidneys to the mid-urethra
    • Cystocentesis is the best method of collection to evaluate for the presence of bacteria in the urine and for cultures. 
    • Urine collected via catheterization (especially in females) or voiding may be contaminated by the distal urogenital tract.
  • The significance of bacteria in the urine is dependent on
    • Method of collection
    • Absolute number of bacteria present in the urine (determined by culture)
    • Complete urinalysis results (e.g. urine specific gravity, pH, urine sediment findings, etc.)
  • Cocci (round bacteria) may be difficult to differentiate from small amorphous crystals or fat droplets, and debris during sediment examination.
  • Bacterial contamination of urine sediment stain can lead to artifactual identification of bacteria.
  • Brownian motion (or random movement) of small particles suspended in the urine (caused by bombardment of the particles by molecules or solutes of the urine) should not be misidentified as cocci or motile bacteria.
  • Questionable presence of bacteria should be confirmed with an air-dried, stained cytologic preparation; or a quantitative urine culture with MIC susceptibility.
  • Romanowsky (e.g. Diff-Quick, Wright's stain, etc.) or Gram-stained slide preparations of urine sediment are superior to wet-mounts for identifying bacteria, especially cocci.  Stained preparations should be used to confirm questionable bacteriuria.
  • Failure to detect bacteriuria or pyuria does not preclude the presence of infection.

 

   References

 

  • Barges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 11/1/2018

BAND:
Description: Bands are immature neutrophils. Bands are not normally found in the systemic circulation in significant numbers, but may be released early from the bone marrow in response to inflammation. The presence of bands is sometimes referred to as a "left shift."

 

Increased Bands

 

  • Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Neoplasia
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome
  • Pelger-Huet anomaly - may be mistaken for bands
  • Myeloproliferative disorders 
      • Myelodysplasia
      • Granulocytic leukemia
        • Acute myeloid leukemia
        • Chronic myeloid leukemia
      • Myelomonocytic leukemia  

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Bands

  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic change  
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Comparison of patient WBC dot plot to species-specific normals may show pattern changes consistent with the presence of bands.
        • For example, in the IDEXX ProCyte Dx, the WBC plot shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population indicating the presence of bands.
      • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) may also show a band indicator if band neutrophils may be present, indicating the need to evaluate the WBC dot plot or perform a blood fillm review.
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
      • Regenerative left shift: mature neutrophils outnumber immature neutrophils (bands +/- earlier cell lines)
      • Degenerative left shift: immature neutrophils (bands +/- earlier cell lines) outnumber mature neutrophils
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia:
        • Non-myeloid neoplasia can result in neutrophilia in response to secondary inflammation or as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with release of G-CSF.
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Pelger-Huet anomaly
    • Congenital condition - neutrophils of affected (clinically healthy) animals have nuclear hyposegmentation and may be confused with band neutrophils
    • Reported in some family lines of Australian shepherds, domestic shorthair cats and Arabian horses
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophils have hyposegmented nuclei with a mature, dark chromatin pattern (allowing differentiation from neutrophil bands).
      • Eosinophils and basophils may may have hyposegmented nuclei.
      • Toxic change and other morphologic abnormalities are lacking.
  • Myeloproliferative disorders
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia, often severe
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - monomorphic population of immature granulocytes
      • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) - extreme neutrophilia; may have overrepresentation of a single granulocytic cell line, or may have a generalized increase
    • Chemistry - calcium variably increased
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
    • Assess for viral causes (e.g. FeLV).
    • Bone marrow:
      • Greater than 30% blast cells in AML
      • Less than 30% blast cells with myelodysplasia (preleukemia)
      • In CML the ratio of myeloid to erythroid precursors is highly variable.
      • Myelofibrosis common
    • Immunocytochemical stains - may differentiate AML from acute lymphoblastic leukemia
    • CML is difficult to distinguish from a leukemoid response to severe inflammation and is often a diagnosis of exclusion.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Bands are an immature stage of development of the neutrophil.
  • Bands have a curved nucleus of uniform thickness in which the sides are approximately parallel to one another throughout the entire length of the nucleus.
  • With severe, often acute, tissue demand for neutrophils the bone marrow storage pool may become depleted of mature, segmented neutrophils; this is typically when band neutrophils (+/- younger forms) appear in circulation.
  • The ability of neutrophils to respond to stimuli and migrate increases with maturation, thus bands may be slightly less responsive than segmented forms.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The band neutrophil percentage (or relative band neutrophil count) is the number of band neutrophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute band count is calculated by multiplying the band percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) show a band indicator when bands may be present, indicating the need to evaluate the WBC dot plot or perform a blood film review.
  • Evaluation of the WBC dot plot can provide valuable information about the presence of immature neutrophils (bands), platelet clumping or morphologic abnormalities which may impact the automated white blood cell differential. If bands are present, the WBC dot plots shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of neutrophil abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).
       

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Thrall MA, Weiser G, Allison R, Campbell TW. Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
BASO:
Description: Basophils are granulated white blood cells that are increased with parasitic, neoplastic, and allergic conditions.

 

Increased Basophils    

 

  • Parasitic infection
  • Hypersensitivity responses
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic
    • Chronic basophilic leukemia  

  

Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Basophils

 

  • Parasitic infection
    • CBC:
      • Variable anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Skin scrapings to assess for ectoparasites
    • Fecal Dx antigen tests and/or fecal ova and parasites test positive with intestinal parasites.
    • Positive heartworm testing (serology for antigen or antibody, microfilaria testing)
  • Hypersenstivity responses
    • Asthma 
      • Bronchial pattern on thoracic radiographs
      • Eosinophilic and neutrophilic inflammation found on transtracheal or endotracheal wash
    • Eosinophilic granuloma complex
      • Histopathology supportive of eosinophilic granuloma complex
    • Allergic dermatitis/atopy
      • Abnormalities on skin allergy testing
      • Positive reactions on serum allergy testing
      • Histopathology supportive of allergic dermatitis
    • Food allergies/eosinophilic gastroenteritis 
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies showing eosinophilic inflammation
      • Gastric and/or intestinal wall thickening found on abdominal ultrasound
      • Abnormal serum folate and cobalamin
    • Allergic rhinitis/sinusitis
      • Lymphoplasmacytic or eosinophilic inflammation on nasal biopsies
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
    • Most comon in middle-aged female, domestic shorthair cats and Rottweiler dogs
    • CBC:
      • Variable mild nonregenerative anemia
      • Marked mature eosinophilia (typically >20,000 cells/ul)
    • Histopathology or cytology of any affected organs or masses - eosinophilic infiltration
    • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy to discriminate from eosinophilic leukemia 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic:
      • Cytology or histopathology - consistent with mast cell neoplasia, lymphoma, carcinoma, pulmonary lymphomatoid granulomatosis, polycythemia vera or essential thrombocythemia
    • Chronic basophilic leukemia
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Variably increased platelets
        • Marked basophilia with orderly left shift

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Basophils are typically present in low numbers in mammals.
  • Basophils originate in the bone marrow, circulate briefly, then marginate to tissues.
  • The granules of basophils are round and stain metachromatically (purple) although the intensity varies by species.
    • Mature basophils in cats have very lightly staining granules.
    • Granules are abundant in most species except for the dog.
  • The most prominent constituents of basophil granules are histamine and heparin, substances that promote hypersenstivity reactions and attract eosinophils.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The basophil percentage (or relative basophil count) is the number of basophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute basophil count is calculated by multiplying the basophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
       

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

BIL:
Description:  Bilirubinuria is an indicator of conjugated bilirubin in the urine.  Excessive bilirubinuria in a dog or any bilirubinuria in a cat is an indication to evaluate serum bilirubin concentrations.

 

Positive Urine Bilirubin 

  

  • Mild increases may be normal in some dogs with concentrated urine (especially males)
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis 
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocoele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia)
  • False positive reactions due to medications
    • Phenothiazines  (e.g., chlorpromazine)
    • Etodolac

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Urine Bilirubin

 

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic of biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL/Spec fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocoele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)

 

Negative Urine Bilirubin

  

 

  • Negative urine bilirubin is a normal finding
  • Artifact - False negatives
    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Centrifugation of urine prior to analysis
    • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Conjugated bilirubin passes freely through the glomerular filtration barrier and is excreted in urine.
  • Unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin and does not normally pass through the glomerular filtration barrier. Therefore, it is not detectable in urine (unless albuminuria or glomerular disease is present).
  • Bilirubinuria usually precedes hyperbilirubinemia and icterus
  • Dogs:  Clinically normal dogs may have detectable bilirubinuria in concentrated urine due to a low renal threshold for bilirubin. 
    • Canine renal tubular epithelial cells can also produce conjugated bilirubin from resorbed hemoglobin (hemoglobinuria).
  • Cats:  Normally do not have detectable bilirubinuria so any positive result is significant

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Bilirubin is detected with a diazonium salt reagent
    • More sensitive for conjugated bilirubin; insensitive to unconjugated bilirubin
  • Dipstick (reagent strips)
    • False positives and false negatives are possible
  • Ictotest reagent tablets
    • Higher sensitivity compared to dipstick
      • Often used to confirm dipstick results
    • False positives and false negatives are possible

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
