    • High urine specific gravity
    • Ascorbic acid, captopril, or formaldehyde in the urine
    • Nitrite from bacterial infections 

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The reagent strip method utilizes the peroxidase activity of heme to catalyze the oxidation of a chromagen or o-toluidine to effect a color change.
  • Erythrocytes, free hemoglobin, methemoglobin, or myoglobin may be a source of heme.
  • RBCs should be confirmed with sediment exam to help differentiate between hematuria and pigmenturia (erythrocytes may lyse in very alkaline or hyposthenuric urine).

 

  References

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote, E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
BLD02:
Description:  Blood/hemoglobin on the reagent strip is most often an indicator of hematuria (RBC in the urine). 

 

Positive Blood/Hemoglobin 
   

  • Hematuria
    • Urinary tract infection
      • Bacterial cystitis
      • Pyelonephritis
      • Prostatitis
    • Urinary tract inflammation
      • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
      • Urolithiasis
    • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma, prostate carcinoma)
    • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract
      • Coagulation or platelet disorder
      • Idiopathic renal hematuria
      • Trauma
      • Estrus (voided sample)
    • Iatrogenic (due to traumatic cystocentesis or catheterization, or manual expression)
  • Hemoglobinuria
    • Intravascular hemolysis
      • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune, e.g. Heinz body anemia)
    • Lysis of RBCs after entering urine
  • Myoglobinuria (e.g. muscle trauma, hyperthermia, toxoplasmosis)
  • Methemoglobinuria (e.g. ibuprofen toxicity)
  • Artifact - false positives
    • Bleach
    • Microbial or leukocyte peroxidase

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Blood/Hemoglobin

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.
  • Coagulation or platelet disorder
    • Evaluate physical exam and history for other evidence of bleeding disorder or blood loss in sites other than the urogenital tract (e.g. melena, petechiae, ecchymoses).
    • CBC:
      • Renegerative anemia (increased reticulocytes)
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased platelets (marked with immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, mild to moderate with consumption)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin, globulins and total protein
      • Variably increased or decreased ALT, ALP, GGT and bilirubin (with liver disease)
    • Coagulation panel:
      • PT/PTT prolongation (e.g. rodenticide, liver disease)
      • von Willebrands testing (breed specific)
      • Factor analysis - decreases in specific coagulation factors with hemophilia
      • Buccal mucosal bleeding time - prolonged (functional testing of platelets)
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria 
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)

 

Negative Blood/Hemoglobin
  

  • Absence of blood/hemoglobin in the urine is a normal finding
  • Artifact - false negative
    • High urine specific gravity
    • Ascorbic acid, captopril, or formaldehyde in the urine
    • Nitrite from bacterial infections 

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The reagent strip method utilizes the peroxidase activity of heme to catalyze the oxidation of a chromagen or o-toluidine to effect a color change.
  • Erythrocytes, free hemoglobin, methemoglobin, or myoglobin may be a source of heme.
  • RBCs should be confirmed with sediment exam to help differentiate between hematuria and pigmenturia (erythrocytes may lyse in very alkaline or hyposthenuric urine).

 

  References

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote, E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
BUN:
Description:  Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) is produced in the liver and excreted by the kidneys.  It is a marker for both liver and kidney dysfunction.

Decreased BUN 

 

  • Chronic, severe liver disease
    • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Cirrhosis
  • Low protein diets
  • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Glucosuria from renal tubular disorders
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Psychogenic polydipsia
  • Drugs
    • Corticosteroids
    • Growth hormone
    • Other drugs causing diuresis
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Overhydration
  • Urea cycle enzyme deficiencies
  • Protein malnutrition
  • Late pregnancy
  • Artifacts (depending on method of analysis)
    • High concentrations of sodium fluoride and sodium citrate
    • Chloramphenicol
    • Severe lipema


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased BUN

 

  • Chronic, severe liver disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine (unless concurrent renal disease is present)
      • Decreased albumin, cholesterol, glucose
      • Increased bilirubin and/or increased liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT)
    • Abnormal liver function tests:
      • Increased fasting and post-prandial bile acids
      • Increased fasting ammonia
    • CBC:
      • Microcytic, hypochromic anemia (especially in PSS)
      • Acanthocytes
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (e.g. PSS)
  • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
    • Urinalysis - decreased urine specific gravity
    • Diabetes mellitus:
      • Increased serum glucose
      • Increased serum fructosamine
      • Urinalysis - glucosuria +/- ketones
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased ALP
        • Normal SDMA and creatinine
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests
        • ACTH stimulation
        • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Increased BUN 

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Infection (e.g. upper UTI, leptospirosis, Lyme)
    • Inflammatory (e.g. glomerulonephritis, tubulointerstitial nephritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, ethylene glycol)
    • Ischemia
    • Congenital kidney disease (e.g. polycystic kidney disease, renal dysplasia)
    • Renal amyloidosis
    • Renal neoplasia
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration
    • Hypovolemia/blood loss
    • Poor cardiac output
    • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease)
    • Recent high protein meal
    • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
    • Catabolism of body tissues
      • Fever
      • Trauma
  • Post-renal
    • Uroabdomen
    • Ureteral or urethral obstruction 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased BUN

  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • IDEXX Cystatin B Test is a urinary kidney biomarker which is increased with active and/or acute renal tubular injury.
    • FGF-23 is an early marker of phosphorus overload which may increase prior to the development of hyperphosphatemia in cats with IRIS (International Renal Interest Society) Stage 1 or 2 CKD.
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for additional findings and concurrent conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration:
      • Urinalysis: increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horse
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum proteins
        • Increased SDMA and creatinine
        • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
      • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration, gastrointestinal bleeding +/- shock
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Increased SDMA and creatinine with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Increased BUN may be associated with gastrointestinal bleeding or decreased renal perfusion
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
        • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation (diagnostic test)
    • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
      • Decreased blood pressure
      • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
      • Abnormal echocardiogram
    • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
      • Evaluate for evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding:
        • Presence of melena or positive fecal occult blood
        • History of predisposing conditions or medications.
      • Chemistry: normal SDMA and creatinine
  •  Post-renal
    • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA and creatinine
      • Increased potassium with urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Uroabdomen:
      • Abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentration than serum
      • Abnormal ultrasound suggests rupture
      • Contrast radiographs for urinary tract rupture/leakage
    • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies, or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones).

 

Additional Information
   
   Physiology

 

  • Urea is produced exclusively by the liver from ammonia.
  • It is predominantly excreted by the kidneys and is the main form in which nitrogen is removed from the body.  Some urea is passively reabsorbed from the renal tubules back into the blood, but most is excreted.
  • While urea is predominantly a waste product of protein metabolism, it is an important factor in establishing the medullary osmotic gradient in the kidneys.  This allows the renal tubules to modify the water content of urine.  In medullary washout syndrome there is insufficient urea in the renal medulla to allow the urine to be appropriately concentrated.
  • Renal urea reabsorption is enhanced by antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
  • SDMA and creatinine are not significantly reabsorbed by the renal tubules, therefore they are less affected by urine flow rate than is BUN.
  • BUN readily diffuses into blood and all body water in similar concentrations.
  • There is an inverse relationship between BUN and glomerular filtration, and between BUN and renal tubular flow rate.
  • Increased BUN is not specific for primary renal disease, but is a major contributor to azotemia, along with SDMA and creatinine.
  • BUN concentrations are affected by other extra renal factors (more so than SDMA and creatinine concentrations).  These extra renal factors include other diseases, some chemicals and drugs, diet, and condition of serum (e.g. lipemia).
  • Because SDMA is influenced by fewer non-renal variables than BUN and creatinine, it is a more accurate indicator of kidney function.

 

   References

  • Braun JP, Lefebre, Watson ADJ. Creatnine in the dog: a review. Vet Clin Path. 2003;32(4): 162-179.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Yu S, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in healthy geriatric cats fed reduced protein foods enriched with fish oil, L-carnitine, and medium-chain triglycerides. Vet J. 2014;202(3): 588-596.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Melendez LD, Jewell DE. Relationship between lean body mass and serum renal biomarkers in healthy dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(3): 808-814.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Almes K, Jewell DE. Serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine in dogs with naturally occurring chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2016;30(3): 794-802.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2014;28(6): 1676-1683.
  • Nabity MB, Lees GE, Boggess M, et al. Symmetric dimethylarginine assay validation, stability, and evaluation as a marker for early detection of chronic kidney disease in dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(4): 1036-1044.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004. 

 

Last Updated 11/1/2023
BUN/CREA:
Description:  The BUN: Creatinine Ratio is the blood urea nitrogen (BUN) divided by the creatinine.  It is of limited use in determining whether azotemia is renal or pre renal in origin.  However, there are too many variables for the ratio itself to be used as a critical diagnostic parameter.  If the ratio is abnormal, the individual parameters (BUN and creatinine) should be evaluated.


Decreased BUN: Creatinine Ratio

 

  • Decreased BUN with normal creatinine
    • Chronic, severe liver disease
      • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • Cirrhosis
      • Low protein diets
    • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Glucosuria from renal tubular disorders
      • Diabetes insipidus
      • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • Drugs 
      • Corticosteroids
      • Growth hormone
      • Other drugs causing diuresis
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Overhydration
    • Urea cycle enzyme deficiencies
    • Protein malnutrition
    • Late pregnancy
    • Artifacts (depending on method of analysis)
      • High concentrations of sodium fluoride and sodium citrate
      • Chloramphenicol
      • Severe lipemia
  • Increased creatinine with normal BUN
    • Acute myositis
    • Severe muscle trauma
    • Artifact (analyzer measures non-creatinine chromogens)
      • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)
      • Uric acid
      • Cephalosporins
      • Pyruvate
    • Feeding cooked meat diet (may cause mild increases in creatinine, especially post-prandially)


  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased BUN: Creatinine Ratio

 

  • Chronic, severe liver disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine (unless concurrent renal disease is present)
      • Decreased albumin, cholesterol, glucose
      • Increased bilirubin and/or increased liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT)
    • Abnormal liver function tests:
      • Increased fasting and post-prandial bile acids
      • Increased fasting ammonia
    • CBC:
      • Microcytic, hypochromic anemia (especially PSS)
      • Acanthocytes
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (e.g. PSS)
  • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
    • Urinalysis - decreased urine specific gravity
    • Diabetes mellitus:
      • Increased urine glucose
      • Urinalysis - glucosuria +/- ketones
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's Disease)
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased ALP
        • Normal SDMA and creatinine
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests
        • ACTH stimulation
        • Low dose dexamethasone suppression
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's Disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Acute myositis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased creatine kinase
  • Muscle trauma
    • Chemistry
      • Increased creatine kinase

 

   Increased BUN: Creatinine Ratio

 

  • Increased BUN with normal creatinine
    • Early or mild prerenal azotemia (dogs and cats)
    • Gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage
    • High protein diet
    • Fever
  • Decreased creatinine with normal BUN
    • Decreased muscle mass
      • Neonates
      • Severe cachexia


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased BUN: Creatinine Ratio

 

  • Early or mild prerenal azotemia

    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased urine specific gravity
    • Chemistry:
      • May have high normal creatinine
      • High normal to increased SDMA, sodium, chloride, total protein
    • CBC:
      • Increased hematocrit/PCV
  • Gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage
    • Presence of melena or positive fecal occult blood
    • History of predisposing conditions or medications
    • CBC:
      • Regenerative anemia is seen unitl iron deficiency develops
      • Non-regenerative anemia may be seen with chronic GI blood loss
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
      • Decreased total protein

 

 Additional Information

 

   Physiology

  • The ratio of BUN to creatinine will change with increases or decreases in either component (see also BUN and creatinine differential diagnoses).
  • The BUN/Creatinine ratio originally was thought to be of value in discriminating between renal and pre-renal azotemia but there is significant overlap in values for the ratio in these two conditions.
  • There are too many variables for the ratio itself to be used as a critical diagnostic parameter.  If the ratio is abnormal the clinician should evaluate each individual parameter to determine the reason
  • In dogs and cats, BUN may be more influenced by pre-renal effects on tubular reabsorption and diffusion rate, and effects of diet and protein metabolism than is creatinine.  This does not apply to horses.

 

  References

  • Braun JP, Lefebre HP, Watson AD.  Creatinine in the dog: a review. Vet Clin Path. 2003;32(4):162-179.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004. 

 

Last updated 5/1/2019
CA:
Description: Calcium is an ion that is required by the body for numerous intracellular and extracellular functions. Calcium also is a major component in the structure of bone.

Decreased Calcium

  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Pancreatic disease (e.g. acute pancreatitis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency)
  • Decreased serum albumin (affects total calcium)
  • Endocrine diseases:
    • Hypoparathyroidism
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • Hypercalcitonism
  • Toxins/medications (e.g. ethylene glycol, tetracycline, blister beetle poisoning [horses], anticoagulant administration)
  • Puerperal tetany/eclampsia (dog, horse)
  • Artifact - EDTA contamination
  • Acute tumor lysis syndrome
  • Intestinal malabsorption
  • Hypovitaminosis D (dog)
  • Nutritional secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Myopathies (exertional rhabdomyolysis or malignant hyperthermia of horses)

﻿Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Calcium

  • Chronic kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), elevated SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and phosphorus
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Acute pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin and potassium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
    • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hypoparathyroidism
    • Chemistry:
      • High normal to increased phosphorus
      • Decreased ionized calcium
    • Parathyroid hormone - decreased
  • Artifact - EDTA contamination
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased potassium
      • Decreased ALP
  • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins or medications
    • Ethylene glycol
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate)
        • Urinalysis
          • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
          • Crystalluria -calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
        • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
        • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue

Increased Calcium

 

  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, anal sac adenocarcinoma)
  • Idiopathic hypercalcemia (cats)
  • Endocrine disease
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Granulomatous inflammation (e.g. fungal infection)
  • Toxins (e.g. cholecalciferol rodenticides, jasmine)
  • Bone disorders
    • Osteolytic bone lesions
    • Hypertrophic osteodystrophy
  • Hemoconcentration (increased serum albumin)
  • Infectious diseases (e.g. canine schistosomiasis, pulmonary angiostrongylus)
  • Young animals, especially large breed dogs
  • Artifact (e.g. lipemia, post-prandial)


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Calcium

 

  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
    • Assess for evidence of neoplasia (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, anal gland adenocarcinoma, thymoma) on physical examination with lymph node palpation, abdominal palpation and rectal exam
    • Chemistry:
      • May have increases in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary kidney damage when both phosphorus and calcium are increased
      • Phosphorus decreased if parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) increased
    • Ionized calcium - increased
    • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - low normal or decreased
    • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) - variably increased
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased or low normal phosphorus
      • SDMA, creatinine and BUN usually normal unless concurrent dehydration or kidney disease
    • Ionized calcium - increased
    • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins:
    • Vitamin D (cholecalciferol rodenticides)
    • Jasmine
    • Cestrum spp.
    • Solanum spp.
    • Calcopotriol or tacalcitol (psoriasis treatments)
  • Chronic kidney disease (renal secondary hyperparathyroidism)
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), elevated SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and phosphorus
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Ionized calcium - normal
    • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Fungal disease
    • CBC - variable increased monocytes and neutrophils
    • Infectious disease testing:
      • Positive serology for antifungal antibodies or antigen
      • Positive PCR or urine antigen tests
    • Cytology and/or histopathology consistent with fungal disease

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Calcium is controlled by PTH and Vitamin D, and their interactions with bone, kidneys, intestines, and parathyroid glands.
  • Total calcium concentration is measured in chemistry panels, and is comprised of three fractions:  50% ionized, 40% protein bound, and 10% complexed to nonprotein anions.
  • Ionized calcium is the active form that is hormonally regulated and is available to tissues.  The protein bound form is not available to tissues.
  • Ionized and complexed forms are filtered by the kidneys; protein bound calcium is not filtered by the kidneys.
  • When albumin decreases, there is a proportional decrease in total calcium, but ionized (active form) calcium is unchanged.

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004. 


Last Updated 9/1/2024
CHOL:
Description:  Cholesterol is one of the main lipids in the body.  It has an important role as an essential component of cell membranes, and it is the precursor of steroid hormones and bile acids.

 

Decreased Cholesterol
   

  • Decreased production
    • Liver disease
      • Chronic severe liver disease with loss of function
      • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
  • Decreased absorption
    • Malabsorption/maldigestion (e.g. small intestinal disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency)
    • Malnutrition (e.g. decreased intake, severe intestinal parasitism)
  • Increased loss
    • Lymphangiectasia (lacteal rupture into the small intestine)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
     

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Cholesterol

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, varaible reticulocytes
      • Microcytic (decreased MCV), hypochromic (decreased MCHC) anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT) may initially be increased, but with loss of functional hepatic mass may be normal to decreased
      • Bilirubin variably increased
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, glucose and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably decreased total protein
      • Globulins usually normal
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably decreased total protein
      • Globulins usually normal
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Gastrointestinal disease (maldigestion/malabsorption, protein-losing enteropathy)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Possible megaloblastic, hypochromic RBCs (especially with folate deficiency)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased BUN, albumin, total protein and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Cobalamin and folate may be abnormal with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
    • Trypsin-like immunoreactivity - decreased with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
    • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - increased with protein-losing enteropathy
    • Abdominal ultrasound - evidence of thickened intestines with small intestinal disease; abdominal effusion may be present with severe protein-losing enteropathy
  • Malnutrition
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein, globulin and albumin
      • Variably decreased BUN
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Evaluation for possible causes of malnutrition:
      • Assess for history of excessive calorie restriction or very low protein diet
      • Fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen - positive with intestinal parasites
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased albumin and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

Increased Cholesterol
   

  • Post-prandial increase
  • Metabolic
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hyperadrenocorticism
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, megestrol acetate)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
  • Nephrotic syndrome with severe protein-losing nephropathy
  • Familial or breed-related
    • Familial hypercholesterolemia (e.g. Briards, Shetland sheepdogs)
    • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency (rare in cats and dogs) 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Cholesterol

 

  • Hypothyroidism
    • Evaluate for clinical signs consistent with hypothyroidism:
      • Lethargy, mental dullness, weakness
      • Weight gain with no increase in appetite
      • Alopecia, hyperpigmentation, otitis, pyoderma
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry - increased triglycerides
    • Total T4 - decreased
    • Free T4 - decreased
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to increased
    • Variably increased thyroglobulin autoantibody in primary hypothyroidism
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP and ALT
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP and bilirubin
      • Variably increased amylase, lipase, and glucose
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, and glucose may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial)- increased if liver function decreased. Note: not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable bilirubin and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Variable triglycerides
    • Urinalysis:
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Protein-losing nephrotpathy with nephrotic syndrome
    • Urinalysis:
      • Proteinuria
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Cholesterol is absorbed from the diet and is also produced in the liver.
  • The total amount of serum cholesterol is under close homeostatic control.  It is influenced by dietary intake, production in the liver, and tissue utilization.  Cholesterol is also taken up by the liver from circulating chlyomicrons and metabolized.  The liver excretes cholesterol unchanged or as bile acids into the intestinal tract.
  • A twelve hour fast is suggested to minimize post-prandial increases in cholesterol.
  • Lipoproteins transport most cholesterol and triglycerides in serum.
  • In addition to its role as a component of cell membranes, cholesterol is a substrate for steroid hormones.

 

   References

 

  • Barrett KE, Barman SM, Boitano S, et al, eds. Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th ed. New York: McGraw-Hill; 2016.
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004. 

 

Last Updated 9/1/2024
CK:
Description:  Creatine kinase (CK) is a muscle enzyme.  Mild increases in CK can be seen in clinically healthy animals following restraint or a difficult blood draw. Moderate to severe increases, especially if accompanied by increased ALT, may indicate muscular diseases or trauma. CK may also be referred to as creatine phosphokinase (CPK).

 

Increased CK
   

  • Muscle trauma
    • Significant trauma (e.g. hit-by-car, surgical procedures, muscle biopsy)
    • Minor trauma (e.g. restraint, difficult blood draw, prolonged recumbency, intramuscular injections)
  • Muscle inflammation
    • Infectious (e.g. Toxoplasma, Neospora, sepsis)
    • Inflammatory (e.g. immune-mediated polymyositis, eosinophilic myositis, dermatomyositis, myocarditis)
  • Muscle ischemia (e.g. aortic thromboembolism, disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC])
  • Muscle necrosis (e.g. heat stroke, envenomation, drug reactions)
  • Exertional disorders
    • Prolonged strenuous exercise (e.g. sled dogs)
    • Exertional rhabdomyolysis
    • Seizures
    • Azoturia/tying up syndrome (horses)
    • Shivering/trembling
    • Vomiting
  • Anorexia (cats, increases reported up to 10-100X normal values)
  • Malignant hyperthermia
  • Hypothermia
  • Congenital/inherited degenerative myopathies (marked increases; e.g. muscular dystrophies, myotonia, hyperkalemic periodic paralysis)
  • Nutritional myopathies (e.g. vitamin E/selenium deficiency in horses, hypokalemia, taurine deficiency in cats)
  • Toxic  (e.g. monensin, castor bean, gossypol)
  • Neoplasia, esp. metastatic
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Physiologic
    • Young animals (increases up to 1.5-4X adult reference interval in cats and dogs)
    • Muscular dog breeds (e.g. Greyhounds)
  • Artifact
    • Hemolysis interferes with some CK assays

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased CK

 

  • Transient mild to moderate increases in CK can be seen in clinically healthy animals in association with restraint, difficult blood draw, shivering, trembling or recent moderate to brief severe exertion. Investigate for muscle disorders in patients with persistently marked increases in CK (i.e. greater than 5-10X the reference interval), clinical signs of muscular disorders, or if AST is also increased. 
  • Trauma
    • CBC (with associated blood loss):
      • Anemia - decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin
      • Reticulocytes may be normal with acute, pre-regenerative anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets variably decreased (consumption)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased AST or LDH suggest more severe injury
      • Increased ALT, usually minor compared to CK increase
      • Variable increased glucose (stress hyperglycemia)
      • Decreased total protein, albumin and globulins with acute blood loss
    • Urinalysis:
      • Myoglobinuria indicates severe injury
      • Hematuria variable, may indicate associated urogenital trauma
    • Lactate - increased with shock
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic inflammation)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Increased eosinophils with eosinophilic myositis
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably increased ALT and AST, depending on severity
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Urinalysis - myoglobinuria if severe inflammation
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation
      • Serology or PCR for infectious diseases (e.g. Toxoplasma gondii, Neospora caninum, Hepatozoon canis, leptospirosis, FIV)
      • Blood or urine culture for systemic bacterial infections
      • Immune-mediated polymyositis
        • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer variably increased
      • Eosinophilic (masticatory) myositis
        • 2M Antibody titers positive
      • Endocarditis
        • Echocardiogram finding supportive
        • Cardiopet proBNP increased
        • Troponin 1 increased
    • Muscle profile with histopathology and special stains consistent with muscle inflammation, necrosis, fibrosis or other neuromuscular diseases. Advanced imaging or electrodiagnostics may be useful to identify specific muscles to sample.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • CK is located in the cytoplasm of muscle and catalyzes a reversible reaction involving the transfer of phosphate (PO4) from creatine-phosphate to ADP thus forming ATP.  Creatine-phosphate is produced in resting muscle and the opposite reaction provides energy during periods of muscle activity.
  • Skeletal muscle is the main source of CK in the blood.  CK is also present in relatively large amounts in myocardium but the contribution of myocardial CK to serum concentrations is minor.  Significant increases in CK are usually the result of skeletal muscle damage.
  • Other tissue sources contributing to serum CK (low concentrations) include the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract, uterus, kidney, and urinary bladder. There is CK activity in the thyroid gland and nervous system.
  • Marked increases in serum CK activity (>20,000 IU/L) are typical with necrotizing myopathies or muscular dystrophies. Generalized inflammatory conditions typically have moderate increases in CK activity (2,000-20,000 IU/L) while the CK activity in focal inflammatory myopathies and other conditions is variably mildly increased. 
  • The serum half-life of CK is very short (2 to 4 hours).  After muscle injury, serum CK activity increases rapidly, peaks in 4 hours, and can return to normal (reference intervals) within 24 to 48 hours after a single minor injury.  After a more severe injury, CK may remain increased for several days before returning to reference intervals.
    • Serial determination of CK differentiates active versus resolving muscle injury.
  • Since muscle injury may occur whenever energy exceeds supply interpretation of measured CK is aided by knowledge of recent activity level and patient fitness.

 

   References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008
  • Thrall MA, Baker DC, Campbell TW, et al.  Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2004.

CREA:
Description:  Creatinine is a breakdown product of muscle.  It is removed by the kidneys and is an indicator of kidney function.

 

Decreased Creatinine

 

  • Marked muscle wasting may result in a low creatinine
    • Neonates
    • Emaciated animals
  • Pregnancy (increases cardiac output and glomerular filtration rate [GFR])
  • Portosysytemic shunts (cats)
  • Artifact (depends on the assay used)
    • Severe increase in bilirubin
    • Lipemia
  • Normal or low creatinine may be seen in animals with decreased kidney function in combination with decreased muscle mass.
    • Creatinine may be falsely normalized in hyperthyroid patients with concurrent chronic kidney disease due to decreased muscle mass and hyperfiltration.
    • SDMA (symmetric dimethylarginine) is not impacted by muscle mass and appears to be less impacted by hyperfiltration seen in hyperthyroidism.
    • Evaluate for high SDMA or high normal SDMA with inappropriate urine specific gravity

 

Increased Creatinine

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Infection (e.g. upper UTI, leptospirosis, Lyme)
    • Inflammatory (e.g. glomerulonephritis, tubulointerstitial nephritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, ethylene glycol)
    • Ischemia
    • Congenital kidney disease (e.g. polycystic kidney disease, renal dysplasia)
    • Renal amyloidosis
    • Renal neoplasia
  • Pre-renal causes accompanied by decreased GFR
    • Dehydration
    • Hypovolemia/blood loss
    • Poor cardiac output
    • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease)
  • Post-renal
    • Uroabdomen
    • Ureteral or urethral obstruction
  • Muscular disease
    • Acute myositis
    • Severe trauma
  • Artifact (assay measures non-creatinine chromogens)
    • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)
    • Uric acid
    • Cephalosporins
    • Pyruvate
  • Feeding cooked meat diet (may cause mild increases <1 mg/dL [<88.4 µmol/L]) especially post-prandially)

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Creatinine

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • IDEXX Cystatin B Test is a urinary kidney biomarker which is increased with active and/or acute renal tubular injury.
    • FGF-23 is an early marker of phosphorus overload which may increase prior to the development of hyperphosphatemia in cats with IRIS (International Renal Interest Society) Stage 1 or 2 CKD.
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration:
      • Urinalysis: increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horses
      • Chemistry:
        • increased serum proteins
        • Increased BUN and SDMA
        • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
      • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
    • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration and shock
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Increased BUN and SDMA due to secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
      • Urinalysis - in appropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
        • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation (diagnostic test)
    • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
      • Decreased blood pressure
      • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
      • Abnormal echocardiogram
  • Post-renal
    • Urinary obstruction occurring in the kidneys, ureter, bladder or urethra
    • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA and BUN
      • Increased potassium with complete urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Uroabdomen - abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentration than serum
    • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies, or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones).

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Creatinine originates from nonenzymatic conversion of creatine and creatinine phosphate in muscles.  This occurs at a generally constant and uniform daily rate.  Creatinine values are not significantly affected by mild catabolism or diet. However, creatinine may be artificially increased post-prandially after ingestion of meat.
  • Creatinine concentrations in serum are determined by kidney function and to a lesser extent by the body’s muscle mass. 
  • It is freely filtered by glomeruli.  Creatinine clearance from plasma to urine is used to approximate GFR. Like SDMA, creatinine is inversely related to GFR. Creatinine rises in proportion to SDMA.
  • Creatinine typically does not increase until up to 75% of kidney function is lost. SDMA increases earlier than creatinine in dogs and cats with kidney disease. SDMA increases on average with 40% and as little as 25% loss of kidney function.
  • SDMA and creatinine are not significantly reabsorbed by the renal tubules; therefore they are less affected by urine flow rate than is blood urea nitrogen (BUN).
  • Because SDMA is influenced by fewer non-renal variables than creatinine and BUN, it is usually a more accurate indicator of kidney function.
  • Decreased creatinine often is not clinically significant.  However, patients with reduced muscle mass (e.g. neonatal animals and very emaciated animals) may have kidney dysfunction but normal serum creatinine concentrations due to lack of muscle mass.  SDMA is a more reliable indicator of kidney function in animals with decreased muscle mass.

 

   References

 

  • Braun JP, Lefebvre, Watson ADJ. Creatinine in the dog: a review. Vet Clin Path. 2003;32(4): 162-179.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Yu S, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in healthy geriatric cats fed reduced protein foods enriched with fish oil, L-carnitine, and medium-chain triglycerides. Vet J. 2014;202(3): 588-596.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Melendez LD, Jewell DE. Relationship between lean body mass and serum renal biomarkers in healthy dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(3): 808-814.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Almes K, Jewell DE. Serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine in dogs with naturally occurring chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2016;30(3): 794-802.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2014;28(6): 1676-1683.
  • Nabity MB, Lees GE, Boggess M, et al. Symmetric dimethylarginine assay validation, stability, and evaluation as a marker for early detection of chronic kidney disease in dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(4): 1036-1044.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
