CRP:
Description: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a highly sensitive and specific marker for systemic inflammation in dogs. It is made by the liver and released into circulation in response to tissue injury. The CRP concentration will change rapidly after improvement of the inflammatory situation.

Learn more about the use of CRP to detect and trend systemic inflammation in dogs at www.idexx.com/crpguidelines.

 

Increased CRP

 

  • Systemic inflammation
    • Systemic infection, for example:
      • Bacterial (e.g. Leptospirosis, sepsis)
      • Vector-borne (e.g. Leishmaniasis)
      • Viral (e.g. parvovirus)
    • Immune-mediated diseases, for example:
      • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (IMT)
      • Evan's syndrome (IMHA + IMT)
      • Immune-mediated polyarthritis
  • Severe local infection or inflammation, for example:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Pyometra
    • Pneumonia
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Post-operative complications
  • Tissue damage associated with trauma or surgery

   

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased CRP

 

  • Systemic inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia +/- microcytosis (hypochromasia uncommon) with long term inflammatory conditions
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Serum albumin is a negative acute phase protein and may be decreased with systemic inflammation.
    • Iron panel - decreased total iron binding capacity (transferrin), with increased serum ferritin and increased stainable bone marrow iron
    • Evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC: regenerative anemia with spherocytosis, severe thrombocytopenia
        • Positive Coombs or anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests
        • Neutrophilic inflammation on joint fluid cytology
      • Systemic infection:
        • Positive PCR, serology or antigen tests for infectious diseases (Lyme, parvovirus, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, etc.)
      • Severe localized inflammation or infection
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) shows evidence of localized inflammation or infection.
        • Pancreatitis - increased Spec cPL Test
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA and creatinine
          • Urinalysis - casts, active urinary sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria)
          • Positive urine culture with MIC susceptibility

 

Normal CRP

 

  • Normal (reference interval includes zero)
    • Absence of inflammation
  • Localized inflammation that is either not severe enough or too early to have resulted in increased concentrations of inflammatory cytokines in systemic circulation.

 

Additional Information

 

    Physiology

  • CRP is produced by the liver in response to circulating inflammatory cytokines
    • At the site of any tissue injury, monocytes and macrophages respond by producing inflammatory cytokines.
    • Initially, the concentration of these inflammatory cytokines increase in the local, affected tissue. With more significant tissue damage, the inflammatory cytokine concentrations in systemic circulation also increase.
    • Inflammatory cytokines trigger the liver to produce various acute phase proteins, including CRP.
    • The CRP in circulation then modulates the body's innate immune response to the tissue injury.
  • CRP values are significantly increased as early as 6 hours after the onset of significant inflammation. After resolution, concentrations of CRP can fall within 24 hours.
  • CRP can be used to:
    • Detect and characterize the severity (but not the cause) of systemic inflammation.
    • Monitor progression or response to therapy.
    • Help with prognostication. Several studies have demonstrated that a decrease in CRP over time tended to be associated with a more favorable outcome
  • CRP production is independent of neutrophil dynamics and bone marrow responses. For example patients with overwhelming inflammatory conditions can have low neutrophil counts (due to consumption exceeding supply) and yet the CRP is dramatically increased.
  • CRP is not influenced by corticosteroids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDS), epinephrine and other treatment regimens that might influence circulating neutrophil numbers and confuse leucogram interpretation.
  • Although CRP is produced in the liver, animals with severely compromised liver function still have a normal CRP response to systemic inflammation.
  • CRP is not significantly affected by age, gender, breed, stress or diet.

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • CRP is available for use in the veterinary clinic on either the IDEXX Catalyst One® or IDEXX Catalyst Dx® chemistry analyzers. The Catalyst CRP Test is a sandwich immunoassay with gold conjugate that is designed to measure canine CRP antigen in serum or lithium heparin plasma samples from dogs.
  • CRP performed at IDEXX Reference Laboratories utilizes a canine Gentian CRP kit which shows strong correlation and minimal bias with the Catalyst CRP method.
  • IDEXX CRP is only available for dogs.

   

References

 

  • Burton SA, Honor DJ, Mackenzie AL, Eckersall PD, Markham RJ, Horney BS. C-reactive protein concentration in dogs with inflammatory leukograms. Am J Vet Res 1994;55(5):613-618.
  • Craig SM, Fry JK, Rodrigues Hoffman A, et al. Serum C-reactive protein and S100A12 concentrations in dogs with hepatic disease. J Small Anim Pract 2016;57:459-464.
  • Fransson BA, Karlstam E, Bergstrom A, Lagerstedt AS, Park JS, Evans MA, Ragle CA. C-reactive protein in the differentiation of pyometra from cystic endometrial hyperplasma/mucometra in dogs. J Am Anim Hosp Assoc 2004;40(5):391-399.
  • Galezowski AM, Snead ECR, Kidney BA, Jackson ML. C-reactive protein as a prognostic indicator in dogs with acute abdomen syndrome. J Vet Diagn Invest 2010;22:395-401.
  • Gebhardt C, Hirschberger J, Rau S, et al. Use of C-reactive protein to predict outcome in dogs with systemic infammatory response syndrome or sepsis: original study. J Vet Emerg Crit Care 2009;19:450-458.
  • Kum C, Voyvoda H, Sekkin S, Karademir U, Tarimcilar T. Effects of carprofen and meloxicam on C-reactive protein, ceruloplasmin, and fibrinogen concentrations in dogs undergoing ovariohysterectomy. Am J Vet Res 2013;74(10):1267-1273.

CRY:
Description:  Crystalluria occurs when the urine is supersaturated with the compounds that comprise the crystals. Crystals can be present in the urine of healthy animals or may reflect underlying disease. The crystal type determines the potential cause of the crystalluria.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm.

Crystal images below represent (from left to right) struvite, calcium oxalate dihydrate and calcium oxalate monohydrate (picket fence form).

  

Crystal images below represent (from left to right) calcium oxalate monohydrate (dumbell form), ammonium biurate and cystine.

   

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CrystalImages. 

 

Increased Crystals
   

  • Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals (triple phosphate, struvite)
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated or alkaline urine)
    • Urinary tract infection (cats and dogs)
    • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
    • Distal renal tubular acidosis (causing alkaline urine)
    • Artifact - may form after collection in stored, refrigerated samples
  • Calcium oxalate crystals
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated or acidic urine)
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Ethylene glycol toxicity (especially monohydrate forms)
    • Dietary
      • Ingestion of food rich in oxalates, calcium or vitamin D
      • Acidifying diet
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Breed predisposition (Schnauzer, Bichon frise, Shih tzu)
    • Artifact - may form after collection in stored, refrigerated samples
  • Ammonium biurate and uric acid crystals
    • Breed-associated hyperuricosuria
      • Most common in Dalmatians, English bulldogs and Black Russian terriers
    • Portosystemic shunt
    • Liver disease/failure
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine)
  • Amorphous phosphate crystals
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine)
  • Calcium phosphate
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine)
    • Hypercalcemia
  • Bilirubin crystals
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine or in male dogs)
    • Liver disease/failure
    • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Intravascular hemolysis
  • Cholesterol crystals
    • Hypercholesterolemia
    • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine)
  • Cystine crystals
    • Breed-associated in English Bulldogs, Newfoundlands, Dachshunds, Mastiffs/Bullmastiffs, Australian Cattle Dogs, Scottish Deerhounds (primarily males), and Siamese and Domestic Shorthair cats
    • Fanconi's syndrome
  • Calcium carbonate crystals
    • May be a normal finding in herbivores
      • Very rarely found in dogs or cats (unknown significance)
    • Diets high in calcium (e.g. subterranean clover)
    • Water with high mineral content
    • Kidney injury associated with NSAID use in the face of dehydration (equines)
    • Artifact - may form after colleciton in stored, refrigerated samples
  • Sulfonamide
    • Treatment with sulfonamides and other sulfur-containing drugs
  • Tyrosine
    • Liver disease in dogs (rare)
  • Xanthine
    • Allopurinol therapy
  • Miscellaneous drug or radiographic contrast crystals
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Crystals

 

  • Possible artifact:
    • Evaluate a fresh urine sample at room temperature immediately after collection to determine whether crystalluria is persistent.
    • Post-collection precipitation of crystals
      • Clinical signs typically absent
      • History or urine specimen being refrigerated or a delay in analysis
      • Urinalysis:
        • Crystalluria with an otherwise inactive urine sediment
        • Urine specific gravity variably high
    • True crystalluria
      • Uncommon crystal types (e.g. ammonium biurate, cystine, calcium oxalate monohydrate) may indicate underlying disease
      • Common crystal types (e.g. calcium oxalate dihydrate or struvite) should be investigated if crystalluria is persistent and/or clinical signs of lower urinary tract disease are present
  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Hypercalcemia
    • Chemistry - increased total calcium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses;  inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status.
      • Calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate crystalluria (or calcium carbonate in horses)
    • Evaluate for underlying causes of hypercalcemia
      • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
        • Assess for evidence of neoplasia (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, anal gland adenocarcinoma, thymoma) on physical examination with lymph node palpation, abdominal palpation and rectal exam
        • Chemistry:
          • May have increases in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary kidney damage when both phosphorus and calcium are inreased
          • Phosphorus decreased if parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) increased
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - low normal or decreased
        • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) - variably increased
      • Primary hyperparathyroidism
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased or low normal phosphorus
          • SDMA, creatinine and BUN usually normal unless concurrent dehydration or kidney disease
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
        • CBC:
          • Nonregegnerative anemia
          • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
      • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins (e.g. vitamin D)
      • Chronic kidney disease (renal secondary hyperparathyroidism)
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Ionized calcium - normal
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
  • Ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate) and calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
      • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
    • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
    • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoid enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  •  Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids (pre- and postprandial)- elevated; note, bile acids measurement is not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Portosystemic shunt
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses
      • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Crystals are the precipitation of salts which may be more likely to form at a given pH (some in acidic urine and others in alkaline urine).
    • Alkaline urine – Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite), amorphous phosphates, calcium phosphate
    • Acidic urine – Calcium oxalate, urate, bilirubin, cystine
  • The amount of crystalluria depends on the pH, ion concentrations, and temperature of the urine.
  • While crystalluria is a risk factor for urolithiasis, the presence or absence of crystals does not predict the presence or absence of urolithiasis.
  • Crystals may form or dissolve in urine samples that are aged or have been altered due to evaporation, refrigeration, or changes in pH. Refrigerated samples should be warmed to room temperature prior to performing the urinalysis.
  • Most urinary crystals can be seen in healthy animals, though increased numbers might indicate underlying pathology causing changes in urine ion concentrations or pH.
  • To evaluate the significance of crystalluria, urinalysis should be performed on a fresh (<30-60 min), non-refrigerated sample. 

  

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB. Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

CaCar:
Description:  Calcium carbonate crystals are common in the urine of healthy herbivores. They appear as large spheroids with radial striations. They can be colorless to yellow-brown. These crystals are normal in horses, rabbits, guinea pigs and goats. They are very rarely reported in dogs and cats and are of unknown significance in these species.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer.

To view additional SediVue Dx reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CrystalImages. 

 

Increased Calcium Carbonate Crystals

 

  • May be a normal finding in herbivores
  • Diets high in calcium (e.g. subterranean clover)
  • Water with high mineral content
  • Kidney injury associated with NSAID use in face of dehydration (equines)
  • Artifact - may form after collection in stored, refrigerated samples

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Calcium carbonate crystals are very rarely reported in the dog and cat, and their significance is unknown in these species. When noted, they are most likely an artifact found in alkaline urine.
  • Crystals are the precipitation of salts which are more likely to form in alkaline urine.
  • The amount of crystalluria depends on the pH, ion concentrations, and temperature of the urine.
  • While crystalluria is a risk factor for urolithiasis, the presence or absence of crystals does not predict the presence or absence of urolithiasis.
  • Crystals may form or dissolve in urine samples that are aged or have been altered due to evaporation, refrigeration, or changes in pH. Refrigerated samples should be warmed to room temperature prior to performing the urinalysis.
  • Most urinary crystals can be seen in healthy herbivores, though increased numbers might indicate underlying pathology causing changes in urine ion concentrations or pH.
  • To evaluate the significance of crystalluria, urinalysis should be performed on a fresh (<30-60 min), non-refrigerated sample. 

 

   References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
CaOx:
Description:  Calcium oxalate crystals in the urine commonly appear either as colorless spindle, oval and dumbbell shapes (calcium oxalate monohydrate) or as colorless squares with connecting lines (calcium oxalate dihydrate). They can be clinically insignificant in the dog, but can also indicate certain active disease states.

  

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm.

The crystal images below represent (from left to right) calcium oxalate dihydrate, calcium oxalate monohydrate (picket fence form) and calcium oxalate monohydrate (dumbell form).

  

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CrystalImages. 

 

Increased Calcium Oxalate Crystals

 

  • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated or acidic urine)
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Ethylene glycol toxicity (especially monohydrate forms)
  • Dietary
    • Ingestion of food rich in oxalates, calcium or vitamin D
    • Acidifying diet
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Breed predisposition (Schnauzer, Bichon frise, Shih tzu)
  • Artifact - may form after collection in stored, refrigerated samples

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Calcium Oxalate Crystals

 

  • Possible artifact:
    • Evaluate a fresh urine sample at room temperature immediately after collection to determine whether crystalluria is persistent.
    • Post-collection precipitation of crystals
      • Clinical signs typically absent
      • History or urine specimen being refrigerated or a delay in analysis
      • Urinalysis:
        • Crystalluria with an otherwise inactive urine sediment
        • Urine specific gravity variably high
    • True crystalluria should be investigated if crystalluria is persistent and/or clinical signs of lower urinary tract disease are present
  • Hypercalcemia
    • Chemistry - increased total calcium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses;  inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status.
      • Calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate crystalluria (or calcium carbonate in horses)
    • Evaluate for underlying vcauses of hypercalcemia
      • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
        • Assess for evidence of neoplasia (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, anal gland adenocarcinoma, thymoma) on physical examination with lymph node palpation, abdominal palpation and rectal exam
        • Chemistry:
          • May have increases in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary kidney damage when both phosphorus and calcium are increased
          • Phosphorus decreased if parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) increased
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - low normal or decreased
        • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) - variably increased
      • Primary hyperparathyroidism
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased or low normal phosphorus
          • SDMA, creatinine and BUN usually normal unless concurrent dehydration or kidney disease
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
        • CBC:
          • Nonregegnerative anemia
          • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
      • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins (e.g. vitamin D)
      • Chronic kidney disease (renal secondary hyperparathyroidism)
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Ionized calcium - normal
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
  • Ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate) and calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
      • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
    • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
    • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Calcium oxalate crystals are the precipitation of salts which may be more likely to form in acidic urine.
  • The amount of crystalluria depends on the pH, ion concentrations, and temperature of the urine.
  • While crystalluria is a risk factor for urolithiasis, the presence or absence of crystals does not predict the presence or absence of urolithiasis.
  • Crystals may form or dissolve in urine samples that are aged or have been altered due to evaporation, refrigeration, or changes in pH. Refrigerated samples should be warmed to room temperature prior to performing the urinalysis.
  • Calcium oxalate crystals can be seen in healthy animals, though increased numbers might indicate underlying pathology causing changes in urine ion concentrations or pH.
  • To evaluate the significance of crystalluria, urinalysis should be performed on a fresh (<30-60 min), non-refrigerated sample. 

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

CanL:
﻿Description:  The Leishmania antibody test detects antibodies to the LiDx2 recombinant antigen derived from amastigotes and is based on polypeptides derived from L. infantum immunodominant kinesin antigens. Antibodies are expressed in infected dogs and bind the LiDx2 antigen, available as both capture and detection antigen in SNAP Leishmania and SNAP Leish 4Dx.  

Positive Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Indicates infection with Leishmania infantum. Infection with Leishmania spp. does not necessarily indicate disease.
  • Diagnosis of canine leishmaniasis is generally supported by detection of Leishmania infantum antibodies.
    • Subclinical infections are common and can be associated with low antibody levels.
    • Clinically sick dogs typically present with high antibody titers that are readily detectable.

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is other evidence of canine leishmaniasis such as supportive history and physical exam findings.
    • Generalised lymphadenopathy
    • Weight loss
    • Change in appetite (decreased or increased)
    • Lethargy
    • Pale mucous membranes
    • Coagulopathies or bleeding disorders (e.g., epistaxis, thrombosis)
    • Lameness/arthritis
    • Ocular disease (e.g., conjunctivitis, uveitis)
    • Splenomegaly
    • Increased thirst or urination
    • Fever
    • Gastrointestinal signs such as vomiting or diarrhoea (may include chronic colitis)
    • Dermatitis that may include:
      • Non-pruritic exfloliative dermatitis with or without alopecia
      • Erosive/ulcerative dermatitis
      • Nodular dermatitis
      • Papular dermatitis
      • Pustular dermatitis
    • Onychogryphosis - abnormal, excessive development and curving of the nails
  • CBC:
    • Mild to moderate non-regenerative anaemia
    • Leucocytosis or leucopaenia
    • Thrombocytopaenia
  • Chemistry
    • Increased globulins and total protein 
    • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin
    • Decreased albumin:globulin ratio, albumin
    • Increased SDMA, creatinine, urea - with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Urinalysis
    • Mild to severe proteinuria
    • Variably inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity < 1.030)
  • Increased urine protein:creatinine ratio (UPC) - with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Abnormal coagulation tests and/or decreased platelet function 
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased with systemic inflammation
  • Serum electrophoresis:
    • Typically polyclonal beta and/or gammaglobulinaemia
    • Hypoalbuminaemia
    • Peak may appear as oligoclonal, biclonal, or monoclonal in some cases
  • Quantitative  ELISA antibody tests - can aid in disease staging
    • Antibody levels are usually low in subclinical infection, and high in clinically sick dogs
  • IFA antibody tests - clinically sick dogs typically have high antibody titers (>1:400) that are readibly detectable
  • Leishmania spp. RealPCR:
    • Can be performed on blood, bone marrow, fluid, nasal or conjunctival swabs, urine, synovial fluid or tissues. Quantitative analysis is available for blood, bone marrow, swabs (nasal/ocular), urine or synovial fluid. Qualitative positive PCR results confirm infection, but do not provide information on clinical disease, immunological status or prognosis
    • Quantitative PCR:
      • Medium to high parasitaemia detected by qPCR has a high positive predictive value for the development of clinical disease
      • qPCR can be used to monitor response to treatment - declining parasitaemia can be demonstrated within one month of initiation of effective treatment.

Negative Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody levels below the limit of detection:
    • Strong cellular immune response
    • Immunosuppression
    • Favorable response to treatment

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Leishmania Antibody Test

  • In a dog with clinical signs or history consistent with canine leishmaniasis, consider a Leishmania spp. RealPCR Test:
    • Positive PCR results indicate the presence of Leishmania DNA in the sample submitted.
      • A positive PCR with negative Leishmania Antibody test may occur prior to seroconversion; if the infection is localised to the tissue sample submitted; or if antibody levels are below the limit of infection.
    • Quantitative positive PCR results can provide additional information about this number of organisms within the blood or bone marrow
      • Medium to high parasitaemia has a high positive predictive value for the development of clinical disease.
      • qPCR values can be used to monitor response to treatment - declining parasitaemia can be demonstrated within one month of initiation of effective treatment
    • Negative PCR results indicate that Leishmania DNA was not detected in the sample submitted. 
      • A negative PCR with negative antibody test suggests absence of infection.
      • A negative PCR may also be caused by:
        • Level of parasitaemia below the limit of detection 
        • Decreased numbers of organisms following treatment 
        • Low levels associated with chronic carrier state
        • Localized infection in an organ or site other than the sample submitted.
    • In dogs in endemic areas with consistent clinical signs, an IFA or quantitative ELISA antibody test may detect positive antibody levels below the limit of detection of qualitative antibody tests.

Additional Information

   Leishmaniasis Resource Quick Links:

  • Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of canine leishmaniasis, along with additional resources, are available at www.leishvet.org.

   Physiology

  • Canine leishmaniasis (CanL) is prevalent throughout southern Europe, the Mediterranean, South America, and parts of Africa and Asia. It is also a concern in non-endemic countries due to dog import, travel, and possible non-vector transmission (e.g., mating, vertical transmission, dog-fighting, or blood transfusions)
  • Canine leishmaniasis is an immune-mediated disease where antibody levels correlate with clinical signs. High antibody levels (3 to 4 fold increase above cut-off) are an indication for therapy. 
  • Leishmania infantum is zoonotic and is considered a neglected tropical disease.
  • Felines and other mammals can be infected with Leishmania, but dogs serve as the primary reservoir of infection. 
  • L. infantum is transmitted to the mammalian host via a phlebotomine sand fly vector which transmits the flagellated infective promastigote form.
  • In the mammalian host, the intracellular amatigote form develops and replicates in macrophages.
  • Sand flies (Phlebotomus spp. in the Old World; Lutzomyia spp. in the New World) are the only arthropods that are adapted for biological transmission of Leishmania.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Diagnosis of canine leishmaniasis is supported by detection of Leishmania infantum antibodies either by indirect fluorescent antibodies (IFAT) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA).  
    • Infection with Leishmania spp. does not necessarily indicate disease. Subclinical infections are common and are usually associated with low antibody levels. 
    • Clinically sick dogs typically present with high antibody titers (>1:400) that are readily detectable.
  • Point-of-care antibody tests aid in the diagnosis of dogs with subclinical infection and clinically sick dogs and are useful for differentiating infected from vaccinated animals (DIVA).
  • SNAP Leish 4Dx and SNAP Leishmania tests detect antibodies to the LiDx2 recombinant antigen derived from amastagoes and is based on polypeptides derived from Leishmania infantum immunodominant kinesin antigens. Antibodies are expressed in infected dogs and bind the LiDx2 antigen.
    • SNAP Leish 4Dx:
      • Sensitivity: 98.8% (95% CI: 93.4-100%)
      • Specificity: 98.9% (95% CI: 96.8-100%)
    • SNAP Leishmania:
      • Sensitivity: 98.8% (95% CI: 93.6-100%)
      • Specificity: 98.2% (95% CI: 95.8-99.4%)
  • Indications for testing:
    • Dogs in endemic areas should be screened annually prior to vaccination.
      • Vaccines are recommended annually in endemic areas in conjunction with topical repellants against sand flies.
    • Dogs with consistent clinical signs, especially after travel to endemic areas or those living in endemic areas, should be tested.
    • Dogs imported from endemic areas to non-endemic areas should be screened for evidence of infection.
    • Dogs that have previously tested positive for Leishmania should be monitored routinely with quantitative testing (ELISA or IFAT) for changes in disease status.

 References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Solano-Gallego L, Miro G, Koitinas A, et al. LeishVet guidelines for the practical management of canine leishmaniosis. Parasit Vectors. 2011;4: 86.
  • Practical Management of Canine and Feline Leishmaniosis. https://www.leishvet.org/fact-sheet/ Accessed 8 March 2023.
  • Paltrinieri S, Granodi L, Roura X, et al. Laboratory tests for diagnosing and monitoring canine leishmaniasis. Vet Clin Pathol. 2016;45(4): 552-578.

Last Updated: 29/09/2023
CatalystTT4:
Description: Thyroxine (T4) is the major secretory hormone of the thyroid gland.  Thyroxine helps to regulate metabolism, growth, and many organ functions in the body. 

 

Decreased Total T4

 

  • Hypothyroidism
    • Primary hypothyroidism (common in the dog)
      • Lymphocytic thyroiditis 
      • Idiopathic atrophy
      • Follicular cell hyperplasia
      • Neoplastic destruction of the thyroid
    • Iatrogenic hypothyroidism (cat):
    • Secondary hypothyroidism (e.g. pituitary diease)
    • Congenital hypothyroidism (rare)
      • Dyshormonogenesis - iodine organification defect (cats)
      • Thyroid gland dysgenesis (e.g. Giant Schnauzer, Boxer, Tenterfield terrier, Abyssinian cat)
      • Iodine deficiency (all-meat diet)
      • Ingestion of giotrogens (horse) - excess iodine intake during pregnancy
  • Suppression of the pituitary-thyroid axis
    • Euthyroid sick syndrome - suppression of total T4 +/- free T4 in response to clinical illness
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, carprofen)
  • Breed variation - Sight hounds (e.g., Greyhounds), Basenjis, conditioned sled dogs
  • Artifact - anti-T4 antibodies can increase or decrease total T4, depending on methodology

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Total T4

 

  • Evaluate for clinical signs consistent with hypothyroidism:
    • Lethargy, mental dullness, weakness
    • Weight gain with no increase in appetite
    • Alopecia, hyperpigmentation, otitis, pyoderma
  • Evaluate history for concurrent drugs which may decrease total T4, e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, carprofen, furosemide, clomipramine, sulfonamides, phenylbutazone, progestagens, methimazole, propylthiouracil (PTU)
  • Hypothyroidism
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry - increased cholesterol, triglycerides
    • Free T4 - decreased
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to increased
    • Variably increased thyroglobulin autoantibody in primary hypothyroidism
  • Euthyroid sick syndrome
    • CBC, chemistry and urinalysis changes reflect underlying disease
    • Free T4 or free T4 by equilibrium dialysis - often normal; however, severe underlying disease may suppress Free T4.
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to decreased
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Free T4 or Free T4 by equilibrium dialysis - often normal
    • Endogenous cTSTH - normal to decreased
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoid enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

 

Increased Total T4

 

  • Hyperthyroidism (common in the cat)
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Iatrogenic (oversupplementation) 
  • Artifact - anti-T4 antibodies may increase or decrease total T4 (varies by methodology)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Total T4

 

  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Thyroxine (T4) is formed in the thyroid gland.  Adequate ingestion of iodide is required for the normal production of thyroid hormones.  Approximately 80% of the thyroid hormone produced by the thyroid gland is T4 and approximately 20% is T3. 
  • Thyrotropin (TSH) from the pituitary gland will stimulate thyroid hormone secretion. 
    • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus is needed to control TSH secretion from the pituitary. 
    • Negative feedback control of TSH is mediated by unbound fractions of T3 and T4 at the level of the pituitary gland.  
  • Approximately 99.9% of circulating T4 is protein bound. 
    • The free or unbound thyroxine is the active form that can enter cells. 
    • The protein-bound T4 serves as a reservoir of thyroxine. 
    • The total T4 measured is comprised of the protein-bound and unbound hormone. 
  • Pregnancy (progesterone) and obesity can cause mild increases in basal T4 levels. 
  • Young clinically healthy dogs with high T4 values are usually a variant of normal or have T4 autoantibodies. 
  • Dogs with signs of hypothyroidism and a low or low normal T4 should be further evaluated with a free T4 and a TSH. 
  • Senior cats that have T4 values at the high end of the reference range usually have early hyperthyroidism and can be further evaluated with a free T4.
  • In dogs and cats receiving thyroid supplementation, it is recommended to obtain a postpill T4 sample 4-6 hours after thyroid supplementation for peak levels.  The peak T4 levels in dogs should be at the high end or slightly above the reference range.
  • In cats on methimazole therapy, blood sampling can be obtained at any time of the day as long as the cat has received its regular daily dose. 
    • Cats on therapy should have T4 values at the lower end of the reference range.
    • The target for cats with concurrent chronic kidney disease is often a bit higher, especially mid-range normal.

 

   References

 

  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW, Reusch CE, Scott-Moncrief, JCR, eds.  Canine & Feline Endocrinology, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2015. 
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse’s Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003. 

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
Cl:
Description: Chloride is the most abundant anion in the extracellular fluid.  Chloride is important for acid/base balance, cellular fluid transport, and nerve function.

 

Decreased Chloride

  

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Diarrhea/vomiting
    • Whipworms
    • Excessive salivation
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Metabolic acidoses with increased anion gap
    • Ketoacidosis
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Ethylene glycol
  • Renal losses (e.g. diuretics, prolonged diuresis, ketonuria)
  • Artifact
    • Hyperlipemia
    • Hyperproteinemia
  • Congestive heart failure (edema)
  • Hypoaldosteronism
  • Respiratory acidosis, especially chronic
  • Cutaneous loss due to sweating (horses)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Chloride

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Radiographs - evaluate for small intestinal obstruction (decreased chloride common with small intestnal obstruction)
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Increased potassium
          • Decreased Na:K ratio
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration

 

Increased Chloride

  

  • Fluid losses where water loss > electrolyte loss
    • Gastrointestinal water loss (acute diarrhea, vomiting, phosphate enemas)
    • Osmotic diuresis
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Kidney disease
      • Diuretic therapy
  • Artifact due to bromide therapy
  • Pure water loss without replacement
    • Insensible losses (e.g. fever/hyperthermia, panting, hyperventilation)
    • Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) 
  • Inadequate water intake
    • Water deprivation
    • Adipsia/hypodipsia/defective thirst response
      • Syndrome in cats and Miniature Schnauzers
      • Central nervous system disease
  • Chloride excess (in face of water restriction)
    • Hypertonic saline fluid therapy
    • Increased intake (e.g. salt poisoning)
    • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Respiratory alkalosis (chronic)
  • Artifact due to sample dehydration from evaporation or sublimation 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Chloride

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
      • Increased sodium
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
  • Pure water loss or inadequate water intake
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Chloride concentration is directly proportional to sodium concentration and inversely proportional to bicarbonate concentration.
  • Serum chloride concentration is controlled by renal and gastrointestinal reabsorption and secretion.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Ion selective electrode assays are most common measurement technique.

 

   References 

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse’s Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology,  4th ed.  Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004
     

Last updated 12/1/2018
