      • Increased sodium
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
  • Pure water loss or inadequate water intake
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Chloride concentration is directly proportional to sodium concentration and inversely proportional to bicarbonate concentration.
  • Serum chloride concentration is controlled by renal and gastrointestinal reabsorption and secretion.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Ion selective electrode assays are most common measurement technique.

 

   References 

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse’s Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology,  4th ed.  Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004
     

Last updated 12/1/2018
Clar:
Description: Clarity is analyzed by visual inspection of the urine sample.  Change in urine clarity is most often due to the presence of red blood cells, white blood cells, or crystals in the urine.

 

Decreased Clarity
   

  • Crystalluria
    • Artifact (e.g. post-collection precipitation of crystals)
    • True crystalluria
  • Urinary tract infection
    • Bacterial cystitis
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Prostatitis
  • Urinary tract inflammation
    • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
    • Urolithiasis
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma, prostate carcinoma)
  • Vaginitis (voided sample)
  • Hyperlipidemia

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Clarity

 

  • Crystalluria
    • Evaluate a fresh urine sample at room temperature immediately after collection to determine whether crystalluria and decreased clarity are persistent.
    • Post-collection precipitation of crystals
      • Clinical signs typically absent
      • History or urine specimen being refrigerated or a delay in analysis
      • Urinalysis:
        • Crystalluria with an otherwise inactive urine sediment
        • Urine specific gravity variably high
    • True crystalluria
      • Uncommon crystal types (e.g. ammonium biurate, cystine, calcium oxalate monohydrate) may indicate underlying disease (see Crystal Differentials for additional details)
      • Common crystal types (e.g. calcium oxalate dihydrate or struvite) should be investigated if crystalluria is persistent and/or clinical signs of lower urinary tract disease are present
  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.

  

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • In most animals, normal urine is clear to slightly cloudy when freshly voided.
  • Urine may become cloudy upon standing (or refrigeration) due to precipitation of salts.

 

  References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and urology of small animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasses KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
Color:
Definition:  Urinary color is analyzed by visual inspection.  Change in urinary color from its normal appearance – light yellow to amber – indicates the presence of pigments in the urine which can indicate urinary tract disease or systemic disease.

 

Urine Color Change

 

  • Red or Red/Brown
    • Hematuria
      • Urinary tract infection
        • Bacterial cystitis
        • Pyelonephritis
        • Prostatitis
      • Urinary tract inflammation
        • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
        • Urolithiasis
      • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma, prostate carcinoma)
      • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract
        • Coagulation or platelet disorder
        • Idiopathic renal hematuria
        • Trauma
        • Estrus (voided sample)
      • Iatrogenic - due to traumatic cystocentesis or catheterization, or manual expression
    • Hemoglobinuria 
      • Intravascular hemolysis
        • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
        • Non-immune red blood cell destruction (e.g. Heinz body anemia)
      • Lysis of red blood cells after entering urine
  •  Yellow/Orange or Yellow/Brown
    • Bilirubinuria
      • Hepatic or biliary disease
      • Extravascular hemolysis
  • Brown/Black
    • Methemoglobinuria (e.g. ibuprofen toxicity)

  

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Urine Color Change

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.
  • Coagulation or platelet disorder
    • Evaluate physical exam and history for other evidence of bleeding disorder or blood loss in sites other than the urogenital tract (e.g. melena, petechiae, ecchymoses)
    • CBC:
      • Regenerative anemia (increased reticulocytes)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased platelets (marked with immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, mild to moderate with consumption)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased albumin, globulins and total protein
      • Variably increased or decreased ALT, ALP, GGT, bilirubin (with liver disease)
    • Coagulation panel
      • PT/PTT prolongation (rodenticide, liver disease)
      • Von Willebrand's testing (breed specific)
      • Factor analysis - decreased in specific coagulation factors with hemophilia
      • Buccal mucosal bleeding time prolonged (functional testing of platelets)
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocyte
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review - spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocyte
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review - Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetaminophen (cats > dogs)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Urochromes are a group of urine pigments that give mammalian urine a yellow/amber color
  • Less concentrated urine is often pale yellow

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Color should be assessed on fresh, well-mixed urine samples.
  • Abnormal color indicates the presences of pigments in the urine; pigmenturia can alter the expected color of the urine.

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D eds. Nephrology and urology of small animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
EC-EE:
﻿Description: ﻿The Ehrlichia antibody test detects IgM and IgG antibodies to the p30/p30/p28 region of the outer membrane of Ehrlichia canis, E. ewingii and E. chaffeensis.

Positive Ehrlichia Antibody Test

  • Active infection with E. canis, E. ewingii and/or E. chaffeensis.
  • Residual or declining antibody response from a previously cleared/treated infection.

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Ehrlichia Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is evidence of ehrlichiosis such as supportive history and physical exam findings.
  • CBC:
    • Thrombocytopenia, normocytic, normochromic nonregenerative anemia
    • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Lymphocytosis, moderate to marked
    • Pancytopenia may be seen in the severe chronic phase.
    • Ehrlichia morulae inclusions within monocytes or granulocytes may be seen on blood film evaluation.
  • Chemistry:
    • Increased globulin, usually polyclonal, but occasionally monoclonal
    • Variably decreased albumin
    • Mild increases in ALT and ALP may be present.
    • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and/or phosphorus may be seen with secondary kidney disease.
  • Urinalysis:
    • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status variable with secondary tubular kidney disease.
    • Variably increased protein
  • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased
  • Infectious disease testing:
    • For dogs presenting with clinical signs consistent with a vector-borne disease, using serology and PCR together improves ability to make a complete and accurate diagnosis.
    • PCR-positive for Ehrlichia canis, E. chaffeensis or E.ewingii
      • Negative PCR result after treatment can indicate a reduction in pathogen load
      • Vector-borne disease PCR panel may identify co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Anaplasma spp., Bartonella spp.)
    • IFA
      • Positive for antibodies
        • IFA available for Ehrlichia canis.
      • IFA can be subjective and may cross react with other species of Ehrlichia.
  • Joint cytology - findings may include increased mononuclear cell, neutrophil and/or lymphocyte counts. Morulae inclusions may be visualized within the cells.
  • CSF - mononuclear or neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased protein
  • Bone marrow - cytologic or histopathologic evidence of plasmacytosis, cellular hypoplasia
  • Asymptomatically infected dogs may not have specific hematologic or biochemical changes, but should be monitored for clinical signs and development of hematologic changes or proteinuria.

Negative Ehrlichia Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody concentration below the limit of detection

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Ehrlichia Antibody Test

  • In dogs with history, clinical signs and clinical pathology consistent with ehrlichiosis consider:
    • Blood film evaluation for morulae inclusions within monocytes or granulocytes
    • Vector-borne disease PCR panel to detect early infection prior to seroconversion and to evaluate for co-infections with other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Anaplasma spp.)

Additional Information

Ehrlichia Resource Quick Links:

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of tick/vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide
  • View the Ehrlichia Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/ehrlichia-next-steps.
  • Visit www.idexx.com/VBD-exposure-and-CKD to learn more about the risk for chronic kidney disease in E. canis positive dogs.
  • Access additional vector borne disease resources at www.idexx.com/4Dx-plus-resources.

Physiology

  • One large study of dogs across central and eastern US demonstrated a seropositive rate to E. canis of 0.8%, to E. ewingii of 5.1% and to E. chaffeensis of 2.8%.
  • Dogs with Ehrlichia antibodies in E. canis endemic areas has a 112% increased risk of developing CKD compared to unexposed dogs.
  • The minimum tick feeding time required prior to transmission of Ehrlichia spp. is unknown.
  • Ehrlichia canis
    • Ehrlichia canis is diagnosed worldwide, primarily in tropical and temperate areas, except Australia.
    • The primary vectors for Ehrlichia canis are Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) and Dermacentor variabilis (American dog tick). E. canis and the brown dog tick have a worldwide geographic distribution, while the American dog tick is found in the eastern US, through the mid-west, and in California.
    • Ehrlichia canis primarily infects dogs since the primary tick vector (Rhipicephalus sanguineus) preferentially feed on dogs (or canid species) in all stages of their lifecycle. The larval or nymphal tick acquires E. canis from a canid reservoir host (coyote, fox, jackal, domestic dog). The infection is then transmitted transstadially. It is not transmitted transovarially.
    • After acquiring E. canis, the tick can infect a host for at least 155 days, which permits the pathogen to overwinter in the tick.
    • Once a tick infected with E. canis feeds on an animal, the organism invades monocytes, macrophages, and lymphocytes, forming membrane-bound, intracytoplasmic colonies of organisms known as morulae. Morulae may appear as early as 8 days after the infection, but are rarely seen. Thrombocytopenia is the most consistent clinicopathologic abnormality associated with infection.
    • Coinfections of E. canis with A. platys are relatively common as Rhipicephalus sanguineus (brown dog tick) is known to transmit E. canis and A. platys, as well as Babesia spp., and Rickettsia rickettsii (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever).  
    • Dermacentor variabilis (American dog tick) may transmit E. canis, and is known to transmit R. rickettsii (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever) and Francisella tularensis (tularemia).
    • Clinical signs in dogs acutely infected with E. canis may include fever, anorexia, lethargy, abnormal bleeding (e.g. epistaxis), polyarthritis, and lymphadenopathy.
    • Clinical signs in dogs chronically infected with E. canis may include fever, anorexia, secondary infections due to neutropenia, neurological issues secondary to hyperviscosity, and vomiting secondary to kidney disease.
  • Ehrlichia ewingii
    • Ehrlichia ewingii is commonly diagnosed in south central and southeastern United States, in Brazil, and in West Africa.
    • The primary vector for Ehrlichia ewingii in North America is Amblyomma americanum (Lone star tick). This tick is present in the eastern US, extending into the Midwest and Texas. Outside of North America, the transmitting arthropod is uncertain.
    • Amblyomma americanum (Lone star tick) is known to transmit E. ewingii, E. chaffeensis, Francisella tularensis (tularemia), and Southern Tick Associated Rash Illness (STARI), possibly caused by the spirochete Borrelia lonestarii.
    • White-tailed deer are the major reservoir for E. ewingii. After a tick feeds on a host, the infection is transmitted transstadially in the tick.
    • Once a tick infected with E. ewingii feeds on an animal, the organism invades granulocytes (i.e. neutrophils) forming membrane-bound, intracytoplasmic colonies of organisms known as morulae. The pathophysiology of the disease that ensues is not well documented.  
    • Morulae of E. ewingii can be observed within granulocytes as soon as 12 days after inoculation. Thrombocytopenia is the most consistent clinicopathologic abnormality associated with infection.
    • Evidence suggests that infection results only in acute illness, though infection may be persistent. There may be an immune-mediated component to the thrombocytopenia and polyarthritis that develop.
    • Clinical signs in dogs infected with E. ewingii may be mild, brief and self-limiting. Acute fever, reluctance to stand/walk, lameness, stiffness and joint effusion are most common. Anorexia, lethargy and occasionally neurologic signs may be present.
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis
    • E. chaffeensis is most commonly diagnosed in the southern, south central and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States.
    • The primary vector for Ehrlichia chaffeensis in North America is Amblycomma americanum (Lone star tick). This tick is present in the eastern US, extending in to the Midwest and Texas. Outside of North America, the transmitting arthropod is uncertain.
    • White-tailed deer are the main reservoir for E. chaffeensis, though other animals may serve as a reservoir, such as goats, dogs, raccoons and coyotes.
    • Tick larvae are infected when they feed on the blood of an infected host. The infection is transmitted to another host at the tick nymphal stage. Adult ticks can also transmit the organism.
    • Once a tick infected with E. chaffeensis feeds on an animal, the organism invades monocytes.
    • Infections with E. chaffeensis are most commonly reported in humans. Infection can also occur in dogs, coyotes, red foxes and white-tailed deer.
    • E. chaffeensis does not often cause clinical illness in dogs. If present, signs may include mild to moderate fever, anorexia, and lethargy.

Diagnostic Methodology

  • ELISA technology is used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies to the p30/p30-1 region of the outer membrane of E. canis, E. ewingii, and E. chaffeensis. Results are reported as positive or negative.
  • The Ehrlichia antibody test will typically be positive 7-21 days after infection with Ehrlichia spp.
  • A positive Ehrlichia Antibody test result generally correlates with an Ehrlichia canis IFA titer of 1:100 or higher.

References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Beall MJ, Alleman AR, et al.  Seroprevalence of Ehrlichia canis, Ehrlichia chaffeensis and Ehrlichia ewingii in dogs in North America. Parasites & Vectors 2012; 5:29.
  • Gaunt SD, Beall MJ et al. Experimental infection and co-infection of dogs with Anaplasma platys and Ehrlichia canis; hematologic, serologic and molecular findings. Parasites & Vectors 2010; 3:33.
  • Sainz A, Roura R, et al. Guidelines for veterinary practitioners on canine ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis in Europe. Parasites & Vectors 2015; 8:75.

Last updated:  12/1/2018
EOS:
Description: Eosinophils are white blood cells that are specialized to combat parasites and other infectious diseases. They are also involved in allergic responses.

 

Decreased Eosinophils   

  • Normal (Some reference intervals include zero.)
  • Corticosteroid-induced eosinopenia
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress   
  • Acute inflammation
  • Decreased bone marrow production   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Eosinophils

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced eosinopenia
    • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    • CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • Absence of a left shift
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased lymphocytes
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 
    • Assess for recent history of glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests 
      • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
          
     

Increased Eosinophils
   

  • Hypersensitivity responses (allergy)
  • Infection
    • Parasitic
    • Fungal
    • Pythium
    • FeLV (rare)
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome
  • Endocrine
    • Hyopadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
  • Eosinophilic bronchopneumopathy
  • Eosinophilic leukemia 
 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Eosinophils 

 

  • Hypersensitivity responses
    • Asthma
      • Bronchial pattern on thoracic radiographs
      • Eosinophilic and neutrophilic inflammation found on transtrachael or endotracheal wash
    • Eosinophilic granuloma complex
      • Histopathology supportive of eosinophilic granuloma complex
    • Allergic dermatitis/atopy
      • Abnormalities on skin allergy testing
      • Positive reactions on serum allergy testing
      • Histopathology supportive of allergic dermatitis
    • Food allergies/eosinophilic gastroenteritis 
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies showing eosinophilic inflammation
      • Gastric and/or intestinal wall thickening found on abdominal ultrasound
      • Abnormal serum folate and cobalamin
    • Allergic rhinitis/sinusitis
      • Lymphoplasmacytic or eosinophilic inflammation on nasal biopsies
  • Infection
    • CBC:
      • Variable anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Variable basophilia with parastic infections
    • Skin scrapings to assess for ectoparasites
    • Fecal Dx antigen tests and/or fecal ova and parasite tests positive with intestinal parasites
    • Serology, PCR or antigen tests positive for other infectious causes (e.g. systemic fungal, heartworm, pythiosis, FeLV) 
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
    • Most comon in middle-aged female, domestic shorthair cats and Rottweiler dogs
    • CBC:
      • Variable mild nonregenerative anemia
      • Marked mature eosinophilia (typically >20,000 cells/ul)
      • Basophilia
    • Histopathology or cytology of any affected organs or masses - eosinophilic infiltration
    • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy to discriminate from eosinophilic leukemia 
  • Neoplasia
    • Paraneoplastic:
      • Cytology or histopathology - consistent with mast cell neoplasia, lymphoma, carcinoma or thymoma
    • Eosinophilic leukemia
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia (often severe)
        • Variable thrombocytopenia and neutropenia
        • Immature myelogenous precursors often present
      • Bone marrow cytology of aspirate or histopathology of biopsy - eosinophilic leukemia with immature forms and disorderly maturation
  • Endocrine
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
      • CBC:
        • Mild nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium 
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol 
        • Abnormal ACTH stimulation 
    • Hyperthyroidism
      • CBC - mild erythryocytosis
      • Chemistry - increased ALT, ALP, glucose and phosphorus
      • Total T4, Free T4 concentrations increased
  • Eosinophilic bronchopneumopathy
    • Reported in dogs, especially Siberian huskies
    • CBC:
      • Deceased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Thoracic radiographs - bronchointerstitial pattern and air trapping, with occasional lobar consolidation or miliary patterns
    • Heartworm, Fecal Dx antigen and fecal ova and parasite testing -  all negative 
    • Transtracheal or endotracheal wash cytology - increased eosinophils

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Eosinophil granules stain variably eosinophilic (pink) depending on the species, and their shape is species specific.
    • The granules are large, round, and uniform in the horse, and rod-shaped and less bright in the cat.
    • Dogs can have varying numbers and sizes of granules.
    • The granules contain lysozymes and other substances that are important to their protective function.
  • Eosinophils are active in killing of helminths and also in the regulation of mast cells.
  • Eosinophils are most commonly found in the skin, lung, gastrointestinal tract and endometrium.

  

Diagnostic Methodology 

 
  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The eosinophil percentage (or relative eosinophil count) is the number of eosinophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute eosinophil count is calculated by multiplying the eosinophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.

  

References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018

FIV:
Description: The FIV antibody ELISA is used to diagnose Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (FIV).  FIV antibody tests use ELISA technology to detect antibodies against FIV structural proteins. 

Positive FIV Antibody

  • FIV infection
  • Artifactual (interferences) 
    • Maternal antibodies
    • FIV vaccination

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive FIV Antibody

  • FIV infection
    • Clinical pathologic findings are not specific for infection and may reflect concurrent disease.
    • CBC:
      • Anemia – usually non-regenerative
      • Leukopenia
        • Lymphopenia, neutropenia
      • Thrombocytopenia
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, globulin
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine – If is unclear if FIV an cause renal disease, renal disease may be concurrent 
    • Infectious disease testing:
      • Confirmatory testing for FIV with another technology (Plate ELISA, RealPCR, Western blot).
  • Maternal antibodies
    • Retest FIV antibody ELISA after kitten reaches 6 months of age
    • FIV RealPCR – negative, but PCR does not exclude FIV, recommend FIV antibody ELISA to confirm negative state after kitten reaches 6 months of age
  • FIV vaccination
    • FIV RealPCR – negative
    • Note FIV vaccines are currently available in Australia and New Zealand

Negative FIV Antibody

  • Absence of FIV infection
    • No exposure
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion/antibody concentration below limit of detection
    • FIV tests can take up to 60 days to become positive

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative FIV Antibody

  • Absence of FIV infection
    • FIV RealPCR and Western Blot can be used to support the absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion/antibody concentration below limit of detection
    • Retest FIV antibody ELISA in 60 days if at high risk of recent exposure

Additional Information

 Analyte Resource Quick Links:

  • View the FIV diagnostic algorithm
  • For more information on diagnosis and management of FIV, read the American Association of Feline Practitioners (AAFP) Retrovirus Guidelines which have been endorsed by the International Society of Feline Medicine (ISFM)
  • For sharing positive results with pet owners, please see the FIV Positive Client Handout.

 Physiology

  • Feline immunodeficiency virus is a retrovirus of the genus Lentivirus. 
  • Five different subtypes (A, B, C, D, E) are found worldwide, which differ in their clinical manifestation and pathogenicity. 
    • New subtypes may emerge and have been described in cats from Texas (subtype F), New Zealand, and Portugal. 
  • FIV is shed in high concentrations in the saliva, therefore FIV is most often transmitted through bite and fight wounds making outdoor cats especially vulnerable.
    • FIV has also been reported to be transmitted from an infected queen to her kittens under experimental conditions.
  • After peak viremia, circulating virus decreases due to the host immune response. A strong, but ultimately ineffective humoral immune response is mounted and anti-FIV antibodies become detectable. 
    • Antibodies are produced against several proteins such as proteins of the viral envelope, capsid, and transmembrane proteins.
  • Indications for testing
    • At the time cat is acquired
    • Before initial vaccination
    • After potential exposure
    • If clinical signs of disease are present
    • Prior to blood donation or breeding
  • Clinical signs
    • Early non-specific signs are seen in experimental disease but may not be present in natural infection or may go unnoticed by pet parents – malaise, stomatitis, respiratory disease, lymphadenopathy, enteritis, dermatitis, conjunctivitis. 
    • Later stages – clinical signs reflect those of opportunistic infections, neoplasia, myelosuppression, and neurologic disease. 
    • With appropriate veterinary care and husbandry, FIV positive cats can live as long as non-infected cats.

 Diagnostic Methodology

  • FIV antibody tests use ELISA technology to detect antibodies against FIV structural proteins and are validated for domestic cats.
  • FIV antigen tests will typically be positive 60 days post-exposure.
  • Results are reported as positive or negative (no antigen detected).

   

References

  • Hartmann K. Clinical Aspects of Feline Retroviruses: A Review. Viruses. 2012;4(11):2684-2710. doi:10.3390/v4112684
  • Litster AL. Transmission of feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) among cohabiting cats in two cat rescue shelters. Vet J. 2014;201(2):184-188. doi:10.1016/j.tvjl.2014.02.030
  • Little S, Levy J, Hartmann K, et al. 2020 AAFP Feline Retrovirus Testing and Management Guidelines. J Feline Med Surg. 2020;22(1):5-30. doi:10.1177/1098612X19895940
  • Sellon R, Hartmann K. Feline Immunodeficiency Virus Infection. In: Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat. 4th ed. Elsevier, Inc; 2012.

Last updated 09/29/2023
FRU:
Description:  Fructosamine is a complex of glucose and protein that can be used to assess the average blood glucose concentration in a dog or cat over the previous 2-3 weeks.  It is used in the diagnosis and management of diabetes mellitus.

Decreased Fructosamine

  • Prolonged hypoglycemia
    • Insulin overdose (exogenous)
    • Insulinoma (endogenous)
  • Decreased albumin (dog) or total protein (cat)
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Artifact:
    • Hypertriglyceridemia may decrease fructosamine (varies by methodology)
    • Hemolysis may decrease fructosamine with certain methodologies e.g. Catalyst Fructosamine

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Fructosamine

 

  • Review medication history, especially insulin and oral hypoglycemics, and potential exposure to toxins.
  • Insulinoma
    • Increased insulin:glucose ratio (measured on a specimen with low glucose)
    • Abominal ultrasound may show pancreatic or hepatic masses
    • Consistent cytological or histopathological findings

 

Increased Fructosamine

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Insulin overdose with Somogyi rebound effect
  • Hypothyroidism 
  • Increased albumin (dog) or total protein (cat)
  • Artifact:
    • Hemolysis may increase fructosamine (varies by methodology)

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Fructosamine

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration

 

Additional Information 

  

  Physiology

 

  • Fructosamine correlates with the patient’s average blood glucose concentration over the last 2-3 weeks. 
    • Fructosamine is not affected by short-term increases in serum glucose such as those that occur with excitement, stress, or intravenous dextrose administration.
  • Fructosamine is a ketoamine that is formed by an irreversible nonenzymatic linking of glucose to proteins (most often albumin and IgG).
    • Formation of fructosamine is related to the degree and duration of hyperglycemia.
    • Removal of fructosamine from the blood is dependent on the loss or degradation of the parent molecule (albumin).
  • Fructosamine should not be used as the sole indicator of diabetic regulation but should be used in conjunction with clinical history (PU/PD, weight stability, polyphagia) and glucose curves to determine the patient’s level of diabetic regulation.
  • Because fructosamine is an indicator of the average glucose levels over the prior 2-3 weeks, animals with insulin overdose and Somogyi rebound can have an increased, decreased or normal fructosamine value, depending on the relative amount of time spent in the hypoglycemic state versus in the rebound hyperglycemic state.
    • Patients with Somogyi effect will often have clinical signs of poor diabetic regulation (PU/PD, weight loss, polyphagia).
  • Interpretation of fructosamine in a diabetic animal must account for the fact that even well-controlled diabetics are hyperglycemic at some time points.
    • This will cause the fructosamine to be slightly higher in a well-controlled diabetic compared to a nondiabetic patient.
    • Therefore a normal fructosamine in a diabetic patient should raise the concern that blood glucose may be inappropriately low.

 

  Diagnostic Methodology 

 

  • Fructosamine assays depend on the ability of fructosamine to reduce tetrazolium salts to a formazan dye in an alkaline environment.
    • The degree of colour produced by the dye is proportional to the amount of fructosamine in the sample.
         

   References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW, eds. Canine and Feline Endocrinology and Reproduction, 3rd ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA, eds. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell Publishing; 2008.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
FeLV:
Description: The FeLV antigen ELISA is used to diagnose Feline Leukemia Virus (FeLV).  FeLV antigen tests use ELISA technology to detect soluble FeLV p27 capsid antigen.

Positive FeLV Antigen

  • Infection with FeLV
    • Progressive infection
      • FeLV antigen positive and FeLV RealPCR positive
    • Regressive infection
      • FeLV antigen positive and FeLV RealPCR negative
    • Focal or atypical infection
      • FeLV antigen positive (may be intermittent); FeLV RealPCR negative

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive FeLV Antigen

  • Infection with FeLV
    • Clinical pathologic findings are not specific for infection and may reflect concurrent disease.
    • CBC:
      • Anemia
        • Regenerative – hemolytic anemia, blood loss anemia
        • Nonregenerative – Pure red cell aplasia, anemia of chronic inflammation
      • Leukopenia
        • Lymphopenia, neutropenia, panleukopenia-like syndrome
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukemia
      • CBC alterations are more commonly seen in progressively infected cats but occasionally seen in regressively infected cats
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin – with secondary hepatopathy
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine – with secondary glomerulonephritis
      • Increased globulin, total protein
      • Decreased albumin in cats with glomerulonephritis
    • UA: 
      • Variably increased protein 
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio – increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
    • Infectious disease testing:
      • Confirmatory testing for FeLV at a reference laboratory with a FeLV antigen ELISA or a different in-house FeLV test - positive
      • FeLV quantitative RealPCR can help determine the stage of disease and prognosis

Negative FeLV Antigen

  • Absence of FeLV Infection
    • No exposure
  • Exposure prior to antigenemia/antigen below limit of detection
    • FeLV can take 30+ days for the antigen load to develop
  • Regressive Infection 
    • FeLV antigen negative and FeLV RealPCR positive
  • Abortive Infection 
    • Negative on both FeLV antigen and FeLV RealPCR

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative FeLV Antigen

  • Absence of FeLV Infection
    • FeLV RealPCR – negative – can be used to support absence of infection 
  • Early infection
    • Retest FeLV antigen ELISA in 30 days – negative – important in cases of recent exposure to FeLV or cats newly adopted into the household
  • FeLV Regressive infection
    • FeLV Quant RealPCR <1.0 X 106 copies/mL

Additional Information

FeLV Antigen (ELISA) Resource Quick Links:

  • View the FeLV diagnostic algorithm
  • Visit idexx.com/FeLVQuant for more information on staging with FeLV Quant RealPCR
  • For more information on diagnosis and management of FeLV, read the American Association of Feline Practitioners (AAFP) Retrovirus Guidelines which have been endorsed by the International Society of Feline Medicine (ISFM)
  • For sharing positive results with pet owners, please see the FeLV Positive Client Handout

Physiology

  • FeLV is a member of the retrovirus family and has the ability to insert a DNA copy of its RNA into the host DNA.
  • Transmission occurs between cats with close contact to each other primarily through the oral nasal route or bite wounds.
    • Transmission can also occur between a queen and her kittens.  
  • Stages of FeLV
    • Progressive Infection – An ineffective immune response allows infection of the bone marrow, lymphoid tissue, mucosa, and glandular epithelium tissues.  This leads to a persistent viremia and viral shedding making these cats a source of infection for other cats. 
      • Progressively infected cats tend to have a shorter survival than regressively infected cats
      • Clinical signs of FeLV infection usually develop in cats with progressive infection, but often not until after several years of persistent viremia
      • Clinical signs can be directly related to retrovirus infection or due to diseases that are secondary to the immunosuppressive effects of retroviruses. 
        • Co-infections - FIP, FIV, upper respiratory, hemotropic mycoplasma, stomatitis
        • Lymphoma, anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, leukemia, myeloproliferative disease.
    • Regressive Infection – The FeLV proviral DNA is integrated into the host cells but an effective immune response suppresses viral replication which decreases virus shedding.
      • Reactivation of the virus can cause these cats to advance from a regressive stage to a progressive stage. 
      • With proper care these cats can lead a long and healthy life
    • Focal or atypical infection –The infection is limited to a certain tissue or organ with intermittent shedding of the virus.  These cats are not infectious to other cats via saliva but can transmit the infection under certain conditions (example queen with mammary focalized FeLV transmits to kittens during nursing).
    • Abortive Infection – The host immune system eliminates the virus after initial infection. 
      • Abortive cats do not shed virus or develop clinical signs.
      • Abortive infections are uncommon
  • Indications for testing
    • At the time cat is acquired
    • Before initial vaccination
    • After potential exposure
    • If clinical signs of disease are present
    • Prior to blood donation or breeding

Diagnostic Methodology

  • FeLV antigen tests use ELISA technology to detect soluble FeLV p27 capsid antigen and are validated for domestic cats.
  • FeLV antigen tests will typically be positive 30 days post-exposure with FeLV but in some cats positive results may take longer.
  • Results are reported as positive or negative (no antigen detected).

   

References

  • Beall MJ, Buch J, Cahill RJ, et al. Evaluation of a quantitative enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for feline leukemia virus p27 antigen and comparison to proviral DNA loads by real-time polymerase chain reaction. Comp Immunol Microbiol Infect Dis. 2019;67:101348. doi:10.1016/j.cimid.2019.101348
  • Hartmann K. Feline Leukemia Virus Infection. In: Infectious Disease of the Dog and Cat. 3rd ed. Elsevier, Inc; 2012.
  • Helfer-Hungerbuehler AK, Widmer S, Kessler Y, et al. Long-term follow up of feline leukemia virus infection and characterization of viral RNA loads using molecular methods in tissues of cats with different infection outcomes. Virus Res. 2015;197:137-150. doi:10.1016/j.virusres.2014.12.025
  • Little S, Levy J, Hartmann K, et al. 2020 AAFP Feline Retrovirus Testing and Management Guidelines. J Feline Med Surg. 2020;22(1):5-30. doi:10.1177/1098612X19895940
  • Lockhart HL, Levy JK, Amirian ES, Hamman NT, Frenden MK. Outcome of cats referred to a specialized adoption program for feline leukemia virus-positive cats. J Feline Med Surg. 2020;22(12):1160-1167. doi:10.1177/1098612X20913359
