GGT:
Description:  Gamma glutamyl transferase (GGT) is a marker of cholestatic liver disease.

 

Increased GGT

 

  • Liver disease with intrahepatic cholestasis
    • Infectious (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. phenobarbital, mycotoxins, ragwort, alsike clover)
    • Vascular anomaly 
      • Portosystemic shunt (primary or acquired)
      • Microvascular dysplasia
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis to liver
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited 
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
      • Degenerative vacuolar hepatopathy in Scottish terriers
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Metabolic diseases with secondary hepatopathy and/or steroid induction
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hepatic lipdosis
  • Colostral intake and absorption
  • Artifact - hemolysis may have a variable effect on GGT depending on methodology

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased GGT

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithisis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically >70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction <60%
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets - mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Elevated ALT, AST, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubinuria, bilirubin or ammonium urate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract.
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's syndrome)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP > GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased (unless concurrent inflammatory disease)
      • Increased ALT and bilirubin
      • BUN decreased
      • Variable cholesterol and albumin
    • Urinalysis:
      • Variable; often inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.035)
      • Variable bilirubinuria (follows increased serum bilirubin)
    • Bile acids - may be increased with severe disease; not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be increased with severe disease
    • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
    • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
    • Liver cytology or biopsy - severe vacuolar hepatopathy
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
      • History of stress or household changes

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • GGT is involved in glutathione metabolism and is mainly associated with the microsomal membranes of biliary epithelium, renal tubular epithelial cells, and pancreatic acinar cells.
  • The activity of serum GGT parallels the activity of serum ALP in dogs, but has higher specificity and lower sensitivity for detection of hepatobiliary disease.
  • In cats GGT often elevates more than ALP in liver diseases other than lipidosis, where GGT elevation is uncommon.
  • Compared to ALP, GGT is less affected by secondary hepatic disease and enzyme-inducing drugs.
  • GGT is more useful than ALP in detecting cholestatic or biliary disease in horses due to the narrow GGT reference interval and the variability of ALP activity in this species.  The GGT half-life in horses is about 3 days.
  • Considering ALP and GGT together increases the predictive value for hepatic disease.

 

  References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004. 

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
GLOB:
Description:  Globulins are produced in the liver and also by the cells of the immune system (immunoglobulins).  They have many vital roles in the body including maintenance of osmotic balance, immune system function, and the inflammatory response.

 

Decreased Globulin
   

  • Increased loss
    • Blood loss
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
  • Decreased production
    • Maldigestion/malabsorption (e.g. small intestinal disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency)
    • Malnutrition
      • Decreased intake
      • Severe intestinal parasitism
    • Chronic severe liver disease with loss of function
  • Immunodeficiency
    • Failure of passive transfer of colostrum (neonates)
    • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) - esp. Arabian foals
    • Agammaglobulinemia (horses)
    • Selective IgG, IgM or IgA deficiencies
  • Transient hypoglobulinemia

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Globulin

 

  • Blood Loss
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin and total protein
      • Albumin: globulin ratio normal
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Gastrointestinal disease (maldigestion/malabsorption, protein-losing enteropathy)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Possible megaloblastic, hypochromic RBCs (especially with folate deficiency)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased BUN, cholesterol, albumin and total protein
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Cobalamin and folate may be abnormal with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
    • Trypsin-like immunoreactivity - decreased with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
    • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - increased with protein-losing enteropathy
    • Abdominal ultrasound - evidence of thickened intestines with small intestinal disease; abdominal effusion may be present with severe protein-losing enteropathy

 

Increased Globulin
   

  • Dehydration (with hemoconcentration)
  • Inflammation
    • Chronic inflammatory or immune-mediated disease (e.g. stomatitis)
    • Infection (e.g. feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], ehrlichiosis, chronic pyoderma, ectoparasites, heartworm infection)
  • Neoplasia
    • Multiple myeloma
    • Extra medullary plasma cell tumor
    • Some lymphomas (especially B-cell lymphoma)
  • Near-term pregnancy
  • Lactation

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Globulin

 

  • Dehydration
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, albumin and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)
    • Urinalysis - increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate stable nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein
      • Albumin variably decreased (negative acute phase protein)
      • Albumin: globulin ratio decreased
    • Serum protein electrophoresis:
      • Polyclonal gammopathy
      • Increased alpha globulins (acute phase proteins, i.e. fibrinogen)
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Coombs or anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive with immune-mediated diseases
      • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation with polyarthritis
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase tests - increased with chronic pancreatitis
      • Consider PCR, serology or antigen tests for infectious diseases (heartworm, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], Bartonella, ehrlichiosis, Lyme, toxoplasmosis, Leishmania, etc.)
  • Neoplasia (multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, some lymphomas)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Variable hypercalcemia
      • Increased total protein
      • Decreased albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine protein variably positive
    • Bence Jones urine protein test - variably positive (especially with multiple myeloma or plasma cell tumor)
    • Serum or urine protein electrophoresis - monoclonal gammopathy with multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumors; rarely seen with lymphoma
    • Diagnostic imaging:
      • Radiographs - lytic bone lesions with multiple myeloma
      • Ultrasound - enlarged lymph nodes, spleen, liver or other masses with lymphoma or plasma cell tumor
    • Bone marrow cytology or fine needle aspirate of affected organs, lymph nodes or masses - consistent with neoplasia
    • Lymphoma:
      • Positive PCR for lymphocyte clonal receptor rearrangement (PARR)
      • Clonal expansion on immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on blood or lymph nodes

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Alpha- and beta-globulins are produced by the liver. Cells of the immune system, such as B-lymphocytes and plasma cells, make immunoglobulins, which are primarily of the gamma-globulin fraction.
  • Globulins have a wide variety of functions in the body.  These include:
    • Binding and transporting various molecules
    • Inactivating proteases (anti-inflammatory role)
    • Acute phase proteins (inflammatory role)
    • Immune response (antibodies)
    • Maintenance of colloidal osmotic pressure, along with albumin
    • Enzyme components
    • Pro-coagulants and anti-coagulants

 

  References

 

  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2018
GLU:
Description:  Glucose is the basic energy source for the body. 

 

Decreased Glucose

 

  • Insulin excess
    • Insulin overdose (exogenous)
    • Insulinoma (endogenous)
  • Neonatal or juvenile hypoglycemia
  • Liver disease/failure
  • Sepsis/severe infection
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Drugs/toxins (e.g. sulfonylureas, xylitol, antihistamines, beta-blockers)
  • Congenital
    • Growth hormone deficiency
    • Hypopituitarism
  • Exercise induced hypoglycemia (hunting dogs, endurance horses)
  • Neoplasia (paraneoplastic)
  • Starvation (mild decrease only)
  • Pregnancy (late gestation in the dog)
  • Artifact
    • Failure to spin and separate the blood sample within 30-60 minutes of collection
    • Handheld glucometer, esp. with hemoconcentration
       


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Glucose

 

  • Review medication history, especially insulin and oral hypoglycemics, and potential exposure to toxins
  • Insulinoma
    • Increased insulin:glucose ratio (measured on specimen with low glucose)
    • Abdominal ultrasound may show pancreatic or hepatic masses.
    • Consistent cytological or histopathological findings
  • Liver disease/failure
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Sepsis/severe infection
    • CBC:
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variably increased bilirubin and globulins
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT) annd activate partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass) - suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

 

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Physiologic response (mild increase)
    • Stress (especially cats)
    • Post-prandial
    • Diestrus (dogs)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Acromegaly (cats)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, megestrol acetate, progesterone, ketamine)
  • Hepatocutaneous syndrome (dogs)
  • Hyperammonemia (horses)
  • Thyroid disease (rare)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
    • Hypothyroidism (dogs)
  • Neoplasia 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Stress hyperglycemia
    • Fructosamine - normal
    • Urinalysis on sample collected at home has normal urine glucose
  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is produced from digestion of carbohydrates in the gastrointestinal tract.  It is also released via breakdown of glycogen stores in the liver (glycogenolysis).  The liver manufactures glucose from products of protein and fat metabolism (gluconeogenesis).
  • Glucose is tightly regulated by various endocrine hormones, especially insulin and glucagon.
  • Insulin stimulates uptake of glucose into most cells, including adipocytes (fat cells) and myocytes (muscle).
  • Neurons, blood cells, and hepatocytes do not require insulin for glucose uptake.
  • Glucagon increases blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology 

 

  • Most glucose assays are photometric and are influenced to varying degrees by lipemia, hemolysis, and icterus.  Nonphotometric assays have fewer chemical and photometric interferences.


   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Macintire DK, Drobatz KJ, Haskins SC, Saxon WD. Manual of Small Animal Emergency and Critical Care Medicine, 2nd ed. West Sussex UK: Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

GLU01:
Description:  Glucose is the basic energy source for the body. 

 

Decreased Glucose

 

  • Insulin excess
    • Insulin overdose (exogenous)
    • Insulinoma (endogenous)
  • Neonatal or juvenile hypoglycemia
  • Liver disease/failure
  • Sepsis/severe infection
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Drugs/toxins (e.g. sulfonylureas, xylitol, antihistamines, beta-blockers)
  • Congenital
    • Growth hormone deficiency
    • Hypopituitarism
  • Exercise induced hypoglycemia (hunting dogs, endurance horses)
  • Neoplasia (paraneoplastic)
  • Starvation (mild decrease only)
  • Pregnancy (late gestation in the dog)
  • Artifact
    • Failure to spin and separate the blood sample within 30-60 minutes of collection
    • Handheld glucometer, esp. with hemoconcentration
       


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Glucose

 

  • Review medication history, especially insulin and oral hypoglycemics, and potential exposure to toxins
  • Insulinoma
    • Increased insulin:glucose ratio (measured on specimen with low glucose)
    • Abdominal ultrasound may show pancreatic or hepatic masses.
    • Consistent cytological or histopathological findings
  • Liver disease/failure
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Sepsis/severe infection
    • CBC:
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variably increased bilirubin and globulins
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT) annd activate partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass) - suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Physiologic response (mild increase)
    • Stress (especially cats)
    • Post-prandial
    • Diestrus (dogs)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Acromegaly (cats)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, megestrol acetate, progesterone, ketamine)
  • Hepatocutaneous syndrome (dogs)
  • Hyperammonemia (horses)
  • Thyroid disease (rare)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
    • Hypothyroidism (dogs)
  • Neoplasia

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration

      • If ketoacidotic:

        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:

    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:

      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is produced from digestion of carbohydrates in the gastrointestinal tract.  It is also released via breakdown of glycogen stores in the liver (glycogenolysis).  The liver manufactures glucose from products of protein and fat metabolism (gluconeogenesis).
  • Glucose is tightly regulated by various endocrine hormones, especially insulin and glucagon.
  • Insulin stimulates uptake of glucose into most cells, including adipocytes (fat cells) and myocytes (muscle).
  • Neurons, blood cells, and hepatocytes do not require insulin for glucose uptake.
  • Glucagon increases blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology 

 

  • Most glucose assays are photometric and are influenced to varying degrees by lipemia, hemolysis, and icterus.  Nonphotometric assays have fewer chemical and photometric interferences.


   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Macintire DK, Drobatz KJ, Haskins SC, Saxon WD. Manual of Small Animal Emergency and Critical Care Medicine, 2nd ed. West Sussex UK: Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

GLU03:
Description:  Glucose is the basic energy source for the body. 

 

Decreased Glucose

 

  • Insulin excess
    • Insulin overdose (exogenous)
    • Insulinoma (endogenous)
  • Neonatal or juvenile hypoglycemia
  • Liver disease/failure
  • Sepsis/severe infection
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Drugs/toxins (e.g. sulfonylureas, xylitol, antihistamines, beta-blockers)
  • Congenital
    • Growth hormone deficiency
    • Hypopituitarism
  • Exercise induced hypoglycemia (hunting dogs, endurance horses)
  • Neoplasia (paraneoplastic)
  • Starvation (mild decrease only)
  • Pregnancy (late gestation in the dog)
  • Artifact
    • Failure to spin and separate the blood sample within 30-60 minutes of collection
    • Handheld glucometer, esp. with hemoconcentration
       


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Glucose

 

  • Review medication history, especially insulin and oral hypoglycemics, and potential exposure to toxins
  • Insulinoma
    • Increased insulin:glucose ratio (measured on specimen with low glucose)
    • Abdominal ultrasound may show pancreatic or hepatic masses.
    • Consistent cytological or histopathological findings
  • Liver disease/failure
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Sepsis/severe infection
    • CBC:
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variably increased bilirubin and globulins
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT) annd activate partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass) - suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

 

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Physiologic response (mild increase)
    • Stress (especially cats)
    • Post-prandial
    • Diestrus (dogs)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Acromegaly (cats)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, megestrol acetate, progesterone, ketamine)
  • Hepatocutaneous syndrome (dogs)
  • Hyperammonemia (horses)
  • Thyroid disease (rare)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
    • Hypothyroidism (dogs)
  • Neoplasia 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Stress hyperglycemia
    • Fructosamine - normal
    • Urinalysis on sample collected at home has normal urine glucose
  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is produced from digestion of carbohydrates in the gastrointestinal tract.  It is also released via breakdown of glycogen stores in the liver (glycogenolysis).  The liver manufactures glucose from products of protein and fat metabolism (gluconeogenesis).
  • Glucose is tightly regulated by various endocrine hormones, especially insulin and glucagon.
  • Insulin stimulates uptake of glucose into most cells, including adipocytes (fat cells) and myocytes (muscle).
  • Neurons, blood cells, and hepatocytes do not require insulin for glucose uptake.
  • Glucagon increases blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology 

 

  • Most glucose assays are photometric and are influenced to varying degrees by lipemia, hemolysis, and icterus.  Nonphotometric assays have fewer chemical and photometric interferences.


   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Macintire DK, Drobatz KJ, Haskins SC, Saxon WD. Manual of Small Animal Emergency and Critical Care Medicine, 2nd ed. West Sussex UK: Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

GLU04:
Description:  Glucosuria is an indicator of increased blood glucose exceeding the renal threshold or an inability of the proximal renal tubules to reabsorb glucose.

 

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Leptospirosis
  • Stress hyperglycemia (cat)
  • Renal tubulopathies (glucosuria with normal serum glucose) 
    • Proximal renal tubular acidosis
      • Acquired Fanconi-like syndrome (e.g. jerky treat toxicosis)
      • Congenital Fanconi syndrome
    • Primary renal glucosuria (certain breeds)
    • Distal renal tubular acidosis
  • Hyperglycemic glucosuria (blood glucose exceeds the renal threshold)
    • Iatrogenic (infusion of fluids with dextrose)
    • Acute pancreatitis
    • Chronic liver disease
  • Artifact - false positive with dipsticks
    • Oxidizing agents (e.g. hydrogen peroxide, chlorine bleach)
    • Outdated reagents
    • Formalin
    • Urine pH >9.0
           

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Glucosuria

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Pyelonephritis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemglobin
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats, <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts
      • Variable proteinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Urine culture with MIC susceptibility - variably positive (may be negative if infection isolated to kidneys)
    • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Leptospirosis
    • CBC:
      • RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin increased due to dehydration
      • Decreased platelets
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
      • Increased albumin
      • Variably increased ALT, ALP and total bilirubin (with liver involvement)
      • Decreased chloride, sodium and TCO2
      • Variably potassium; often decreased, but may be increased with acute oliguric renal failure
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats, <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria
      • Proteinuria
      • Urinary casts (cellular most common, granular casts may be seen)
    • Confirm infection:
      • A combination of serology and PCR on both peripheral blood and urine is recommended for the highest sensitivty
      • Leptospira antibody by ELISA:
        • Positive in an unvaccinated dog with clinical signs - consistent with infection
        • Negative antibody may be seen in early infection prior to seroconversion
        • Vaccination also results in a positive antibody test
      • Leptospira microagglutination antibody test (MAT) - paired acute and convalescent tests may show a rise in titer consistent with infection. A single titer result less than 1:1600 may be difficult to interpret in a vaccinated dog.
      • Leptospira PCR - positive in peripheral whole blood in early infection, prior to seroconversion. Urine becomes PCR positive 7-14 days after infection (at which point, detection in peripheral blood may be intermittent
  • Stress hyperglycemia
    • Fructosamine - normal
    • Urinalysis on sample collected at home is negative for urine glucose.
  • Renal tubulopathies (proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis)
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased potassium, phosphorus and TCO2
      • Increased chloride
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Serum glucose normal despite glucosuria
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Urine pH variable - pH <5.5 with Fanconi's syndrome (proximal renal tubular acidosis) and pH >6.0 in distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Variable struvite crystalluria may be seen with distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
    • Evaluate for risk factors:
      • Breed predisposition - Basenjis (congenital Fanconi's syndrome)
      • History of possible drug or toxin exposure (acquired Fanconi's syndrome, e.g. contaminated jerky treats, gentamicin)

 

Decreased Glucose
   

  • Absence of glucose in the urine is a normal finding
  • False negative with dipsticks
    • Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
    • Low urine temperature (refrigerated urine)
    • Drugs (e.g. salycilates, tetracyclines)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is not normally detected in the urine of dogs and cats.
  • The glucose present in the glomerular filtrate is almost completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubules if the cell's maximum transport mechanism (renal threshold) is not exceeded.
  • The renal threshold for glucose in the dog is 180-200 mg/dL and in the cat is 280-290 mg/dL

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Reference laboratories often use the glucose oxidase/peroxidase system for detection of urine glucose.

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine: diseases of the dog and the cat, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Greene CE, et al. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE. Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2019

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Leptospirosis
  • Stress hyperglycemia (cat)
  • Renal tubulopathies (glucosuria with normal serum glucose) 
    • Proximal renal tubular acidosis
      • Acquired Fanconi-like syndrome (e.g. jerky treat toxicosis)
      • Congenital Fanconi syndrome
    • Primary renal glucosuria (certain breeds)
    • Distal renal tubular acidosis
  • Hyperglycemic glucosuria (blood glucose exceeds the renal threshold)
    • Iatrogenic (infusion of fluids with dextrose)
    • Acute pancreatitis
    • Chronic liver disease
  • Artifact - false positive with dipsticks
    • Oxidizing agents (e.g. hydrogen peroxide, chlorine bleach)
    • Outdated reagents
    • Formalin
    • Urine pH >9.0
           

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Glucosuria

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Pyelonephritis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemglobin
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats, <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts
      • Variable proteinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Urine culture with MIC susceptibility - variably positive (may be negative if infection isolated to kidneys)
    • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Leptospirosis
    • CBC:
      • RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin increased due to dehydration
      • Decreased platelets
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
      • Increased albumin
      • Variably increased ALT, ALP and total bilirubin (with liver involvement)
      • Decreased chloride, sodium and TCO2
      • Variably potassium; often decreased, but may be increased with acute oliguric renal failure
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats, <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria
      • Proteinuria
      • Urinary casts (cellular most common, granular casts may be seen)
    • Confirm infection:
      • A combination of serology and PCR on both peripheral blood and urine is recommended for the highest sensitivty
      • Leptospira antibody by ELISA:
        • Positive in an unvaccinated dog with clinical signs - consistent with infection
        • Negative antibody may be seen in early infection prior to seroconversion
        • Vaccination also results in a positive antibody test
      • Leptospira microagglutination antibody test (MAT) - paired acute and convalescent tests may show a rise in titer consistent with infection. A single titer result less than 1:1600 may be difficult to interpret in a vaccinated dog.
      • Leptospira PCR - positive in peripheral whole blood in early infection, prior to seroconversion. Urine becomes PCR positive 7-14 days after infection (at which point, detection in peripheral blood may be intermittent
  • Stress hyperglycemia
    • Fructosamine - normal
    • Urinalysis on sample collected at home is negative for urine glucose.
  • Renal tubulopathies (proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis)
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased potassium, phosphorus and TCO2
      • Increased chloride
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Serum glucose normal despite glucosuria
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Urine pH variable - pH <5.5 with Fanconi's syndrome (proximal renal tubular acidosis) and pH >6.0 in distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Variable struvite crystalluria may be seen with distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
    • Evaluate for risk factors:
      • Breed predisposition - Basenjis (congenital Fanconi's syndrome)
      • History of possible drug or toxin exposure (acquired Fanconi's syndrome, e.g. contaminated jerky treats, gentamicin)

 

Decreased Glucose
   

  • Absence of glucose in the urine is a normal finding
  • False negative with dipsticks
    • Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
    • Low urine temperature (refrigerated urine)
    • Drugs (e.g. salycilates, tetracyclines)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is not normally detected in the urine of dogs and cats.
  • The glucose present in the glomerular filtrate is almost completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubules if the cell's maximum transport mechanism (renal threshold) is not exceeded.
  • The renal threshold for glucose in the dog is 180-200 mg/dL and in the cat is 280-290 mg/dL

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Reference laboratories often use the glucose oxidase/peroxidase system for detection of urine glucose.

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine: diseases of the dog and the cat, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Greene CE, et al. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE. Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

GLU07:
Description:  Glucosuria is an indicator of increased blood glucose exceeding the renal threshold or an inability of the proximal renal tubules to reabsorb glucose.

 

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Leptospirosis
  • Stress hyperglycemia (cat)
  • Renal tubulopathies (glucosuria with normal serum glucose) 
    • Proximal renal tubular acidosis
      • Acquired Fanconi-like syndrome (e.g. jerky treat toxicosis)
      • Congenital Fanconi syndrome

    • Distal renal tubular acidosis
