Giardia:
Description: Giardia is a protozoal parasite which is an important cause of acute or chronic small-bowel diarrhea in dogs and cats. Giardia infections may also be subclinical in some animals (especially adults). The Giardia antigen immunoassay detects soluble cell surface antigens from the Giardia trophozoites, and is a more sensitive and specific test for Giardia than fecal flotation.

 

Learn more about the diagnosis and management of Giardia infections at www.idexx.com/FecalGuide. 

Read more about the comparative accuracy of different in-clinic and reference laboratory diagnostic tests for Giardia at https://parasitesandvectors.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13071-018-2990-6

 

Positive Giardia Antigen

 

  • Giardia infection
  • Following successful treatment:
    • Shedding of antigen from dead organisms
    • Subclinical carrier state without shedding of cysts (non-infective)
  • Coprophagy
    • Detection of antigen from non-pathogenic Giardia spp. following ingestion of feces (e.g. from non-mammalian source such as birds, reptile or amphibians)

 

    Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Giardia Antigen

 

  • Giardia infection
    • Clinical signs
      • Infections in cats and adult dogs are often asymptomatic
      • Clinical signs are more common in puppies and kittens:
        • Chronic small-bowel diarrhea associated with weight loss, anorexia and abdominal cramping
        • Mild acute self-limiting diarrhea
    • Fecal flotation - variably positive due to intermittent cyst shedding. Evaluation of three separate fecal samples collected over five days may be required to detect shedding of infective cysts.
    • In patients with persistent or severe diarrhea, consider PCR and antigen tests for co-infections (common):
      • Fecal Dx Antigen Panel for hookworms, roundworms and whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR panel for enterotoxins, and viral, bacterial or protozoal causes of diarrhea
    • In a patient with continued clinical signs after appropriate treatment for Giardia, fecal flotation to evaluate for cysts, and Giardia
      antigen testing should be considered.
      • Fecal flotation positive for Giardia cysts, Giardia antigen test positive
        • Re-infection from the environment is most common cause of treatment failure.
        • Infection with Giardia strain resistant to medication or dose utilized
        • Poor owner compliance in administering treatment with inadequate drug levels
        • Immunosuppression
        • Sequestration in the gall bladder or pancreatic ducts
      • Fecal flotation negative for Giardia cysts, Giardia antigen test positive
        • False negative on fecal flotation possible due to intermittent shedding and low sensitivity of fecal flotation
          • Evaluation of three separate fecal samples collected over five days is recommended to detect shedding of infective cysts
        • Diarrhea due to other cause, such as concurrent infections, food allergy, dietary indiscretion or inflammatory bowel disease. 
          • Giardia infection persisting in subclinical state, or antigen not entirely cleared from intestines, causing a positive result on antigen test, but not the cause of the clinical signs.
  • Following successful treatment:
    • “Successful” treatment for Giardia is measured by suppression of cyst shedding (lack of infectivity) and resolution of clinical signs and does not necessarily reflect eradication of Giardia from the intestinal flora.
    • Stools may test positive for Giardia antigen for several weeks following successful treatment until the intestinal lining has regenerated.
    • In some dogs and cats, Giardia may appear to become part of the “normal” flora, residing in a quiescent state in the intestines (not shedding or causing clinical signs). Subclinical carrier state may be relatively common in certain populations. Although not shedding cysts, detectible antigen is still shed with the intestinal lining.
    • After treatment, the American Association of Feline Practitioners (AAFP) Advisory Panel on Zoonoses recommends performing a single fecal flotation by centrifugation within 2-4 weeks of the end of treatment.
    • Giardia antigen testing is not recommended following treatment in a nonclinical patient with a negative fecal flotation except in cases of an immunocompromised owner where a greater potential for zoonosis exists if the Giardia should revert to active infection in the future.
  • Coprophagy:
    • Detection of antigen from non-pathogenic Giardia spp. following ingestion of feces (e.g. from non-mammalian source such as birds, reptile or amphibians)
    • Fecal flotation - variable, ingested cysts are usually not present in sufficient numbers to be detected.
    • Giardia RealPCR test - negative (test is specific for mammalian strains)

 

Negative Giardia Antigen

  • Absence of infection
  • Low parasite burden with antigen below level of detection of the immunoassay

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Giardia Antigen

 

  • If clinical signs of diarrhea are present, evaluate for other infectious causes of diarrhea
    • Fecal Dx Antigen tests for hookworm, roundworm and whipworms
    • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
    • Parvovirus antigen SNAP or ELISA if bloody diarrhea in a poorly vaccinated dog
    • Fecal flotation - for other less common intestinal parasites

Additional Information

 

    Physiology

 

  • Giardia infections are found in dogs and cats.
    • There are specific genotypes of Giardia that affect these species.
      • Dogs are predominantly infected by G. canis (assemblages C and D); but G. duodenalis (also known as G. duodenalis; assemblage A) and rarely G. enterica (assemblage B) have also been associated with dogs.
      • Cats are predominantly infected by G. felis (assemblage F) but G. duodenalis (assemblage A) could also infect cats.
      • Transmission of Giardia infections from dogs and cats to humans is rare.
  • Giardia cysts are shed intermittently and do not always correlate with clinical signs of giardiasis.
  • Dogs and cats are infected with Giardia by ingestion of cysts from contaminated food, water or fomites.
    • Ingested cysts excyst in the upper small intestine.
    • Trophozoites attach to the intestinal mucosa from the duodenum to the ileum.
    • After replication of trophozoites, cysts are passed in the host’s feces 1-2 weeks after infection.
  • The prevalence of Giardia infections in dogs in the United States ranges from 0.8 -7.2%
    • In some kennel situations, prevalence up to 100% has been reported.
  • Cysts are susceptible to UV light, heat/steam, desiccation, bleaches and quaternary ammonium compounds, and partially susceptible to freezing. Disinfection of soils, grasses and earth may be challenging.

 

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The sensitivity of a single fecal flotation test for detection of Giardia is approximately 70%-80%.
  • Combining traditional fecal flotation methods with the Giardia antigen immunoassay results in a sensitivity of 97.8%.
  • Giardia antigen immunoassay detects soluble Giardia-specific antigens from the cell surface of Giardia.
    • These antigens are produced when the trophozoite begins to encyst.
  • Traditionally, diagnosis of Giardia is made by fecal flotation. Cysts are best detected using a zinc sulfate centrifugation technique.
    • Multiple fecal exams (three exams over a period of 5 days) are needed to sufficiently rule out infection due to intermittent shedding and low sensitivity of fecal flotation.
    • Giardia cysts are elliptical with a thin cyst wall, they contain 2-4 nuclei, 2 intracytoplasmic flagella and 2 median bodies.
      • Cyst size: 9-13 x 7-9 µm
  • Trophozoites can occasionally be seen in a direct fecal smear.
    • Giardia trophozoites are bilaterally symmetrical, tear-drop shaped with 2 nuclei, 8 flagella and 2 median bodies.
    • They have been described as having a “clown face”.
    • Live trophozoites have a wobbling (falling leaf) type of motion.
      • Trophozoite size: 12-17 x 7-10 µm
  • A cyst flotation negative result and antigen positive result may occur due to intermittent shedding of cysts.

 

    References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 7th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders Elsevier; 2010.
  • Greene CE, ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO. Saunders Elsevier; 2012.
  • Lappin, MR. Management of Giardia Spp. In Cats and Dogs: Frequently Asked Questions. Presented ACVIM Small Animal Infectious Disease Course. Las Vegas, NV, September 19, 2014.
  • Little SE, Johnson EM, Lewis D, Jakilitsh RP, et al. Prevalence of intestinal parasites in pet dogs in the United States. Vet Parasitology. 2009; 166: 144-152.
  • Mizhquiri Barbecho J, Bowman DD, Liotta JL. Comparative performance of reference laboratory tests and in-clinic tests for Giardia in canine feces. Parasites and Vectors.2019;11: 444. Read online at https://parasitesandvectors.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13071-018-2990-6
  • Zajac AM, Conboy GA, eds. Veterinary Clinical Parasitology, 8th ed. Ames, IA, Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
HCT:
Description: Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume made up by red blood cells. 

 

Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Primary immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
      • Heinz body anemia
        • Toxins
        • Drugs
        • Dietary
      • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
        • Vasculitis
        • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
        • Hemangiosarcoma
        • Heartworm infection
      • Metabolic
      • Hereditary
      • Envenomation
  • Decreased red blood cell production
    • Chronic blood loss
    • Chronic inflammatory disease
    • Reduced erythropoietin
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Liver disease or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
      • Folate
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia   

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry: increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis: bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Decreased erythropoietin production
    • CBC:
      • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
      • Decreased RBC with normal to decreased reticulocytes
      • Normal RDW
    • Evaluate for underlying causes:
      • Chronic kidney disease:
        • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
          • +/- proteinuria
        • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
        • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
      • Hypothyroidism:
        • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
        • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
        • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol
          • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
  • Bone marrow suppression:
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukopenia
      • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Increased Hematocrit
   

  • Dehydration
  • Splenic contraction (dogs)
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Hematocrit

 

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- increased phosphorus
    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • CBC:
      • High normal to increased RBCs
      • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
        • Acromegaly
    • Secondary polycythemia:
      • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
      • Systemic hypoxia:
        • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
        • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
        • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
        • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
    • Polycythemia vera:
      • CBC:
        • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • Variably increased platelets
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
      • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion
         

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Red blood cells (RBCs, erythrocytes, red cells, red corpuscles) are the longest-lived of the circulating blood cells. They are produced primarily in the bone marrow, but some production can occur at secondary sites such as spleen and liver. Red blood cell production is stimulated by erythropoietin which is released from the kidneys.
  • Red blood cells contain hemoglobin and are critical for cellular respiration, delivering oxygen to tissues and carrying carbon dioxide away.
  • Hematocrit estimates the total red cell mass.
  • Red blood cells are not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • Anemias can be classified as regenerative or nonregenerative based on the adequacy of the bone marrow response to produce new red blood cells (in all species but the horse). Reticulocytosis typically appears 3-4 days after the onset of anemia, with peak production in 7 days for dogs and 7-14 days for cats.
  • Anemia is a common clinical problem that may need emergency treatment with transfusion of red blood cell products if acute and/or severe.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated hematology analyzers calculate the hematocrit by multiplying the number of red blood cells x their average volume, or RBC x MCV, then divided by total volume. Simply stated - HCT = (RBC x MCV)/10.
  • Packed cell volume (PCV) specifies that centrifugation was used to separate the blood sample into three layers:  plasma, buffy coat (leukocytes and platelets), and packed red cells. The red cell layer height is divided by total sample height to obtain the percent value.
  • The PCV is usually slightly greater than a HCT determined by automated equipment because of plasma trapping.  The difference is usually less than 2% but may approach 4% in some samples. 
  • Anemia is defined as a decrease in the hematocrit.  More specifically, anemia can be a reduction in the numbers (count) of red blood cells (RBC), the concentration of hemoglobin, or the hematocrit or packed cell volume (PCV).  Decreases in these parameters may not be uniform, owing to differences in reference intervals or to the presence of abnormal RBCs.

  

References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds. Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

HCT_BLD:
Description: Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume made up by red blood cells. 

 

Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Primary immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
      • Heinz body anemia
        • Toxins
        • Drugs
        • Dietary
      • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
        • Vasculitis
        • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
        • Hemangiosarcoma
        • Heartworm infection
      • Metabolic
      • Hereditary
      • Envenomation
  • Decreased red blood cell production
    • Chronic blood loss
    • Chronic inflammatory disease
    • Reduced erythropoietin
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Liver disease or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
      • Folate
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia   

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry: increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis: bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Decreased erythropoietin production
    • CBC:
      • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
      • Decreased RBC with normal to decreased reticulocytes
      • Normal RDW
    • Evaluate for underlying causes:
      • Chronic kidney disease:
        • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
          • +/- proteinuria
        • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
        • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
      • Hypothyroidism:
        • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
        • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
        • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol
          • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
  • Bone marrow suppression:
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukopenia
      • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

  • Splenic contraction (dogs)

    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC

    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride

    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs

      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs

      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis

      • High normal to increased RBCs

    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:

      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome

  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Increased Hemoglobin

  

  • Dehydration
  • Splenic contraction (dogs)
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds
  • Artifact
    • Marked lipemia
    • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Hemoglobin derivatives (e.g. Oxyglobin)

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Hemoglobin

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- increased phosphorus
    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • CBC:
      • High normal to increased RBCs
      • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
        • Acromegaly
    • Secondary polycythemia:
      • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
      • Systemic hypoxia:
        • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
        • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
        • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
        • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
    • Polycythemia vera:
      • CBC:
        • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • Variably increased platelets
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
      • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Hemoglobin is a large globular protein that is composed of two alpha chains and two beta chains, for a total of four iron-containing heme groups bound to four globulin chains.
  • Hemoglobin gives blood its characteristic red color and (as oxyhemoglobin) is responsible for oxygen transport by the red blood cells (as oxyhemoglobin).
  • Hemoglobin measurements are the most direct indication of oxygen transport capacity of blood in a patient, estimating the red blood cell mass.
  • Hemoglobin concentration is not altered by changes in red blood cell size or in vitro hemolysis, although both hematocrit and PCV may be affected.
  • Hemoglobin is not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • Anemias can be classified as regenerative or nonregenerative based on the adequacy of the bone marrow response to produce new red blood cells or reticulocytes (in all species but the horse). Reticulocytes typically appear 3-4 days after the onset of anemia, with peak production in 7 days for dogs and 7-14 days for cats.
  • Anemia is a common clinical problem that may need emergency treatment with transfusion of red blood cell products if acute and/or severe.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Hemoglobin may be measured by a variety of automated spectrophotometric methods. Manual and noninvasive methods of hemoglobin measurement are also available.
  • Anemia can be a reduction in the numbers (count) of red blood cells (RBC), the concentration of hemoglobin, or the hematocrit or packed cell volume (PCV).  Note that decreases in these parameters may not be uniform, owing to differences in reference intervals or to the presence of abnormal RBCs.
  • In general, hematocrit values are approximately three times the value of hemoglobin.

 

   References

 

  • Bauer N, Nakagawa J, Dunker C, Failing K, Moritz A. Evaluation of the automated hematology analzyer Sysmex XT-2000iV for its use in dogs, cats and horses: part 1 - precision, linearity and accuracy of complete blood count. ﻿JVDI﻿ 2011; 23(6): 1168-1180.
  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds. Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

HOOK:
Description: Hookworms, including Ancylostoma spp. and Uncinaria stenocephala, are intestinal parasites of the dog and cat. Hookworms are blood-feeders; by attaching to the small intestine, they can potentially cause blood loss anemia. The Fecal Dx® Test detects a hookworm-specific antigen which is secreted by adult hookworms, allowing detection during the pre-patent period.

For routine testing, the Companion Animal Parasite Council (CAPC) recommends combining fecal antigen tests with microscopic examination of feces for eggs to ensure the widest breadth of intestinal parasite detection.

Quick Links:

  • Learn more about the fecal antigen testing at idexx.com/fecal.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of hookworm infections at www.idexx.com/FecalGuide.

Negative Hookworm Antigen

 

  • Absence of infection
  • Infection with only early larval stages, prior to the development of mature worms.
  • Low worm burden with antigen below level of detection of the immunoassay
  • An egg flotation positive result and antigen negative result may occur due to:
    • Spurious eggs due to ingestion of feces (coprophagy) without the presence of worms in the intestinal lumen
    • Large animal strongyle eggs are very similar morphologically to Ancylostoma spp. eggs and may be identified as Ancylostoma spp. in feces of coprophagic dogs or cats
    • Low worm burden, with antigen below the level of detection of the immunoassay

 

Positive Hookworm Antigen

 

  • Ancylostoma caninum infection
  • Infection with other hookworms (e.g. Uncinaria stenocephala)
  • An egg flotation negative result and antigen positive result may occur due to:
    • Pre-patent infection
    • Intermittent shedding of eggs

   

    Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Hookworm Antigen

 

  • Clinical signs
    • Asymptomatic (especially cats and adult dogs)
    • Clinical signs are more common in puppies or with heavy infections:
      • Chronic diarrhea and decreased total protein (more common with Uncinaria)
      • Weight loss, dehydration, tarry stool, anemia and occasionally death (severe cases, more common with Ancylostoma spp.)
    • CBC:
      • Anemia due to the blood-sucking behavior of hookworms is more common with heavy infections in puppies, and can be severe.
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes - initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption) or increased (iron deficiency)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin

 

Additional Information

 

    Physiology

 

  • Hookworm infections are found in dogs and cats.
    • Ancylostoma caninum infects dogs and is the most widely distributed,
    • Ancylostoma tubaeforme infects cats and has a worldwide distribution.
    • Ancylostoma brasilense (dogs and cats) is found in tropical and subtropical regions, including the southern United States.
    • Ancylostoma ceylanicum (dogs and cats) is found in various parts of Asia.
    • Uncinaria is found primarily in canids, and rarely in cats, in the northern temperate climates in North America and Europe. It is generally less pathogenic than Ancylostoma.
  • Hookworm infection can occur by several routes:
    • Direct skin penetration by infective larvae (most important route for Ancylostoma, less common for Uncinaria; common route for zoonotic infections)
    • Transmammary transmission (Ancylostonum caninum) to puppies is a clinically significant route.
    • Ingestion of infective third-stage larvae from the environment or in paratenic hosts (rodents)
    • Transplacental transmission can occur in dogs (least important route).
    • Larvae which have penetrated the skin migrate to the small intestines and mature into adults. Both 4th stage larvae and adults cause blood-loss anemia by ingesting large amounts of blood.
    • Hookworms can repopulate the bowel following successful treatment of intestinal infections from larvae sequestered in the tissues.
    • Larvae which have arrested in the maternal tissues can reactivate during pregnancy and migrate transplacentally or transmammary, infecting puppies.
    • Adult worms reside in the small intestines, producing eggs which are shed in the feces and hatch into infective larvae in the environment.
  • Ancylostoma spp. larvae (but not those of Uncinaria) are destroyed by freezing, so a hard winter may help control clinical hookworm infections.
  • The prevalence of hookworm infections in dogs in the United States ranges from 0.8 to 39%.

   

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • In 1,626,104 samples submitted for fecal screening during wellness visit testing of dogs, the hookworm antigen immunoassay detected hookworms in 3.5% of dogs, while fecal flotation detected hookworms in 2.2%. Combining fecal flotation with the hookworm antigen immunoassay increased the detection to 4.1% of samples.
  • Traditionally, diagnosis of hookworms is made by fecal flotation.
    • Uncinaria and Ancylostoma eggs are morphologically identical, differing only in their size. Hookworm eggs are elliptical in shape with a smooth shell wall. They contain a grapelike cluster of cells (morula).
      • Ancylostoma spp. size: 52-79 x 28-58 µm
      • Uncinaria spp. size: 71-92 x 35-58 µm
    • Severe clinical disease with blood-loss anemia and bloody stool can occur during the pre-patent period before eggs are shed in the stool, when eggs cannot be detected by fecal flotation.
  • Hookworm antigen immunoassay detects hookworm-specific antigens secreted from Ancylostoma caninum parasites.  May also potentially detect other hookworms (e.g. Uncinaria stenocephala).
    • The hookworm-specific antigen is secreted from adult hookworms and is not present in hookworm eggs or early larval stages.

      References

  • CAPC Guidelines: Hookworms. Companion Animal Parasite Council. www.capcvet.org/guidelines/hookworm. Accessed July 27, 2022.
  • Elsemore D, Jeng J, Cote J, Hanna R, Lucio-Forster A, Bowman D. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for coproantigen detection of ﻿Ancylostoma caninum ﻿and ﻿Toxocara canis﻿ in dogs and ﻿Toxocara cati﻿ in cats. ﻿J Vet Diag Invest. ﻿2017;29(5): 645-653.
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 7th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders Elsevier; 2010.
  • Little SE, Johnson EM, Lewis D, Jakilitsh RP, et al. Prevalence of intestinal parasites in pet dogs in the United States, Vet Parasitology. 2009; 166: 144-152.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA, Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sweet S, Hegarty E, McCrann DJ, Kincaid D, Szlosek D. A 3-year retrospective analysis of canine intestinal parasites: fecal testing positivity by age, U.S. geographical region and reason for veterinary visit. Parasite Vector, 2021;14(10):173.
  • Zajac AM, Conboy GA, eds. Veterinary Clinical Parasitology, 8th ed. Ames, IA, Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.

HW:
Description:  The heartworm antigen test is used to diagnose infection with Dirofilaria immitis, the causative agent of canine and feline heartworm disease. The test detects a uterine antigen found predominantly in mature female heartworms.

Positive Heartworm Antigen

  • Presence of one or more adult female Dirofilaria immitis
  • Post-adulticide therapy - antigen tests may remain positive up to 6 months post-therapy in dogs
  • Artifact - false positive due to hemolysis

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Heartworm Antigen

  • The American Heartworm Society recommends all positive heartworm antigen tests should be confirmed through additional testing, including identification of circulating microfilariae (if present) and/or a second positive result obtained from a different antigen test
  • CBC:
    • Variably present nonregenerative anemia, neutrophilia, eosinophilia and basophilia
    • Regenerative or pre-regenerative anemia may be seen with caval syndrome
    • Blood film review: variable target cells, schistocytes and spherocytes (especially with caval syndrome)
  • Chemistry:
    • Increased ALP, ALT, GGT and bilirubin in severe heartworm disease with heart failure
    • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN:
      • May be pre-renal in origin with dehydration or poor cardiac output
      • May be secondary to glomerulonephritis
    • Decreased albumin with secondary glomerulonephritis
    • Hemoglobinemia may be seen with intravascular hemolysis due to caval syndrome
  • Urinalysis:
    • Variably increased protein
    • Hemoglobinuria in dogs with caval syndrome
  • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Microfilaria - variably positive in dogs, uncommon in cats
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably positive, especially with more severe pulmonary arterial disease or thromboembolism
  • Chest radiographs:
    • Main pulmonary artery and right ventricle enlargement
    • Increased size and density of pulmonary arteries and/or pulmonary artery tortuosity
  • Echocardiogram:
    • Insensitive as a diagnostic tool except with caval syndrome or heavy worm burden
    • Heartworms may be seen in the right ventricle and/or pulmonary artery
    • Useful to assess right heart enlargement
  • Heartworm antibody test (cats) - may be positive in early larval stages of infection, but does not confirm active infection

Negative Heartworm Antigen

  • Absence of infection
  • Pre-patent infection
  • Antigen/antibody complexing
  • Low worm burden or single sex infection (male worms only)

  Next Steps for Negative Heartworm Antigen

  • If heartworm infection is suspected based on history or clinical signs, consider additional diagnostics
  • Pre-patent infection or low worm burden infection
    • Chest radiographs - changes consistent with heartworm disease
    • Echocardiogram:
      • Insensitive as a diagnostic tool except with caval syndrome or heavy worm burden
      • Heartworms may be seen in the right ventricle and/or pulmonary artery
      • Useful to assess right heart enlargement
    • Heartworm antibody test (cats) - may be positive in early larval stages of infection but does not confirm active infection
    • Recheck heartworm antigen test in 6 months.
  • Antigen/antibody complexing (rare)
    • Seen when a strong immune response results in antibody binding the heartworm antigen in circulation, interfering with the detection of heartworm antigen by heartworm tests.
    • History of slow kill treatment regimen may increase suspicion for antibody/antigen complexes.
    • Increased suspicion in patients with chronic inflammation
    • Heartworm antigen by ELISA following heat treatment - positive
    • CBC:
      • Eosinophilia
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.) may be seen with antigen/antibody complexing
      • Mild to moderate stable anemia +/-microcytosis with long term inflammatory conditions
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Variably decreased albumin
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased

Additional Information

 Heartworm Resource Quick Links:

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of heartworm and other vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide.
  • View the Canine Heartworm Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/heartworm-next-steps.
  • View the Feline Heartworm Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/feline-heartworm-next-steps.
  • For more information on prevention, treatment and management of heartworm disease, read the American Heartworm Society Guidelines.
  • For sharing positive results in cats with pet owners, please see the Feline Heartworm Positive Client Handout.

Physiology

  • Dirofilaria immitis infections occur primarily in canids (dog, fox and coyote) and can also be detected in felids.
    • The domestic dog and some wild canids are the normal definitive hosts for heartworms and are most likely to develop high microfilaria counts, allowing them to serve as the main reservoir of infection.
    • Less suitable hosts, such as cats and ferrets, occasionally have low-level, transient microfilaremia and theoretically may serve as a limited source of infection for mosquitoes during their short periods of microfilaremia.
  • Canine - D. immitis life cycle and clinical signs
    • The life cycle of D. immitis lasts approximately 7-9 months in the dog.
      • The mosquito is the required vector for transmission of D. immitis and becomes infected by consuming a blood meal from a microfilaremic host.
      • The D. immitis microfilariae mature in the Malpighian tubules of the mosquito, developing into larval stage 1 (L1), then molting into larval stage (L2), and finally molting into the infective third-stage larvae (L3), which are transmitted to the dog when bitten by infected mosquitoes.
      • Once the infective L3 enter the dog, they molt into fourth-stage larvae (L4).
      • The final molt into juvenile/immature adults occurs between days 50 and 70, while migrating through the body and appear in the smallest pulmonary arteries as early as day 67 after transmission.
      • Sexual maturity occurs approximately 120 days post-infection with dogs developing patent infections (i.e., having circulating microfilariae) as early as 6 months but usually by 7 to 9 months after infection.
    • Clinical signs consistent with heartworm disease:
      • Mild - asymptomatic or cough
      • Moderate - cough, exercise intolerance, abnormal lung sounds
      • Severe - cough, exercise intolerance, dyspnea, abnormal heart and lung sounds, enlarged liver (hepatomegaly), syncope (temporary loss of consciousness from reduced blood flow to the brain), ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity), death.
      • Caval syndrome - sudden onset of severe lethargy, weakness and shock.
  • Feline - D. immitis life cycle and clinical signs
    • Cats are more resistant to heartworm infection than dogs.
      • The mosquito is the required vector for transmission of D. immitis and becomes infected by consuming a blood meal from a microfilaremic host.
      • The D. immitis microfilariae develop from first-stage larvae (L1) to third-stage larvae (L3) within the mosquito.
      • The infective third stage larvae (L3) are transmitted to the cat when bitten by infected mosquitoes.
      • Once the infective L3 larvae enter the cat, they molt into fourth-stage larvae (L4) and then develop to the juvenile worm stage about 2 months post-infection. 
      • There is some loss of larvae as they migrate through the host.
      • There is high mortality of the juvenile worms as they enter the lungs 3-4 months after exposure.
      • Heartworms can reach the adult stage approximately 7-8 months post-infection.
        • Cats have a lower burden of adult worms compared to dogs with heartworm infection.
        • Adult heartworms will produce some microfilariae in cats, but the microfilariae only circulate for a short period of time.
    • Clinical signs consistent with heartworm infection in cats:
      • Many cats do not have clinical signs or show only transient clinical signs
      • Heartworm-associated respiratory disease (HARD) - occurs when larvae initially enter the lungs
        • Respiratory distress, cough, increased respiratory rate
      • Sudden death
      • Vomiting, anorexia, weight loss
      • Occasionally ascites, hydrothorax, ataxia or seizures can be observed

Diagnostic Methodology

  • Heartworm tests utilize immunoassay-based technology to detect antigen (carbohydrate) that is primarily excreted from the uterus of mature female worms.
  • Different methodologies (e.g. SNAP, PetChek) are employed for commercially available immunoassays and therefore sensitivity and specificity between the tests will vary.
  • The SNAP test is not quantitative and therefore, the intensity of color change should not be used to predict the heartworm burden.
  • Antigen/antibody complexing (rare)
    • Seen when a strong immune response results in non-specific antibody binding the heartworm antigen in circulation, the bound antibody interferes with the detection of antigen by heartworm tests.
    • A suspicion of antigen/antibody complexing can be considered in a patient where there is a high clinical suspicion of heartworm disease but a negative antigen test.
    • Heartworm antigen testing following heat treatment can be used to help further evaluate cases which are suspected to have antigen/antibody complexes.
    • History of slow kill treatment regimen may increase suspicion for antibody/antigen complexes.

References

  • Nelson, CT, McCall JW, Jones S, Moorhead, AW. Current Canine Guidelines for the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Management of Heartworm (Dirofilaria immitis) Infection in Dogs (Revised 2018). https://www.heartwormsociety.org/veterinary-resources/american-heartworm-society-guidelines. Accessed October 16, 2018.
  • Jones S, Graham W, von Simson C, et al. Current Feline Guidelines for the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Management of Heartworm (Dirofilaria immitis) Infection in Cats,  https://www.heartwormsociety.org/veterinary-resources/american-heartworm-society-guidelines. Accessed August 1, 2023.
  • Bowman DD, Atkinds CE. Heartworm Biology Treatment, and Control. Vet Clin Small Anim 39 (2009) 1127-1158.
  • Beall MJ, Arguello-Marin A, Drexel J, Liu J, Chandrashekar R, Alleman R. Validation of immune complex dissociation methods for use with heartworm antigen tests. Parasit Vectors 2017, 10(Suppl 2):481.

Last Updated 9/29/2023
HYA:
Description:  Hyaline casts are formed in the lumen of renal tubules and are composed of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein, without any cellular components. Hyaline casts may be seen in low numbers in the urine of clinically healthy dogs and cats. In greater numbers, hyaline casts are an indication of kidney injury or diseases, most commonly glomerulonephropathy.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm.

The first two images (from left to right) represent hyaline casts. The third image is an example of an artifact which may be mistaken for a hyaline cast.

      

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CastImages. 

 

Increased Hyaline Casts

 

  • Low numbers (0-2/lpf) of hyaline casts may be a normal finding
  • Fever/exercise (low numbers)
  • Glomerular disease
    • Glomerulonephritis
    • Glomerular amyloidosis

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Hyaline Casts

 

  • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate the urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria or active sediment.
  • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased albumin
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased kidney function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease.
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Proteinuria
      • Otherwise inactive sediment
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
    • Blood pressure - variably increased
    • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes of glomerular proteinuria:
      • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], toxoplasmosis)
      • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Hyaline casts are cylindrical concretions made of Tamm-Horsfall mucoproteins produced by the epithelial cells lining the loops of Henle, distal tubules, and collecting ducts.
  • Some hyaline casts may be seen in healthy animals from normal turnover of tubular epithelial cells or following physical activity or fever.
    • These are less than approximately 1-2 per low power field in moderately concentrated urine of otherwise normal patients.
  • The presence of large numbers of hyaline casts should prompt an investigation for underlying causes of proteinuria
  • Casts can deteriorate rapidly, especially in dilute, alkaline, or aged samples.
  • Aggressive centrifugation (>250g) may distort casts
  • The number of casts is not a reliable index of the severity, duration, or reversibility of the underlying disease.

 

   References

 

  • Bartjes J, Polzin D, eds. Nephroloy and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
Hct(c):
Description: Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume made up by red blood cells. 

 

Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Primary immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
      • Heinz body anemia
        • Toxins
        • Drugs
        • Dietary
      • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
        • Vasculitis
        • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
        • Hemangiosarcoma
        • Heartworm infection
      • Metabolic
      • Hereditary
      • Envenomation
  • Decreased red blood cell production
    • Chronic blood loss
    • Chronic inflammatory disease
    • Reduced erythropoietin
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Liver disease or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
      • Folate
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia   

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Hematocrit

 

  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry: increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis: bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Decreased erythropoietin production
    • CBC:
      • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
      • Decreased RBC with normal to decreased reticulocytes
      • Normal RDW
    • Evaluate for underlying causes:
      • Chronic kidney disease:
        • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
          • +/- proteinuria
        • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
        • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
      • Hypothyroidism:
        • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
        • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
        • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol
          • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
  • Bone marrow suppression:
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukopenia
      • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Increased Hematocrit
   

  • Dehydration
  • Splenic contraction (dogs)
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Hematocrit

 

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- increased phosphorus
    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • CBC:
      • High normal to increased RBCs
      • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
        • Acromegaly
    • Secondary polycythemia:
      • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
      • Systemic hypoxia:
        • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
        • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
        • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
        • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
    • Polycythemia vera:
      • CBC:
        • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • Variably increased platelets
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
      • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion
         

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Red blood cells (RBCs, erythrocytes, red cells, red corpuscles) are the longest-lived of the circulating blood cells. They are produced primarily in the bone marrow, but some production can occur at secondary sites such as spleen and liver. Red blood cell production is stimulated by erythropoietin which is released from the kidneys.
  • Red blood cells contain hemoglobin and are critical for cellular respiration, delivering oxygen to tissues and carrying carbon dioxide away.
  • Hematocrit estimates the total red cell mass.
  • Red blood cells are not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • Anemias can be classified as regenerative or nonregenerative based on the adequacy of the bone marrow response to produce new red blood cells (in all species but the horse). Reticulocytosis typically appears 3-4 days after the onset of anemia, with peak production in 7 days for dogs and 7-14 days for cats.
  • Anemia is a common clinical problem that may need emergency treatment with transfusion of red blood cell products if acute and/or severe.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated hematology analyzers calculate the hematocrit by multiplying the number of red blood cells x their average volume, or RBC x MCV, then divided by total volume. Simply stated - HCT = (RBC x MCV)/10.
  • Packed cell volume (PCV) specifies that centrifugation was used to separate the blood sample into three layers:  plasma, buffy coat (leukocytes and platelets), and packed red cells. The red cell layer height is divided by total sample height to obtain the percent value.
  • The PCV is usually slightly greater than a HCT determined by automated equipment because of plasma trapping.  The difference is usually less than 2% but may approach 4% in some samples. 
  • Anemia is defined as a decrease in the hematocrit.  More specifically, anemia can be a reduction in the numbers (count) of red blood cells (RBC), the concentration of hemoglobin, or the hematocrit or packed cell volume (PCV).  Decreases in these parameters may not be uniform, owing to differences in reference intervals or to the presence of abnormal RBCs.

  

References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds. Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
