Heartworm:
Description:  The heartworm antigen test is used to diagnose infection with Dirofilaria immitis, the causative agent of canine and feline heartworm disease. The test detects a uterine antigen found predominantly in mature female heartworms.

Positive Heartworm Antigen

  • Presence of one or more adult female Dirofilaria immitis
  • Post-adulticide therapy - antigen tests may remain positive up to 6 months post-therapy in dogs
  • Artifact - false positive due to hemolysis

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Heartworm Antigen

  • The American Heartworm Society recommends all positive heartworm antigen tests should be confirmed through additional testing, including identification of circulating microfilariae (if present) and/or a second positive result obtained from a different antigen test
  • CBC:
    • Variably present nonregenerative anemia, neutrophilia, eosinophilia and basophilia
    • Regenerative or pre-regenerative anemia may be seen with caval syndrome
    • Blood film review: variable target cells, schistocytes and spherocytes (especially with caval syndrome)
  • Chemistry:
    • Increased ALP, ALT, GGT and bilirubin in severe heartworm disease with heart failure
    • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN:
      • May be pre-renal in origin with dehydration or poor cardiac output
      • May be secondary to glomerulonephritis
    • Decreased albumin with secondary glomerulonephritis
    • Hemoglobinemia may be seen with intravascular hemolysis due to caval syndrome
  • Urinalysis:
    • Variably increased protein
    • Hemoglobinuria in dogs with caval syndrome
  • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Microfilaria - variably positive in dogs, uncommon in cats
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably positive, especially with more severe pulmonary arterial disease or thromboembolism
  • Chest radiographs:
    • Main pulmonary artery and right ventricle enlargement
    • Increased size and density of pulmonary arteries and/or pulmonary artery tortuosity
  • Echocardiogram:
    • Insensitive as a diagnostic tool except with caval syndrome or heavy worm burden
    • Heartworms may be seen in the right ventricle and/or pulmonary artery
    • Useful to assess right heart enlargement
  • Heartworm antibody test (cats) - may be positive in early larval stages of infection, but does not confirm active infection

Negative Heartworm Antigen

  • Absence of infection
  • Pre-patent infection
  • Antigen/antibody complexing
  • Low worm burden or single sex infection (male worms only)

  Next Steps for Negative Heartworm Antigen

  • If heartworm infection is suspected based on history or clinical signs, consider additional diagnostics
  • Pre-patent infection or low worm burden infection
    • Chest radiographs - changes consistent with heartworm disease
    • Echocardiogram:
      • Insensitive as a diagnostic tool except with caval syndrome or heavy worm burden
      • Heartworms may be seen in the right ventricle and/or pulmonary artery
      • Useful to assess right heart enlargement
    • Heartworm antibody test (cats) - may be positive in early larval stages of infection but does not confirm active infection
    • Recheck heartworm antigen test in 6 months.
  • Antigen/antibody complexing (rare)
    • Seen when a strong immune response results in antibody binding the heartworm antigen in circulation, interfering with the detection of heartworm antigen by heartworm tests.
    • History of slow kill treatment regimen may increase suspicion for antibody/antigen complexes.
    • Increased suspicion in patients with chronic inflammation
    • Heartworm antigen by ELISA following heat treatment - positive
    • CBC:
      • Eosinophilia
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.) may be seen with antigen/antibody complexing
      • Mild to moderate stable anemia +/-microcytosis with long term inflammatory conditions
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Variably decreased albumin
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased

Additional Information

 Heartworm Resource Quick Links:

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of heartworm and other vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide.
  • View the Canine Heartworm Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/heartworm-next-steps.
  • View the Feline Heartworm Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/feline-heartworm-next-steps.
  • For more information on prevention, treatment and management of heartworm disease, read the American Heartworm Society Guidelines.
  • For sharing positive results in cats with pet owners, please see the Feline Heartworm Positive Client Handout.

Physiology

  • Dirofilaria immitis infections occur primarily in canids (dog, fox and coyote) and can also be detected in felids.
    • The domestic dog and some wild canids are the normal definitive hosts for heartworms and are most likely to develop high microfilaria counts, allowing them to serve as the main reservoir of infection.
    • Less suitable hosts, such as cats and ferrets, occasionally have low-level, transient microfilaremia and theoretically may serve as a limited source of infection for mosquitoes during their short periods of microfilaremia.
  • Canine - D. immitis life cycle and clinical signs
    • The life cycle of D. immitis lasts approximately 7-9 months in the dog.
      • The mosquito is the required vector for transmission of D. immitis and becomes infected by consuming a blood meal from a microfilaremic host.
      • The D. immitis microfilariae mature in the Malpighian tubules of the mosquito, developing into larval stage 1 (L1), then molting into larval stage (L2), and finally molting into the infective third-stage larvae (L3), which are transmitted to the dog when bitten by infected mosquitoes.
      • Once the infective L3 enter the dog, they molt into fourth-stage larvae (L4).
      • The final molt into juvenile/immature adults occurs between days 50 and 70, while migrating through the body and appear in the smallest pulmonary arteries as early as day 67 after transmission.
      • Sexual maturity occurs approximately 120 days post-infection with dogs developing patent infections (i.e., having circulating microfilariae) as early as 6 months but usually by 7 to 9 months after infection.
    • Clinical signs consistent with heartworm disease:
      • Mild - asymptomatic or cough
      • Moderate - cough, exercise intolerance, abnormal lung sounds
      • Severe - cough, exercise intolerance, dyspnea, abnormal heart and lung sounds, enlarged liver (hepatomegaly), syncope (temporary loss of consciousness from reduced blood flow to the brain), ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity), death.
      • Caval syndrome - sudden onset of severe lethargy, weakness and shock.
  • Feline - D. immitis life cycle and clinical signs
    • Cats are more resistant to heartworm infection than dogs.
      • The mosquito is the required vector for transmission of D. immitis and becomes infected by consuming a blood meal from a microfilaremic host.
      • The D. immitis microfilariae develop from first-stage larvae (L1) to third-stage larvae (L3) within the mosquito.
      • The infective third stage larvae (L3) are transmitted to the cat when bitten by infected mosquitoes.
      • Once the infective L3 larvae enter the cat, they molt into fourth-stage larvae (L4) and then develop to the juvenile worm stage about 2 months post-infection. 
      • There is some loss of larvae as they migrate through the host.
      • There is high mortality of the juvenile worms as they enter the lungs 3-4 months after exposure.
      • Heartworms can reach the adult stage approximately 7-8 months post-infection.
        • Cats have a lower burden of adult worms compared to dogs with heartworm infection.
        • Adult heartworms will produce some microfilariae in cats, but the microfilariae only circulate for a short period of time.
    • Clinical signs consistent with heartworm infection in cats:
      • Many cats do not have clinical signs or show only transient clinical signs
      • Heartworm-associated respiratory disease (HARD) - occurs when larvae initially enter the lungs
        • Respiratory distress, cough, increased respiratory rate
      • Sudden death
      • Vomiting, anorexia, weight loss
      • Occasionally ascites, hydrothorax, ataxia or seizures can be observed

Diagnostic Methodology

  • Heartworm tests utilize immunoassay-based technology to detect antigen (carbohydrate) that is primarily excreted from the uterus of mature female worms.
  • Different methodologies (e.g. SNAP, PetChek) are employed for commercially available immunoassays and therefore sensitivity and specificity between the tests will vary.
  • The SNAP test is not quantitative and therefore, the intensity of color change should not be used to predict the heartworm burden.
  • Antigen/antibody complexing (rare)
    • Seen when a strong immune response results in non-specific antibody binding the heartworm antigen in circulation, the bound antibody interferes with the detection of antigen by heartworm tests.
    • A suspicion of antigen/antibody complexing can be considered in a patient where there is a high clinical suspicion of heartworm disease but a negative antigen test.
    • Heartworm antigen testing following heat treatment can be used to help further evaluate cases which are suspected to have antigen/antibody complexes.
    • History of slow kill treatment regimen may increase suspicion for antibody/antigen complexes.

References

  • Nelson, CT, McCall JW, Jones S, Moorhead, AW. Current Canine Guidelines for the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Management of Heartworm (Dirofilaria immitis) Infection in Dogs (Revised 2018). https://www.heartwormsociety.org/veterinary-resources/american-heartworm-society-guidelines. Accessed October 16, 2018.
  • Jones S, Graham W, von Simson C, et al. Current Feline Guidelines for the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Management of Heartworm (Dirofilaria immitis) Infection in Cats,  https://www.heartwormsociety.org/veterinary-resources/american-heartworm-society-guidelines. Accessed August 1, 2023.
  • Bowman DD, Atkinds CE. Heartworm Biology Treatment, and Control. Vet Clin Small Anim 39 (2009) 1127-1158.
  • Beall MJ, Arguello-Marin A, Drexel J, Liu J, Chandrashekar R, Alleman R. Validation of immune complex dissociation methods for use with heartworm antigen tests. Parasit Vectors 2017, 10(Suppl 2):481.

Last Updated 9/29/2023

K:
Description: Potassium is an intracellular ion that is responsible for maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance.  Potassium is essential for muscle and nerve function.


Decreased Potassium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss (vomiting/diarrhea)
  • Renal loss
    • Chronic kidney disease (cats)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Diuretic therapy
    • Renal tubular acidosis
    • Post-obstructive diuresis
    • Hyperaldosteronism (cats)
  • Decreased intake
    • Dietary deficiency
    • Fluid therapy without adequate potassium
  • Potassium translocation from extracellular fluid (ECF) space
    • Drugs/toxins (e.g. bicarbonate therapy; albuterol inhaler ingestion, insulin with glucose administration)
    • Alkalemia
  • Hypokalemic myopathy of Burmese kittens
  • Hypokalemic periodic paralysis   

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Potassium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
  • Chronic kidney disease (esp. cats)
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  •  Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Renal tubulopathies (proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis)
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased potassium, phosphorus and TCO2
      • Increased chloride
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Serum glucose normal despite glucosuria
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Urine pH variable - pH <5.5 with Fanconi's syndrome (proximal renal tubular acidosis) and pH >6.0 in distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Variable struvite crystalluria may be seen with distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
    • Evaluate for risk factors:
      • Breed predisposition - Basenjis (congenital Fanconi's syndrome)
      • History of possible drug or toxin exposure (acquired Fanconi's syndrome, e.g. contaminated jerky treats, gentamicin)

 

Increased Potassium

 

  • Pseudohyperkalemia - translocation of potassium from cells post-collection
    • Asian dog breeds (Akita, Shiba Inu, Jindo, Chow Chow, Shar pei)
    • Hemolysis
    • Delayed serum separation
    • Markedly increased platelets or white blood cell count
  • Decreased potassium excretion
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Acute anuric or oliguric kidney failure
    • Urinary obstruction or ruptured bladder
    • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Drugs (e.g. ACE inhibitors, trimethoprim, spironolactone)
    • Selected gastrointestinal diseases (e.g. whipworms, salmonellosis, perforated duodenal ulcer)
  • Potassium translocation from intracellular fluid to extracellular fluid
    • Metabolic acidosis due to increased organic acids (e.g. ketones, lactate)
    • Diabetes mellitus with hyperosmolar syndrome
    • Tissue necrosis, severe
      • Acute tumor lysis syndrome
      • Reperfusion syndrome
      • Aortic thromboembolism
      • Rhabdomyolysis/muscle necrosis (e.g. post-seizure, strenuous exercise)
    • Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
    • Post-exercise in hypothyroid dogs (mild increase)
  • Increased intake
    • Administration of potassium rich fluids
    • Dietary excess
  • Pleural effusion and ascites
  • Artifact:
    • Collection from IV line where potassium was administered
    • EDTA contamination

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Potassium

 

  • Pseudohyperkalemia
    • Evaluate for potential causes of pseudohyperkalemia:
      • Asian dog breed
      • Hemolysis or delayed serum separation
      • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count > 100,000/uL)
      • Increased platelets (platelets > 1,000,000/uL)
    • Recheck a potassium on a heparinized plasma sample spun down and separated immediately after collection to minimize translocation of potassium from the cells post-collection.
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
    Acute kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (polyuria, polydipsia, exposure to renal toxins), increased SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis - urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
      • Infectious renal diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease):
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status.
  • Urinary obstruction or rupture
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Crystalluria (crystals may not reflect urolith composition)
      • Active urinary sediment (pyuria, bacteriuria, casts, hematuria)
    • Uroabdomen
      • Abdominal fluid has higher creatinine concentrations than serum
      • Contrast radiographs for urinary tract rupture and leakage
    • Abdominal ultrasound for evidence of obstruction or rupture and to identify masses, stones, other causes of obstruction in the urinary tract.
  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel - for infectious causes, e.g. Salmonella
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Decreased Na:K ratio and sodium
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Potassium is the major intracellular cation
  • Serum concentration does not accurately reflect total body concentration, but is nearly equivalent to the amount of potassium in the extracellular fluid compartment.
  • Serum potassium concentrations change with acidosis and alkalosis.
  • Potassium is responsible for maintenance of intracellular volume and determining cellular membrane potential

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis: MO; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018

    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Urine pH variable - pH <5.5 with Fanconi's syndrome (proximal renal tubular acidosis) and pH >6.0 in distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Variable struvite crystalluria may be seen with distal renal tubular acidosis
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
    • Evaluate for risk factors:
      • Breed predisposition - Basenjis (congenital Fanconi's syndrome)
      • History of possible drug or toxin exposure (acquired Fanconi's syndrome, e.g. contaminated jerky treats, gentamicin)

 

Increased Potassium

 

  • Pseudohyperkalemia - translocation of potassium from cells post-collection
    • Asian dog breeds (Akita, Shiba Inu, Jindo, Chow Chow, Shar pei)
    • Hemolysis
    • Delayed serum separation
    • Markedly increased platelets or white blood cell count
  • Decreased potassium excretion
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Acute anuric or oliguric kidney failure
    • Urinary obstruction or ruptured bladder
    • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Drugs (e.g. ACE inhibitors, trimethoprim, spironolactone)
    • Selected gastrointestinal diseases (e.g. whipworms, salmonellosis, perforated duodenal ulcer)
  • Potassium translocation from intracellular fluid to extracellular fluid
    • Metabolic acidosis due to increased organic acids (e.g. ketones, lactate)
    • Diabetes mellitus with hyperosmolar syndrome
    • Tissue necrosis, severe
      • Acute tumor lysis syndrome
      • Reperfusion syndrome
      • Aortic thromboembolism
      • Rhabdomyolysis/muscle necrosis (e.g. post-seizure, strenuous exercise)
    • Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
    • Post-exercise in hypothyroid dogs (mild increase)
  • Increased intake
    • Administration of potassium rich fluids
    • Dietary excess
  • Pleural effusion and ascites
  • Artifact:
    • Collection from IV line where potassium was administered
    • EDTA contamination

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Potassium

 

  • Pseudohyperkalemia
    • Evaluate for potential causes of pseudohyperkalemia:
      • Asian dog breed
      • Hemolysis or delayed serum separation
      • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count > 100,000/uL)
      • Increased platelets (platelets > 1,000,000/uL)
    • Recheck a potassium on a heparinized plasma sample spun down and separated immediately after collection to minimize translocation of potassium from the cells post-collection.
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
    Acute kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (polyuria, polydipsia, exposure to renal toxins), increased SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis - urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
      • Infectious renal diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease):
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status.
  • Urinary obstruction or rupture
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Crystalluria (crystals may not reflect urolith composition)
      • Active urinary sediment (pyuria, bacteriuria, casts, hematuria)
    • Uroabdomen
      • Abdominal fluid has higher creatinine concentrations than serum
      • Contrast radiographs for urinary tract rupture and leakage
    • Abdominal ultrasound for evidence of obstruction or rupture and to identify masses, stones, other causes of obstruction in the urinary tract.
  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel - for infectious causes, e.g. Salmonella
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Decreased Na:K ratio and sodium
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Potassium is the major intracellular cation
  • Serum concentration does not accurately reflect total body concentration, but is nearly equivalent to the amount of potassium in the extracellular fluid compartment.
  • Serum potassium concentrations change with acidosis and alkalosis.
  • Potassium is responsible for maintenance of intracellular volume and determining cellular membrane potential

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis: MO; 2004.

KET:
Description:  Ketonuria indicates a derangement in energy metabolism that usually occurs in states of negative energy balance. The presence of ketones in the urine is most commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis in dogs and cats.

 

Positive Ketones
   

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged fasting or starvation
  • Low carbohydrate diet
  • Strenuous exercise, e.g. endurance racing
  • Exposure to severely cold environment
  • Lactation (in dogs)
  • Genetic diseases
    • Mitochondrial myopathy
    • Glycogen storage disease
  • Persistent fever
  • Artifact - false positive with dipsticks
    • Highly pigmented urine
    • Urine containing
      • Phthalein dyes
      • Compounds with sulfhydryl groups (captopril, valproic acid, d-penicillamine, tiopronin, cystine)
      • Salicylates (e.g. aspirin)
      • Levodopa metabolites
           

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Ketones

 

  • Diabetes mellitus with diabetic ketoacidosis
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL® or Spec cPL® test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administation

 

Negative Ketones
   

  • The absence of ketones is a normal finding
  • False negative
    • Aged urine sample
    • Improper storage of reagent strip (exposed to moisture, heat, or light)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Ketones, such as beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone, are produced by lipolysis and are filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Normally, ketones are completely resorbed by the proximal tubules.
  • Ketonuria is present before ketonemia can be detected.
  • The severity of ketoacidosis cannot be correlated with the degree of ketonuria.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Nitroprusside reaction
    • Detects acetoacetate (primarily) and acetone (to a lesser degree)
    • Does not detect beta hydroxybutyrate (the major intermediate in ketosis)

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman SC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine: diseases of the dog and the cat, 8th ed., St, Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE, Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

LAC:
Description: Lactate is an energy storage molecule of glycolysis that is produced in increased amounts when oxygen demand exceeds supply. Decreased oxygen delivery to tusses, e.g shock, is by far the most common cause of increased lactate in dogs and cats. It is an indicator of tissue perfusion, oxygenation, and hypermetabolism. 

Increased Lactate

  • Type A: Inadequate oxygen supply to tissues
    • Decreased oxygen delivery
      • Shock
        • Hypovolemic
        • Maldistributive
        • Cardiogenic
        • Obstructive
      • Regional ischemia
        • Splanchnic and/or gastrointestinal, e.g., gastric dilatation/volvulus (dog)
        • Aortic thromboembolism (cat)
      • Severe anemia (hematocrit <10-15%)
        • Blood loss
        • Hemolysis
        • Decreased red blood cell production
      • Carbon monoxide poisoning
      • Severe hypoxemia (PaO2 < 25-40 mmHg)
    • Increased oxygen demand
      • Seizure
      • Extreme exercise
      • Struggling, esp. in cats
      • Trembling, shivering
  • Type B: Impaired tissue oxygen utilization or clearance
    • Sepsis/systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Neoplasia, e.g. lymphoma
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Liver disease
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Thiamine deficiency
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Drugs/toxins
      • Corticosteroids
      • Acetominophen, salicylates
      • Adrenergic agonists and sympathomimetics
      • Alcohols, e.g. ethylene glycol, propylene glycol
      • Cyanide, sodium nitroprusside
    • Defective metabolic pathways
      • Mitochondrial myopathies (e.g. German shepherd, Jack Russell terrier, Old English sheepdog)
      • Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency (e.g. Clumber and Sussex spaniels)
    • Physiologic - neonates < 4 weeks of age may have significant increases
    • Artifact - delay in processing blood sample 
      • Specimen should be processed within 15 minutes of collection or placed in an ice bath

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Lactate

  • Transient increases of lactate can be seen in clinically healthy animals in association with severe struggling, shivering, trembling or severe exertion. If indicated, confirm increased lactate is persistent by repeat testing in 1-2 hours.
  • Electrocardiogram - tachycardia (dog) or bradycardia (cat)
  • Blood pressure - hypotension is common with decompensated shock
  • Blood gas - base excess
  • Hypovolemic shock:
    • Trauma - investigate for any history or physical evidence of blunt trauma (e.g. hit-by-car), crush injury or falling from height.
      • Chemistry - increased CK, ALT, AST
      • Urinalysis - variable hematuria
    • Acute, severe blood loss (esp. decompensated shock)
      • CBC:
        • Anemia may be pre-regenerative with normal reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Mild to moderately decreased platelets
      • Chemistry - variably decreased total protein, albumin and globulins
    • Dehydration (profound)
      • Investigate for history of water restriction, frozen water sources or ongoing losses, etc.
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBC and hemoglobin
        • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCH, MCHC)
        • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein, albumin and globulins
        • Increased sodium and chloride
        • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- phosphorus, if severe
      • Urinalysis - increased specific gravity (>1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats)
    • Gastrointestinal disease
      • CBC:
        • Variable increased hematocrit, RBC with associated acute dehydration (e.g. hemorrhagic gastroenteritis)
        • Mild to moderate stable nonregenerative anemia with chronic disease 
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Variable leukopenia (suggestive of infection, e.g. Salmonella, parvovirus)
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Potassium may be increased or decreased
        • Decreased albumin and globulin with protein-losing enteropathy 
      • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease:
        • SNAP Parvovirus fecal antigen test for parvovirus in poorly vaccinated dogs
        • Fecal Dx antigen tests for whipworms, hookworms and roundworms
        • PCR panel - e.g. for CPnetEF toxin (associated with hemorrhagic gastroenteritis), parvovirus, Salmonella spp.
      • Abdominal imaging to evaluate for gastrointestinal obstruction
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
        • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
    • Pancreatitis
      • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Variable mildly decreased platelets
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry
        • Increased ALT, ALP and bilirubin
        • Variably increased amylase, lipase, cholesterol, triglycerides and glucose
        • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
        • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
      • Urinalysis
        • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
        • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
      • Radiographs:
        • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
        • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
        • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
        • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
      • Biopsy:
        • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
        • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Maldistributive shock
    • Sepsis/SIRS
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • Red blood cell fragments (e.g. schistocytes, poikilocytes) may be seen with secondary disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils)
        • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/uL) and left shift can be seen in some cases
        • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils in a degenerative left shift
        • Variably decreased platelets
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin and glucose
        • Variably increased ALT, bilirubin and globulins
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
      • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
        • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation
        • Systemic infection:
          • Serology, PCR or antigen tests for infectious diseases
          • Blood or urine culture for systemic bacterial infections
        • Localized inflammation or infection:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
          • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass) - suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
          • Culture with MIC susceptibility of affected site variably positive
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Assess for pyelonephritis:
            • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
            • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
            • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive
        • Immune-mediated diseases:
          • CBC:
            • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
            • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
          • Coombs - positive with IMHA
          • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Neoplasia:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Cardiogenic shock
    • Congestive heart failure
      • CBC:
        • RBC normal to increased with systemic hypoxia
        • Reticulocytes variably increased
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased sodium with edema
        • Variable increase in ALT and ALP
        • Variable increasd in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with pre-renal decrease in GFR, acute kidney injury or cardiorenal syndrome
      • Urinalysis - variable; may have concentrated urine (urine specific gravity >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horses) or inappropriate in light of hydration status
      • Cardiopet proBNP test increased
      • PaO2 decreased
      • Chest radiographs - cardiac enlargement, pulmonary edema, variable pericardial or pleural effusion
      • Echocardiography reflects underlying cardiac disease
      • Abdominal imaging may show hepatic congestion, abdominal effusion
      • Electrocardiogram - chamber enlargement patterns, conduction disturbances or arrythmias may be seen
  • Regional ischemia
    • Aortic thromboembolism (saddle thrombus) - typically acute onset of decreased/absent femoral pulses; cold, painful extremities; and cyanotic nail beds.
      • CBC:
        • Stress leukogram
        • Platelets mild to moderately decreased with consumption
      • Chemistry:
        • SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus variably increased due to acute kidney injury or renal arterial embolism (may indicate poor prognosis)
        • ALT and AST increased
        • CK severely increased
        • Glucose variably increased with stress hyperglycemia
        • Potassium increased with reperfusion or acute kidney injury
      • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased
      • D-dimers - variably increased
      • Thoracic imaging consistent with cardiomyopathy with enlarged left atrium+/- congestive heart failure

Additional Information

   Physiology

  • Lactate is normally produced in small amounts during glycolysis, primarily in skeletal muscle (40-50%), brain and adipose tissue where it acts as an energy storage molecule. Lactate production increases when tissue oxygen demand exceeds supply.  
  • With type A lactic acidosis, there is decreased oxygen supply to tissues that may be absolute (decreased oxygen delivery due to poor perfusion, regional ischemia, anemia) or relative (increased oxygen consumption due to seizures, exercise, struggling, shivering). Tissue hypoperfusion with shock is by far the most common cause of increased blood lactate concentration.  The increase in lactate is proportional to the severity of hypoperfusion and resulting tissue hypoxia.  
  • Lactate is a useful prognostic tool in dogs (less clear in cats). Normal initial lactate predicts survival better than an increased initial lactate predicts death (high negative predictive value).
  • Lactate has a serum half-life of 20-60 minutes and should decrease rapidly with successful treatment (decrease of 50% every 1-2 hours). Persistently increased lactate is an indication to re-evaluate the patient and pursue more aggressive treatment.
  • Increased lactate in peritoneal fluid and increased difference between fluid and serum lactate suggest septic peritonitis. Increased lactate in synovial fluid indicates high likelihood of septic arthritis (vs. immune-mediated or osteoarthritis).
  • The less common type B lactic acidosis is caused by impaired tissue oxygen utilization or impaired clearance due to a concurrent disease process, drugs/toxins or congenital errors of metabolism.
  • L-lactate, is the major product of mammalian cells. The isomeric form, D-lactate, may rarely contribute to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis in diabetic ketoacidosis, propylene glycol intoxication, or intestinal dysbiosis without a consistent significant increase in the measureable L-lactate. 

   Diagnostic Methodology  

  • Lactate, as L-lactate, can be measured routinely using reference laboratory or in house analyzers, as well as numerous point of care handheld devices.

   References

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine: Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Rosenstein PG, Tennent-Brown BS, Hughes D. Clinical use of plasma lactate concentration. Part 1: Physiology, pathophysiology and measurement. Journal of Veterinary Emergency and Critical Care. 28(2); 2018: 85-105.
  • Rosenstein PG< Tennent-Brown BS, Hughes D. Clinical use of plasma lactate concentration. Part 2: Prognostic and diagnostic utility and clinical management of hyperlactatemia. Journal of Veterinary Emergency and Critical Care. 28(2); 2018: 106-121.
  • Silverstein DC, Hopper K, eds., Small Animal Critical Care Medicine, 2nd ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2015.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

LIPA:
Description:  Lipase is an enzyme produced primarily in the pancreas and other tissue sources. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of triglycerides in many sites within the body (e.g. intestines, liver, vascular endothelium, fat stores) and is involved with lipid metabolism. 

 

Increased Lipase

 

  • Pancreatic acinar cell damage
    • Pancreatitis (acute or chronic)
    • Pancreatic inflammation secondary to other primary disease
    • Subclinical pancreatitis (if clinical signs are absent)
    • Pancreatic neoplasia
  • Decreased clearance by the kidneys (any condition that reduces glomerular filtration rate [GFR])
    • Kidney disease
    • Pre-renal
    • Post-renal
  • Glucocorticoids
    • Exogenous
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
  • Gastrointestinal disease
  • Hepatic neoplasia (dogs)
  • Widespread steatitis
  • Peritonitis

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Lipase

 

  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP and bilirubin
      • Variably increased amylase, cholesterol, triglycerides and glucose
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Decreased clearance by the kidneys (decreased GFR)
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - normal, unless secondary pancreatic inflammation is present
    • Kidney disease
      • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
      • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Chemistry: 
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
      • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
      • Increased blood pressure
      • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
      • Investigate for underlying causes:
        • Toxic insult:
          • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
          • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
        • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
          • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
          • Chemistry:
            • Decreased albumin
            • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
        • Infectious kidney diseases:
          • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
            • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
            • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
      • Assess for confounding conditions:
        • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
    • Pre-renal
      • Dehydration:
        • Urinalysis: increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horses
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased serum proteins
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA
          • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
        • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
      • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration and shock
        • CBC:
          • Nonregenerative anemia
          • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA due to secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation (diagnostic test)
      • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
        • Decreased blood pressure
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
        • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
        • Abnormal echocardiogram
    • Post-renal
      • Urinary obstruction occurring in the kidneys, ureter, bladder or urethra
      • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
      • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
        • Increased potassium with complete urinary tract obstruction or leakage
      • Uroabdomen - abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentration than serum
      • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies, or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones) or rupture.
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • Moderate increases in amylase may be seen in a variety of intestinal diseases.
    • CBC:
      • Non-regenerative anemia and decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with chronic disease
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin, cholesterol and total protein with more severe disease
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - normal or may be increased with secondary pancreatic inflammation
    • Decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with diffuse small intestinal disease
    • Abdominal imaging (radiographs or ultrasound) - abnormalities consistent with intestinal disease, obstruction or rupture.

 

Decreased Lipase

 

  • Artifact
    • Hemolysis directly inhibits lipase activity in the assay
  • Decreased lipase is not clinically significant.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Lipase is a cytoplasmic enzyme in the pancreas that is released into the small intestine to catalyze the hydrolysis of triglycerides for absorption into the lacteals and gastrointestinal blood vessels.
  • In addition to pancreatic acinar cells, lipase is produced by gastric mucosal cells, hepatocytes, and many other cells (including adipocytes and myocytes) and is involved with lipid metabolism in various sites within the body.
  • Lipase is often increased in dogs and cats with pancreatic inflammation. 
    • Lipase is not as sensitive or specific an indicator of pancreatic inflammation as Spec cPL®/Spec fPL®.
  • In dogs with pancreatitis, serum lipase activity usually increases within 24 hours and peaks (at a higher level of activity compared to amylase) at 2-5 days. 
    • Lipase activity can remain within reference intervals in dogs with pancreatitis.
  • In cats with pancreatitis, serum lipase is usually increased, but can also be within reference intervals
  • In horses, serum lipase activity is not diagnostically useful.
  • The kidneys excrete or inactivate lipase.  Hence serum lipase tends to increase with acute and chronic kidney disease as well as pre- and post-renal conditions that reduce GFR. 
    • Diseases that reduce GFR usually do not result in more than 2- to 3- fold increase in serum lipase activity.
    • Serum lipase activity tends to parallel serum amylase activity when renal blood flow or functional renal tissue is decreased.
  • Glucocorticoid administration may cause up to 5-fold increase in serum lipase activity.  The mechanism is unknown.

 

Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The assay measures lipase activity through consumption of substrate, not the quantity of lipase.

 

References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Hulsebosch SE, Palm, Segev G, et al. Evaluation of canine pancreas-specific lipase activity, lipase activity, and trypsin-like immunoreactivity in an experimental model of acute kidney injury in dogs. JVIM 2016. Vol 30(1):192-199.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
     

Last updated 9/1/2024
LYM:
Description:  Lymphocytes are white blood cells which are derived from lymphoid tissues including the lymph nodes, spleen and thymus.  Lymphocytes play a role in cell-mediated and humoral immune responses.

 

Decreased Lymphocytes 

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Acute systemic infection
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
    • Chylous effusions
  • Immunosuppressive therapy
  • Infiltrative lymphatic disease
  • Hereditary immunodeficiency
       

     Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Lymphocytes

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    • CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • Absence of a left shift
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased eosinophils 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 
    • Assess for recent history of glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests 
      • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Acute systemic infection
    • Lymphopenia most commonly seen with sepsis, endotoxemia or early viral infections
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic change +/- band neutrophils
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils 
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of systemic infection:
      • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (esp.viral)
      • Blood culture or urine culture to assess for systemic bacterial infections
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin and globulin
        • Decreased cholesterol
        • Decreased total calcium
      • GI panel:
        • Folate variably decreased (if proximal infiltrative intestinal disease) or increased (with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)
        • Cobalamin decreased (if distal infiltrative intestinal disease)
        • Spec cPL or fPL test - variably increased with secondary pancreatic inflammation
      • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - confirms gastrointestinal protein loss
      • Ultrasound to assess for thickened intestinal walls, loss of wall layering and/or enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies to evaluate for lymphangiectasia and infiltrative disease (lymphoma, severe inflammatory bowel disease)
    • Chylous effusions
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin
      • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for body cavity effusions
      • Cytology of effusion consistent with chylous effusion
      • Effusion triglycerides and cholesterol:
        • Fluid triglycerides higher than serum triglycerides
        • Fluid cholesterol lower than serum cholesterol
        • Effusion cholesterol: triglyceride ratio <1
      • Next steps to assess for underlying causes:
        • Cardiopet proBNP test:
          • Increased with cardiomyopathy
          • Variably decreased with significant pericardial effusion
        • Heartworm antigen serology for antigen or antibody testing, microfilaria testing
        • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound, echocardiogram) to evaluate for cardiac disease, cranial mediastinal mass, or venous obstruction

 

  Increased Lymphocytes   

 

  • Physiologic lymphocytosis (epinephrine effect)
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • Chronic infection
    • Post-vaccination
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • Lymphocytic leukemia, acute and chronic
    • Leukemic phase of lymphoma
    • Thymoma

   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Lymphocytes

 

  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia
      • Larger and/or reactive lymphocytes 
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - variably increased
    • Assess for recent vaccination (especially serial vaccinations).
    • Next steps to assess for chronic infection:
      • Positive serology, PCR or antigen tests for infectious diseases (esp. ehrlichiosis)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Mild nonregenerative anemia 
      • Normal to increased eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium 
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol 
      • Abnormal ACTH stimulation test 
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia common
      • Variable leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
      • Lymphoid blasts present with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and the leukemic phase of lymphoma
      • Mature lymphocytosis with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL); may be reactive
    • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound) to help differentiate between leukemic stage lymphoma and ALL
    • Serology, PCR and antigen tests:
      • Negative for tick-borne diseases and other infectious causes of reactive lymphocytosis 
      • FeLV positive common as predisposing cause of leukemia and lymphoma in cats
    • Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on whole blood - confirms leukemia/leukemic phase vs reactive lymphocytosis
    • Cytology or histopathology of enlarged lymph nodes or lymphoid organs - consistent with lymphoma
    • Bone marrow cytology or histopathology:
      • ALL - blast cells present, may require immunocytochemical stains to differentiate
      • CLL - infiltration with mature lymphocytes
    • Lymphoma PCR (PCR for antigen receptor rearrangement [PARR]) - confirms lymphoma/leukemia and determines B-cell vs T-cell for specimen with equivocal cytology (whole blood, bone marrow, lymph node or splenic aspirate)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Mature lymphocytes are approximately 1-1.5 times the size of a red blood cell, with scant bluish cytoplasm, round to oval nuclei, and aggregated or clumped chromatin.
  • Lymphocytes differ from other leukocytes in that after leaving the vascular system, they can recirculate and have a relatively long half-life (months to years).
  • Their primary function is humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

  

   Diagnostic  Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The lymphocyte percentage (or relative lymphocyte count) is the number of lymphocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute lymphocyte count is calculated by multiplying the lymphocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of lymphocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
