  • Their primary function is humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

  

   Diagnostic  Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The lymphocyte percentage (or relative lymphocyte count) is the number of lymphocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute lymphocyte count is calculated by multiplying the lymphocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of lymphocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
LYMPCT_BLD:
Description:  Lymphocytes are white blood cells which are derived from lymphoid tissues including the lymph nodes, spleen and thymus.  Lymphocytes play a role in cell-mediated and humoral immune responses.

 

Decreased Lymphocytes 

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Acute systemic infection
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
    • Chylous effusions
  • Immunosuppressive therapy
  • Infiltrative lymphatic disease
  • Hereditary immunodeficiency
       

     Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Lymphocytes

 

  • Corticosteroid-induced lymphopenia
    • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    • CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • Absence of a left shift
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased eosinophils 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 
    • Assess for recent history of glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests 
      • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Acute systemic infection
    • Lymphopenia most commonly seen with sepsis, endotoxemia or early viral infections
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic change +/- band neutrophils
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils 
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of systemic infection:
      • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (esp.viral)
      • Blood culture or urine culture to assess for systemic bacterial infections
  • Loss of lymphocyte-rich fluid
    • Protein-losing enteropathy
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin and globulin
        • Decreased cholesterol
        • Decreased total calcium
      • GI panel:
        • Folate variably decreased (if proximal infiltrative intestinal disease) or increased (with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)
        • Cobalamin decreased (if distal infiltrative intestinal disease)
        • Spec cPL or fPL test - variably increased with secondary pancreatic inflammation
      • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - confirms gastrointestinal protein loss
      • Ultrasound to assess for thickened intestinal walls, loss of wall layering and/or enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes
      • Gastrointestinal biopsies to evaluate for lymphangiectasia and infiltrative disease (lymphoma, severe inflammatory bowel disease)
    • Chylous effusions
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased albumin
      • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for body cavity effusions
      • Cytology of effusion consistent with chylous effusion
      • Effusion triglycerides and cholesterol:
        • Fluid triglycerides higher than serum triglycerides
        • Fluid cholesterol lower than serum cholesterol
        • Effusion cholesterol: triglyceride ratio <1
      • Next steps to assess for underlying causes:
        • Cardiopet proBNP test:
          • Increased with cardiomyopathy
          • Variably decreased with significant pericardial effusion
        • Heartworm antigen serology for antigen or antibody testing, microfilaria testing
        • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound, echocardiogram) to evaluate for cardiac disease, cranial mediastinal mass, or venous obstruction

 

  Increased Lymphocytes   

 

  • Physiologic lymphocytosis (epinephrine effect)
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • Chronic infection
    • Post-vaccination
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • Lymphocytic leukemia, acute and chronic
    • Leukemic phase of lymphoma
    • Thymoma

   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Lymphocytes

 

  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia 
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
  • Antigenic stimulation
    • CBC:
      • Neutrophilia
      • Larger and/or reactive lymphocytes 
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Urine protein:creatinine ratio - variably increased
    • Assess for recent vaccination (especially serial vaccinations).
    • Next steps to assess for chronic infection:
      • Positive serology, PCR or antigen tests for infectious diseases (esp. ehrlichiosis)
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Mild nonregenerative anemia 
      • Normal to increased eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium 
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol 
      • Abnormal ACTH stimulation test 
  • Lymphoid neoplasia
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia common
      • Variable leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
      • Lymphoid blasts present with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and the leukemic phase of lymphoma
      • Mature lymphocytosis with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL); may be reactive
    • Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound) to help differentiate between leukemic stage lymphoma and ALL
    • Serology, PCR and antigen tests:
      • Negative for tick-borne diseases and other infectious causes of reactive lymphocytosis 
      • FeLV positive common as predisposing cause of leukemia and lymphoma in cats
    • Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on whole blood - confirms leukemia/leukemic phase vs reactive lymphocytosis
    • Cytology or histopathology of enlarged lymph nodes or lymphoid organs - consistent with lymphoma
    • Bone marrow cytology or histopathology:
      • ALL - blast cells present, may require immunocytochemical stains to differentiate
      • CLL - infiltration with mature lymphocytes
    • Lymphoma PCR (PCR for antigen receptor rearrangement [PARR]) - confirms lymphoma/leukemia and determines B-cell vs T-cell for specimen with equivocal cytology (whole blood, bone marrow, lymph node or splenic aspirate)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Mature lymphocytes are approximately 1-1.5 times the size of a red blood cell, with scant bluish cytoplasm, round to oval nuclei, and aggregated or clumped chromatin.
  • Lymphocytes differ from other leukocytes in that after leaving the vascular system, they can recirculate and have a relatively long half-life (months to years).
  • Their primary function is humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

  

   Diagnostic  Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The lymphocyte percentage (or relative lymphocyte count) is the number of lymphocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute lymphocyte count is calculated by multiplying the lymphocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of lymphocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
Leish:
﻿Description:  The Leishmania antibody test detects antibodies to the LiDx2 recombinant antigen derived from amastigotes and is based on polypeptides derived from L. infantum immunodominant kinesin antigens. Antibodies are expressed in infected dogs and bind the LiDx2 antigen, available as both capture and detection antigen in SNAP Leishmania and SNAP Leish 4Dx.  

Positive Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Indicates infection with Leishmania infantum. Infection with Leishmania spp. does not necessarily indicate disease.
  • Diagnosis of canine leishmaniasis is generally supported by detection of Leishmania infantum antibodies.
    • Subclinical infections are common and can be associated with low antibody levels.
    • Clinically sick dogs typically present with high antibody titers that are readily detectable.

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Confirm that there is other evidence of canine leishmaniasis such as supportive history and physical exam findings.
    • Generalised lymphadenopathy
    • Weight loss
    • Change in appetite (decreased or increased)
    • Lethargy
    • Pale mucous membranes
    • Coagulopathies or bleeding disorders (e.g., epistaxis, thrombosis)
    • Lameness/arthritis
    • Ocular disease (e.g., conjunctivitis, uveitis)
    • Splenomegaly
    • Increased thirst or urination
    • Fever
    • Gastrointestinal signs such as vomiting or diarrhoea (may include chronic colitis)
    • Dermatitis that may include:
      • Non-pruritic exfloliative dermatitis with or without alopecia
      • Erosive/ulcerative dermatitis
      • Nodular dermatitis
      • Papular dermatitis
      • Pustular dermatitis
    • Onychogryphosis - abnormal, excessive development and curving of the nails
  • CBC:
    • Mild to moderate non-regenerative anaemia
    • Leucocytosis or leucopaenia
    • Thrombocytopaenia
  • Chemistry
    • Increased globulins and total protein 
    • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin
    • Decreased albumin:globulin ratio, albumin
    • Increased SDMA, creatinine, urea - with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Urinalysis
    • Mild to severe proteinuria
    • Variably inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity < 1.030)
  • Increased urine protein:creatinine ratio (UPC) - with secondary glomerulonephritis
  • Abnormal coagulation tests and/or decreased platelet function 
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased with systemic inflammation
  • Serum electrophoresis:
    • Typically polyclonal beta and/or gammaglobulinaemia
    • Hypoalbuminaemia
    • Peak may appear as oligoclonal, biclonal, or monoclonal in some cases
  • Quantitative  ELISA antibody tests - can aid in disease staging
    • Antibody levels are usually low in subclinical infection, and high in clinically sick dogs
  • IFA antibody tests - clinically sick dogs typically have high antibody titers (>1:400) that are readibly detectable
  • Leishmania spp. RealPCR:
    • Can be performed on blood, bone marrow, fluid, nasal or conjunctival swabs, urine, synovial fluid or tissues. Quantitative analysis is available for blood, bone marrow, swabs (nasal/ocular), urine or synovial fluid. Qualitative positive PCR results confirm infection, but do not provide information on clinical disease, immunological status or prognosis
    • Quantitative PCR:
      • Medium to high parasitaemia detected by qPCR has a high positive predictive value for the development of clinical disease
      • qPCR can be used to monitor response to treatment - declining parasitaemia can be demonstrated within one month of initiation of effective treatment.

Negative Leishmania Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion
  • Antibody levels below the limit of detection:
    • Strong cellular immune response
    • Immunosuppression
    • Favorable response to treatment

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Leishmania Antibody Test

  • In a dog with clinical signs or history consistent with canine leishmaniasis, consider a Leishmania spp. RealPCR Test:
    • Positive PCR results indicate the presence of Leishmania DNA in the sample submitted.
      • A positive PCR with negative Leishmania Antibody test may occur prior to seroconversion; if the infection is localised to the tissue sample submitted; or if antibody levels are below the limit of infection.
    • Quantitative positive PCR results can provide additional information about this number of organisms within the blood or bone marrow
      • Medium to high parasitaemia has a high positive predictive value for the development of clinical disease.
      • qPCR values can be used to monitor response to treatment - declining parasitaemia can be demonstrated within one month of initiation of effective treatment
    • Negative PCR results indicate that Leishmania DNA was not detected in the sample submitted. 
      • A negative PCR with negative antibody test suggests absence of infection.
      • A negative PCR may also be caused by:
        • Level of parasitaemia below the limit of detection 
        • Decreased numbers of organisms following treatment 
        • Low levels associated with chronic carrier state
        • Localized infection in an organ or site other than the sample submitted.
    • In dogs in endemic areas with consistent clinical signs, an IFA or quantitative ELISA antibody test may detect positive antibody levels below the limit of detection of qualitative antibody tests.

Additional Information

   Leishmaniasis Resource Quick Links:

  • Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of canine leishmaniasis, along with additional resources, are available at www.leishvet.org.

   Physiology

  • Canine leishmaniasis (CanL) is prevalent throughout southern Europe, the Mediterranean, South America, and parts of Africa and Asia. It is also a concern in non-endemic countries due to dog import, travel, and possible non-vector transmission (e.g., mating, vertical transmission, dog-fighting, or blood transfusions)
  • Canine leishmaniasis is an immune-mediated disease where antibody levels correlate with clinical signs. High antibody levels (3 to 4 fold increase above cut-off) are an indication for therapy. 
  • Leishmania infantum is zoonotic and is considered a neglected tropical disease.
  • Felines and other mammals can be infected with Leishmania, but dogs serve as the primary reservoir of infection. 
  • L. infantum is transmitted to the mammalian host via a phlebotomine sand fly vector which transmits the flagellated infective promastigote form.
  • In the mammalian host, the intracellular amatigote form develops and replicates in macrophages.
  • Sand flies (Phlebotomus spp. in the Old World; Lutzomyia spp. in the New World) are the only arthropods that are adapted for biological transmission of Leishmania.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Diagnosis of canine leishmaniasis is supported by detection of Leishmania infantum antibodies either by indirect fluorescent antibodies (IFAT) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA).  
    • Infection with Leishmania spp. does not necessarily indicate disease. Subclinical infections are common and are usually associated with low antibody levels. 
    • Clinically sick dogs typically present with high antibody titers (>1:400) that are readily detectable.
  • Point-of-care antibody tests aid in the diagnosis of dogs with subclinical infection and clinically sick dogs and are useful for differentiating infected from vaccinated animals (DIVA).
  • SNAP Leish 4Dx and SNAP Leishmania tests detect antibodies to the LiDx2 recombinant antigen derived from amastagoes and is based on polypeptides derived from Leishmania infantum immunodominant kinesin antigens. Antibodies are expressed in infected dogs and bind the LiDx2 antigen.
    • SNAP Leish 4Dx:
      • Sensitivity: 98.8% (95% CI: 93.4-100%)
      • Specificity: 98.9% (95% CI: 96.8-100%)
    • SNAP Leishmania:
      • Sensitivity: 98.8% (95% CI: 93.6-100%)
      • Specificity: 98.2% (95% CI: 95.8-99.4%)
  • Indications for testing:
    • Dogs in endemic areas should be screened annually prior to vaccination.
      • Vaccines are recommended annually in endemic areas in conjunction with topical repellants against sand flies.
    • Dogs with consistent clinical signs, especially after travel to endemic areas or those living in endemic areas, should be tested.
    • Dogs imported from endemic areas to non-endemic areas should be screened for evidence of infection.
    • Dogs that have previously tested positive for Leishmania should be monitored routinely with quantitative testing (ELISA or IFAT) for changes in disease status.

 References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Solano-Gallego L, Miro G, Koitinas A, et al. LeishVet guidelines for the practical management of canine leishmaniosis. Parasit Vectors. 2011;4: 86.
  • Practical Management of Canine and Feline Leishmaniosis. https://www.leishvet.org/fact-sheet/ Accessed 8 March 2023.
  • Paltrinieri S, Granodi L, Roura X, et al. Laboratory tests for diagnosing and monitoring canine leishmaniasis. Vet Clin Pathol. 2016;45(4): 552-578.

Last Updated: 29/09/2023
Lyme:
﻿Description:  The Lyme antibody test detects antibodies to C6, a peptide derived from the VlsE outer surface protein of Borrelia burgdorferi.  This protein is only expressed during replication of the organism in the mammalian host, making the test specific for infection with Borrelia burgdorferi.  

Positive Lyme C6 Antibody Test

  • Infection with Borrelia burgdorferi
  • Residual or declining antibody response from a previously cleared/treated infection.

Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Lyme Antibody Test

  • Recommended first steps include assessment of clinical signs, quantification with Lyme Quant C6 antibody test, and a urinalysis to check for protein-loss.  See also the Lyme Disease Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/lyme-disease-next-steps.
  • Assess for clinical signs
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of Lyme disease such as supportive history and physical exam findings (fever, lymphadenopathy, polyarthritis, lethargy, anorexia).
    • Asymptomatic dogs may not have specific hematologic or biochemical changes, but should be monitored for proteinuria or development of clinical signs.
  • Lyme Quant C6 Antibody test:
    • High antibody titer ≥30 U/mL with active infection
    • Moderate antibody titer (10-29 U/mL) may be seen with early infection (rising antibody response) or following treatment of a prior or resolving infection (memory titer).
    • With successful treatment, a convalescent titer is expected to be <50% of initial acute titer
  • Evaluate for evidence of secondary glomerulonephritis:
    • Urinalysis:
      • Proteinuria
      • Variably inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Urine protein:creatinine ratio (UPC) - increased
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus may be seen with secondary tubular damage
    • Blood Pressure - systemic hypertension
  • CBC:
    • Mild normocytic, normochromic non-regenerative anemia
    • Variably decreased reticulocyte-hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased with systemic inflammation
  • Consider a Vector-borne Disease RealPCR panel to evaluate for common co-infections (e.g. Anaplasma spp., Bartonella spp., Babesia spp.)
  • Joint cytology (if signs of shifting leg lameness) - increased mononuclear cell and neutrophil cell counts
  • Evaluate tick prevention strategies and reinforce value of year-round protection.

Negative Lyme C6 Antibody Test

  • Absence of infection
  • Exposure prior to seroconversion

Next Steps and Related Findings for Negative Lyme C6 Antibody Test

  • In a dog with clinical signs or history consistent with Lyme disease or known exposure, consider:
    • Vector-borne disease PCR panel to evaluate for other vector-borne diseases (e.g. Babesia spp., Ehrlichia spp., Bartonella spp.) which may have similar clinical signs.
    • Recheck Lyme Quant C6 Antibody test or SNAP 4Dx Plus test in two to three weeks to look for seroconversion.

Additional Information

   Lyme Disease Resource Quick Links:

  • For more information on the diagnosis and management of Tick/Vector-borne diseases, see www.idexx.com/4DxGuide
  • View the Lyme Disease Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/lyme-disease-next-steps.
  • Learn more and explore the science behind the accurate diagnosis and effective management of Lyme disease at www.idexx.com/facts-about-lyme.
  • Read about the risk of chronic kidney disease in Lyme positive dogs at www.idexx.com/VBD-exposure-and-CKD

   Physiology

  • Borrelia burgdorferi is a spirochete bacterium and is the etiologic agent of Lyme disease.
  • B. burgdorferi is transmitted to the mammalian host via a tick vector (Ixodes spp.).
    • Transmission of the spirochete requires 1-2 days of tick attachment to the host.
    • Several surface proteins (OspA, Osp C, VlsE) allow the spirochete to avoid the host immune response as active infection is established.
  • Dogs diagnosed with Lyme disease most commonly have clinical signs such as polyarthritis, fever, lethargy, anorexia and lymphadenopathy.
  • Onset of clinical signs is typically delayed, occurring weeks to months after initial infection and seroconversion.
  • An acute, progressive protein-losing glomerulopathy has also been associated with Lyme disease.
  • In Lyme endemic areas dogs with antibodies to the C6 peptide of B. burgdorferi had a 43% increased risk of developing CKD.
  • Other less common manifestations of Lyme disease include:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Myocarditis
    • Dermatologic lesions
  • Many dogs are subclinical and do not show clinical signs of disease.
  • Co-infection with other vector borne diseases (Anaplasma phagocytophilum, Babesia microti, Bartonella spp.) is common in dogs with Lyme disease and may be associated with more severe clinical signs.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • The C6 antigen is associated with one of the variable regions of the VlsE outer surface protein of B. burgdorferi organisms.
    • The VlsE surface protein is encoded by the VlsE gene, which has numerous variable regions as well as six constant regions.
    • B. burgdorferi expresses different variable sequences in the VlsE protein over time to evade the host immune response.
    • The VlsE gene is only expressed in the mammalian host (not in the tick or culture grown B. burgdorferi). 
    • The VlsE protein is produced after the organism has been in the mammalian host for 7-21 days.
  • ELISA technology in both the SNAP 4Dx Plus and the Lyme Quant C6 tests is used to detect serum antibodies against the C6 antigen.
    • The SNAP 4Dx Plus test is used as a screening test and can detect very low levels of antibody (<10 U/mL) which increases the sensitivity of this platform.
    • The Lyme Quant C6 test is used to confirm the diagnosis and has a higher specificity.
      • The lower limit of detection of the Lyme Quant C6 antibody test is 10 U/mL.
        • The clinical significance of a titer <10 U/mL is unknown.
      • The results from the Lyme Quant C6 test indicate:
        • <30 U/mL
          • Clinically insignificant titer
          • Early exposure, prior to development of significant amounts of C6 antibodies
          • Residual antibodies from a previously cleared/treated infection
        • ≥30 U/mL
          • Clinically significant titer associated with active infection with Borrelia burgdorferi
          • Post-treatment declining C6 antibody concentration, which generally indicates a response to treatment.
  • C6 antibodies are not produced in response to commercially available Lyme vaccines.
  • Antibodies against the C6 antigen can be detected as early as 3-4 weeks post-infection, prior to most dogs showing clinical signs.
  • Studies have shown that as the amount of C6 antibody rises, more organism can be detected in the tissues of infected dogs.
  • The level of C6 antibody has been shown to correlate with the level of circulating antibody-antigen complexes.
  • The concentration of C6 antibodies decline significantly with successful treatment of Lyme disease.
    • A ≥50% decline in Quant C6 Antibody indicates successful treatment
    • A <50% decline in Quant C6 Antibody indicates concern for treatment failure
      • Non-compliance with treatment (inability of owners to medicate dog)
      • Ineffective antibiotic therapy
      • Re-infection
      • Chronic infection
  • There are multiple strains of Borrelia in Europe, including:  Borrelia burgdorferi, B. garinii and B. afzelii.
    • The prevalence of the three strains varies throughout the continent.
    • B. garinii and B. afzelii are not as well characterized as B. burgdorferi but similar disease manifestations in dogs might be expected with these strains.
    • Co-infection of B. burgdorferi with other B. burgdorferi sensu lato strains (e.g. B. garinii) may predispose dogs to the development clinical illness. 
    • These species may be detected with the Lyme Quant C6 Antibody test although data on these species are limited.

 References

  • Greene, CE ed. Infectious Diseases of the Dog and Cat, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier Saunders; 2012.
  • Levy SA, O'Connor TP, Hanscom LJ, et al. Quantitative measurement of C6 antibody following antibiotic treatment of Borrelia burgdorferi antibody-positive nonclinical dogs. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2008; 15(1): 115-119.
  • Liang FT, Jacobson RH, Straubinger RK et al. Characterization of a Borrelia burgdorferi VlsE invariable region useful in canine Lyme disease serodiagnosis by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. J Clin Microbiol. 2000;38(11): 4160-4166.
  • Littman MP, Goldstein RE, Labato MA, et al.  ACVIM small animal consensus statement on Lyme disease in dogs: Diagnosis, treatment and prevention. J Vet Intern Med 2006; 20: 422-434.
  • O'Connor TP, Esty KJ, Hanscom JL, et al. Dogs vaccinated with common Lyme disease vaccines do not respond to IR6, the conserved immunodominant region of the VlsE surface protein of Borrelia burgdorferi. Clinical and Diagnostic Laboratory Immunology. May 2004.
  • Pantchev N, Pluta S, Huisinga E, et al. Tick-borne diseases (Borreliosis, Anaplasmosis, Babesiosis) in German and Austrian dogs: status quo and review of distribution, transmission, clinical findings, diagnostics and prophylaxis. ﻿Parasitol Res. ﻿2015;114:S19-S54. [EBM-C]

Last Updated: 5/1/2019
MCH:
Description:  Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) is the calculated concentration of hemoglobin per red blood cell irrespective of red blood cell size. The MCH usually parallels the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) value.

 

Decreased MCH
  

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Blood loss
    • Hemolysis
  • Reticulocytosis in absence of anemia
    • Physiologic reticulocytosis - splenic contraction
    • Compensated anemia
    • Absolute erythrocytosis
  • Decreased hemoglobin production
    • Chronic blood loss with decreased iron stores
    • Copper deficiency
    • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased MCH

 

  • Regenerative anemia:
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit and MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Reticulocytosis in absence of anemia
    • Physiologic reticylocytosis - most often due to splenic contraction (dogs only)
      • CBC - normal RBC, hematocrit, MCV and RDW
    • Compensated anemia - regeneration of RBCs is keeping up with RBC loss or destruction
      • CBC:
        • RBC and hematocrit at low end of normal
        • MCV and RDW increased
        • Decreased MCHC
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Absolute erythrocytosis
      • CBC:
        • High normal to increased hematocrit
        • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
      • Endocrine
        • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
        • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
          • Hyperthyroidism
          • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
          • Acromegaly
      • Secondary polycythemia
        • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
        • Systemic hypoxia:
          • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
          • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
          • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
          • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
        • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
          • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
          • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera
        • CBC:
          • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
          • Variably increased platelets
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
        • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
        • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion
  • Decreased hemoglobin production
    • Most commonly seen with decreased iron stores associated with nonregenerative anemia due to chronic blood loss
    • Chronic blood loss - causing iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC and hematocrit
        • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration

 

Increased MCH

 

  • Artifact
    • Hemolysis (in vitro)
    • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Hemoglobin derivatives (e.g. Oxyglobin)

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased MCH

  • Severe hemolysis may result in an inability to read RBC parameters.
  • Hemolysis (in vitro)
    • Hemolysis can be an artifact of collection or can be seen post-collection secondary to severe lipemia
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, RDW (unless severe), MCV
      • Absence of reticulocytes
    • Chemistry - increased serum triglycerides causing lipemia
  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit and MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) is the calculated concentration of hemoglobin per red blood cell.
  • Hemoglobin is a large globular protein that is composed of two alpha chains and two beta chains for a total of four iron-containing heme groups bound to four globulin chains.
  • Hemoglobin gives blood its characteristic red color and (as oxyhemoglobin) is responsible for oxygen transport by the red blood cells.
  • Hemoglobin measurements are the most direct indication of oxygen transport capacity of blood in a patient.
  • Neither changes in red blood cell size nor in vitro hemolysis will alter the hemoglobin concentration, although both HCT and PCV may be affected.
  • Hemoglobin is not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • A true increase in MCH is not possible as cells cannot contain an increased amount of hemoglobin.
  • The MCH usually parallels the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) value is determined by the equation:  MCH = (Hemoglobin/RBC) x 10.
  • The MCH is expressed as picograms (pg) of hemoglobin (per average red cell).
  • The MCH may be affected by cell size (MCV); however MCHC corrects for cell volume and should be used for classification of anemia if different from the MCH value.

  

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018

    • Compensated anemia

    • Chronic blood loss with decreased iron stores

    • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency

        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram

    • Absolute erythrocytosis

        • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:

      • Polycythemia vera:

          • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
          • Variably increased platelets
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity

  • Decreased hemoglobin production
    • Most commonly seen with decreased iron stores associated with nonregenerative anemia due to chronic blood loss

        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration

 

Increased MCHC

  • Artifact
    • Hemolysis (in vitro)
    • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Hemoglobin derivatives (e.g. Oxyglobin)

   Related Findings

 

  • Severe hemolysis may result in an inability to read RBC parameters.
  • Hemolysis (in vitro)
    • Hemolysis can be an artifact of collection or can be seen post-collection secondary to severe lipemia
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, RDW (unless severe), MCV
      • Absence of reticulocytes
    • Chemistry - increased serum triglycerides causing lipemia
  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit and MCHC
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
             

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is the calculated concentration of hemoglobin in a specific volume of red blood cells.
  • Hemoglobin is a large globular protein that is composed of two alpha chains and two beta chains for a total of four iron-containing heme groups bound to four globulin chains.
  • Hemoglobin gives blood its characteristic red color and (as oxyhemoglobin) is responsible for oxygen transport by the red blood cells.
  • Cels cannot contain an increased amount of hemoglobin so a true increase in MCHC is not possible.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is the ratio of the weight of hemoglobin to the volume of the erythrocyte and is expressed as either a percentage or in grams per deciliter of red cells (g/dL).
  • The MCHC is classically determined by the equation:  MCHC = (HGB/HCT) x 100.
  • The MCHC value from an automated hematology analyzer is based on all three red blood cell parameters (hemoglobin, RBC and MCV) and is affected by an abnormality in any one of these measurements. Automated equipment often calculates the hematocrit from the RBC and MCV values, RBC being directly measured and MCV typically calculated.
  • Since MCHC is the mean value of the hemoglobin in all the red cells, it is a relatively insensitive test. Multiple processes that affect the MCHC may be off-setting and result in a mean value within the reference interval. (e.g. A reticulocytosis which decreases the MCHC may be counterbalanced by hemolysis which increases the MCHC.)
  • MCHC corrects for cell volume (size) and should be used for classification of anemia, if different from the MCH value.
       

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

MCV:
Description: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) is a measure of the average size of the red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Decreased MCV (Microcytosis)

 

  • Iron deficiency
    • Chronic blood loss
  • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt
  • Asian dog breed microcytosis
  • Young animals typically have lower MCVs than adults
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency
  • Low serum sodium
  • Abnormal red blood cell morphology due to various systemic causes
    • Fragmented red blood cells
    • Spherocytes

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased MCV

  • Iron deficiency
    • Most commonly seen with decreased iron stores associated with nonregenerative anemia due to chronic blood loss.
    • Chronic blood loss - causing iron deficiency
      • CBC: 
        • Decreased RBC and hematocrit
        • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Thrombocytosis
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with PSS
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acathocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased (or decreased) ALT, ALP
      • Variably increased bilirubin (not seen with PSS)
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol, glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity is variable, may be inappropriate (USG < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats) due to altered thirst and/or low BUN
      • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
      • Bilirubinuria (not seen with PSS)
    • Increased bile acids
    • Increased ammonia
  • Asian dog breed microcytosis:
    • Commonly reported in Akitas
    • Variably expressed in Shiba Inu, Jindo, Tosa, Chow Chow, Shar Pei
    • CBC - normal RBC, MCHC, MCH and reticulocytes

Increased MCV (Macrocytosis)

 

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Blood loss
    • Hemolysis
  • Myelodysplasic disorders, including FeLV infection
  • Artifact
    • Agglutination of RBCs
    • Cell swelling
      • Aged samples
      • Short samples (low blood to EDTA ratio)
  • Hereditary macrocytosis of Poodles

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased MCV

 

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin and MCH
        • Increased RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulcoyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • FeLV - positive antigen or PCR on peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Artifact:
    • RBC agglutination on blood film review and confirmed with saline agglutination

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

  • Red cell production requires adequate RBC precursors in the bone marrow and stimulation by erythropoietin. During normal maturation, red blood cells reduce in size as the nucleus is extruded. Red cell size or volume corresponds to maturity: younger, less mature cells are typically larger.
  • An increased MCV is commonly associated with increased erythropoiesis, typically in response to anemia or hypoxic stimulus, as more immature, polychromatophilic cells exit the bone marrow (excepting the horse).
  • In horses, increased MCV is the primary evidence for erythroid regeneration.
  • In dogs and cats, macrocytosis (increased MCV) without other evidence of regeneration (polychromasia, reticulocytosis) suggests bone marrow dysplasia or myeloproliferative disease.
  • The calculated MCV represents an average of all red cells, so the influence of individual cell populations of larger and smaller cells may be offset, as may occur with progressive iron deficiency when RBC regeneration diminishes and smaller, microcytic cells begin to predominate over time.

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Most automated hematology analyzers calculate the MCV using measured hematocrit and RBC counts using the formula: MCV(fl) = hematocrit/RBC
  • Traditionally, MCV was calculated with the equation: PCV x 10/RBC

 

  References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

MG:
Description: Magnesium is primarily an intracellular cation that is important in many enzymatic reactions.  Knowledge of magnesium concentrations is most beneficial in critically ill patients but can be useful in patients with gastrointestinal disease.

Decreased Magnesium

 

  • Hypoproteinemia
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Malabsorption (decreased uptake)
    • Secretory diarrhea (increased loss, e.g. severe colitis)
  • Malnutrition (e.g. dietary deficiency)
  • Kidney disease leading to high urine output
    • Acute kidney injury
    • Nephrotoxins (e.g. aminoglycocides, cisplatin, amphotericin B)
    • Post-obstructive diuresis
    • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Shifts from the extracellular to the intracellular space
    • Therapy for diabetic ketoacidosis (e.g. insulin, bicarbonate)
  • Endocrine disease:
    • Primary hypoparathyroidism
    • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Blister beetle poisoning (horses)
  • Lactation tetany (Shetland mares)
    • Excessive loss from lactation is also possible in dogs

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Magnesium

 

  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), elevated SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and phosphorus
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
  • Acute pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin and potassium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
    • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hypoparathyroidism
    • Chemistry:
      • High normal to increased phosphorus
      • Decreased ionized calcium
    • Parathyroid hormone - decreased

 

Increased Magnesium

 

  • Kidney disease
  • Urinary obstruction
  • Increased intake (e.g. antacids, laxatives, IV infusion of magnesium containing fluids)
  • Thoracic neoplasia and pleural effusion (cats)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Magnesium

 

  • Kidney Disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), elevated SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and phosphorus
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
        • Infectious kidney diseases:
          • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
            • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
            • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Urinary obstruction
    • If urinary obstruction is suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Increased potassium with complete urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones) or rupture.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Magnesium is present in both ionized and protein-bound forms.  The ionized (Mg2+) form is the biologically active form.
  • 40-50% of the ion is intracellular.  

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 5th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2012.

MONO:
Description: Monocytes are white blood cells that are responsible for phagocytosis, antigen presentation, and production of cytokines.

Increased Monocytes 

  •   Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced monocytosis
  • Chronic or acute monocytic/myelomonocytic leukemia
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia  

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Monocytes

  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophilia with toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs- positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
     Corticosteroid-induced monocytosis
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils
      • Absence of a left shift 
      • +/-increased platelets, RBC
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Monocytes are the largest cells (typically 15-20 µm in diameter) present in normal peripheral blood.
  • They have abundant blue-gray cytoplasm, often with multiple, variably-sized clear vacuoles.  Their nuclei may be oval, kidney bean-shaped, or convoluted.  The nuclear chromatin is finely granular to lacy, with only a few clumped areas.
  • Monocytes arise in the bone marrow, circulate, then differentiate into tissue macrophages after they leave the peripheral blood vasculature.  They do not recirculate.
  • Their main functions include phagocytosis of infectious agents and particulate matter, production of mediators that promote blood cell production (hemopoiesis), and release of inflammatory mediators.
  • They produce cytokines important for immunoregulation and present foreign substances to immunocompetent lymphocytes.
  • Monocytes also differentiate into many types of tissue macrophages (e.g. Kupffer cells in the liver).
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The monocyte percentage (or relative monocyte count) is the number of monocytes (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute monocyte count is calculated by multiplying the monocyte percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of monocyte abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

  

References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Reagan WJ, Irizarry Rovira AR, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology Atlas of Common Domestic and Non-Domestic Species, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Wiley-Blackwell; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

MPV:
Description:  The mean platelet volume (MPV) is a measure of the average size or volume of the platelets

 

Decreased MPV

 

  • Decreased platelet production
    • Bone marrow suppression
  • Pre-regenerative immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP) with microplatelets
    • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia
    • Secondary ITP
      • Infection
      • Neoplasia
      • Systemic immune-mediated disease
      • Drugs/vaccines

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased MPV

 

  • Decreased production of platelets
    • Assess for history of exposure to drugs, e.g.
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (exogenous or endogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Leukopenia
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of megakaryocytes or other changes

 

Increased MPV

 

  • Increased platelet production
    • Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP)
      • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia
      • Secondary ITP
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Inflammation
      • Infection
      • Immune-mediated
      • Surgery
      • Trauma
    • Non-hemopoeitic neoplasia
    • Iron deficiency
      • Chronic blood loss
    • Rebound
      • Recovery from thrombocytopenia
      • Following significant anemia (secondary effect of erythropoietin)
    • Corticosteroid-induced 
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
      • Exogenous steroids
      • Stress
    • Chemotherapy (vincristine, vinblastine)
    • Post-splenectomy
    • Reactive thrombocytosis
    • Hemic neoplasia (clonal thrombocytosis)
      • Primary (essential) thrombocytosis
      • Chronic myeloproliferative disease
        • Polycythemia vera
        • Primary erythrocytosis
        • Chronic myeloid leukemia
      • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia
      • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Breed-related macrothrombocytopenia (giant platelet disorder)
  • Artifact - prolonged exposure (>24 hrs) to EDTA can cause platelet swelling

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased MPV

 

  • Increased platelet production - resulting in release of large platelets
    • Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP)
      • CBC:
        • Thrombocytopenia is typically severe; platelet counts below 50,000/uL
        • Decreased plateletcrit (PCT)
        • Increased PDW
        • Variable regenerative anemia with blood loss or concurrent immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary ITP:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis, Leishmania spp., Angiostrongylus vasorum, leptospirosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
    • Inflammation
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia - with chronic inflammation
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and PDW
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) increased
    • Iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Variable anemia, with microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) developing with progression
        • Reticulocytes - initially may be elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and PDW
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Rebound thrombocytosis
      • CBC:
        • Regenerative anemia
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and PDW
        • Large platelets observed on blood film or RBC dot plot
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and PDW
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
        • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
          • ACTH stimulation
  • Breed-related thrombocytopenia (giant platelet disorder)
    • Present in up to 50% of Cavalier King Charles Spaniels (CKCS). Identical genetic defect has also been identified less commonly in many other breeds.
    • History of persistently low platelets without evidence of abnormal bleeding, petechiae or ecchymoses
    • CBC:
      • Low normal to mildly decreased platelet count
      • Normal to increased plateletcrit (PCT)
      • Large platelets observed on blood film review
      • RBC dot plot shows a shift in platelet population up and to the right
      • CKCS Macrothrombocytopenia DNA test positive for beta-1 tubulin mutation
        • Note: DNA test can also be performed on breeds other than CKCS
            

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

  • An increased MPV is commonly associated with the early release of large platelets from the bone marrow as part of a regenerative thrombopoeitic response.
  • The MPV is usually inversely proportional to the platelet count.
  • Platelet production requires presence of adequate megakaryocytes in the bone marrow (megakaryopoiesis) and normal formation and delivery of platelets to the circulation (thrombopoiesis).
  • In situations with inadequate megakaryopoeisis and thrombopoeisis, the MPV may be decreased.
  • In immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, large platelets may be present due to thrombopoeisis, but the concurrent presence of microplatelets (platelet particles) may offset these, resulting in a normal or low MPV.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Some automated analyzers may measure platelet volume (MPV) directly with proprietary laser or impedance technologies.
  • Indirect methods performed at IDEXX Reference Laboratories and with the IDEXX ProCyte Dx calculate MPV using the equation:
MPV (fL) = (Plateletcrit [%] / Platelet count [103/uL]) x 10000
