NEU:
Description: Segmented neutrophils are the most abundant type of white blood cell (WBC). They respond quickly to inflammation and stress, are capable of phagocytosis, and have antimicrobial properties.

 

Decreased Neutrophils

  • Decreased neutrophil production (bone marrow suppression)
    • Infection
    • Drugs/toxins
    • Immune-mediated destruction (targeting neutrophil precursors)
    • Bone marrow disease
    • Cyclic hemopoiesis - Grey Collie Syndrome
    • Neutropenia of Giant Schnauzers (secondary to vitamin B12 malabsorption)
    • Idiopathic
  • Excessive tissue demand and/or destruction of neutrophils
    • Endotoxemia/sepsis
    • Inflammation
    • Bacterial infection  
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Neutrophils

 

  • Decreased neutrophil production
    • CBC may show decreases in other cell lines:
      • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Thrombocytopenia
    • Assess for history or possibility of exposure to drugs that may suppress bone marrow, e.g.: 
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Azathioprine
      • Chloramphenicol
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Methimazole
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy shows decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of myeloid cell line or other changes.
    • Next steps to evaluate for infectious causes:
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Blood film review - toxic neutrophils, band neutrophils or reactive lymphocytes may be seen 
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Positive serology or PCR tests for infectious diseases (e.g. parvovirus, panleukopenia, FeLV, FIV, ehrlichiosis)
    • Idiopathic neutropenia is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Excessive tissue demand (and destruction) of neutrophils
    • Migration into tissues in response to endotoxin, inflammation or infection where the rate of migration exceeds the rate of replacement from the bone marrow.
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review:
        • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils, toxic neutrophils may be seen 
        • Red blood cell fragments (e.g. schistocytes, poikilocytes) may be seen with secondary disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP) 
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for effusion, localized inflammation or infection where neutrophils may be sequestered
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
      • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria

 

Increased Neutrophils 

  

  • Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia (stress leukogram)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • Granulocytic leukemia 
    • Chronic myeloid leukemia
    • Acute myeloid leukemia
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic neutrophilia
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Neutrophils

 

  • Evaluate for the presence of immature neutrophils (bands):
    • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) may show a band indictator.
    • Comparison of patient WBC dot plot to species-specific normals may show pattern changes consistent with the presence of bands. 
      • For example, in the IDEXX ProCyte Dx, the WBC dot plot shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population if bands are present.
    • Blood film review
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophils have toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Increased monocytes and neutrophils
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile -variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases: 
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia:
        • Non-myeloid neoplasia can result in neutrophilia in response to secondary inflammation or as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with release of G-CSF.
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • +/- increased platelets, RBC
      • Increased monocytes 
      • Absence of a left shift 
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response 
    • CBC:
      • Increased lymphocytes and neutrophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Segmented neutrophils are the mature neutrophils that form the largest portion of the WBC count in domestic animals.
  • Neutrophils are only in the peripheral blood for approximately ten hours before exiting the vascular system, either from normal cell death or in response to chemotactic factors.
  • Neutrophils are quickly activated and increase in number in response to a myriad of stimuli, such as infecting agents (viral, bacterial, fungal, parasitic, etc), foreign substances, tissue damage, necrosis, and cancers.
  • Neutrophils exist in two main pools in the peripheral blood: those freely floating in circulation (circulating neutrophil pool or CNP) and those adhered to the endothelium (marginated neutrophil pool or MNP); only the neutrophils in the CNP are measured on a CBC.
  • Neutrophils can be recruited from the MNP within minutes (e.g. in response to stress) and will then increase the neutrophil count
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The segmented neutrophil percentage (or relative segmented neutrophil count) is the number of segmented neutrophils (typically per 100 to 200 white blood cells) and is reported as a percentage.
  • The absolute neutrophil count is calculated by multiplying the neutrophil percentage by the total white blood cell count.
  • Absolute cell counts for white blood cells are considered more clinically relevant than the reported percentages because they reflect the patient's functional capacity, which is extremely important when cell counts are extreme, rather than their relative contribution.
  • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX ProCyte Dx) show a band indicator when bands may be present, indicating the need to evaluate the WBC dot plot and/or perform a blood film review.
  • Evaluation of the WBC dot plot can provide valuable information about the presence of immature neutrophils (bands), platelet clumping or morphologic abnormalities which may impact the automated white blood cell differential. 
  • Morphology evaluation may provide valuable clues to the potential causes of neutrophil abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).
      

   References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Reagan WJ, Irizarry Rovira AR, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology Atlas of Common Domestic and Non-Domestic Species, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Wiley-Blackwell; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
     

Last updated 7/1/2018

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Reagan WJ, Irizarry Rovira AR, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology Atlas of Common Domestic and Non-Domestic Species, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Wiley-Blackwell; 2008.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

NRBC:
Description: Nucleated red blood cells (metarubricytes) are nucleated RBC precursors. NRBCs can be an indicator of regenerative anemia, splenic disease or diseases of the bone marrow.

Increased Nucleated RBCs
   

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Hemolysis
    • Blood loss
  • Splenic disease
  • Post-splenectomy
  • Bone marrow disease
    • Leukemia
    • Myelodysplasia
    • Myelofibrosis
    • Bone marrow damage
  • Breed related increases (slight) noted in some Minature Schnauzers and Dachshunds
  • Extramedullary hematopoiesis, especially splenic
  • Lead poisoning
  • Iron or copper deficiency
  • Hereditary macrocytosis of Poodles
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Nucleated RBCs

 

  • Regenerative Anemia:
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, MCHC, MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Splenic disease
    • History of splenectomy or other splenic disorders
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin and RDW
      • Blood film review - variable abnormal RBC morphology (e.g. schistocytes, keratocytes or acanthocytes)
    • Abdominal imaging to assess for splenomegaly, splenic mass, evidence of splenic infiltration or absence of spleen
    • Cytology or histopathology of spleen to confirm splenic disease, e.g. neoplasia or splenitis
  • Bone marrow disease:
    • CBC: 
      • Increased or decreased cell lines, depending on cause
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, disordered maturation, neoplastic infiltration, myelofibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Nucleated red blood cells are nucleated precursors to mature red blood cells found in circulation, produced primarily in the bone marrow.
  • Their presence in peripheral blood may be associated with a regenerative anemia or due to pathologic conditions affecting release or gating of red blood cells by the reticuloendothelial system, including bone marrow and spleen.
  • Moderate to significant increases in nucleated RBCs have been associated with severe hematopoietic conditions and poor prognosis, e.g. heat stroke and regenerative anemia.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Many automated analyzers count circulating nucleated red blood cells along with white blood cells as part of the white blood cell count due to their similarity of cellular and nuclear size. Newer analyzers may utilize specific reagents to count nucleated RBCs with fluorescent flow cytometry.
  • Manual blood film review is used to count the number of nucleated RBCs per 100 white blood cells to determine a corrected white blood cell count.
  • The correction is performed using this equation: Corrected WBC count = (WBC count [obtained by machine] x 100)/ (# NRBC [obtained during 100 cell differential count] + 100)
       

   References

 

  • Aroch I, Segev G, Loeb E, et al.  Peripheral nucleated red blood cells as a prognostic indicator heatstroke in dogs.  JVIM 2009; 23(3):  544-51.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

Na:
Description: Sodium is the most abundant cation in the extracellular fluid.  It is partially responsible for the regulation of fluid volume within the blood stream.  Sodium also is important for nerve and muscle function.


Decreased Sodium

 

  • Decreased effective blood volume (with compensatory water retention)
    • Gastrointestinal loss
      • Diarrhea/vomiting
      • Whipworm infection
      • Excessive salivation
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Blood loss
    • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Fluid sequestration (third spacing)
      • Abdominal effusion
      • Pleural effusion
      • Ruptured bladder
    • Cutaneous losses through excessive sweating (horses)
  • Increased circulating blood volume
    • Congestive heart failure (with edema)
    • Liver failure (with ascites)
    • Nephrotic syndrome (with effusion or edema)
  • Artifact (pseudonhyponatremia)
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Hyperproteinemia
    • Hyperglycemia
  • Normal circulating blood volume
    • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • Kidney disease
    • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Sodium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Increased potassium
          • Decreased Na:K ratio
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • CBC unremarkable
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • Decreased sodium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment exam
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Serum osmolality - decreased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • Leptospirosis screening - negative
    • Ability to concentrate with water restriction is variable secondary to medullary washout and loss of concentrating gradient. 
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient. 

 

Increased Sodium

 

  • Fluid losses where water loss > electrolyte loss
    • Gastrointestinal (acute diarrhea, vomiting, phosphate enemas)
    • Osmotic diuresis
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Kidney disease
      • Diuretic therapy
  • Pure water loss without replacement
    • Insensible losses (e.g. fever/hyperthermia, panting, hyperventilation)
    • Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic)
  • Inadequate water intake
    • Water deprivation
    • Adipsia/hypodipsia/defective thirst response
      • Syndrome in cats and Miniature Schnauzers
      • Central nervous system disease
  • Sodium excess (in face of water restriction)
    • Hypertonic fluid administration (e.g. sodium bicarbonate, hypertonic saline)
    • Increased intake (e.g. paint ball toxicosis, salt water intake)
    • Hyperaldosteronism

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Sodium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
  • Pure water loss or inadequate water intake
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Serum sodium levels depend on regulation of blood volume and plasma osmolality
  • Hyponatremia suggests hypoosmolality
  • Hypernatremia suggests hyperosmolality

  

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Ion-selective electrode is the most common measurement technique

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss LB, eds. Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 5th ed. San Diego, CA: Academic Press; 1997.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
Na/K:
Description: The ratio of sodium to potassium in the peripheral blood is often used as an indicator of hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease).

Decreased Na: K Ratio
    

  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Diabetes mellitus with ketonuria
  • Gastrointestinal disease (e.g. whipworms, Salmonella, gastrointestinal sodium loss)
  • Acute anuric or oliguric kidney failure
  • Urinary obstruction or rupture
  • Third-space fluid/chyle loss or drainage
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Na: K Ratio

  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Gastrointestinal disease
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel - for infectious causes, e.g. Salmonella
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Decreased Na:K ratio and sodium
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test
  • Acute kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (polyuria, polydipsia, exposure to renal toxins), increased SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis - urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
      • Infectious renal diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease):
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
  • Assess for confounding conditions:
    • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status.
  • Urinary obstruction or rupture
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Crystalluria (crystals may not reflect urolith composition)
      • Active urinary sediment (pyuria, bacteriuria, casts, hematuria)
    • Uroabdomen
      • Abdominal fluid has higher creatinine concentrations than serum
      • Contrast radiographs for urinary tract rupture and leakage
    • Abdominal ultrasound for evidence of obstruction or rupture and to identify masses, stones, other causes of obstruction in the urinary tract.

Additional Information

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

Na01:
Description: Sodium is the most abundant cation in the extracellular fluid.  It is partially responsible for the regulation of fluid volume within the blood stream.  Sodium also is important for nerve and muscle function.


Decreased Sodium

 

  • Decreased effective blood volume (with compensatory water retention)
    • Gastrointestinal loss
      • Diarrhea/vomiting
      • Whipworm infection
      • Excessive salivation
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Blood loss
    • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Fluid sequestration (third spacing)
      • Abdominal effusion
      • Pleural effusion
      • Ruptured bladder
    • Cutaneous losses through excessive sweating (horses)
  • Increased circulating blood volume
    • Congestive heart failure (with edema)
    • Liver failure (with ascites)
    • Nephrotic syndrome (with effusion or edema)
  • Artifact (pseudonhyponatremia)
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Hyperproteinemia
    • Hyperglycemia
  • Normal circulating blood volume
    • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • Kidney disease
    • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Sodium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Increased potassium
          • Decreased Na:K ratio
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • CBC unremarkable
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • Decreased sodium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment exam
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Serum osmolality - decreased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • Leptospirosis screening - negative
    • Ability to concentrate with water restriction is variable secondary to medullary washout and loss of concentrating gradient. 
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient. 

 

Increased Sodium

 

  • Fluid losses where water loss > electrolyte loss
    • Gastrointestinal (acute diarrhea, vomiting, phosphate enemas)
    • Osmotic diuresis
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Kidney disease
      • Diuretic therapy
  • Pure water loss without replacement
    • Insensible losses (e.g. fever/hyperthermia, panting, hyperventilation)
    • Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic)
  • Inadequate water intake
    • Water deprivation
    • Adipsia/hypodipsia/defective thirst response
      • Syndrome in cats and Miniature Schnauzers
      • Central nervous system disease
  • Sodium excess (in face of water restriction)
    • Hypertonic fluid administration (e.g. sodium bicarbonate, hypertonic saline)
    • Increased intake (e.g. paint ball toxicosis, salt water intake)
    • Hyperaldosteronism

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Sodium

 

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
  • Pure water loss or inadequate water intake
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Serum sodium levels depend on regulation of blood volume and plasma osmolality
  • Hyponatremia suggests hypoosmolality
  • Hypernatremia suggests hyperosmolality

  

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Ion-selective electrode is the most common measurement technique

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss LB, eds. Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 5th ed. San Diego, CA: Academic Press; 1997.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

PCT:
Description: Plateletcrit (PCT) is the percentage of blood volume filled by platelets and represents the circulating platelet mass. Normal or increased PCT in patients with decreased platelet counts reflects increased platelet size (MPV) associated with platelet recovery or congenital conditions, and may be a clinical indicator of reduced bleeding risk.

Decreased Plateletcrit

  • Artifact (most common cause)
    • Platelet clumping
    • Clots in specimen tube 
  • Immune-mediated platelet destruction
    • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP)
    • Secondary ITP
      • Infection
      • Neoplasia
      • Systemic immune-mediated disease
      • Drugs/vaccines
  • Increased platelet consumption
    • Blood loss, acute and severe
    • Localized intravascular coagulation
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia
    • Post-transfusion purpura
    • Envenomation
    • Vasculitis/endocarditis
  • Decreased platelet production
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Immune-mediated (targeting megakaryocytes)
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia
    • Greyhounds - normal reference interval is lower than other breeds 
    • Endotoxemia
    • Hypophosphatemia
    • Anaphylaxis
    • Sequestration (rarely causes clinically relevant disease)

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Plateletcrit

 

  • Artifact
    • Evaluate a freshly prepared blood film and/or dot plots for evidence of platelet clumping
      • Platelet clumps are often found along the feathered edge on blood film
      • Comparison of patient RBC and WBC dot plots to species-specific normals may show pattern changes suggestive of platelet clumping
        • Smaller platelet clumps may result in a shift in position of the platelet population on the RBC run up and to the right.
        • Larger platelet clumps may appear on the WBC run as pale blue (LaserCyte Dx) or orange (ProCyte Dx) populations starting from the lower left and crossing the white blood cell populating in an upward angle.
    • Platelet clumps may interfere wtih the measurement of platelet indices (MPV, PDW) and plateletcrit
    • Recheck platelets on a freshly-drawn specimen
  • Immune-mediated platelet destruction
    • CBC:
      • Thrombocytopenia is typically severe; platelet counts below 50,000/uL
      • Increased PDW and MPV with regenerative thrombocytosis resulting in release of large platelets
      • Variable regenerative anemia with blood loss or concurrent immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary ITP:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis, Leishmania spp., Angiostrongylus vasorum, leptospirosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Increased consumption of platelets
    • Typically, mild to moderately decreased platelets
    • Acute, severe blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Anemia may be pre-regenerative with normal reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased total protein
      • Hypovolemia and shock may be noted on physical exam
    • Localized intravascular coagulation
      • Pulmonary thromboembolism
        • Thoracic radiographs may be normal or may show evidence of pulmonary hypertension, interstitial or alveolar pulmonary pattern or pleural effusion
        • Blood gas:
          • Hypoxemia
          • Metabolic acidosis
          • Increased alveolar-arterial gradient
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Aortic thromboembolism (saddle thrombus)
        • Decreased perfusion and pulses in affected limb
        • Elevated Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Hemangiosarcoma:
        • May cause both localized intravascular coagulation within the spleen or liver and systemic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • Abdominal imaging to check for splenic or liver mass(es) or loss of detail due to hemorrhage within abdomen
        • Thoracic imaging to assess for cardiomegaly and pericardial effusioon associated with cardiac hemangiosarcoma
      • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • CBC:
          • Blood film review - evidence of red blood cell fragmentation such as schistocytes or poikilocytosis
        • Coagulation profile:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Increased d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
          • Decreased fibrinogen
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of DIC (systemic inflammation, infection, neoplasia)
          • Increased C-reactive protein
          • Positive blood or urine culture
          • Positive Spec cPL or Spec fPL test with acute pancreatitis
          • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
  • Decreased platelet production
    • Assess history for exposuire to drugs, e.g.
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Leukopenia
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of megakaryocytes or other changes

 

Increased Plateletcrit

 

  • Increased platelet production
    • Inflammation
      • Infection
      • Immune-mediated 
      • Surgery
      • Trauma
    • Non-hematopoietic neoplasia
    • Iron deficiency
      • Chronic low grade blood loss
    • Rebound
      • Recovery from thrombocytopenia
      • Following significant anemia (secondary effect of erythropoietin)
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
      • Exogenous steroids
      • Stress
    • Chemotherapy (vincristine, vinblastine)
    • Post-splenectomy
    • Reactive thrombocytosis
    • Hemic neoplasia (clonal thrombocytosis)
      • Primary (essential) thrombocytosis
      • Chronic myeloproliferative disease
        • Polycythemia vera
        • Primary erythrocytosis
        • Chronic myeloid leukemia
      • Acute megakaryocytic leukemia
      • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Redistribution
    • Exercise
    • Epinephrine

   

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Plateletcrit

  • Increased platelet production:
    • Inflammation
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia - with chronic inflammation
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased platelets, MPV and PDW
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) increased
    • Iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Variable anemia, with microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) developing with progression
        • Reticulocytes - initially may be elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased platelets, MPV and PDW
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Rebound thrombocytosis
      • CBC:
        • Regenerative anemia
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Increased platelets, MPV and PDW
        • Large platelets observed on blood film or RBC dot plot
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased platelets, MPV and PDW
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
        • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
        • ACTH stimulation
  • Platelet redistribution
    • CBC:
      • Increased platelets
      • Normal PDW and MPV

 

Additional Information

 

    Physiology

  • The main function of platelets is formation of the hemostatic plug (clot) in primary hemostasis.
  • The platelecrit (PCT) has been proposed as a better representation of the total functional platelet potential and stimulus for thrombopoeisis than the platelet count.
  • Normal or increased PCT in patients with decreased platelet counts reflects increased platelet size (MPV) associated with platelet recovery or congenital conditions, and may be a clinical indicator of reduced bleeding risk.
  • Patients with a normal PCT may be less likely to show clinical bleeding tendency despite a significantly reduced platelet count, e.g. Cavalier King Charles spaniels with increased MPV due to congenital macrothrombocytopenia.
  • In canine patients responding to treatment for ITP, PCT returns to normal more rapidly than the platelet count; however the relationship with size is complex. MPV and PCT could vary during the clinical course of disease, being decreased or normal before the regenerative response is noted.

  Diagnostic Methodology:

  • Plateletcrit can be measured directly by impedance technology on some automated analyzers or may be calculated indirectly from the MPV and platelet count.

  

  References

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 6th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2005.
  • Kelly J, Sharkey LC, Christopherson PW et al. Platelet count and plateletcrit in Cavalier King Charles Spaniels and Greyhounds using the Advia 120 and 2120. Vet Clin Pathol 2014;43(1):43-49.
  • Kuter DJ The physiology of platelet production. Stem Cells 1996;14(Suppl 1):88-101.
  • Lattimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Schwartz D, Sharkey L, Armstrong PJ, et al. Platelet volume and plateletcrit in dogs with presumed primary immune-mediated thrombocytopenia. J Vet Intern Med. 2014;28(5):1575-1579.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Thrall MA, Baker DC, Campbell TW, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry:  Text and Clinical Case Presentation.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2006.
  • Zaldi'var-Lopez S, Marion LM, Iazbik MC, et al. Clinical pathology of Greyhounds and other sighthounds. Vet Clin Path 2011;40(4):414-425.

PDW:
Description:  Platelet distribution width (PDW) is a measure of the variability in size of the platelets. An increased PDW suggests presence of either large platelets (commonly seen in association with thrombopoiesis) or microplatelets.

 

Increased PDW

 

  • Increased PDW due to presence of large platelets (increased MPV)
    • Increased platelet production
      • Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (IMT)
        • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia
        • Secondary ITP
          • Infection
          • Neoplasia
          • Systemic immune-mediated disease
          • Drugs/vaccines
      • Inflammation
        • Infection
        • Immune-mediated
        • Surgery
        • Trauma
      • Non-hemopoeitic neoplasia
      • Iron deficiency
        • Chronic low grade blood loss
      • Rebound
        • Recovery from thrombocytopenia
        • Following significant anemia (secondary effect of erythropoietin)
      • Corticosteroid-induced
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
        • Exogenous steroids
        • Stress
      • Chemotherapy (vincristine, vinblastine)
      • Post-splenectomy
      • Reactive thrombocytosis
      • Hemic neoplasia (clonal thrombocytosis)
        • Primary (essential) thrombocytosis
        • Chronic myeloproliferative disease
          • Polycythemia vera
          • Primary erythrocytosis
          • Chronic myeloid leukemia
        • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia
        • Myelodysplastic syndrome
    • Artifact - prolonged exposure (>24 hours) to EDTA can cause platelet swelling
  • Increased PDW due to the presence of platelet fragments or microplatelets (decreased MPV)
    • Decreased platelet production
      • Insufficient megakaryocytic response
      • Bone marrow aplasia
    • Pre-regenerative early immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP) with microplatelets
      • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia
      • Secondary ITP
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased PDW

 

  • Increased platelet production - resulting in release of large platelets
    • Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP)
      • CBC:
        • Thrombocytopenia is typically severe; platelet counts below 50,000/uL
        • Decreased plateletcrit (PCT)
        • Increased MPV
        • Variable regenerative anemia with blood loss or concurrent immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary ITP:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis, Leishmania spp., Angiostrongylus vasorum, leptospirosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
    • Inflammation
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia - with chronic inflammation
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and MPV
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) increased
    • Iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Variable anemia, with microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) developing with progression
        • Reticulocytes - initially may be elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and MPV
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Rebound thrombocytosis
      • CBC:
        • Regenerative anemia
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and MPV
        • Large platelets observed on blood film or RBC dot plot
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and MPV
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
        • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
        • ACTH stimulation
     

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

  • An increased PDW is commonly associated with the early release of large platelets from the bone marrow as part of a regenerative thrombopoeitic response.
  • The PDW is usually inversely proportional to the platelet count.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • The PDW is a calculated value based on the distribution width of the MPV using the equation:
PDW = (Standard deviation of MPV / MPV) x 100

 

   References

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 6th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2005.
  • Lattimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Schwartz D, Sharkey L, Armstrong PJ, et al. Platelet volume and plateletcrit in dogs with presumed primary immune-mediated thrombocytopenia. J Vet Intern Med. 2014;28(5):1575-9.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Thrall MA, Baker DC, Campbell TW, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry:  Text and Clinical Case Presentation.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2006.

Last updated 7/1/2018
