PHBR:
Description: Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that is primarily used for seizure control.  Serum phenobarbital concentrations are assessed to help determine if the drug is reaching therapeutic levels and to assess for toxic levels.

 

Decreased Phenobarbital (below therapeutic level)

 

  • Insufficient dosage or noncompliance
  • Artifact - collection and transportation in a serum separator tube may artifactually decrease phenobarbital concentrations
  • Reduced elimination half-life associated with liver enzyme induction
  • Decreased absorption (e.g. gastrointestinal disease)
  • Increased clearance (rare)
    • Alkaline urine (pH > 7.0)
    • Diuretics
  • Medications (e.g. rifampicin)

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Phenobarbital

  • Review dose, dosing protocol, sample collection and history of concurrent drugs.
  • Evaluate history for clinical signs of gastrointestinal disease which might affect absorption.
  • Assess for adequate seizure control. If phenobarbital levels are below the therapeutic range in the face of good seizure control, the dose does not have to be increased.

Increased Phenobarbital (above therapeutic level)

 

  • Over-medication
  • Dietary - low protein or low fat diets may increased phenobarbital half-life
  • Decreased clearance - severe anuric or oliguric renal failure
  • Medications (e.g. chloramphenicol, felbamate, imidazole antifungals)

  

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Phenobarbital

 

  • Review dose, dosing protocol, sample collection and history of recent diet changes or concurrent drugs.
  • Above therapeutic levels carry an increased risk of toxicity. However, toxicity may also be seen with therapeutic levels in some patients.
  • Evaluate for seizure control.
    • If good seizure control is present, consider decreasing the phenobarbital dosage.
    • If inadequate seizure control, consider adding an additional anticonvulsant to allow a decrease is phenobarbital dosage.
  • Evaluate CBC, chemistry and urinalysis for evidence of toxicity. 
  • CBC - bone marrow suppression (anemia, decreased neutrophils and platelets) may be seen with phenobarbital toxicity.
  • Chemistry:
    • Increased ALP and ALT can be seen with both therapeutic concentration (without toxicity) and with secondary hepatotoxicity
    • Decreased albumin and increased bilirubin (with hepatoxicity)
  • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - increased with hepatoxicitiy
  • Spec cPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with secondary pancreatitis
  • Total T4 and Free T4 - secondarily decreased wtih phenobarbital therapy
  • PT and PTT increased with secondary hematotoxicity and in cats with secondary coagulopathy (rare)
  • Abdominal ultrasound - significant (potentially reversible) liver changes may be seen with phenobarbital hepatotoxicity which may be difficult to differentiate from neoplasia visually.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Phenobarbital’s exact mechanism of action on the CNS is unknown.  Phenobarbital likely increases the effects of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA, and decreases the release of the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate. 
    • Phenobarbital can decrease the release of acetylcholine and norepinephrine.
  • The drug has good oral absorption in dogs, cats, and horses.
  • Approximately 40-60% of phenobarbital is protein bound.
  • Peak levels occur 4-8 hours after oral administration in dogs.
  • Steady state serum levels are achieved after 2-3 weeks. 
  • Timing of the blood collection for phenobarbital levels is not important in the majority of cases.
    • If there are signs of toxicity, it is recommended to get a peak sample 4-6 hours after the phenobarbital administration.
    • If there are signs of breakthrough seizures, it is recommended to get a trough sample right before the next dose of phenobarbital, or during a seizure if emergency treatment is needed.   
  • If phenobarbital levels are below the therapeutic range, the dose does not have to be increased in the face of good seizure control.
  • If the phenobarbital level is above the therapeutic range, there is an increased risk for hepatotoxicity. 
    • The dose of the phenobarbital should be decreased and another anti-epileptic drug may need to be started to maintain good seizure control. 
    • Drugs that can increase the risk for phenobarbital-induced hepatotoxicity
      • Carprofen
      • Acetaminophen
  • Phenobarbital induces hepatic microsomal enzyme activity, which can increase the metabolism of many drugs and decrease serum concentrations of those drugs.
    • Lists of these drugs can be found in most pharmacology texts or formularies.

 

  References

  • Boothe DM. Small Animal Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, 2nd ed. Philadelphia, Pa: WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Plumb DC, ed. Plumb's Veterinary Drug Handbook, 8th ed. Stockholm, WI: PharmaVet Inc.; 2015.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
PHOS:
Description: Phosphorus is essential for energy production, protein synthesis, and acid/base balance in the body. Phosphorus is also a major component of bone.

 

Decreased Phosphorus

 

  • Increased urinary excretion
    • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • Diuretics
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • Translocation from extracellular fluid (ECF) to intracellular fluid (ICF)
    • Bicarbonate administration
    • Insulin therapy
    • Insulinoma
    • Intravenous glucose administration
    • Metabolic or respiratory alkalosis
  • Defective mobilization from bone
    • Eclampsia (dogs)
  • Decreased intestinal absorption
    • Diet imbalance
      • Dietary insufficiency
      • Prolonged anorexia
    • Intestinal malabsorption
    • Phosphate binding agents
    • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Renal tubular defects
    • Fanconi syndrome (dogs)
    • Other renal tubular defects
  • Unknown mechanism
    • Renal failure (horses)
    • Halothane anesthesia (horses
  • Artifact
    • Icterus may lower measured phosphorus, depending on method used
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Phosphorus

 

  • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT, BUN, creatinine, cholesterol, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2, sodium, potassium (can also be normal or increased)
    • Increased fructosamine
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria and ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Spec fPL®, Spec cPL®, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
  • Hyperparathyroidism
    • High normal to increased PTH
    • Increased total and ionized calcium
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
    • Increased total and ionized calcium
    • Decreased PTH
    • Increased PTH-related protein
    • Cytology and/or histopathology consistent with neoplasia
  • Eclampsia (dogs)
    • Decreased total and ionized calcium

 

Increased Phosphorus

 

  • Decreased urinary excretion
    • Decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
      • Kidney failure
      • Pre-renal azotemia
      • Post-renal azotemia
    • Growing animals (2X increase common)
    • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Increased intestinal absorption
    • Increased intake
      • Phosphate enema
      • Phosphate-containing urinary acidifier ingestion
    • Increased vitamin D or vitamin D analogue 
      • Cholecalciferol rodenticide
      • Jessamine/wild jasmine (Cestrum diurnum)
    • Dietary excess (low Ca/PO4 ratio)
    • Intestinal ischemia
  • Shift from ICF to ECF
    • Acute tumor lysis syndrome
    • Myopathies
      • Exertional rhabdomyolysis
      • Malignant hyperthermia
      • Endurance rides (horses)
  • Other or unknown mechanisms
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Neoplasia with osteolytic bone lesions
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
    • Acromegaly
  • Artifact
    • Caused by hemolysis in vitro

 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Phosphorus

 

  • Kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), elevated SDMA, abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine
      • May have increased total calcium with decreased ionized calcium
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic disease (due to decreased erythropoietin) 
    • Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to renal secondary hyperparathyroidism
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis - urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
      • Infectious renal diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease):
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Pre-renal azotemia (severe)
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and serum proteins
    • Urinalysis - increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria; >1.030 dogs, >1.040 cats, >1.025 horses)
    • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
  • Post-renal azotemia
    • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria and consider abdominal imaging.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Increased potassium with urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria
    • Uroabdomen
      • Abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentrations than serum
    • Abnormalities on abdominal radiographs, contrast studies or ultrasound may suggest rupture or post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones).
  • Growing animals
    • Often also have increased ALP (especially dogs and horses)
  • Hypoparathyroidism
    • Decreased total and ionized calcium
    • Decreased PTH

 

 Additional Information

 

   Physiology

  • Most phosphorus occurs free; smaller amounts are complexed to nonprotein cations and cationic proteins.
  • Inorganic phosphorus is predominantly HPO42- at neutral pH of 7.4; chemical forms vary with pH.
  • Balance between parathyroid hormone (PTH) and Vitamin D metabolism is critical for phosphorus homeostasis.
  • Phosphorus is an important component of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and depletion may significantly affect brain, RBC, and skeletal muscle cells.
  • Renal excretion of phosphorus is a major route of elimination in most mammals.

 

   References

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
     

Last updated 9/1/2024
PLT:
Description:  Platelets are involved in clot formation and stabilization (primary hemostasis).

 

Decreased Platelets
 

  • Artifact (most common cause)
    • Platelet clumping
    • Clots in specimen tube 
  • Immune-mediated platelet destruction
    • Primary (idiopathic) immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (ITP)
    • Secondary ITP
      • Infection
      • Neoplasia
      • Systemic immune-mediated disease
      • Drugs/vaccines
  • Increased platelet consumption
    • Blood loss, acute and severe
    • Localized intravascular coagulation
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia
    • Post-transfusion purpura
    • Envenomation
    • Vasculitis/endocarditis
  • Decreased platelet production
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Immune-mediated (targeting megakaryocytes)
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia
    • Breed-related:   
      • Macrothrombocytopenia (giant platelet disorder)
      • Greyhounds - normal reference interval is lower than other breeds
    • Endotoxemia
    • Hypophosphatemia
    • Anaphylaxis
  • Sequestration (rarely causes clinically relevant disease)

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Platelets

 

  • Artifact
    • Evaluate a freshly prepared blood film and/or dot plots for evidence of platelet clumping
      • Platelet clumps are often found along the feathered edge on blood film
      • Comparison of patient RBC and WBC dot plots to species-specific normals may show pattern changes suggestive of platelet clumping
        • Smaller platelet clumps may result in a shift in position of the platelet population on the RBC run up and to the right.
        • Larger platelet clumps may appear on the WBC run as pale blue (LaserCyte Dx) or orange (ProCyte Dx) populations starting from the lower left and crossing the white blood cell populating in an upward angle.
    • Platelet clumps may interfere wtih the measurement of platelet indices (MPV, PDW) and plateletcrit
    • Recheck platelets on a freshly-drawn specimen
  • Immune-mediated platelet destruction
    • CBC:
      • Thrombocytopenia is typically severe; platelet counts below 50,000/uL
      • Decreased plateletcrit (PCT)
      • Increased PDW and MPV with regenerative thrombocytosis resulting in release of large platelets
      • Variable regenerative anemia with blood loss or concurrent immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary ITP:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis, Leishmania spp., Angiostrongylus vasorum, leptospirosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Increased consumption of platelets
    • Typically, mild to moderately decreased platelets
    • Acute, severe blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Anemia may be pre-regenerative with normal reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased total protein
      • Hypovolemia and shock may be noted on physical exam
    • Localized intravascular coagulation
      • Pulmonary thromboembolism
        • Thoracic radiographs may be normal or may show evidence of pulmonary hypertension, interstitial or alveolar pulmonary pattern or pleural effusion
        • Blood gas:
          • Hypoxemia
          • Metabolic acidosis
          • Increased alveolar-arterial gradient
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Aortic thromboembolism (saddle thrombus)
        • Decreased perfusion and pulses in affected limb
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Hemagiosarcoma:
        • May cause both localized intravascular coagulation within the spleen or liver and systemic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • Abdominal imaging to check for splenic or liver mass(es) or loss of detail due to hemorrhage within abdomen
        • Thoracic imaging to assess for cardiomegaly and pericardial effusion associated with cardiac hemagiosarcoma
      • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • CBC:
          • Blood film review - evidence of red blood cell fragmentation such as schistocytes or poikilocytosis
        • Coagulation profile:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Increased d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
          • Decreased fibrinogen
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of DIC (systemic inflammation, infection, neoplasia)
          • Increased C-reactive protein
          • Positive blood or urine culture
          • Positive Spec cPL or Spec fPL test with acute pancreatitis
          • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
  • Decreased platelet production
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Leukopenia
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of megakaryocytes or other changes
  •  Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Breed-related macrothrombocytopenia (giant platelet disorder)
      • Present in up to 50% of Cavalier King Charles Spaniels (CKCS). Identical genetic defect has also been identified less commonly in many other breeds.
      • History of persistently low platelets without evidence of abnormal bleeding, petechiae or ecchymoses
      • CBC:
        • Low normal to mildly decreased platelet count
        • Normal to increased plateletcrit (PCT)
        • Increased MPV
        • Large platelets observed on blood film review
        • RBC dot plot shows a shift in platelet population up and to the right
      • CKCS Macrothrombocytopenia DNA test positive for beta-1 tubulin mutation
        • Note: DNA test can also be performed on breeds other than CKCS

 

Increased Platelets
   

  • Increased platelet production
    • Inflammation
      • Infection
      • Immune-mediated 
      • Surgery
      • Trauma
    • Non-hematopoietic neoplasia
    • Iron deficiency
      • Chronic low grade blood loss
    • Rebound
      • Recovery from thrombocytopenia
      • Following significant anemia (secondary effect of erythropoietin)
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
      • Exogenous steroids
      • Stress
    • Chemotherapy (vincristine, vinblastine)
    • Post-splenectomy
    • Reactive thrombocytosis
    • Hemic neoplasia (clonal thrombocytosis)
      • Primary (essential) thrombocytosis
      • Chronic myeloproliferative disease
        • Polycythemia vera
        • Primary erythrocytosis
        • Chronic myeloid leukemia
      • Acute megakaryocytic leukemia
      • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Redistribution
    • Exercise
    • Epinephrine
 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Platelets

 

  • Increased platelet production:
    • Inflammation
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia - with chronic inflammation
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) increased
    • Iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Variable anemia, with microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) developing with progression
        • Reticulocytes - initially may be elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Rebound thrombocytosis
      • CBC:
        • Regenerative anemia
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Large platelets observed on blood film or RBC dot plot
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
        • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
        • ACTH stimulation
  • Platelet redistribution
    • CBC:
      • Increased plateletcrit
      • Normal PDW and MPV

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Platelets are small cytoplasmic fragments of megakaryocytes.  Megakaryocytes are derived from pluripotent stem cells in the bone marrow.
  • Platelet production requires presence of adequate megakaryocytes in the bone marrow (megakaryopoiesis) and normal formation and delivery of platelets to the circulation (thrombopoiesis).
  • Megakaryopoiesis and thrombopoiesis are primarily mediated by thrombopoietin.  This hormone is derived from hepatocytes, renal tubular epithelium and stromal bone marrow cells.  Thrombopoietin is cleared by platelets and megakaryocytes.  Erythropoietin plays a lesser role in platelet production.
  • Platelet alpha granules store proteins involved in hemostasis and vessel repair.
  • Dense granules in platelets contain Ca2+, Mg2+, ADP, ATP and serotonin which are also secreted with appropriate stimuli.
  • The main function of platelets is in primary hemostasis.  They are involved in formation of the hemostatic plug (clot).
  • In addition to vascular damage repair and formation of hemostatic plugs, platelets participate in inflammation and wound healing.

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • There are multiple methods for quantifying platelets, but since activation (and clumping) can occur during collection or storage, blood films made from fresh samples should also be evaluated whenever possible.
  • Platelet clumping (pseudothrombocytopenia) is the most common cause of low platelet counts because clumps may be counted as individual platelets.  Even small clumps on a smear make the platelet count and estimate inaccurate.  Platelet clumping is very common in cats, but can occur in all species.
  • Evaluation of dot plots may provide evidence of platelet clumping

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 6th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2005.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Thrall MA, Baker DC, Campbell TW, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry:  Text and Clinical Case Presentation.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2006.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Platelets

 

  • Artifact
    • Evaluate a freshly prepared blood film and/or dot plots for evidence of platelet clumping
      • Platelet clumps are often found along the feathered edge on blood film
      • Comparison of patient RBC and WBC dot plots to species-specific normals may show pattern changes suggestive of platelet clumping
        • Smaller platelet clumps may result in a shift in position of the platelet population on the RBC run up and to the right.
        • Larger platelet clumps may appear on the WBC run as pale blue (LaserCyte Dx) or orange (ProCyte Dx) populations starting from the lower left and crossing the white blood cell populating in an upward angle.
    • Platelet clumps may interfere wtih the measurement of platelet indices (MPV, PDW) and plateletcrit
    • Recheck platelets on a freshly-drawn specimen
  • Immune-mediated platelet destruction
    • CBC:
      • Thrombocytopenia is typically severe; platelet counts below 50,000/uL
      • Decreased plateletcrit (PCT)
      • Increased PDW and MPV with regenerative thrombocytosis resulting in release of large platelets
      • Variable regenerative anemia with blood loss or concurrent immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary ITP:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis, Leishmania spp., Angiostrongylus vasorum, leptospirosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Increased consumption of platelets
    • Typically, mild to moderately decreased platelets
    • Acute, severe blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Anemia may be pre-regenerative with normal reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased total protein
      • Hypovolemia and shock may be noted on physical exam
    • Localized intravascular coagulation
      • Pulmonary thromboembolism
        • Thoracic radiographs may be normal or may show evidence of pulmonary hypertension, interstitial or alveolar pulmonary pattern or pleural effusion
        • Blood gas:
          • Hypoxemia
          • Metabolic acidosis
          • Increased alveolar-arterial gradient
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Aortic tromboembolism (saddle thrombus)
        • Decreased perfusion and pulses in affected limb
        • Elevated Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Hemagiosarcoma:
        • May cause both localized intravascular coagulation within the spleen or liver and systemic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • Abdominal imaging to check for splenic or liver mass(es) or loss of detail due to hemorrhage within abdomen
        • Thoracic imaging to assess for cardiomegaly and pericardial effusioon associated with cardiac hemagiosarcoma
      • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
        • CBC:
          • Blood film review - evidence of red blood cell fragmentation such as schistocytes or poikilocytosis
        • Coagulation profile:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Increased d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
          • Decreased fibrinogen
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of DIC (systemic inflammation, infection, neoplasia)
          • Increased C-reactive protein
          • Positive blood or urine culture
          • Positive Spec cPL or Spec fPL test with acute pancreatitis
          • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
  • Decreased platelet production
    • Assess history for exposuire to drugs, e.g.
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Leukopenia
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of megakaryocytes or other changes
  •  Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Breed-related macrothrombocytopenia (giant platelet disorder)
      • Present in up to 50% of Cavalier King Charles Spaniels (CKCS). Identical genetic defect has also been identified less commonly in many other breeds.
      • History of persistently low platelets without evidence of abnormal bleeding, petechiae or ecchymoses
      • CBC:
        • Low normal to mildly decreased platelet count
        • Normal to increased plateletcrit (PCT)
        • Increased MPV
        • Large platelets observed on blood film review
        • RBC dot plot shows a shift in platelet population up and to the right
      • CKCS Macrothrombocytopenia DNA test positive for beta-1 tubulin mutation
        • Note: DNA test can also be performed on breeds other than CKCS

 

Increased Platelets
   

  • Increased platelet production
    • Inflammation
      • Infection
      • Immune-mediated 
      • Surgery
      • Trauma
    • Non-hematopoietic neoplasia
    • Iron deficiency
      • Chronic low grade blood loss
    • Rebound
      • Recovery from thrombocytopenia
      • Following significant anemia (secondary effect of erythropoietin)
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
      • Exogenous steroids
      • Stress
    • Chemotherapy (vincristine, vinblastine)
    • Post-splenectomy
    • Reactive thrombocytosis
    • Hemic neoplasia (clonal thrombocytosis)
      • Primary (essential) thrombocytosis
      • Chronic myeloproliferative disease
        • Polycythemia vera
        • Primary erythrocytosis
        • Chronic myeloid leukemia
      • Acute megakaryocytic leukemia
      • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Redistribution
    • Exercise
    • Epinephrine
 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Platelets

 

  • Increased platelet production:
    • Inflammation
      • CBC:
        • Variable nonregenerative anemia - with chronic inflammation
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) increased
    • Iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Variable anemia, with microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) developing with progression
        • Reticulocytes - initially may be elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Rebound thrombocytosis
      • CBC:
        • Regenerative anemia
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Large platelets observed on blood film or RBC dot plot
    • Corticosteroid-induced
      • May be a transient stress response or may reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
        • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
        • ACTH stimulation
  • Platelet redistribution
    • CBC:
      • Increased plateletcrit
      • Normal PDW and MPV

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Platelets are small cytoplasmic fragments of megakaryocytes.  Megakaryocytes are derived from pluripotent stem cells in the bone marrow.
  • Platelet production requires presence of adequate megakaryocytes in the bone marrow (megakaryopoiesis) and normal formation and delivery of platelets to the circulation (thrombopoiesis).
  • Megakaryopoiesis and thrombopoiesis are primarily mediated by thrombopoietin.  This hormone is derived from hepatocytes, renal tubular epithelium and stromal bone marrow cells.  Thrombopoietin is cleared by platelets and megakaryocytes.  Erythropoietin plays a lesser role in platelet production.
  • Platelet alpha granules store proteins involved in hemostasis and vessel repair.
  • Dense granules in platelets contain Ca2+, Mg2+, ADP, ATP and serotonin which are also secreted with appropriate stimuli.
  • The main function of platelets is in primary hemostasis.  They are involved in formation of the hemostatic plug (clot).
  • In addition to vascular damage repair and formation of hemostatic plugs, platelets participate in inflammation and wound healing.

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • There are multiple methods for quantifying platelets, but since activation (and clumping) can occur during collection or storage, blood films made from fresh samples should also be evaluated whenever possible.
  • Platelet clumping (pseudothrombocytopenia) is the most common cause of low platelet counts because clumps may be counted as individual platelets.  Even small clumps on a smear make the platelet count and estimate inaccurate.  Platelet clumping is very common in cats, but can occur in all species.
  • Evaluation of dot plots may provide evidence of platelet clumping

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 6th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2005.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Thrall MA, Baker DC, Campbell TW, DeNicola DB.  Veterinary Hematology and Clinical Chemistry:  Text and Clinical Case Presentation.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2006.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
PRO:
Description:  Protein in the urine can be an indicator of renal disease (interpret in conjunction with urine concentration) or lower urinary tract disease, when pre-renal causes of proteinuria have been ruled out.

 

 

Positive Urine Protein

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Glomerulonephritis
        • Idiopathic (primary)
        • Immune-mediated/infectious (secondary)
      • Renal amyloidosis
    • Tubular proteinuria
      • Acute and chronic kidney disease
      • Defects in proximal renal tubular function
      • Congenital disorders
    • Functional – transient
      • Fever, shock, cardiac disease, exercise (horse), seizures
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Overflow/overload pre-glomerular proteinuria
      • Bence Jones proteins, hyperglobulinemia
      • Post-colostral proteinuria (foals)
      • Hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Transient mild proteinuria
      • Shock
      • Fever
      • Increased physical exercise
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Inflammation or infection of the upper or lower urinary tract (or reproductive tract in voided specimen)
    • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract or reproductive tract
    • Neoplasia of the urinary tract
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • False positives
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Prolonged contact of dipstick reagent pad with alkaline urine
      • Quaternary ammonium or chlorhexidine contamination
      • Pigmenturia
        • Myoglobin
        • Hemoglobin
        • Recent administration of certain blood substitutes (e.g. Oxyglobin)
    • Sulfosalicylic acid test
      • Turbid urine
      • Radiographic contrast media
      • High doses of antibiotics (penicillin, cephaloridin, sulfisoxazole)
      • Co-precipitation of urinary crystals due to low pH of reagent

   

 

Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Urine Protein

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Small amounts of protein (trace to 1+) can be normal in urine, especially if urine is concentrated.
      • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Positive Bence Jones proteins in urine
    • Hemoglobinuria
      • CBC - anemia
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
    • Myoglobinuria
      • Chemistry - increased CK, AST
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts or crystals
    • Urine culture - positive with urinary tract infection
    • Transitional cell carcinoma:
      • Urine cytology consistent with neoplasia
      • Positive bladder tumor analyte test
      • Mass visualized on ultrasound
    • Urinary calculi may be visualized on radiographs and ultrasound
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s Disease)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • ACTH stimulation
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Negative Urine Protein

 

  • Clinically normal animal
  • False negatives:
    • Bence Jones protein unreliable
    • Highly buffered alkaline urine (when measuring by sulfosalicyclic acid test)

 

 

Additional Information

 

   Proteinuria Resource Quick Links:

  • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of renal proteinuria at www.idexx.com/UrineProtein.

   Physiology

  • When proteinuria is detected, its potential clinical significance must be established.
  • Localization of proteinuria as pre-renal, renal or post-renal is the first step in determining its clinical significance.
  • If it is renal in origin, then the magnitude of proteinuria needs to be quantified and determined to be persistent or not.
  • A UPC ratio can be performed to quantify the degree of renal proteinuria to determine its clinical significance. The UPC ratio is a quantitative measure of all urine proteins. By measuring both the urine creatinine along with the urine protein, the UPC ratio normalizes for variations in urine concentration.
  • The presence of renal proteinuria is a negative prognostic indicator in chronic kidney disease. The greater the magnitude of proteinuria, the greater the risk for progression of renal disease and possible death.
  • Treatments can decrease proteinuria, slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease and improving survival.

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Semiquantitative
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Sensitive screening test
      • Primarily detects albumin; does not reliably detect globulins or Bence Jones proteins associated with multiple myeloma.
      • Reported as negative, trace, and 1+ to 3+ or 4+ reaction
    • Acid precipitation tests (includes sulfosalicylic acid test - SSA)
      • Detects albumin and nonalbumin proteins, including Bence Jones paraprotein
      • Historically used to confirm positive dipstick results
      • High specificity, but relatively low sensitivity
  • Quantitative
    • Colorimetric, spectrophotometric
    • Electrophoresis, immunoelectrophoresis
       

   References

  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW.  Canine and Feline Endocrinology and Reproduction, 3rd ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
  • IDEXX Reference Labs. Comparison of automated colorimetric reagent strip method and sulfosalicylic acid (SSA) precipitation method for detection of urine protein. Internal study available at www.idexx.com/SSAstudy.
  • Jacob F, Polzin DJ, Osborne CA, et al. Evaluation of the association between initial proteinuria and morbidity rate or death in dogs with naturally occurring chronic renal failure. J Am Vet Med Assoc 2005;226: 393-400.
  • Jepson RE, Elliot J, Brodbelt D, et al. Effect of control of systemic blood pressure on survival in cats with systemic hypertension. Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 402-409.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • King JN, Tasker S, Gunn-Moore DA, et al. Prognostic factors in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 906.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Lees GE, Brown SA, et al. Assessment and management of proteinuria in dogs and cats: 2004 ACVIM Consensus Statement (small animal). J Vet Intern Med 2005;19: 377-385.
  • Nabity MB. Re-evaluating urine dipstick protein in dogs: when should you be concerned? Adv Small Anim Med Surg. 2011;24(11): 1-3.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Syme HM, Markwell PJ, Pfeiffer D, et al. Survival of cats with naturally occurring chronic renal failure is related to severity of proteinuria. J Vet Intern Med. 2006;20: 528-535.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
     

Last updated 12/1/2018

        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Positive Bence Jones proteins in urine
    • Hemoglobinuria
      • CBC - anemia
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
    • Myoglobinuria
      • Chemistry - increased CK, AST
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts or crystals
    • Urine culture - positive with urinary tract infection
    • Transitional cell carcinoma:
      • Urine cytology consistent with neoplasia
      • Positive bladder tumor analyte test
      • Mass visualized on ultrasound
    • Urinary calculi may be visualized on radiographs and ultrasound
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s Disease)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • ACTH stimulation
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Negative Urine Protein

 

  • Clinically normal animal
  • False negatives:
    • Bence Jones protein unreliable
    • Highly buffered alkaline urine (when measuring by sulfosalicyclic acid test)

 

 

Additional Information

 

   Proteinuria Resource Quick Links:

  • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of renal proteinuria at www.idexx.com/UrineProtein.

   Physiology

  • When proteinuria is detected, its potential clinical significance must be established.
  • Localization of proteinuria as pre-renal, renal or post-renal is the first step in determining its clinical significance.
  • If it is renal in origin, then the magnitude of proteinuria needs to be quantified and determined to be persistent or not.
  • A UPC ratio can be performed to quantify the degree of renal proteinuria to determine its clinical significance. The UPC ratio is a quantitative measure of all urine proteins. By measuring both the urine creatinine along with the urine protein, the UPC ratio normalizes for variations in urine concentration.
  • The presence of renal proteinuria is a negative prognostic indicator in chronic kidney disease. The greater the magnitude of proteinuria, the greater the risk for progression of renal disease and possible death.
  • Treatments can decrease proteinuria, slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease and improving survival.

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Semiquantitative
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Sensitive screening test
      • Primarily detects albumin; does not reliably detect globulins or Bence Jones proteins associated with multiple myeloma.
      • Reported as negative, trace, and 1+ to 3+ or 4+ reaction
    • Acid precipitation tests (includes sulfosalicylic acid test - SSA)
      • Detects albumin and nonalbumin proteins, including Bence Jones paraprotein
      • Historically used to confirm positive dipstick results
      • High specificity, but relatively low sensitivity
  • Quantitative
    • Colorimetric, spectrophotometric
    • Electrophoresis, immunoelectrophoresis

PRO03:
Description:  Protein in the urine can be an indicator of renal disease (interpret in conjunction with urine concentration) or lower urinary tract disease, when pre-renal causes of proteinuria have been ruled out.

 

 

Positive Urine Protein

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Glomerulonephritis
        • Idiopathic (primary)
        • Immune-mediated/infectious (secondary)
      • Renal amyloidosis
    • Tubular proteinuria
      • Acute and chronic kidney disease
      • Defects in proximal renal tubular function
      • Congenital disorders
    • Functional – transient
      • Fever, shock, cardiac disease, exercise (horse), seizures
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Overflow/overload pre-glomerular proteinuria
      • Bence Jones proteins, hyperglobulinemia
      • Post-colostral proteinuria (foals)
      • Hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Transient mild proteinuria
      • Shock
      • Fever
      • Increased physical exercise
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Inflammation or infection of the upper or lower urinary tract (or reproductive tract in voided specimen)
    • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract or reproductive tract
    • Neoplasia of the urinary tract
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • False positives
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Prolonged contact of dipstick reagent pad with alkaline urine
      • Quaternary ammonium or chlorhexidine contamination
      • Pigmenturia
        • Myoglobin
        • Hemoglobin
        • Recent administration of certain blood substitutes (e.g. Oxyglobin)
    • Sulfosalicylic acid test
      • Turbid urine
      • Radiographic contrast media
      • High doses of antibiotics (penicillin, cephaloridin, sulfisoxazole)
      • Co-precipitation of urinary crystals due to low pH of reagent

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Small amounts of protein (trace to 1+) can be normal in urine, especially if urine is concentrated.

      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus

    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Positive Bence Jones proteins in urine
    • Hemoglobinuria
      • CBC - anemia
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
    • Myoglobinuria
      • Chemistry - increased CK, AST
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts or crystals
    • Urine culture - positive with urinary tract infection
    • Transitional cell carcinoma:
      • Urine cytology consistent with neoplasia
      • Positive bladder tumor analyte test
      • Mass visualized on ultrasound
    • Urinary calculi may be visualized on radiographs and ultrasound
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s Disease)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • ACTH stimulation
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Negative Urine Protein

 

  • Clinically normal animal
  • False negatives:
    • Bence Jones protein unreliable
    • Highly buffered alkaline urine (when measuring by sulfosalicyclic acid test)

 

 

Additional Information

  • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of renal proteinuria at www.idexx.com/UrineProtein.

  • A UPC ratio can be performed to quantify the degree of renal proteinuria to determine its clinical significance. The UPC ratio is a quantitative measure of all urine proteins. By measuring both the urine creatinine along with the urine protein, the UPC ratio normalizes for variations in urine concentration.
  • The presence of renal proteinuria is a negative prognostic indicator in chronic kidney disease. The greater the magnitude of proteinuria, the greater the risk for progression of renal disease and possible death.
  • Treatments can decrease proteinuria, slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease and improving survival.

  • Semiquantitative

      • Historically used to confirm positive dipstick results
      • High specificity, but relatively low sensitivity
  • Quantitative

PROG:
Description: Progesterone is a reproductive hormone. Progesterone is commonly measured to predict ovulation for timing of breeding, determine spay status, assess for ovarian remnants, assess health of pregnancy, predict parturition date or to time C-section (use varies by species). Progesterone is produced during late proestrus, through estrus, into diestrus, and is necessary for maintenance of pregnancy in most species.

Increased Progesterone

  • Intact female, normal heat cycle:
    • Late proestrus/estrus phase - from ovarian follicles
    • Diestrus phase - from corpus luteum
    • A definite and persistent rise in progesterone can be used for timing of breeding
  • Pregnancy:
    • Sustained concentrations produced by corpus luteum (and placenta in some species) throughout gestation
      • In horses, placental progestins produced in late pregnancy may not cross-react with many progesterone assays
    • Concentration drops shortly before parturition
  • Pseudopregnancy
  • Ovarian remnant syndrome
  • Disorders of steroid production pathway:
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Adrenal tumor
    • Occult hyperadrenocorticism (atypical Cushing's disease)
  • Ovarian cyst(s)
  • Exposure to exogenous progesterone

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Progesterone

  • Intact female, normal heat cycle
    • Late proestrus/estrus:
      • For timing of breeding:
        • Assess progesterone in combination with other monitoring techniques (e.g. clinical signs of standing heat, vaginal cytology, luteinizing hormone)
        • Obtain baseline vaginal cytology and progesterone levels at the onset of heat signs
        • Once 75% cornified superficial cells are seen on vaginal cytology, begin to assess serial progesterone levels (minimum of every other day) until a persistent and definite rise in levels is confirmed.
      • Luteinizing hormone - positive just prior to ovulation
      • Vaginal cytology:
        • Majority are superficial vaginal epithelial cells
        • Clear background
        • Variable red blood cells
        • Few to no neutrophils
        • Bacteria common
      • Progesterone - moderate increase is progressive and repeatable
      • Female becomes receptive and attractive to males
    • Diestrus:
      • Ultrasound or palpation of ovaries confirms presence of corpus luteum
      • Progesterone concentrations sustained high through diestrus
      • Luteinizing hormone - negative
      • Vaginal cytology:
        • Majority are parabasal and intermediate epithelial cells
        • Neutrophils often present
        • Bacteria may be clearing
      • Female ceases to stand for breeding
      • Abdominal ultrasound - uterus and ovaries present
    • Pregnancy:
      • Progesterone is sustained high through majority of gestation, then drops shortly before parturition
      • Relaxin (dogs, cats) - produced by placenta, positive in later pregnancy
      • Palpation, radiographs or ultrasound confirm presence of fetuses
      • Estrone sulfate (horses) - increased, especially in later pregnancy
      • Equine chorionic gonadotropin (eCG)/Pregnant mare serum gonadotropin (PMSG) positive in mid-pregnancy (horses)
    • Pseudopregnancy:
      • Abnormally prolonged progesterone production by the corpus luteum in diestrus
      • Clinical signs of pregnancy present:
        • Weight gain, increased appetite, nesting behavior
        • Rarely may also lactate
      • Abdominal imaging (radiographs or ultrasound) do not confirm pregnancy
    • Ovarian remnant syndrome:
      • Progesterone levels - variable, but may be increased 2-8 weeks post clinical signs of estrus (dogs) or following HCG or GnRH stimulation (cats)
      • Clinical signs of proestrus or estrus
      • Vaginal cytology when female is receptive and attactive to males:
        • Primarily consists of superficial vaginal epithelial cells
      • Antimullerian hormone - variable
        • If positive, consistent with ovarian remnant in a "spayed" female
      • Luteinizing hormone - variable, not reliable for ovarian remnants if positive
        • If negative, consistent with ovarian remnant in a "spayed" female
      • Abdominal ultrasound - ovarian remnants variably detectable
    • Disorders of steroid production pathway:
      • CBC shows stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Increased plateletcrit, platelets and MPV
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Chemistry - increased ALP (dogs)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
        • Variable mild proteinuria
      • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably mildly increased
      • Hyperadrenocorticism:
        • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
          • ACTH stimulation
          • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
          • Endogenous ACTH (horses)
        • Abdominal ultrasound - bilaterally enlarged adrenals
      • Adrenal tumor
        • Variable adrenal function tests:
          • Low and high dose dexamethasone suppression tests may show high cortisol concentration with lack of suppression.
          • ACTH stimulation may show exaggerated responses in cortisol, aldosterone and/or sex hormones
        • Abdominal ultrasound - adrenal mass
      • Occult hyperadrenocortism (atypical Cushing's disease)
        • Normal low dose dexamethasome suppression test
        • ACTH stimulation shows normal cortisol responses but exaggerated responses in steroid precursors such as progesterone and 17-hydroxy progesterone
        • Abdominal ultrasound - bilaterally enlarged adrenals

Decreased Progesterone

  • Neutered female
  • Anestrus phase in intact female
  • Luteal phase insufficiency (hypoluteoidism)
  • Pregnancy loss
  • Peri-parturition drop
  • Late pregnancy in horses - progestins produced by the placenta do not reliably cross-react with many progesterone assays
  • Artifact:
    • Lipemia
    • Serum separator gel

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Progesterone

  • Neutered female:
    • Resting progesterone low
    • HCG or GnRH stimulation - no increase in progesterone
    • Luteinizing hormone - positive
    • Antimullerian hormone - negative
    • Abdominal ultrasound - no evidence of uterus, ovaries or ovarian remnants
  • Anestrus phase in intact female
    • Resting progesterone low
    • Luteinizing hormone - negative
    • Antimullerian hormone - positive
    • Abdominal ultrasound - uterus and ovaries present
  • Luteal phase inadequacy:
    • Unusually low progesterone during pregnancy
      • May reflect inadequate production by the corpus luteum
      • May be associated with unsuccessful pregnancy
    • May be difficult to differentiate from progesterone drop associated with impending pregnancy loss due to other reasons

Additional Information

  Physiology

  • During a normal heat cycle, a rise in progesterone (produced by luteinizing ovarian follicles) is seen in the late proestrus phase, immediately before the LH surge, and followed by ovulation and the onset of standing heat, continuing through the estrus phse.
  • After ovulation, the corpus luteum produces sustained high progesterone levels throughout the diestrus phase.
  • In pregnant dogs and cats, the corpus luteum maintains high progesterone levels throughout gestation until immediately prior to partutition.
  • In pregnant horses, high progesterone levels are maintained by the corpus luteum, secondary corpora lutea and the placenta. By late pregnancy (> day 120), the placenta takes over the production of progesterone, along with other related progestins. Progestins produced by the equine placenta in late pregnancy do not reliably cross-react with many progesterone assays.
  • Progesterone levels remain low during the anestrus phase until the onset of the next heat cycle.

References:

  • England G, von Heimendahl. Chapter 5 Determining Breeding Status. BSAVA Manual of Canine and Feline Reproduction and Neonatology, 2nd ed. BSAVA, Gloucester, UK. 2010
  • England GCW and Russo M. Breeding Management of the Bitch. In Kirk's Current Veterinary Therapy XV. Philadelphia, PA: Saunders; 2014.
  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW.  Canine and Feline Endocrinology and Reproduction, 3rd ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.
  • Kutzler MA, Mohammed HO, et al. Accuracy of canine parturition data prediction from initial rise in preovulatory progesterone concentration. Theriogenology 60(2003): 1187-1196.
  • Root Kustritz MV, Johnstone SD. Use of serum progesterone for ovulation timing in the bitch. In: Kirk's Current Veterinary Therapy XIII. Philadelphia, PA: Saunders; 2000.
  • Root Kustritz MV, Clinical Canine and Feline Reproduction, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2010.
  • Wright B, Sendel T. Anatomy, Physiology and Reproduction in the Mare. Ontario Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs Fact Sheet; 2010 at http://www.omafra.gov.on.ca/english/livestock/horses/facts/10-099.htm.
