QPL:
Description:  Lipase is an enzyme produced primarily in the pancreas and other tissue sources. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of triglycerides in many sites within the body (e.g. intestines, liver, vascular endothelium, fat stores) and is involved in lipid metabolism. Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase is a quantitative lipase assay that is specifically designed to align with the Spec cPL and Spec fPL tests making it more specific for pancreatic lipase than traditional lipase.

Increased Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase

 

  • Pancreatic acinar cell damage
    • Pancreatitis (acute or chronic)
    • Pancreatic inflammation secondary to other primary disease
    • Subclinical pancreatitis (if clinical signs are absent)
    • Pancreatic neoplasia (rare) 

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase

 

  • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
  • Pancreatitis
    • Clinical signs consistent with pancreatitis (vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, variable fever, diarrhea and weakness)
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased glucose, ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Radiographs - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
    • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas with acute pancreatitis
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
    • Treat appropriately based on clinical presentation.
    • Investigate for risk factors and concurrent diseases including gastroenteritis or intestinal foreign body.
    • Monitor Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase to help assess response to treatment.
  • Pancreatic inflammation secondary to other primary disease
    • Clinical signs present, but not consistent with pancreatitis
    • CBC, chemistry and urinalysis findings variable - may be similar to those listed for pancreatitis above, or may reflect underlying disease
    • Investigate for associated diseases such as hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease).
    • Manage primary disease and monitor closely for clinical signs of pancreatitis.
    • Recheck Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test once primary disease has resolved, or sooner if clinical signs develop.
  • Subclinical pancreatitis
    • Clinical signs of pancreatitis are not observed
    • CBC, chemistry and urinalysis findings variable - may be similar to those listed for pancreatitis above or may be normal with mild inflammation.
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - variably increased depending on severity of inflammation
    • Diagnostic imaging - variable, changes may be typical for pancreatitis, but may also be subtle or absent
    • Review history (diet, treats, drugs, etc.) with owner and assess for possible risk factors.
    • Increase owner awareness of risk of developing clinical pancreatitis
    • Recheck Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test in 2-3 weeks (sooner if clinical signs develop).

 

Additional Information

 

   Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase Resource Quick Links:

  • View the Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase Diagnostic Algorithm
  • Read the Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase White Paper

   Physiology

 

  • Lipase is a cytoplasmic enzyme produced by the pancreas and released into the small intestine to catalyze the hydrolysis of triglycerides for absorption into the lacteals and gastrointestinal blood vessels.
  • In addition to pancreatic acinar cells, lipase is produced by gastric mucosal cells, hepatocytes, and many extrahepatic cells (including adipocytes and myocytes).
  • Pancreatitis in cats has been associated with cholangitis/cholangiohepatitis and inflammatory bowel disease; these are the components of the syndrome known as "triaditis". 
  • In dogs, risk factors for pancreatitis may include breed predisposition, hypertriglyceridemia, obesity, dietary indiscretion or high fat diets, Babesia infection, drug reactions (e.g. anticonvulsants, NSAIDs, azathioprine, L-asparaginase, clomipramine), endocrine disorders (hyperadrenocorticism, hypothyroidism and diabetes mellitus) and trauma.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase measures lipase activity through consumption of substrate, not the quantity of lipase.

 

  References

 

  • Cridge H, Twendt DC, Marolf AJ, Sahrkey LC, Steiner JM. Advances in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis in dogs. J Vet Intern Med.2021; 35(6): 2572-2587. doi:10.1111/jvim.16292 
  • Spillman T. Pancreatitis: Etiology, Pathogenesis, and Pathophysiologic Consequences. In: Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine Expert Consult. Vol 2 9th ed. Elsevier; 2024: 1859-1861.
  • Forman MA, Steiner JM, Armstrong PJ, et al. ACVIM consensus statement on pancreatitis in cats. J Vet Intern Med. 2021; 35(2): 703-723. doi:10.1111/jvim.16053.

 

Last updated 9/01/2024
RBC:
Description: Red blood cells (RBCs) are the most numerous blood cells and are critical for oxygen delivery and acid-base balance.

 

Decreased Red Blood Cells
   

  • Blood Loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Primary immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
      • Heinz body anemia
        • Toxins
        • Drugs
        • Dietary
      • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
        • Vasculitis
        • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
        • Hemangiosarcoma
        • Heartworm infection
      • Metabolic
      • Hereditary
      • Envenomation
  • Decreased red blood cell production
    • Chronic blood loss
    • Chronic inflammatory disease
    • Reduced erythropoietin
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Liver disease or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
      • Folate
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial
    • Infection
    • Neoplasia   
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry: increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis: bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Decreased erythropoietin production
    • CBC:
      • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
      • Decreased RBC with normal to decreased reticulocytes
      • Normal RDW
    • Evaluate for underlying causes:
      • Chronic kidney disease:
        • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
          • +/- proteinuria
        • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
        • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
      • Hypothyroidism:
        • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
        • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
        • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol
          • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
  • Bone marrow suppression:
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukopenia
      • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Increased Red Blood Cells
   

  • Dehydration
  • Splenic contraction (dogs)
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- increased phosphorus
    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • CBC:
      • High normal to increased hematocrit
      • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
        • Acromegaly
    • Secondary polycythemia:
      • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
      • Systemic hypoxia:
        • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
        • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
        • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
        • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
    • Polycythemia vera:
      • CBC:
        • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • Variably increased platelets
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
      • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Red blood cells (RBCs, erythrocytes, red cells, red corpuscles) are the longest-lived of the circulating blood cells. They are produced primarily in the bone marrow, but some production can occur at secondary sites (spleen, liver). Red blood cell production is stimulated by erythropoietin which is released from the kidneys.
  • Red blood cells contain hemoglobin and are critical for cellular respiration, delivering oxygen to tissues and carrying carbon dioxide away.
  • Red blood cell counts estimate the total red cell mass in a patient.
  • Red cells are not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • Anemias can be classified as regenerative or nonregenerative based on the adequacy of the bone marrow response to produce new red blood cells or reticulocytes (in all species but the horse). Reticulocytosis typically appears 3-4 days after the onset of anemia, with peak production in 7 days for the dog and 7-14 days for cats.
  • Anemia is a common clinical problem that may need emergency treatment with transfusion of red blood cell products if acute and/or severe.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Red cells are individual counted and sized by automated equipment using electronic impedence (the Coulter principle) or with a combination of laminar flow impedance and laser flow cytometry. Hemocytometers may be used for manual counts.
  • Anemia can be a reduction in the numbers (count) of red blood cells (RBC), the concentration of HGB, or the hematocrit or packed cell volume (PCV).  Decreases in these parameters may not be uniform, owing to differences in reference intervals or to the presence of abnormal RBCs.
       

   References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds. Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 3/1/2019
RBC01:
Description:  Red blood cells in the urine sediment can be normal in very low amounts, especially in samples obtained by catheterization or cystocentesis. When present in higher amounts, they are most often an indicator of inflammation, infection, or neoplasia in the urinary tract. 

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm. 

  

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/BloodCellImages.

 

Increased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Bacterial cystitis
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Prostatitis
  • Urinary tract inflammation
    • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
    • Urolithiasis
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma, prostate carcinoma)
  • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract
    • Coagulation or platelet disorder
    • Idiopathic renal hematuria
    • Trauma
    • Estrus (voided sample)
  • Iatrogenic (due to traumatic cystocentesis or catheterization, or manual expression)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.
  • Coagulation or platelet disorder
    • Evaluate physical exam and history for other evidence of bleeding disorder or blood loss in sites other than the urogenital tract (e.g. melena, petechiae, ecchymoses).
    • CBC:
      • Renegerative anemia (increased reticulocytes)
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased platelets (marked with immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, mild to moderate with consumption)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin, globulins and total protein
      • Variably increased or decreased ALT, ALP, GGT and bilirubin (with liver disease)
    • Coagulation panel:
      • PT/PTT prolongation (e.g. rodenticide, liver disease)
      • von Willebrands testing (breed specific)
      • Factor analysis - decreases in specific coagulation factors with hemophilia
      • Buccal mucosal bleeding time - prolonged (functional testing of platelets)

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Rare erythrocytes detected on sediment examination of the urine may be found in healthy animals.
  • Crenated erythrocytes may be confused with leukocytes in non-stained sediment.
  • Erythrocytes may swell and lyse in very alkaline or dilute urine (especially with delayed analysis) and can result in the appearance of ghost cells.
  • If erythrocytes are detected on the urine sediment exam, the heme reaction on the reagent strip should also be positive.

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
RBC_BLD:
Description: Red blood cells (RBCs) are the most numerous blood cells and are critical for oxygen delivery and acid-base balance.

 

Decreased Red Blood Cells
   

  • Blood Loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
      • Primary immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA)
      • Secondary IMHA
        • Infection
        • Neoplasia
        • Systemic immune-mediated disease
        • Drugs/vaccines
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune)
      • Heinz body anemia
        • Toxins
        • Drugs
        • Dietary
      • Mechanical fragmentation (microangiopathic)
        • Vasculitis
        • Intravascular coagulation, both disseminated and local
        • Hemangiosarcoma
        • Heartworm infection
      • Metabolic
      • Hereditary
      • Envenomation
  • Decreased red blood cell production
    • Chronic blood loss
    • Chronic inflammatory disease
    • Reduced erythropoietin
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Liver disease or portosystemic shunt (PSS)

    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
      • Folate
  • Idiopathic/multifactorial

    • Neoplasia   
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry: increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis: bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Decreased erythropoietin production
    • CBC:
      • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
      • Decreased RBC with normal to decreased reticulocytes
      • Normal RDW
    • Evaluate for underlying causes:
      • Chronic kidney disease:
        • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
        • Urinalysis:
          • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
          • +/- proteinuria
        • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
        • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
      • Hypothyroidism:
        • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
        • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
        • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Chemistry:
          • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
          • Variably increased potassium and calcium
          • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
          • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol
          • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
  • Bone marrow suppression:
    • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Griseofulvin (cats)
    • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
      • Thrombocytopenia
      • Leukopenia
      • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
  • Acute pre-regenerative anemia:
    • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator.
    • Acute blood loss:
      • Chemistry - low serum total protein
      • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
    • Hemolytic disease:
      • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
      • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Increased Red Blood Cells
   

  • Dehydration
  • Splenic contraction (dogs)
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • Endocrine
    • Secondary polycythemia
    • Polycythemia vera
  • Breed-related increases
    • Greyhounds, sighthounds, some lines of dachshunds
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Red Blood Cells

 

  • Dehydration
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and/or albumin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine, +/- increased phosphorus
    • Urinalysis:
      • Increased specific gravity (>1.030 for dogs, > 1.035 for cats)
  • Splenic contraction
    • Physiologic response to stress, excitement or exercise seen primarily in dogs
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit, RBCs and nucleated RBCs
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal to mildly increased reticulocytes and normal reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • +/- physiologic leukocytosis (neutrophilia, lymphocytosis)
      • Platelets mildly increased
  • Absolute erythrocytosis
    • CBC:
      • High normal to increased hematocrit
      • Increased reticulocytes and nucleated RBCs
    • Endocrine:
      • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
      • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
        • Acromegaly
    • Secondary polycythemia:
      • CBC - marked increases in RBC, hemoblobin and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Erythropoeitin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal.
      • Systemic hypoxia:
        • Thoracic imaging reveals evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
        • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
        • Decreased PaO2, SpO2
        • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
        • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneopastic syndrome
        • Abdominal imaging reveals evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia
    • Polycythemia vera:
      • CBC:
        • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • Variably increased platelets
      • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
      • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
      • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney anormalities or neoplasia
      • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Red blood cells (RBCs, erythrocytes, red cells, red corpuscles) are the longest-lived of the circulating blood cells. They are produced primarily in the bone marrow, but some production can occur at secondary sites (spleen, liver). Red blood cell production is stimulated by erythropoietin which is released from the kidneys.
  • Red blood cells contain hemoglobin and are critical for cellular respiration, delivering oxygen to tissues and carrying carbon dioxide away.
  • Red blood cell counts estimate the total red cell mass in a patient.
  • Red cells are not normally found in body fluids other than blood.
  • Anemias can be classified as regenerative or nonregenerative based on the adequacy of the bone marrow response to produce new red blood cells or reticulocytes (in all species but the horse). Reticulocytosis typically appears 3-4 days after the onset of anemia, with peak production in 7 days for the dog and 7-14 days for cats.
  • Anemia is a common clinical problem that may need emergency treatment with transfusion of red blood cell products if acute and/or severe.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Red cells are individual counted and sized by automated equipment using electronic impedence (the Coulter principle) or with a combination of laminar flow impedance and laser flow cytometry. Hemocytometers may be used for manual counts.
  • Anemia can be a reduction in the numbers (count) of red blood cells (RBC), the concentration of HGB, or the hematocrit or packed cell volume (PCV).  Decreases in these parameters may not be uniform, owing to differences in reference intervals or to the presence of abnormal RBCs.
       

   References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds. Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed. Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott Williams and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Nelson RW, Couto CG, eds.  Small Animal Internal Medicine, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Mosby-Elsevier; 2009.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

RBC_HJBOD:
Description: Howell Jolly bodies are remnants of nuclear material that remain in the red blood cell (RBC) after mitosis. They develop during RBC production and can be an indicator of regenerative anemia.

 

Increased Howell Jolly Bodies

   

  • Low numbers may be seen in healthy mammals
    • Frequently in cats
    • Occasionally in dogs and horses.
  • Regenerative anemia
    • Blood loss
    • Hemolysis
  • Decreased removal by the spleen
    • Post-splenectomy
    • Other splenic diseases
  • Hereditary macrocytosis of Poodles
  • Nonregenerative megaloblastic anemia

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Howell Jolly Bodies

 

  • Regenerative Anemia:
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, MCHC, MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel - iron deficiency with chronic blood loss
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW, anisocytosis
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW, anisocytosis
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  •  Splenic disease
    • History of splenectomy or other splenic diseases
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin and RDW
      • Blood film review - variable abnormal RBC morphology (e.g. shistocytes, keratocytes or acanthocytes)
    • Abdominal imaging to assess for splenomegaly, splenic mass, evidence of splenic infiltrative disease or absence of spleen
    • Cytology or histopathology of spleen to confirm splenic disease, e.g. neoplasia or splenitis

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Howell Jolly bodies are found during evaluation of a blood film.
  • Morphologic features: small, round basophilic structures that typically occur individually within the cytoplasm of erythrocytes
  • Howell-Jolly bodies should be discriminated from stain precipitate, other artifacts, erythrocyte inclusions and sideocytes

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008. 
  • Côté E, ed. ﻿Clinical Veterinary Advisor: Dogs and Cats, ﻿3rd ed. St. Louis, MO: Mosby Elseview; 2015.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
RBC_HNZ:
Description: Heinz bodies are small aggregates of denatured hemoglobin found within red blood cells (RBCs).  They indicate oxidative injury to the RBC. A low level of Heinz bodies (up to 10% of RBCs) can be a normal finding in cats.

 

Increased Heinz Bodies

  

  • Toxins
    • Zinc toxicity
    • Copper toxicity
    • Red maple toxicity
    • Skunk musk
  • Drugs
    • Acetaminophen (cats, dogs)
    • Phenothiazine (horses)
    • Propofol (cats)
    • Hydrogen peroxide (dogs)
    • Propylene glycol in stool softeners e.g. Miralax® (cats)
    • Vitamin K1 and K3 (dogs)
    • Benzocaine
    • Methylene blue
    • Phenazopyridine
    • Phenacetin (cats)
  • Dietary
    • Onions (dogs, cats, horses)
    • Garlic (dogs, horses)
    • Semi-moist diets with propylene glycol (cats)
      • Prohibited in cat food in the United States since 1996
    • Salmon-based diet
  • Lymphoma
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Selenium deficiency (horses)

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Heinz Bodies

  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - normal to slightly increased RBCs
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, ALP
      • Variably increased glucose, phosphorus
    • Thyroid tests: high total T4 and free T4
    • Cardiopet proBNP - may be increased with secondary cardiac changes
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum glucose
      • Decreased sodium, potassium, phosphorus, chloride
      • High anion gap
      • +/- increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria
      • Ketonuria
  • Lymphoma
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to evaluate for enlarged lymph nodes or organs
    • Cytology or histopathology consistent with lymphoma

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Heinz bodies in RBCs cause hemolytic anemia or shortened erythrocyte lifespan; sometimes associated with methemoglobinemia
  • Heinz bodies are more common in cats since feline hemoglobin has a greater number of oxidizable sulfhydryl bonds and the feline spleen is less efficient at removing Heinz bodies
  • Heinz bodies in up to 10% of red blood cells is considered a normal finding in cats.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Heinz bodies are found during evaluation of a blood smear.
  • Morphological features:  round structures that protrude from the erythrocyte membrane or occur in the cytoplasm
  • Can be indistinct with Romanowsky stains, but stain more prominently (basophilic) with New Methylene Blue 
       

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Williard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
RBC_NUC:
Description: Nucleated red blood cells (metarubricytes) are nucleated RBC precursors. NRBCs can be an indicator of regenerative anemia, splenic disease or diseases of the bone marrow.

Increased Nucleated RBCs
   

  • Regenerative anemia
    • Hemolysis
    • Blood loss
  • Splenic disease
  • Post-splenectomy
  • Bone marrow disease
    • Leukemia
    • Myelodysplasia
    • Myelofibrosis
    • Bone marrow damage
  • Breed related increases (slight) noted in some Minature Schnauzers and Dachshunds
  • Extramedullary hematopoiesis, especially splenic
  • Lead poisoning
  • Iron or copper deficiency
  • Hereditary macrocytosis of Poodles
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Nucleated RBCs

 

  • Regenerative Anemia:
    • Blood loss
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, MCHC, MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Splenic disease
    • History of splenectomy or other splenic disorders
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin and RDW
      • Blood film review - variable abnormal RBC morphology (e.g. schistocytes, keratocytes or acanthocytes)
    • Abdominal imaging to assess for splenomegaly, splenic mass, evidence of splenic infiltration or absence of spleen
    • Cytology or histopathology of spleen to confirm splenic disease, e.g. neoplasia or splenitis
  • Bone marrow disease:
    • CBC: 
      • Increased or decreased cell lines, depending on cause
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, disordered maturation, neoplastic infiltration, myelofibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Nucleated red blood cells are nucleated precursors to mature red blood cells found in circulation, produced primarily in the bone marrow.
  • Their presence in peripheral blood may be associated with a regenerative anemia or due to pathologic conditions affecting release or gating of red blood cells by the reticuloendothelial system, including bone marrow and spleen.
  • Moderate to significant increases in nucleated RBCs have been associated with severe hematopoietic conditions and poor prognosis, e.g. heat stroke and regenerative anemia.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Many automated analyzers count circulating nucleated red blood cells along with white blood cells as part of the white blood cell count due to their similarity of cellular and nuclear size. Newer analyzers may utilize specific reagents to count nucleated RBCs with fluorescent flow cytometry.
  • Manual blood film review is used to count the number of nucleated RBCs per 100 white blood cells to determine a corrected white blood cell count.
  • The correction is performed using this equation: Corrected WBC count = (WBC count [obtained by machine] x 100)/ (# NRBC [obtained during 100 cell differential count] + 100)
       

   References

 

  • Aroch I, Segev G, Loeb E, et al.  Peripheral nucleated red blood cells as a prognostic indicator heatstroke in dogs.  JVIM 2009; 23(3):  544-51.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018

        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)

      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
        • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
      • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
      • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
      • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
        • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
        • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
      • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
    • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
        • Increased MCV and RDW
        • Increased reticulocytes
        • Increased nucleated RBCs
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Splenic disease
    • History of splenectomy or other splenic disorders
    • CBC:
      • Normal RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin and RDW
      • Blood film review - variable abnormal RBC morphology (e.g. schistocytes, keratocytes or acanthocytes)
    • Abdominal imaging to assess for splenomegaly, splenic mass, evidence of splenic infiltration or absence of spleen
    • Cytology or histopathology of spleen to confirm splenic disease, e.g. neoplasia or splenitis
  • Bone marrow disease:
    • CBC: 
      • Increased or decreased cell lines, depending on cause
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, disordered maturation, neoplastic infiltration, myelofibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Nucleated red blood cells are nucleated precursors to mature red blood cells found in circulation, produced primarily in the bone marrow.
  • Their presence in peripheral blood may be associated with a regenerative anemia or due to pathologic conditions affecting release or gating of red blood cells by the reticuloendothelial system, including bone marrow and spleen.
  • Moderate to significant increases in nucleated RBCs have been associated with severe hematopoietic conditions and poor prognosis, e.g. heat stroke and regenerative anemia.
       

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Many automated analyzers count circulating nucleated red blood cells along with white blood cells as part of the white blood cell count due to their similarity of cellular and nuclear size. Newer analyzers may utilize specific reagents to count nucleated RBCs with fluorescent flow cytometry.
  • Manual blood film review is used to count the number of nucleated RBCs per 100 white blood cells to determine a corrected white blood cell count.
  • The correction is performed using this equation: Corrected WBC count = (WBC count [obtained by machine] x 100)/ (# NRBC [obtained during 100 cell differential count] + 100)
       

   References

 

  • Aroch I, Segev G, Loeb E, et al.  Peripheral nucleated red blood cells as a prognostic indicator heatstroke in dogs.  JVIM 2009; 23(3):  544-51.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

RDW:
Description: Red blood cell distribution width (RDW) is a measure of the variability in size of the red blood cells. This provides an index of the degree of anisocytosis present. An increased RDW suggests the presence of either microcytic red blood cells and/or macrocytic red blood cells.

 

Increased RDW

 

  • Increased RDW due to presence of macrocytic red blood cells (increased MCV):
    • Regenerative anemia
      • Blood loss
      • Hemolysis
    • Myelodysplasic disorders, including FeLV infection
    • Artifact
      • Agglutination of RBCs
      • Cell swelling
        • Aged samples
        • Short samples (low blood to EDTA ratio)
    • Hereditary macrocytosis of Poodles
  • Increased RDW due to presence of microcytic red blood cells (decreased MCV):
    • Iron deficiency
      • Chronic blood loss
    • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt
    • Asian dog breed microcytosis
    • Young animals typically have lower MCVs than adults
    • Vitamin B6 deficiency
    • Low serum sodium
    • Abnormal red blood cell morphology due to various systemic causes
      • Fragmented red blood cells
      • Spherocytes

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased RDW

 

  • CBC:
    • Evaluate MCV to determine if increased RDW is due to microcytic RBCs (low MCV) or macrocytic RBCs (high MCV)
    • Anisocytosis
  • Increased RDW with high MCV:
    • Regenerative anemia
      • Blood loss
        • CBC:
          • Decreased RBC, hematocrit and MCH
          • Increased MCV and RDW
          • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
          • Decreased reticulcoyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Iron panel:
          • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
          • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
          • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
          • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
          • Abnormal coagulation tests:
            • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
            • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
            • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
      • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
        • CBC:
          • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
          • Increased MCV and RDW
          • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
          • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
        • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
        • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
        • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
          • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
          • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
          • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
          • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
        • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
      • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
        • CBC:
          • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
          • Increased MCV and RDW
          • Increased reticulocytes
          • Increased nucleated RBCs
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased serum bilirubin
          • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
          • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
        • Urinalysis:
          • Hemoglobinuria
          • Bilirubinuria
          • Proteinuria
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
          • Increased zinc concentration
          • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
          • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
            • Onions
            • Garlic
            • Propylene glycol
            • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
            • Phenothiazine (horses)
    • FeLV - positive antigen or PCR on peripheral blood or bone marrow
    • Artifact:
      • RBC agglutination on blood smear review and confirmed with saline agglutination
  • Increased RDW with low MCV
    • Iron deficiency
      • Most commonly seen with decreased iron stores associated with nonregenerative anemia due to chronic blood loss.
      • Chronic blood loss - causing iron deficiency
        • CBC: 
          • Decreased RBC and hematocrit
          • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Thrombocytosis
        • Iron panel:
          • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
          • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
        • Next steps to evaluate for blood loss:
          • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
          • Urinalysis - hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
          • Abnormal coagulation tests:
            • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
            • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
            • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased MCV
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with PSS
        • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acathocytes
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased (or decreased) ALT, ALP
        • Variably increased bilirubin (not seen with PSS)
        • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol, glucose
      • Urinalysis:
        • Urine specific gravity is variable, may be inappropriate (USG < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats) due to altered thirst and/or low BUN
        • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
        • Bilirubinuria (not seen with PSS)
      • Increased bile acids
      • Increased ammonia
    • Asian dog breed microcytosis:
      • Commonly reported in Akitas
      • Variably expressed in Shiba Inu, Jindo, Tosa, Chow Chow, Shar Pei
      • CBC - normal RBC, MCHC, MCH and reticulocytes

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • The RDW is a calculated value based on the distribution width of the MCV using the equation:

RDW = (Standard deviation of MCV / MCV) x 100

RET-He:
Description: Reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) reflects iron availability for developing red blood cells and their function. Because of the short circulating time for reticulocytes (3–4 days), decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin provides a sensitive and early indicator of decreased iron availability caused by blood loss or inflammatory conditions. Reticulocyte hemoglobin decreases prior to the development of anemia. 

 

Decreased RETIC-HGB: decreased iron availability for recent RBC production

 

  • Blood loss
    • Hemorrhage
    • Parasitism
  • Inflammatory disease
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated
    • Neoplasia
  • Combination of blood loss and inflammatory disease
  • Decreased intestinal uptake of iron
  • Iron-deficient diets (very rare)
  • Portosystemic shunts (PSS)
  • Asian dog breed microcytosis

  

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased RETIC-HGB

 

  • Blood Loss (causing decreased iron stores):
    • CBC:
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency worsens
      • Anemia - with severe or continued blood loss
      • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) - with severe or continued blood loss
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
    • CBC:
      • Developing mild to moderate, stable anemia
      • +/- microcytosis
      • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein and globulins
      • Decreased albumin
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Iron Panel:
      • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Increased serum ferritin
    • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Immune-mediated diseases:
        • CBC:
          • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
          • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Systemic infection:
        • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
      • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Neoplasia:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
     

Increased RETIC-HGB (rare)

 

  • Disorders of erythropoiesis, e.g., FeLV, chemotherapy
  • Breed-associated macrocytosis
  • Artifact: severe hemolysis 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased RETIC-HGB

 

  • Disorders of erythropoiesis
    • FeLV infection
      • CBC - macrocytic (high MCV) anemia
      • Positive FeLV antigen or PCR on peripheral blood or bone marrow
    • History of chemotherapy
  • Breed-associated macrocytosis
    • Hereditary condition seen rarely in poodles
    • CBC:
      • Hematocrit normal, RBC low normal
      • Increased MCV
      • Absence of reticulocytosis
  • Artifact of severe hemolysis
    • Severe hemolysis may result in an inability to read RBC parameters.
    • Hemolysis (in vitro)
      • Hemolysis can be an artifact of collection or can be seen post-collection secondary to severe lipemia
      • CBC:
        • Normal RBC, RDW (unless severe), MCV
        • Absence of reticulocytes
      • Chemistry - increased serum triglycerides causing lipemia
    • Intravascular hemolysis
      • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
        • CBC:
          • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, hemoglobin, MCHC
          • Increased MCV and RDW
          • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
          • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
        • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
        • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
        • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
          • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
          • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
          • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
          • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
        • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes
      • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
        • CBC:
          • Decreased RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit and MCHC
          • Increased MCV and RDW
          • Increased reticulocytes
          • Increased nucleated RBCs
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased serum bilirubin
          • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
          • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
        • Urinalysis:
          • Hemoglobinuria
          • Bilirubinuria
          • Proteinuria
        • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
          • Increased zinc concentration
          • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
          • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
            • Onions
            • Garlic
            • Propylene glycol
            • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
            • Phenothiazine (horses)
               

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB), also known as RET-He, is the iron-containing oxygen transport protein inside reticulocytes. Reticulocyte hemoglobin reflects iron availability for developing erythrocytes and red blood cell function.
  • Because of the short circulating time for reticulocytes (3-4 days), decreased RETIC-HGB provides a sensitive and early indicator of inflammatory conditions (causing iron sequestration) and blood loss (causing decreased iron stores) prior to the development of anemia. This is in contrast to changes in red blood cell indices (hemoglobin, MCHC, etc.) which may demonstrate a marked lag time (weeks to months) to become evident following the onset of blood loss or inflammation.
  • RETIC-HGB levels are relatively stable during health. A downward trend in levels, even within the reference interval, in a particular patient is likely to be clinically significant and possible causes of decreased iron availability should be considered.

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • Automated hematology analyzers measure reticulocyte hemoglobin indirectly by different proprietary methods that correlate well.
    • Combined flow cytometric and optical fluorescence is the basis for RET-He measurement at IDEXX Reference Laboratory and on the IDEXX ProCyte Dx.
    • Cellular hemoglobin of reticulocytes is identified as CHr, which is the mean cellular hemoglobin in the reticulocyte histogram on some other platforms.
