        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum bilirubin
        • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
        • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hemoglobinuria
        • Bilirubinuria
        • Proteinuria
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
        • Increased zinc concentration
        • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
        • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
          • Onions
          • Garlic
          • Propylene glycol
          • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
          • Phenothiazine (horses) 
  • Reticulocytosis in absence of anemia
    • Physiologic reticulocytosis - most often due to splenic contraction (dogs only)
      • CBC:
        • Normal RBC, hematocrit, MCV and RDW
        • Reticulocytosis is generally mild
    • Compensated anemia - regeneration of RBCs is keeping up with RBC loss or destruction
      • CBC:
        • RBC and hematocrit at low end of normal
        • MCV and RDW increased
        • Decreased MCH and MCHC
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Absolute erythrocytosis
      • CBC:
        • High normal to increased RBC and hematocrit
        • +/- increased nucleated RBCs 
      • Endocrine
        • Increases in RBC, hemoglobin and hematocrit are typically mild
        • Evaluate for endocrine imbalances:
          • Hyperthyroidism
          • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
          • Acromegaly
      • Secondary polycythemia
        • CBC - marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Erythropoietin (where available) usually increased, but may be normal
        • Systemic hypoxia:
          • Thoracic imaging for evidence of pulmonary disease, cardiac disease, or right-to-left heart defects
          • History of residence in, or travel to, high altitude
          • Decreased PA02 and Sa02
          • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
        • Inappropriate erythropoietin secretion:
          • Renal disorders causing localized hypoxia or paraneoplastic syndrome
          • Abdominal imaging for evidence of kidney abnormalities (e.g. cyst, tumor, hydronephrosis) or extra-renal neoplasia (e.g. hepatoma)
      • Polycythemia vera
        • CBC:
          • Marked increases in RBC and hematocrit (typically > 60%)
          • Platelets - variably increased
        • No evidence of dehydration on physical exam, chemistry or urine specific gravity
        • Decreased or normal erythropoietin (where available)
        • No evidence of systemic hypoxemia, endocrine imbalances, kidney abnormalities or neoplasia
        • Polycythemia vera is often a diagnosis of exclusion

 

Normal Reticulocytes

  • Normal reticulocytes with anemia
    • Non-regenerative anemia
      • Chronic inflammatory disease
        • Infection
        • Immune-mediated
        • Neoplasia
      • Chronic blood loss
        •  Parasitism
        • Hemorrhage
      • Decreased erythropoietin production
        • Chronic kidney disease
        • Hypothyroidism
        • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
      • Bone marrow suppression
        • Drugs/toxins
        • Bone marrow disease
      • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • Immune-mediated (targeting RBC precursors)
        • Pure red cell aplasia
      • Nutritional deficiences
        • Vitamin B12 (cobalamin)
        • Folate
    • Acute pre-regenerative anemia
      • Acute blood loss
      • Acute hemolytic anemia
  • Normal reticulocytes in absence of anemia
    • Normal - a non-anemic patient typically has low numbers of circulating reticulocytes

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Anemia without Reticulocytosis

 

  • Non-regenerative anemia
    • Anemia of chronic inflammatory disease (causing iron sequestration)
      • CBC:
        • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
        • +/- microcytosis
        • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased total protein and globulins
        • Decreased albumin
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Iron Panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and iron binding capacity (transferrin)
        • Increased serum ferritin
      • Next steps to evaluate for evidence of underlying causes of inflammation:
        • Immune-mediated diseases:
          • CBC:
            • Spherocytosis (if IMHA)
            • RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
            • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
          • Coombs - positive if IMHA
          • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
          • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
        • Systemic infection:
          • PCR, serology or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. Lyme, ehrlichiosis, leptospirosis, systemic fungal, heartworm, etc.)
        • Chronic localized inflammation or infection:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
          • Pancreatitis:
            • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
            • Amylase and lipase variably increased
          • Pyelonephritis:
            • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
            • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
            • Urine culture - positive
        • Neoplasia:
          • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
    • Chronic blood Loss - causing iron deficiency
      • CBC:
        • Microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC)
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Iron panel:
        • Decreased total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
        • Normal to increased total iron binding capacity (transferrin)
      • Chemistry:
        • Decreased total protein and/or albumin
      • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
        • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx™ antigen, fecal occult blood
        • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
        • Abnormal coagulation tests:
          • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
          • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
          • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
    • Decreased erythropoietin production
      • CBC:
        • Normocytic, normochromic anemia
        • Decreased RBC and hematocrit
        • Normal RDW
      • Evaluate for underlying causes:
        • Chronic kidney disease:
          • Degree of anemia is relative to severity and chronicity of kidney disease
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus
          • Urinalysis:
            • Inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
            • +/- proteinuria
          • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - variably increased
          • Evaluate blood pressure for systemic hypertension
        • Hypothyroidism:
          • Chemistry - increased fasting serum cholesterol and triglycerides
          • Decreased T4 and free T4, increased cTSH
        • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease):
          • CBC - normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
            • Variably increased potassium and calcium
            • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
            • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
          • Adrenal function tests:
            • Decreased resting serum cortisol
            • Abnormal ACTH stimulation
    • Bone marrow suppression:
      • Assess history for exposure to drugs, e.g.:
        • Chemotherapy
        • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
        • Phenylbutazone (dogs and horses)
        • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
        • Griseofulvin (cats)
      • CBC - variable decreases in other cell lines
        • Thrombocytopenia
        • Leukopenia
        • Absence of regenerative response (normal reticulocytes)
      • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, erythrophagocytosis, immune-mediated destruction of erythrocyte precursors, megakaryocytes or other changes
    • Liver failure or portosystemic shunt (PSS)
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with PSS
        • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acathocytes
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased (or decreased) ALT, ALP
        • Variably increased bilirubin (not seen with PSS)
        • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol, glucose
      • Urinalysis:
        • Urine specific gravity is variable, may be inappropriate (USG < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats) due to altered thirst and/or low BUN
        • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
        • Bilirubinuria (not seen with PSS)
      • Increased bile acids
      • Increased ammonia
    • Acute pre-regenerative anemia
      • Regenerative response can take 3-4 days to become apparent. Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) may be an early indicator
      • Acute blood loss
        • Chemistry - low serum total protein
        • Evaluate for evidence of blood loss
      • Hemolytic disease
        • CBC - RBC agglutination, spherocytes
        • Coombs or saline agglutination tests - variably positive
        • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
        • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria +/- hemoglobinuria

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Reticulocytes are immature red blood cells that do not have a nucleus. Reticulocytes have stainable cytoplasmic RNA which differentiates them from mature red blood cells.
  • Reticulocytes are released into circulation as part of a regenerative response to anemia (except in the horse).
  • Circulating reticulocytes have a 2-3 day life span in dogs.  Reticulocyte life span is more variable in cats.
    • In dogs with an acute anemia, reticulocytosis is noted in about 3-4 days, peak reticulocyte production occurs at about 7 days
    • In cats, peak reticulocyte production is expected 7-14 days after an acute anemia
  • For all species except the horse, anemia can be classified as non-regenerative or regenerative based on the bone marrow response assessed by the number of reticulocytes in circulation. Reticulocytes are rare in the horse.
    • Non-regenerative anemias have low reticulocyte counts.
      • Note that some non-regenerative anemias may be pre-regenerative (the anemia has developed too recently for the regenerative response to have started; typically <3-4 days).
    • Regenerative anemias have increased reticulocyte counts.
  • Reticulocytosis can be found in non-anemic animals due to either splenic contraction or a compensated anemia (the RBC production is greater than RBC loss or destruction)
    • Splenic contraction usually results in a mild reticulocytosis. Moderate to severe reticulcytosis is concerning for signficant underlying disease with compensated anemia.
    • Monitoring CBCs over time can help to determine if the reticulocytosis is persistent and progressive.
    • Concurrent decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) suggests compensated anemia

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Incubation of RBCs with new methylene blue causes the stain to precipitate and allows detection of the RNA and mitochondria on the blood film.
  • Some reticulocytes can be seen on a Wright-stained blood film.  The cells have a blue tinge (polychromatophils) to them but if there is not enough RNA in the cell it may not be detected by this method.
  • Cats have two types of reticulocytes (punctate and aggregate) that can be detected when evaluating reticulocytes on a new methylene blue stained blood film.
    • Aggregate reticulocytes have large aggregates of RNA and are a better indicator of active marrow release
    • Punctate reticulocytes have 2-6 small granules
  • Reticulocytes can be expressed as a reticulocyte concentration or reticulocyte percentage
    • Absolute reticulocyte count (reticulocyte concentration) – the number of reticulocytes per µL.  This is the preferred method for reporting reticulocytes
    • Reticulocyte percentage- the percent RBC that are reticulocytes.  For example – if you have 5 reticulocytes per 1000 RBC, the reticulocyte percentage would be 0.5%
  • Reticulocytes can be evaluated by two techniques
    • Manual – A new methylene blue stained blood smear is evaluated – the number of reticulocytes per 1000 nonnucleated RBCs is evaluated
    • Automated – CBC analyzers either use a light scatter method or florescence detection to identify reticulocytes.

 

   References

 

  • Fuchs J, Moritz A, et al. Reticulocytosis in non-anaemic cats and dogs. J Small An Practice2019 in press.
  • Harvey JW. Atlas of Veterinary Hematology: Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals. Philadelphia, PA: WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA. Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
ROUND:
Description: Roundworms, including Toxocara cati, Toxocara canis, Toxascaris leonina and Baylisascaris procyonis, are intestinal parasites that can infect dogs and cats. Roundworms can cause diarrhea, weight loss or failure to thrive in young puppies and kittens.The Fecal Dx® Test detects a roundworm-specific antigen which is secreted by adult roundworms, allowing detection during the pre-patent period.
 
For routine testing, the Companion Animal Parasite Council (CAPC) recommends combining fecal antigen tests with microscopic examination of feces for eggs to ensure the widest breadth of intestinal parasite detection.
 
Quick Links:
  • Learn more about fecal antigen testing at idexx.com/fecal.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of roundworm infections at www.idexx.com/FecalGuide.
Negative Roundworm Antigen
 
  • Absence of infection
  • Infection with only early larval stages, prior to development of mature worms
  • Low worm burden with antigen below level of detection of the immunoassay
  • An egg flotation positive result and antigen negative result may occur due to:
    • Spurious eggs due to ingestion of feces (coprophagy) without the presence of worms in the intestinal lumen
    • Low worm burden with antigen below the level of detection of the immunoassay

 

Positive Roundworm Antigen

 

  • T. cati or T. canis infection 
  • Infection with other roundworms (e.g. Toxascaris leonina or Baylisascaris procyonis)
  • An egg flotation negative result and antigen positive result may occur due to:
    • Pre-patent infection
    • Intermittent shedding of eggs

 

    Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Roundworm Antigen

 

  • Clinical signs
    • Asymptomatic (especially mature animals)
    • Clinical signs may be seen in heavy infections, especially in puppies and kittens
      • Chronic diarrhea, weight loss
      • Pot belly, poor hair coat, failure to thrive
      • Severe cases have been reported to cause gastrointestinal obstruction and perforation.

 

Additional Information

 

    Physiology

 

  • Toxocara spp. infect the small intestines of dogs and cats.
    • They have a worldwide distribution
    • Dogs are infected with Toxocara canis by transplacental or transmammary transmission or by ingestion of larvated eggs or paratenic hosts (rodents).
    • Cats are infected by ingestion of larvated eggs or paratenic hosts (rodents). Uncommonly, transmammary transmission can occur in cats.
    • Migrating T. canis larvae can cause hepatic, pulmonary and ocular damage.
    • Toxocara can cause significant disease in puppies and kittens: including diarrhea, weight loss, stillbirth and failure to thrive
      • Adult dogs and cats are less likely to have symptomatic infections.
    • Toxocara species are also a zoonotic risk to humans as they are involved with visceral and ocular larval migrans
  • Toxascaris leonina are small intestinal parasites of dogs and cats.
    • They have a worldwide distribution
    • Dogs and cats are infected by ingestion of larvated eggs or paratenic hosts (rodents, rabbits)
    • Toxascaris is much less common than Toxocara and the clinical significance of this organism is considered minor
  • Baylisascaris procyonis (raccoon roundworm) can occasionally infect the small intestine of dogs and cats.
    • They can be found in parts of North America and Europe.
    • The presumed route of infection in dogs is ingestion of infective eggs or paratenic hosts (rodents, rabbits, birds).
    • Infection in dogs are often asymptomatic with adult worms living in the small intestine; occasionally larval tissue migration to the central nervous system can occur
    • B. procyonis is a zoonotic concern due to severe neurologic and ocular manifestations in infected humans.  Humans are usually exposed by being in close proximity to raccoon fecal material.
  • The prevalence of roundworm infections in dogs in the United States ranges from 2-15.2%.

 

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • In 1,626,104 samples submitted for fecal screening during wellness visit testing of dogs, the roundworm antigen immunoassay detected roundworms in 1.4% of dogs, while fecal flotation detected roundworms in 1.2%. Combining centrifugation fecal flotation with the roundworm antigen immunoassay increased the detection to 1.7% of samples.
  • Traditionally, diagnosis of roundworms is made by fecal flotation.
    • Toxocara spp. are difficult to differentiate to the species level.
      • Toxocara eggs have a thick shell wall with a pitted outer coating. They contain a dark, round single-celled embryo.
      • T. canis tend to have a subspherical shape
        • Size: 85-90 x 75 µm
      • T. cati tend to be more elliptical shaped
        • Size: 65 x 75 µm
    • Toxascaris eggs are elliptical with a thick smooth outer shell; the inner wall of the shell appears wavy. The eggs contain a light colored, single-celled embryo.
      • Size: 75-85 x 60-75 µm
    • Baylisascaris eggs are elliptical in shape with a thick, granular shell wall and contain a single, large, round-celled embryo. The eggs are often covered in a brown proteinaceous material.
      • Size: 63-75 x 53 - 60 µm
  • Roundworm antigen immunoassay detects roundworm-specific antigens secreted from T. cati and T. canis parasites. May potentially also detect the presence of other roundworms (e.g. T. leonina or B. procyonis.)
    • The roundworm-specific antigen is secreted from adult roundworms and is not present in roundworm eggs or early larval stages.

  

  References

 

  • CAPC Guidelines: Ascarid. Companion Animal Parasite Council. capcvet.org/guidelines/ascarid. Accessed July 27, 2022.
  • Elsemore D, Jeng J, Cote J, Hanna R, Lucio-Forster A, Bowman D. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for coproantigen detection of Anclyostroma caninum and Toxocara canis in dogs and Toxocara cati in cats. J of Vet Diagn Invest 2017:177(1-2): 186-189.
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 7th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders Elsevier; 2010.
  • Fahrion AS, Schnyder M, Wichert B, Deplazes P. Toxocara eggs shed by dogs and cats and their molecular and morphometric species specific identification: is the finding of T. cati shed by dogs of epidemiologic relevance? Veterinary Parasitology 2011;177(1-2):186-189.
  • Little SE, Johnson EM, Lewis D, Jakilitsh RP, et al. Prevalence of intestinal parasites in pet dogs in the United States.Vet Parasitology. 2009; 166: 144-152.
  • Sweet S, Hegarty E, McCrann DJ, Kincaid D, Szlosek D. A 3-year retrospective analysis of canine intestinal parasites: fecal testing positivity by age, U.S. geographical region and reason for veterinary visit. Parasite Vector, 2021;14(10):173.
  • Zajac AM, Conboy GA, eds. Veterinary Clinical Parasitology, 8th ed. Ames, IA, Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.

 

Last updated 4/10/2024
SDMA:
Description: IDEXX SDMA (Symmetric DiMethylArginine) is a proven indirect measurement of glomerular filtration rate (GFR), closely reflecting changes in kidney function. As a more sensitive, reliable and earlier indicator of impairment in GFR than creatinine, increased SDMA will often be the first indication of decline of kidney function. An increased SDMA can indicate a variety of primary kidney diseases, and is not influenced by muscle mass, allowing it to remain more reliable than creatinine for reflecting kidney function in patients with poor muscle mass. SDMA can also be an indicator of concurrent diseases causing a negative secondary impact on kidney function, broadening the differential diagnoses and conditions to rule out when SDMA is increased.

 

Increased IDEXX SDMA (>14 µg/dL)

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Includes both acute and chronic kidney disease
      • Infection (e.g. upper UTI, leptospirosis, Lyme)
      • Inflammatory (e.g. glomerulonephritis, tubulointerstitial nephritis)
      • Toxic insult (e.g. NSAIDs, vitamin D toxicity, ethylene glycol)
      • Ischemia
      • Congenital kidney disease (e.g. polycystic kidney disease, renal dysplasia)
      • Renal amyloidosis
      • Renal neoplasia
  • Secondary kidney injury associated with non-renal diseases:
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Vector-borne disease
    • Urinary obstruction - lower
    • Sepsis
    • Certain cancers (e.g. lymphoma)
    • Cardiorenal syndrome
    • Toxic insult
  • High SDMA with normal or decreased creatinine
    • Kidney disease (or secondary kidney injury) accompanied by less than 75% loss of kidney function
      • Early chronic kidney disease
      • Acute kidney injury (e.g. leptospirosis, NSAIDs, toxins, bacterial infection)
    • Kidney disease in a patient with concurrent decreased muscle mass
    • Age-associated increases
      • Puppies have a wider SDMA reference interval of 0-16 µg/dL. SDMA in small-breed dogs may align with adults as early as 6 months of age, while large to giant-breed dogs may take longer to fully mature.
      • Read more at www.idexx.com/SDMApeds
  • Pre-renal: reduction of GFR may increase SDMA in advance of, or along with, creatinine
    • Dehydration
    • Hypovolemia/blood loss
    • Poor cardiac output
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
  • Post-renal
    • Ureteral or urethral obstruction

 

     Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased SDMA

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Start with a complete urinalysis with urine sediment examination to evaluate for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry:
      • SDMA is highly correlated to GFR: impaired GFR will lead to increases in SDMA.
      • SDMA is usually the most sensitive indicator of loss of kidney function, identifying as little as 25% function loss.
      • BUN, creatinine and phosphorus may be increased, but SDMA can increase earlier.
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • IDEXX Cystatin B Test is a urinary kidney biomarker which is increased with active and/or acute renal tubular injury.
    • FGF-23 is an early marker of phosphorus overload which may increase prior to the development of hyperphosphatemia in cats with IRIS (International Renal Interest Society) Stage 1 or 2 CKD.
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging: abnormal kidney size or structure or evidence of pyelonephritis
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs, e.g.
          • Acute: grape/raisin, lily, ethylene glycol, melamine, heavy metals, NSAIDs
          • Chronic: NSAIDs, vitamin D overdose, aminoglycosides, chemotherapeutics
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
        • Ethylene glycol toxicity
          • Urinalysis:
            • Calcium oxalate crystalluria (especially monohydrate forms) as early as 3-6 hours post-ingestion
            • Decreased urine pH
          • Chemistry:
            • Variable increased phophorus and glucose
            • Potassium increased with acute oliguric kidney failure
            • Decreased calcium and TCO2 (bicarbonate)
          • Ethylene glycol levels increased briefly following ingestion; usually negative by 72 hours post-ingestion
        • Vitamin D toxicity
          • History of vitamin D rodenticide ingestion, oversupplementation with vitamin D, or exposure to psoriasis topical treatments
          • Urinalysis: variable calcium oxalate crystalluria
          • Chemistry:
            • Increased calcium and phosphorus
            • Decreased potassium and TCO2 (bicarbonate)
            • Increased ionized calcium
          • Vitamin D serum concentrations increased
          • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreased
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases causing secondary kidney damage
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment: 
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for additional findings and concurrent conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
    • Monitor SDMA and other kidney parameters for normalization, persistence or progression.
      • Aggressive medical management and continued monitoring of renal parameters are indicated when progressive disease is identified.
    • See also the IDEXX SDMA Test Algorithm for additional recommendations on actions to be taken.
  • High SDMA with normal or decreased creatinine
    • Evaluate for other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Start with a complete urinalysis with urine sediment examination to evaluate for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • SDMA is a more sensitive indicator of loss of kidney function than creatinine. Sensitive detection with SDMA provides the opportunity to investigate for active and acute causes of kidney injury which might be reversible if identified and treated promptly, such as in long term monitoring of potentially nephrotoxic drug therapy.
    • Monitor SDMA and other kidney parameters for normalization, persistence or progression.
      • Normalization:
        • SDMA initially increased (with or without concurrent changes in other kidney parameters) but returns to normal on follow-up testing
        • Transient elevations in SDMA that resolve on recheck are consistent with:
          • Dehydration (clinical or subclinical) which has resolved or been treated
          • Acute kidney injury (infection, toxicity or other acute impact) which has resolved
        • Chemistry:
          • SDMA - normalizes on follow-up testing
          • Creatinine and BUN normal and in alignment with SDMA on follow-up testing
        • Urinalysis: urine concentration appropriate in light of hydration status
      • Persistence:
        • SDMA - does not significantly change on follow-up testing
        • Stable increases in SDMA (with or without concurrent changes in other kidney parameters) are consistent with:
          • Stable/ongoing kidney disease
          • Stable/ongoing kidney dysfunction secondary to concurrent disease
      • Progression:
        • Follow-up SDMA concentrations are significantly increased relative to initial results.
        • Progressive increases in SDMA are consistent with:
          • Progressive kidney disease
          • Concurrent disease causing progressive kidney damage
        • Chemistry:
          • SDMA - increases on follow-up testing
          • Creatinine and BUN, if previously normal, will usually come into alignment with SDMA as disease progresses.
        • Urinalysis - loss of concentrating ability becomes apparent
        • Aggressive medical management and continued monitoring of renal parameters are indicated when progressive disease is identified.
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration:
      • Urinalysis - increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum proteins
        • Increased BUN and creatinine
        • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
      • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration +/- shock
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Increased creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
        • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
    • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
      • Decreased blood pressure
      • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
      • Abnormal echocardiogram
  • Post-renal
    • Urinary obstruction occurring in the kidneys, ureter, bladder or urethra
    • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably increased BUN and creatinine
        • Unilateral ureteral or kidney obstruction may result in increases in only SDMA if the non-obstructed kidney has normal function.
      • Increased potassium with complete urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones).

 

Normal IDEXX SDMA (≤14 µg/dL)

  • Normal SDMA with normal or low creatinine
    • Normal kidney function is likely.
      • If SDMA and/or creatinine is at the upper limit of the reference interval, early kidney disease cannot be ruled out. Evaluate a complete urinalysis to confirm there is no other evidence of kidney disease.
  • Normal SDMA with high creatinine (rare)
    • Severe hemolysis
      • IDEXX SDMA results performed at the Reference Laboratory may be decreased by 10-25% in dogs and 10-20% in cats when severe hemolysis is present.
      • The Catalyst SDMA Test is not affected by hemolysis.
    • Biologic and assay variability
      • SDMA and creatinine can both be affected by biologic and assay variability resulting in fluctuations around the upper end of the reference interval.
      • This can be seen with well-managed stable chronic kidney disease (CKD) and results will likely align as disease progresses.
    • Muscular dogs with normal kidney function
      • May have a normal SDMA and a creatinine just exceeding the reference interval.

Additional Information

 

    SDMA Resource Quick Links:

  • ﻿Visit www.idexx.com/SDMA for additional information about SDMA.

  • View the IDEXX SDMA Test Algorithm for information on how to investigate, manage and monitor kidney disease.

  • Visit www.idexx.com/SDMA-IRIS for information about SDMA and the International Renal Interest Society (IRIS) CKD staging guidelines.

  • Read more about using the IDEXX SDMA Test to assess kidney function in puppies and kittens at www.idexx.com/SDMApeds. 

    Physiology

 

  • SDMA is highly correlated to glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Impairment in GFR is reflected by an increase in SDMA, indicating decline in kidney function.
  • SDMA is more sensitive than creatinine as an indicator of kidney function.
    • SDMA increases on average with 40% and as little as 25% loss of kidney function versus creatinine, which does not increase until up to 75% of kidney function is lost. As a result, creatinine can miss mild to moderate function loss.
    • Sensitive detection with SDMA provides the opportunity to investigate for active and acute causes of kidney injury which might be reversible if identified and treated promptly. Examples would include pyelonephritis, acute kidney injury secondary to infectious causes (e.g. leptospirosis), toxins or long-term monitoring of potentially nephrotoxic drug therapy (e.g. nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)
  • SDMA is more reliable than creatinine as an indicator of kidney function.
    • SDMA is not impacted by muscle mass.
      • Creatinine can be falsely lowered in patients with poor muscle mass. Reductions in lean body mass occur with aging and chronic disease.
      • SDMA is a more reliable indicator of kidney function in cats with hyperthyroidism because SDMA is not impacted by muscle mass.
    • SDMA is not impacted by diet.
      • Creatinine is impacted by ingestion of high meat meals.
  • SDMA increases earlier in acute as well as chronic kidney disease.
    • SDMA can aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of chronic kidney disease (CKD), and in the selection of treatment options for patients staged according to IRIS CKD guidelines.
    • Persistent increases in SDMA provides early identification of developing chronic kidney disease (defined as persistent renal dysfunction with and without increased creatinine)
    • In cats with CKD, SDMA increases on average 17 months before creatinine.
    • In dogs with CKD, SDMA increases on average 9.8 months before creatinine.
    • To learn more, visit www.idexx.com/IRIS-SDMA.
  • An increased SDMA may also serve as an indicator of concurrent diseases that may have a secondary impact on kidney function.
    • Kidney disease can be associated with various diseases including hyperthyroidism, vector-borne disease, hypertension, urinary obstruction, sepsis, neoplasia, cardiorenal syndrome and toxicity.
  • Basic physiology:
    • SDMA is a molecule formed by post-translational methylation of the amino acid L-arginine in the nucleus of cells by the protein-arginine methyltransferase enzymes.
    • During normal protein degradation, these methylated arginine molecules are released.
    • Biologically, SDMA is considered an inert molecule.
    • SDMA is eliminated by the kidneys; therefore, blood concentrations are affected by changes in GFR, making SDMA a good marker for kidney disease.
    • SDMA has been shown to rise in proportion to declining GFR (measured by iohexol clearance) in dogs and cats with kidney disease. Impairment in GFR is reflected by an increased SDMA.
    • SDMA also correlates with creatinine, which becomes apparent with moderate to severe kidney disease when creatinine exceeds the reference interval.
    • Week-to-week variability of iohexol clearance (reflecting GFR), serum creatinine and SDMA are similar in dogs with stable kidney disease.
  • In adult dogs and cats, kittens, and horses, the SDMA reference interval is 0-14 µg/dL.
  • In rats, SDMA reference interval is 0-11 µg/dL. 
  • In puppies, SDMA reference interval is 0-16 µg/dL. 

 

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • The IDEXX SDMA® Test is an immunoassay that uses a patented and proprietary antibody that requires no chemical pretreatment of specimens and specifically binds to SDMA for consistent and accurate measurement. The IDEXX SDMA Test can be measured at IDEXX Reference Laboratories using a high throughput immunoassay or in the veterinary clinic on either the IDEXX Catalyst One® or IDEXX Catalyst Dx® chemistry analyzers.
  • Both the Reference Laboratory IDEXX SDMA Test and the Catalyst SDMA Test have been validated for veterinary use and show extremely high correlation and minimal bias when compared to the reference method, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS).
  • The Reference Laboratory IDEXX SDMA Test is currently validated for dogs, cats, horses and rats.
  • The Catalyst SDMA Test is currently validated for dogs and cats.
  • SDMA can be performed on serum or lithium heparin plasma on both the Catalyst and at the Reference Laboratory. In addition, Catalyst SDMA can be run on whole blood using the Catalyst Lithium Heparin Whole Blood Separator. EDTA plasma is also an acceptable specimen at the Reference Laboratory. 
  • For testing at the Reference Laboratory, SDMA is stable for 4 days at room temperature and 14 days refrigerated. It is also stable for years in specimens that remain frozen and do not undergo freeze-thaw cycles. Long-term stability studies are underway for the Catalyst SDMA Test.
  • Lipemia and icterus do not affect SDMA results. For the Reference Laboratory IDEXX SDMA Test, severe hemolysis may slightly decrease SDMA (10-25% in dogs; 10-20% in cats). Rarely in specimens with severe hemolysis and lipemia, SDMA cannot be measured. The Catalyst SDMA Test is not affected by hemolysis.

SG:
Description:  Urine specific gravity (USG) is a measurement of the concentration of the urine. USG is influenced by several factors including: hydration status, presence of protein or glucose, and underlying disease states.   

 

Inappropriate Urine Concentration (in light of hydration status, USG<1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 

 

  • Resistance to ADH (secondary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Pyometra
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Liver disease
    • Leptospirosis
    • Drug administration (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital)
    • Hypokalemia
    • Polycythemia
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Acromegaly
  • Osmotic
    • Kidney disease
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Renal tubulopathies (e.g. Fanconi syndrome)
    • Drug administration (e.g. furosemide, hydroxyethyl starch solution)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Post-obstructive diuresis
    • High salt diet
  • Lack of medullary concentrating ability
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
    • Liver disease
    • Portosystemic shunt
    • Low protein diet
  • Increased water consumption (primary polydipsia)
    • Liver disease
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Urinary tract infection
    • Hypokalemia
    • Psychogenic water drinking (dog)
    • Gastrointestinal disease
  • Central or primary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Inappropriate Urine Concentration

  • An unconcentrated urine specific gravity may be a normal finding in a well-hydrated patient with no other evidence of disease. This is less common in cats.
    • Confirm that the history is consistent with persistently unconcentrated urine (polyuria, polydipsia, changes in urinary habits, weight loss, etc)
    • Confirm that the lack of urine concentration is persistent on multiple samples, especially on a first morning sample, and evaluate in light of hydration status.
    • Dogs can have a USG as low as 1.000 if engaging in water-based games (e.g. pool play, water hunting). 
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis)e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithaisis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably increased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Hypercalcemia
    • Chemistry - increased total calcium
    • Evaluate for underlying causes of hypercalcemia
      • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
        • Assess for evidence of neoplasia (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, anal gland adenocarcinoma, thymoma) on physical examination with lymph node palpation, abdominal palpation and rectal exam
        • Chemistry:
          • May have increases in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary kidney damage when both phosphorus and calcium are increased
          • Phosphorus decreased if parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) increased
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - low normal or decreased
        • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) - variably increased
      • Primary hyperparathyroidism
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased or low normal phosphorus
          • SDMA, creatinine and BUN usually normal unless concurrent dehydration or kidney disease
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
      • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins (e.g. vitamin D)
      • Chronic kidney disease (renal secondary hyperparathyroidism)
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Ionized calcium - normal
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
  • Hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and PCV
    • Chemistry - variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Total T4 and Free T4 increased

 

 

Decreased Urine Specific Gravity (hyposthenuria; USG<1.008) 

 

  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
  • Pyometra
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Atypical leptospirosis
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
  • Central diabetes insipidus

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Urine Specific Gravity

 

  • The presence of hyposthenuria (urine specific gravity < 1.008) indicates that the kidneys retain the ability to actively dilute the urine, but are unable to concentrate the urine. There are many overlapping causes of inappropriate urine concentration and hyposthenuria.
  • An unconcentrated urine specific gravity may be a normal finding in a well-hydrated patient with no other evidence of disease. This is less common in cats.
    • Confirm that the history is consistent with persistently hyposthenuric urine (polyuria, polydipsia, changes in urinary habits, weight loss, etc)
    • Confirm that the decreasead urine concentration is persistent on multiple samples, especially on a first morning sample, and evaluate in light of hydration status.
    • Dogs can have a USG as low as 1.000 if engaging in water-based games (e.g. pool play, water hunting). 
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoid enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Pyometra
    • History of recent heat in an intact female
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts
      • Variable glucose, proteinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Urine culture with MIC susceptibility - variably positive (may be negative if infection isolated to kidneys)
    • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Atypical leptospirosis
    • Leptospirosis may rarely present with polyuria as the only clinical sign accompanied by minimal changes on minimum data base
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased SDMA
        • Variably mildly increased creatinine and BUN
      • Urinalysis:
        • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria
        • Proteinuria, variable glucosuria
        • Urinary casts (cellular most common, granular casts may also be seen)
      • Confirm infection:
        • A combination of serology and PCR on both peripheral blood and urine is recommended for the highest sensitivity
        • Leptospira antibody by ELISA:
          • Positive in an unvaccinated dog with clinical signs - consistent with infection
          • Negative antibody may be seen in early infection prior to seroconversion
          • Vaccination also results in a positive antibody test
        • Leptospira microagglutination antibody test (MAT) - paired acute and convalescent tests may show a rise in titer consistent with infection. A single titer result less than 1:1600 may be difficult to interpret in a vaccinated dog.
        • Leptospira PCR - positive in peripheral whole blood in early infection, prior to seroconversion. Urine becomes PCR positive 7-14 days after infection (at which point, detection in peripheral blood may be intermittent)
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • CBC unremarkable
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • Decreased sodium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment exam
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Serum osmolality - decreased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • Leptospirosis screening - negative
    • Ability to concentrate with water restriction is variable secondary to medullary washout and loss of concentrating gradient. 
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient.
  • Central diabetes insipidus
    • Rule out other causes of dilute urine prior to investigating for central diabetes insipidus.
    • CBC - variably increased hematocrit, RBC and hemoglobin with secondary dehydration
    • Chemistry - often normal
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • BUN variably decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity consistently <1.012
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - negative
    • Serum osmolality variably high, especially with limited access to water
    • Urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg
    • Daily water consumption >100 ml/kg/day
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • ADH or DDAVP therapeutic trial results in the ability to concentrate urine
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient.
    • CT or MRI may show pituitary tumor

 

Increased Urine Specific Gravity (hypersthenuria; USG > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses)
     

  • Dehydration
  • Concentrated urine may be a normal finding (especially in cats)
  • Artifact - significant glucosuria or proteinuria may increase urine specific gravity
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Urine Specific Gravity

 

  • Dehydration
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, albumin and globulin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Specific gravity is the ratio of a solution's weight to the weight of an equal volume of water and is a reflection of solute concentration and osmolality.
  • Refractive index is an estimate of urine specific gravity
    • Determined by refractometry
    • Highly dependent on three factors
      • Solute concentration
      • Chemical composition of solute
      • Temperature
  • The refractive index of urine should be measured using a properly calibrated veterinary refractometer since calbration scales are different for human urine.
  • Use of dipsticks for measurement of urine specific gravity of veterinary species is unrelable, and is therefore not recommended
  • Specific gravity of randomly collected urine may indicate adequate concentrating ability by the renal tubules
    • Canine:  >1.030
    • Feline:  >1.035
    • Neonates (dogs and cats < 12 weeks of age) and foals on milk do not have efficient urine concentrating ability
  • The amount of other substrates in the urine should be interpreted with consideration of the specific gravity and vice versa
    • Significant glucosuria and proteinuria can falsely increase the urine specific gravity
  • Interpretation of specific gravity requires knowledge of the patient's hydration status, diet, and medications
    • Diuretics, glucocorticoids, anticonvulsants, excessive thyroid hormone supplementation, fluid therapy, low-protein diet, or administration of radiographic contrast media may lower the USG.
  • Specific gravity indicative of adequate renal tubule concentrating ability does not rule out the presence of diseases associated with polyuria/polydipsia, including hepatic insufficiency, hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease), hyperthyroidism or diabetes mellitus.

 

  References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE. Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Toulsa O, Center SA, Brooks MB, et al. Evaluation of plasma protein C activity for detection of hepatobiliary disease and portosystemic shunting in dogs. J Am Vet Med Assoc 2006; 229: 1761-1771.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

SNAPTT4:
Description: Thyroxine (T4) is the major secretory hormone of the thyroid gland.  Thyroxine helps to regulate metabolism, growth, and many organ functions in the body. 

 

Decreased Total T4

 

  • Hypothyroidism
    • Primary hypothyroidism (common in the dog)
      • Lymphocytic thyroiditis 
      • Idiopathic atrophy
      • Follicular cell hyperplasia
      • Neoplastic destruction of the thyroid
    • Iatrogenic hypothyroidism (cat):
    • Secondary hypothyroidism (e.g. pituitary diease)
    • Congenital hypothyroidism (rare)
      • Dyshormonogenesis - iodine organification defect (cats)
      • Thyroid gland dysgenesis (e.g. Giant Schnauzer, Boxer, Tenterfield terrier, Abyssinian cat)
      • Iodine deficiency (all-meat diet)
      • Ingestion of giotrogens (horse) - excess iodine intake during pregnancy
  • Suppression of the pituitary-thyroid axis
    • Euthyroid sick syndrome - suppression of total T4 +/- free T4 in response to clinical illness
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, carprofen)
  • Breed variation - Sight hounds (e.g., Greyhounds), Basenjis, conditioned sled dogs
  • Artifact - anti-T4 antibodies can increase or decrease total T4, depending on methodology

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Total T4

 

  • Evaluate for clinical signs consistent with hypothyroidism:
    • Lethargy, mental dullness, weakness
    • Weight gain with no increase in appetite
    • Alopecia, hyperpigmentation, otitis, pyoderma
  • Evaluate history for concurrent drugs which may decrease total T4, e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, carprofen, furosemide, clomipramine, sulfonamides, phenylbutazone, progestagens, methimazole, propylthiouracil (PTU)
  • Hypothyroidism
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry - increased cholesterol, triglycerides
    • Free T4 - decreased
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to increased
    • Variably increased thyroglobulin autoantibody in primary hypothyroidism
  • Euthyroid sick syndrome
    • CBC, chemistry and urinalysis changes reflect underlying disease
    • Free T4 or free T4 by equilibrium dialysis - often normal; however, severe underlying disease may suppress Free T4.
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to decreased
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Free T4 or Free T4 by equilibrium dialysis - often normal
    • Endogenous cTSTH - normal to decreased
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoid enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

 

Increased Total T4

 

  • Hyperthyroidism (common in the cat)
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Iatrogenic (oversupplementation) 
  • Artifact - anti-T4 antibodies may increase or decrease total T4 (varies by methodology)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Total T4

 

  • Feline hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT
      • Variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity variably <1.035; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status in some cats
      • Variable proteinuria, especially with secondary systemic hypertension
    • Free T4 - increased
    • Endogenous cTSH - decreased
    • Blood pressure - secondary systemic hypertension common
    • Cardiopet proBNP test - increased with secondary cardiomyopathy
    • I-131 thyroid scan abnormal

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Thyroxine (T4) is formed in the thyroid gland.  Adequate ingestion of iodide is required for the normal production of thyroid hormones.  Approximately 80% of the thyroid hormone produced by the thyroid gland is T4 and approximately 20% is T3. 
  • Thyrotropin (TSH) from the pituitary gland will stimulate thyroid hormone secretion. 
    • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus is needed to control TSH secretion from the pituitary. 
    • Negative feedback control of TSH is mediated by unbound fractions of T3 and T4 at the level of the pituitary gland.  
  • Approximately 99.9% of circulating T4 is protein bound. 
    • The free or unbound thyroxine is the active form that can enter cells. 
    • The protein-bound T4 serves as a reservoir of thyroxine. 
    • The total T4 measured is comprised of the protein-bound and unbound hormone. 
  • Pregnancy (progesterone) and obesity can cause mild increases in basal T4 levels. 
  • Young clinically healthy dogs with high T4 values are usually a variant of normal or have T4 autoantibodies. 
  • Dogs with signs of hypothyroidism and a low or low normal T4 should be further evaluated with a free T4 and a TSH. 
  • Senior cats that have T4 values at the high end of the reference range usually have early hyperthyroidism and can be further evaluated with a free T4.
  • In dogs and cats receiving thyroid supplementation, it is recommended to obtain a postpill T4 sample 4-6 hours after thyroid supplementation for peak levels.  The peak T4 levels in dogs should be at the high end or slightly above the reference range.
  • In cats on methimazole therapy, blood sampling can be obtained at any time of the day as long as the cat has received its regular daily dose. 
    • Cats on therapy should have T4 values at the lower end of the reference range.
    • The target for cats with concurrent chronic kidney disease is often a bit higher, especially mid-range normal.

 

   References

 

  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW, Reusch CE, Scott-Moncrief, JCR, eds.  Canine & Feline Endocrinology, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2015. 
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse’s Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
