TBIL:
Description:  Bilirubin is an indicator of liver disease, gall bladder disease or hemolysis.

 

Increased Bilirubin
      

  • Liver disease with intrahepatic cholestasis
    • Infectious (e.g. leptospirosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], bacterial cholangiohepatitis)
    • Inflammatory
      • Primary (e.g. chronic hepatitis, cholangiohepatitis)
      • Secondary (e.g. pancreatitis, gastroenteritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. phenobarbital, mycotoxins, ragwort, alsike clover)
    • Metabolic - hepatic lipidosis
    • Neoplasia
      • Primary liver cancer
      • Metastasis to liver
    • Liver hypoxia or hypoperfusion (e.g. severe anemia, congestive heart failure, shock)
    • Trauma
    • Inherited 
      • Copper storage disease (e.g. Bedlington terriers)
      • Lysosomal storage disorders
      • Degenerative vacuolar hepatopathy in Scottish terrier
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia
  • Functional cholestasis of sepsis (esp. cats)
  • Artifact due to hemolysis or lipemia (varies by methodology)

   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased BIlirubin

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis:
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - bilirubinuria, variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria, bilirubinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Bilirubin is a waste product resulting from the breakdown of heme in a variety of proteins, mainly the red blood cell protein hemoglobin.
  • Hemoglobin is broken down to heme, iron, and globin in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.  Following several additional steps, the heme molecule is further degraded to bilirubin (unconjugated) before release back into the circulation.
  • Unconjugated bilirubin binds to albumin, is transported to the liver, and bound by receptors within the membrane of the liver cell.  Bilirubin is released from albumin, and is taken into the cell by transport molecules.  Bilirubin is then joined with glucuronic acid (conjugated), which allows bilirubin to become water-soluble.
  • Conjugated bilirubin is released into the biliary system to be excreted into the intestinal tract via the bile duct.  Intestinal bacteria convert conjugated bilirubin to the final products that are excreted in the feces.
  • Serum concentrations of bilirubin are proportional to the rate of hemoglobin breakdown, subsequent removal from the serum by the liver, and excretion into the intestinal tract.
  • Horses have higher total bilirubin than other domestic animals; most is unconjugated.

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Most methods of bilirubin measurement are based on the diazo reaction.  With the addition of a reagent, color develops rapidly (direct reaction).  After the addition of alcohol, further color development occurs (indirect reaction). 
  • The direct reacting component is equal to conjugated bilirubin and the indirect reaction gives a measurement of the total serum bilirubin. The difference between these two results, gives a calculated value of unconjugated bilirubin.
  • The proportions of conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin have been investigated in order to differentiate between red blood cell destruction and liver disease.  However, the proportions vary greatly and are of limited clinical use.

 

   References

 

  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
TC02:
Description: TCO2 (Bicarbonate) acts an important buffer in the blood and is used diagnostically to evaluate acid-base status.

 

Decreased TCO2

 

  • Metabolic acidosis
    • Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • Kidney failure
    • Drugs/toxins (e.g. ethylene glycol, metaldehyde, aspirin, ammonium chloride, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors)
    • Gastrointestinal disease (vomiting/diarrhea)
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Lactic acidosis (e.g. shock, hypoxia)
    • Severe rhabdomyolysis
    • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Renal tubular acidosis
    • Urinary obstruction/uroabdomen
  • Compensatory for respiratory alkalosis 
    • Hypoxemia
    • Pulmonary parenchymal disease
    • Central nervous system-mediated hyperventilation
    • Mechanical ventilation

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased TCO2

 

  •  Diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Kidney failure
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate) and calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
      • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
    • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
    • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue
  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Evaluate for history of clinical signs consistent with gastrointestinal disease.
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia, decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variable decreased albumin, cholesterol, total proteins
    • Variable decreased cobalamin, increased or decreased folate with small intestinal diarrhea
    • Abdominal ultrasound - may show evidence of thickened intestines 
    • Evaluate for infectious causes of gastrointestinal disease
      • Fecal Dx Antigen - for hookworms, roundworms and especially for whipworms
      • Diarrhea RealPCR Panel for enterotoxins and viral, bacterial and protozoal causes of diarrhea
      • Whipworm infection
        • Clinical signs:
          • Asymptomatic
          • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
            • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
            • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
        • CBC:
          • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
          • +/- microcytosis
          • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
          • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Chemistry:
          • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
          • Increased potassium
          • Decreased Na:K ratio
          • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
          • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
        • Adrenal tests normal:
          • Resting cortisol
          • ACTH stimulation test
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

 

Increased TCO2 

 

  • Metabolic alkalosis
    • Gastrointestinal disease (upper)
      • Gastric vomiting
      • Small intestinal obstruction
    • Decreased potassium
    • Drugs (e.g. diuretics, bicarbonate administration)
    • Endurance races (horses)
  • Compensatory for respiratory acidosis (with ineffective ventilation)
    • Airway obstruction
    • Cardiac arrest
    • Respiratory center depression
    • Neuromuscular disease
    • Restrictive pulmonary disease
    • Pulmonary parenchymal or vascular disease
    • Inadequate mechanical ventilation
         

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased TCO2

 

  • Gastric vomiting/small intestinal obstruction
    • CBC:
      • Increased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin with secondary dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Chemistry - decreased chloride often seen in cases of GI obstruction
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Diagnostic imaging - evidence of foreign body or other obstruction 

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Bicarbonate is secreted by erythrocytes and selected cells of the kidney, stomach and pancreas and act as as an important buffer in blood.
  • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the major contributor to Total CO2 (TCO2).
  • HCO3- contributes to the calculated anion Gap:  (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-)
  • TCO2 is a component in the evaluation of the patient's acid-base status.
    • Decreased TCO2 is associated with a metabolic acidosis
    • Increased TCO2 is associated with metabolic alkalosis.
  • TCO2 measurement may help to determine if blood gas analysis is needed.
    • Metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders cannot be differentiated using only TCO2 

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
TP:
Description:  Total protein in the blood is primarily composed of albumin and globulins (see individual Differentials) with a minor contribution from coagulation proteins and fibrinogen.

 

Decreased Total Protein

 

  • Decreased production
    • Maldigestion/malabsorption (e.g. small intestinal disease, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency)
    • Malnutrition
      • Decreased intake
      • Severe intestinal parasitism
    • Liver disease
      • Chronic severe liver disease with loss of function
      • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Immunodeficiency (decreased globulins)
      • Failure of passive transfer of colostrum (neonates)
      • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) - esp. Arabian foals
      • Agammaglobulinemia
  • Increased loss
    • Blood loss
    • Protein-losing nephropathy (PLN) 
    • Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE)/lymphangiectasia
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • Protein-losing dematopathy
    • High protein effusions (e.g. pancreatitis, peritonitis, vasculitis, pleuritis)
  • Hemodilution
    • Excess administraion of intravenous fluids
    • Edema disorders (e.g. congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome)
    • Concurrent hypovolemia and increased total body water
      • Fluid accumulation in third space
      • Fluid accumulation in the GI tract
    • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Total Protein

  •  Gastrointestinal disease (maldigestion/malabsorption, protein-losing enteropathy)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Possible megaloblastic, hypochromic RBCs (especially with folate deficiency)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Decreased BUN, cholesterol, albumin and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Cobalamin and folate may be abnormal with secondary small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
    • Trypsin-like immunoreactivity - decreased with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis
    • Fecal alpha-1 protease inhibitor - increased with protein-losing enteropathy
    • Abdominal ultrasound - evidence of thickened intestines with small intestinal disease; abdominal effusion may be present with severe protein-losing enteropathy
  • Malnutrition
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin, globulin and cholesterol
      • Variably decreased BUN
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration variable but may be inappropriate in light of hydration status if BUN is decreased (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Evaluation for possible causes of malnutrition:
      • Assess for history of excessive calorie restriction or very low protein diet
      • Fecal ova and parasites screen, Fecal Dx antigen - positive with intestinal parasites
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit, varaible reticulocytes
      • Microcytic (decreased MCV), hypochromic (decreased MCHC) anemia
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT) may initially be increased, but with loss of functional hepatic mass may be normal to decreased
      • Bilirubin variably increased
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, glucose, cholesterol and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Globulins usually normal
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
  • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and albumin: globulin ratio
      • Globulins usually normal
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
  • Blood Loss:
    • CBC:
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss
      • Reticulocytes: initially elevated, but then decreased as iron deficiency develops
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Platelets - variably decreased (consumption)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
    • Iron panel:
      • Decreasing total serum iron concentration and serum ferritin
      • Normal to increasing total iron binding capacity (transferrin) with progression
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin and globulin
      • Albumin: globulin ratio normal
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of blood loss:
      • Positive fecal ova and parasite screen, Fecal Dx antigen, fecal occult blood
      • Urinalysis: hematuria, transitional epithelial cells on urine cytology
      • Abnormal coagulation tests:
        • Increased prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
        • Prolonged buccal mucosal bleeding time
        • Low von Willebrand factor concentration
  • Protein-losing nephropathy
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoetin)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variable globulins - normal to increased
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
      • Proteinuria 
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)

Increased Total Protein

 

  • Dehydration (with hemoconcentration)
  • Inflammation
    • Chronic inflammatory or immune-mediated disease (e.g. stomatitis)
    • Infection (e.g. feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], ehrlichiosis, chronic pyoderma, ectoparasites, heartworm infection)
  • Neoplasia
    • Multiple myeloma
    • Extra medullary plasma cell tumor
    • Some lymphomas (especially B-cell lymphoma)
  • Artifact - depending on methodology, increases may be seen with:
    • Lipemia
    • Hemolysis
    • Icterus
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Total Protein

  • Dehydration
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, albumin and globulin
      • Normal albumin: globulin ratio
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)
    • Urinalysis - increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate stable nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased globulins
      • Albumin variably decreased (negative acute phase protein)
      • Albumin: globulin ratio decreased
    • Serum protein electrophoresis:
      • Polyclonal gammopathy
      • Increased alpha globulins (acute phase proteins, i.e. fibrinogen)
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for underlying causes of inflammation:
      • Coombs or anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive with immune-mediated diseases
      • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation with polyarthritis
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with chronic pancreatitis
      • Consider PCR, serology or antigen tests for infectious diseases (heartworm, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], Bartonella, ehrlichiosis, Lyme, toxoplasmosis, Leishmania, etc.)
  • Neoplasia (multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, some lymphomas)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Variable hypercalcemia
      • Increased globulins
      • Decreased albumin: globulin ratio
    • Urinalysis - urine protein variably positive
    • Bence Jones urine protein test - variably positive (especially with multiple myeloma or plasma cell tumor)
    • Serum or urine protein electrophoresis - monoclonal gammopathy with multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumors; rarely seen with lymphoma
    • Diagnostic imaging:
      • Radiographs - lytic bone lesions with multiple myeloma
      • Ultrasound - enlarged lymph nodes, spleen, liver or other masses with lymphoma or plasma cell tumor
    • Bone marrow cytology or fine needle aspirate of affected organs, lymph nodes or masses - consistent with neoplasia
    • Lymphoma:
      • Positive PCR for lymphocyte clonal receptor rearrangement (PARR)
      • Clonal expansion on immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) on blood or lymph nodes

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Total protein in serum is made up of albumin and globulins only. In plasma there is also some contribution from fibrinogen and coagulation proteins
  • Total protein in the body is manufactured mostly in the liver and by the structures that comprise the immune system (which make gamma-globulins)

 

  References

 

  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
TRIG:
Description:  Triglycerides are a type of lipid used by the body as an energy source between meals, during times of starvation, or when glucose is unavailable as an energy source (e.g. diabetes mellitus).

 

Increased Triglycerides

  • Post-prandial increase
  • Metabolic
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hyperadrenocorticism
    • Equine hyperlipidemia syndrome
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital, megestrol acetate)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
  • Nephrotic syndrome with severe protein-losing nephropathy
  • Familial or breed-related
    • Idiopathic hyperlipidemia (Miniature Schnauzers)
    • Familial hyperlipoproteinemia (Beagles)
    • Hypertriglyceridemia (Brittany spaniels)
    • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency (rare in dogs and cats)

    Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Triglycerides

 

  • Confirm hypertriglyceridemia is persistent following an overnight fast.
  • Hypothyroidism
    • Evaluate for clinical signs consistent with hypothyroidism:
      • Lethargy, mental dullness, weakness
      • Weight gain with no increase in appetite
      • Alopecia, hyperpigmentation, otitis, pyoderma
    • CBC - nonregenerative anemia
    • Chemistry - increased cholesterol
    • Total T4 - decreased
    • Free T4 - decreased
    • Endogenous cTSH - normal to increased
    • Variably increased thyroglobulin autoantibody in primary hypothyroidism
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, cholesterol, ALP and ALT
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose and cholesterol variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP and bilirubin
      • Variably increased amylase, lipase, cholesterol and glucose
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT, cholesterol and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, and glucose may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial)- increased if liver function decreased. Note: not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable bilirubin and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic or biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT, cholesterol and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Protein-losing nephropathy with nephrotic syndrome
    • Urinalysis:
      • Proteinuria
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Increased cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Triglycerides are a type of lipid, made up of three free fatty acids attached to glycerol.
  • Most circulating triglycerides are found within lipoprotein molecules such as chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDLs).
  • Serum chylomicron concentration peaks 2-6 hours after a meal in dogs and cats
    • Chylomicrons should clear by 8-16 hours after the meal.
  • After digestion triglycerides are packaged into chylomicrons by the enterocytes.
    • The chylomicrons are transported through the lymphatic system to the systemic circulation
    • Once in circulation the triglyceride is broken down by endothelial lipoprotein lipase into free fatty acids and glycerol
      • The free fatty acids diffuse into the tissues and are either resynthesized into triglyceride for storage or used for energy.
    • Excess free fatty acids in the liver are transformed into triglycerides and packaged into VLDL particles which are secreted into the blood
      • Once in the circulation, endothelial lipoprotein lipase breaks down triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol which are then stored or utilized by local tissues for energy.
      • Once the triglycerides are removed from the VLDL, the particle becomes a low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Triglycerides should be measured on a serum sample after a 12 hour fast to avoid postprandial hyperlipidemia.
  • Most assays use a lipase to remove the glycerol from the triglyceride molecule; the glycerol is then measured via spectrophotometry.

 

   References

 

  • Barrett KE, Barman SM, Biotano S, et al., eds. Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th ed. New York: McGraw-Hill; 2016.
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine: Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Williard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

UBG:
Description: Urobilinogen can be an indicator of increased serum bilirubin.  However, there is a poor correlation between increased levels of urobilinogen and either hepatobiliary disease or hemolysis in dogs and cats.

 

Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia)
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocoele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Artifact - False positives due to medications
    • Aminosalicylic acid
    • Sulfonamides
    • Aminobenzoic acid

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic of biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL/Spec fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocoele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.

 

Negative Urobilinogen

 

  • A negative urobilinogen is a normal finding
  • Artifact - False negative
    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Formalin

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Intestinal bacteria convert conjugated bilirubin to urobilinogen (a colorless compound)
  • Most is excreted in the feces.  The remainder is delivered back to the liver via portal blood, recycled, and excreted in the bile. 
  • A small amount of urobilinogen passes through the glomerular filtrate into urine.
  • Diagnostic utility is limited.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Formalin

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Intestinal bacteria convert conjugated bilirubin to urobilinogen (a colorless compound)
  • Most is excreted in the feces.  The remainder is delivered back to the liver via portal blood, recycled, and excreted in the bile. 
  • A small amount of urobilinogen passes through the glomerular filtrate into urine.
  • Diagnostic utility is limited.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
UBG03:
Description: Urobilinogen can be an indicator of increased serum bilirubin.  However, there is a poor correlation between increased levels of urobilinogen and either hepatobiliary disease or hemolysis in dogs and cats.

 

Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia)
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocoele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Artifact - False positives due to medications
    • Aminosalicylic acid
    • Sulfonamides
    • Aminobenzoic acid

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic of biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL/Spec fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocoele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.

 

Negative Urobilinogen

 

  • A negative urobilinogen is a normal finding
  • Artifact - False negative
    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Formalin

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Intestinal bacteria convert conjugated bilirubin to urobilinogen (a colorless compound)
  • Most is excreted in the feces.  The remainder is delivered back to the liver via portal blood, recycled, and excreted in the bile. 
  • A small amount of urobilinogen passes through the glomerular filtrate into urine.
  • Diagnostic utility is limited.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
UPC:
Description:  The urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio is a quantitative measure of all urine proteins. By measuring both the urine creatinine along with the urine protein, the UPC ratio normalizes for variations in urine concentration. Once pre-renal and post-renal causes of proteinuria have been ruled out, a UPC ratio can be used to quantify the degree of renal proteinuria to determine its clinical significance. 

 

Increased Urine Protein: Creatinine (UPC) Ratio

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Glomerulonephritis
        • Idiopathic (primary)
        • Immune-mediated/infectious (secondary)
      • Renal amyloidosis
    • Tubular proteinuria
      • Acute and chronic renal failure
      • Defects in proximal renal tubular function
      • Congenital disorders
    • Functional - transient
      • Fever, shock, cardiac disease, exercise (horse), seizures
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Overload/overflow due to pre-glomerular proteinuria
      • Bence Jones proteins, hyperglobulinemia
      • Post-colostral proteinuria (foals)
      • Hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Transient mild proteinuria
      • Shock
      • Fever
      • Increased physical exercise
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Inflammation or infection in the upper or lower urinary tract (or reproductive tract in voided specimens)
    • Hemorrhage into the urinary or reproductive tract
    • Neoplasia of the urinary tract
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased UPC Ratio

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status.
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, BUN, creatinine and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary renal tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease.
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to deceased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Chemistry: increased globulins
    • Positive Bence Jones proteins in urine
    • Hemoglobinuria
      • CBC - anemia
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
    • Myoglobinuria
      • Chemistry - increased CK, AST
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Complete urinalysis for active sediment:
      • Active urine sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts or crystals
    • Urine culture - positive with urinary tract infection
    • Transitional cell carcinoma:
      • Urine cytology consistsent with neoplasia
      • Positive bladder tumor analyte test
      • Mass visualized on ultrasound
    • Urinary calculi may be visualized on radiographs or ultrasound
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
    • Urinalysis:  urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • ACTH stimulation
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Additional Information

 

   Proteinuria Resource Quick Links:

  • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of renal proteinuria at www.idexx.com/UrineProtein.

 

   Physiology

 

  • The UPC is calculated by dividing the urine protein concentration (mg/dL) by the urine creatinine concentration (mg/dL).  The ratio has no units.
  • Urinary creatinine excretion is constant and is not affected by glomerular filtration rate, therefore, a change in the UPC is due to a change in the urine protein excretion.
  • The UPC correlates with the 24-hour urine protein measurement.
  • The UPC is not affected by gender or time of day.
  • The collection method (cystocentesis vs free catch) does not affect the UPC as long as there is no trauma or hemorrhage with the cystocentesis, and as long as there is no lower urinary tract disease detected by the free catch.
  • A urinalysis with urine sediment should be performed on the same sample as a UPC to evaluate for post-renal causes of proteinuria.
  • If the UPC shows significant proteinuria, then two more UPCs should be done within two weeks to evaluate for transient causes of proteinuria.
  • In dogs, persistent renal proteinuria with UPC values >2.0 usually is due to glomerular disease.
  • In cats, persistent renal proteinuria with UPC values >1.0 usually is due to glomerular disease.
  • The presence of renal proteinuria is a negative prognostic indicator in chronic kidney disease. The greater the magnitude of proteinuria, the greater the risk for progression of renal disease and possible death.
  • Treatments can decrease proteinuria, slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease and improving survival.
  • The UPC can decrease with severe chronic renal disease, because, there is a decrease in functional nephrons and a decrease in the amount of protein lost.  

 

   References

  • Beatrice L, Zatelli A, et al.  Comparison of urine protein-to-creatinine ratio in urine samples collected by cystocentesis versus free catch in dogs.  JAVMA June 2010;236(11):1221-1224.
  • Grodecki KM, Gains MJ, Baumal R, et al. Treatment of X-linked hereditary nephritis in Samoyed dogs with angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. J Comp Pathol. 1997;117: 209-225.
  • Grauer GF, Greco DS, Getzy DM, et al. Effects of enalapril versus placebo as a treatment for canine idiopathic glomerulonephritis. J Vet Intern Med. 2000;14: 526-533.
  • Jacob F, Polzin DJ, Osborne CA, et al. Evaluation of the association between initial proteinuria and morbidity rate or death in dogs with naturally occurring chronic renal failure. J Am Vet Med Assoc. 2005;226: 393-400.
  • Jepson RE, Elliot J, Brodbelt D, et al. Effect of control of systemic blood pressure on survival in cats with systemic hypertension. Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 402-409.
  • King JN, Tasker S, Gunn-Moore DA, et al. Prognostic factors in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 906-916.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Lees GE, Brown SA, et al. Assessment and management of proteinuria in dogs and cats: 2004 ACVIM Forum Consensus Statement (small animal). J Vet Intern Med 2005;19:377-385.
  • Mizutani H, Koyama H, Watanabe T, et al. Evaluation of the clinical efficacy of benazepril in the treatment of chronic renal insufficiency in cats. J Vet Intern Med. 2006;20: 1074-1079.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Syme HM, Markwell PJ, Pfeiffer D, et al. Survival of cats with naturally occurring chronic renal failure is related to severity of proteinuria. J Vet Intern Med. 2006;20: 528-535.
