UREA:
Description:  Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) is produced in the liver and excreted by the kidneys.  It is a marker for both liver and kidney dysfunction.

Decreased BUN 

 

  • Chronic, severe liver disease
    • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
    • Cirrhosis
  • Low protein diets
  • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Glucosuria from renal tubular disorders
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Psychogenic polydipsia
  • Drugs
    • Corticosteroids
    • Growth hormone
    • Other drugs causing diuresis
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Overhydration
  • Urea cycle enzyme deficiencies
  • Protein malnutrition
  • Late pregnancy
  • Artifacts (depending on method of analysis)
    • High concentrations of sodium fluoride and sodium citrate
    • Chloramphenicol
    • Severe lipema


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased BUN

 

  • Chronic, severe liver disease
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine (unless concurrent renal disease is present)
      • Decreased albumin, cholesterol, glucose
      • Increased bilirubin and/or increased liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT)
    • Abnormal liver function tests:
      • Increased fasting and post-prandial bile acids
      • Increased fasting ammonia
    • CBC:
      • Microcytic, hypochromic anemia (especially in PSS)
      • Acanthocytes
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (e.g. PSS)
  • Severe polyuria/polydipsia
    • Urinalysis - decreased urine specific gravity
    • Diabetes mellitus:
      • Increased serum glucose
      • Increased serum fructosamine
      • Urinalysis - glucosuria +/- ketones
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased ALP
        • Normal SDMA and creatinine
      • Abnormal adrenal function tests
        • ACTH stimulation
        • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Increased BUN 

 

  • Kidney disease
    • Infection (e.g. upper UTI, leptospirosis, Lyme)
    • Inflammatory (e.g. glomerulonephritis, tubulointerstitial nephritis)
    • Toxic (e.g. NSAIDs, ethylene glycol)
    • Ischemia
    • Congenital kidney disease (e.g. polycystic kidney disease, renal dysplasia)
    • Renal amyloidosis
    • Renal neoplasia
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration
    • Hypovolemia/blood loss
    • Poor cardiac output
    • Hypoadrenocortism (Addison's disease)
    • Recent high protein meal
    • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
    • Catabolism of body tissues
      • Fever
      • Trauma
  • Post-renal
    • Uroabdomen
    • Ureteral or urethral obstruction 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased BUN

  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • IDEXX Cystatin B Test is a urinary kidney biomarker which is increased with active and/or acute renal tubular injury.
    • FGF-23 is an early marker of phosphorus overload which may increase prior to the development of hyperphosphatemia in cats with IRIS (International Renal Interest Society) Stage 1 or 2 CKD.
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal renal size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
        • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
          • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
            • Urinary casts
            • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
          • CBC:
            • Inflammatory leukogram
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
          • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for additional findings and concurrent conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Pre-renal
    • Dehydration:
      • Urinalysis: increased urine specific gravity (hypersthenuria) >1.030 in dogs; >1.035 in cats; >1.025 in horse
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased serum proteins
        • Increased SDMA and creatinine
        • Increased phosphorus only with severe pre-renal disease
      • CBC - increased hematocrit/PCV
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease) - often accompanied by dehydration, gastrointestinal bleeding +/- shock
      • CBC:
        • Nonregenerative anemia
        • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Chemistry:
        • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
        • Variably increased potassium and calcium
        • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
        • Increased SDMA and creatinine with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
        • Increased BUN may be associated with gastrointestinal bleeding or decreased renal perfusion
      • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status. (Urine specific gravity < 1.030 in dogs; < 1.035 in cats; < 1.025 in horses)
      • Adrenal function tests:
        • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
        • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation (diagnostic test)
    • Heart failure or shock - decreased cardiac output and blood flow to the kidneys
      • Decreased blood pressure
      • Increased Cardiopet proBNP test
      • Abnormal cardiac silhouette/pulmonary parenchyma on thoracic radiographs
      • Abnormal echocardiogram
    • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
      • Evaluate for evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding:
        • Presence of melena or positive fecal occult blood
        • History of predisposing conditions or medications.
      • Chemistry: normal SDMA and creatinine
  •  Post-renal
    • If post-renal causes are suspected based on physical exam and history, evaluate a complete urinalysis for active sediment and crystalluria.
    • Urinalysis - urine sediment may have white blood cells, red blood cells, crystals or bacteria.
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA and creatinine
      • Increased potassium with urinary tract obstruction or leakage
    • Uroabdomen:
      • Abdominal fluid contains higher creatinine concentration than serum
      • Abnormal ultrasound suggests rupture
      • Contrast radiographs for urinary tract rupture/leakage
    • Abdominal radiographs, contrast studies, or ultrasound may suggest post-renal obstruction (e.g. masses, stones).

 

Additional Information
   
   Physiology

 

  • Urea is produced exclusively by the liver from ammonia.
  • It is predominantly excreted by the kidneys and is the main form in which nitrogen is removed from the body.  Some urea is passively reabsorbed from the renal tubules back into the blood, but most is excreted.
  • While urea is predominantly a waste product of protein metabolism, it is an important factor in establishing the medullary osmotic gradient in the kidneys.  This allows the renal tubules to modify the water content of urine.  In medullary washout syndrome there is insufficient urea in the renal medulla to allow the urine to be appropriately concentrated.
  • Renal urea reabsorption is enhanced by antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
  • SDMA and creatinine are not significantly reabsorbed by the renal tubules, therefore they are less affected by urine flow rate than is BUN.
  • BUN readily diffuses into blood and all body water in similar concentrations.
  • There is an inverse relationship between BUN and glomerular filtration, and between BUN and renal tubular flow rate.
  • Increased BUN is not specific for primary renal disease, but is a major contributor to azotemia, along with SDMA and creatinine.
  • BUN concentrations are affected by other extra renal factors (more so than SDMA and creatinine concentrations).  These extra renal factors include other diseases, some chemicals and drugs, diet, and condition of serum (e.g. lipemia).
  • Because SDMA is influenced by fewer non-renal variables than BUN and creatinine, it is a more accurate indicator of kidney function.

 

   References

  • Braun JP, Lefebre, Watson ADJ. Creatnine in the dog: a review. Vet Clin Path. 2003;32(4): 162-179.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Yu S, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in healthy geriatric cats fed reduced protein foods enriched with fish oil, L-carnitine, and medium-chain triglycerides. Vet J. 2014;202(3): 588-596.
  • Hall JA, Yerramilli M, Obare E, Yerramilli M, Melendez LD, Jewell DE. Relationship between lean body mass and serum renal biomarkers in healthy dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(3): 808-814.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Almes K, Jewell DE. Serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine in dogs with naturally occurring chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2016;30(3): 794-802.
  • Hall JA, Yeramilli M, Obare E, Yeramilli M, Jewell DE. Comparison of serum concentrations of symmetric dimethylarginine and creatinine as kidney function biomarkers in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2014;28(6): 1676-1683.
  • Nabity MB, Lees GE, Boggess M, et al. Symmetric dimethylarginine assay validation, stability, and evaluation as a marker for early detection of chronic kidney disease in dogs. J Vet Intern Med. 2015;29(4): 1036-1044.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

URIC01:
Description:  Uric acid crystals in the urine are uncommon.  They can be variable in size with yellow, yellow-brown or red appearance. These crystlas often have pointed ends with a diamond, hexagonal or barrel shape appearance.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. 

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CrystalImages.   

 

Increased Uric Acid Crystals

 

  • Breed-associated hyperuricosuria
    • Most common in Dalmations, English bulldogs and Black Russian Terrier breeds.
  • Portosystemic shunt
  • Liver disease
  • May be a normal finding (especially in concentrated urine)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Uric Acid Crystals

 

  • Possible artifact:
    • Evaluate a fresh urine sample at room temperature immediately after collection to determine whether crystalluria is persistent.
    • Post-collection precipitation of crystals
      • Clinical signs typically absent
      • History or urine specimen being refrigerated or a delay in analysis
      • Urinalysis:
        • Crystalluria with an otherwise inactive urine sediment
        • Urine specific gravity variably high
    • True crystalluria - uric acid crystals are uncommon in clinically healthy animals and underlying disease should be investigated.
  • Breed-associated hyperuricosuria
    • CBC and chemistry typically unremarkable
    • Bile acids (pre- and post-prandial) - normal
    • Genetic test on buccal swab - positive for mutation in SLC2A9 gene
  • Portosystemic shunt
    • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
    • CBC:
      • Decreased MCV
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
    • Chemistry:
      • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
      • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose
      • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses
      • Ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
    • Ammonia - increased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
    • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
    • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
    • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
    • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids (pre- and post-prandial) - elevated
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Uric acid crystals are the precipitation of salts which are more likely to form in acidic urine.
  • The amount of crystalluria depends on the pH, ion concentrations, and temperature of the urine.
  • While crystalluria is a risk factor for urolithiasis, the presence or absence of crystals does not predict the presence or absence of urolithiasis.
  • Crystals may form or dissolve in urine samples that are aged or have been altered due to evaporation, refrigeration, or changes in pH. Refrigerated samples should be warmed to room temperature prior to performing the urinalysis.
  • Uric acid crystals can be seen in healthy animals, though increased numbers might indicate underlying pathology causing changes in urine ion concentrations or pH.
  • To evaluate the significance of crystalluria, urinalysis should be performed on a fresh (<30-60 min), non-refrigerated sample. 

 

   References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
VSGlu:
Description:  Glucose is the basic energy source for the body. 

 

Decreased Glucose

 

  • Insulin excess
    • Insulin overdose (exogenous)
    • Insulinoma (endogenous)
  • Neonatal or juvenile hypoglycemia
  • Liver disease/failure
  • Sepsis/severe infection
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
  • Drugs/toxins (e.g. sulfonylureas, xylitol, antihistamines, beta-blockers)
  • Congenital
    • Growth hormone deficiency
    • Hypopituitarism
  • Exercise induced hypoglycemia (hunting dogs, endurance horses)
  • Neoplasia (paraneoplastic)
  • Starvation (mild decrease only)
  • Pregnancy (late gestation in the dog)
  • Artifact
    • Failure to spin and separate the blood sample within 30-60 minutes of collection
    • Handheld glucometer, esp. with hemoconcentration
       


   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Glucose

 

  • Review medication history, especially insulin and oral hypoglycemics, and potential exposure to toxins
  • Insulinoma
    • Increased insulin:glucose ratio (measured on specimen with low glucose)
    • Abdominal ultrasound may show pancreatic or hepatic masses.
    • Consistent cytological or histopathological findings
  • Liver disease/failure
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL, Spec fPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis) e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN and cholesterol (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably deceased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Sepsis/severe infection
    • CBC:
      • Inflammatory leukogram (band neutrophils, toxic neutrophils, etc.)
      • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • Variably increased bilirubin and globulins
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT) annd activate partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass) - suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

 

Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Physiologic response (mild increase)
    • Stress (especially cats)
    • Post-prandial
    • Diestrus (dogs)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • Acromegaly (cats)
  • Drugs (e.g. glucocorticoids, megestrol acetate, progesterone, ketamine)
  • Hepatocutaneous syndrome (dogs)
  • Hyperammonemia (horses)
  • Thyroid disease (rare)
    • Hyperthyroidism (cats)
    • Hypothyroidism (dogs)
  • Neoplasia 

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Glucose

 

  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL, Spec cPL, or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Stress hyperglycemia
    • Fructosamine - normal
    • Urinalysis on sample collected at home has normal urine glucose
  • Pancreatitis
    • Evaluate for presence of clinical signs consistent with acute or chronic pancreatitis and for conditions which might be associated with secondary pancreatitic inflammation (e.g. intestinal obstruction, cholangiohepatitis).
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Variable mildly decreased platelets
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry
      • Increased ALT, ALP, bilirubin and cholesterol
      • Variably increased amylase and lipase
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
      • Decreased albumin, potassium and, in severe cases, calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Bilirubinuria, variable glucosuria
      • Variable proteinuria and urinary casts
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Spec cPL, Spec fPL or Catalyst Pancreatic Lipase test - increased
    • Radiographs:
      • Acute pancreatitis - loss of abdominal detail, dilated intestinal loops, variable pleural effusion
      • Chronic pancreatitis - no specific findings
    • Abdominal ultrasound:
      • Acute pancreatitis - enlarged hypoechoic pancreas, hyperechoic peripancreatic fat, free fluid in region of pancreas
      • Chronic pancreatitis - variable changes may be detected or may be unremarkable
      • Ultrasound has a low sensitivity for pancreatitis (especially chronic) in cats.
    • Biopsy:
      • Pancreatic acinar cell damage and inflammatory infiltrates, +/- fibrosis (in chronic pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic lesions may have a patchy distribution throughout the pancreas; multiple biopsies may be necessary to confirm diagnosis
  • Hyperadrenocortism (Cushing's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy

Additional Information

   Physiology

 

  • Glucose is produced from digestion of carbohydrates in the gastrointestinal tract.  It is also released via breakdown of glycogen stores in the liver (glycogenolysis).  The liver manufactures glucose from products of protein and fat metabolism (gluconeogenesis).
  • Glucose is tightly regulated by various endocrine hormones, especially insulin and glucagon.
  • Insulin stimulates uptake of glucose into most cells, including adipocytes (fat cells) and myocytes (muscle).
  • Neurons, blood cells, and hepatocytes do not require insulin for glucose uptake.
  • Glucagon increases blood glucose by stimulating glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology 

 

  • Most glucose assays are photometric and are influenced to varying degrees by lipemia, hemolysis, and icterus.  Nonphotometric assays have fewer chemical and photometric interferences.


   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Macintire DK, Drobatz KJ, Haskins SC, Saxon WD. Manual of Small Animal Emergency and Critical Care Medicine, 2nd ed. West Sussex UK: Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 9/1/2024
WBC:
Description: White blood cells (WBC) are the sum of various types of circulating immune cells (neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils and basophils). Changes in any individual cell line can affect the total WBC count, however, changes in WBC most commonly reflect increases or decreases in the neutrophils. See the separate Differentials summary for the affected cell type for a detailed summary specfic to that cell line.

 

Decreased White Blood Cells    

   

  • Decreased white blood cell production
    • Infection
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Immune-mediated (targeting white blood cell precursors) 
    • Idiopathic
  • Excessive tissue demand and/or destruction of neutrophils
    • Endotoxemia/sepsis
    • Inflammation
    • Bacterial infection
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia 

  

Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased White Blood Cells

 

  • CBC may show decreases in other cell lines:
    • Non-regenerative anemia
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Assess for history or possibility of exposure to drugs that may suppress bone marrow, e.g.: 
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Azathioprine
      • Chloramphenicol
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Methimazole 
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of myeloid cell line or other changes
    • Next steps to evaluate for infectious causes:
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Blood film review - toxic neutrophils, band neutrophils or reactive lymphocytes 
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Serology or PCR tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. parvovirus, panleukopenia, FeLV, FIV, ehrlichiosis)
    • Idiopathic neutropenia is a diagnosis of exclusion.
      Decreased white blood production
  • Excessive tissue demand (and destruction) of neutrophils
    • Migration into tissues in response to endotoxin, inflammation or infection where the rate of migration exceeds the rate of replacement from the bone marrow.
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review:
        • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils, toxic neutrophils may be seen 
        • Red blood cell fragments (e.g. schistocytes, poikilocytes) may be seen with secondary disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP) 
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection where neutrophils may be sequestered
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
      • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria

 

Increased White Blood Cells 

 

  • Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia (stress leukogram)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
  • Chronic or acute leukemia

  

Related Findings and Next Steps for Increased White Blood Cells

 

  • Evaluate for the presence of immature neutrophils (bands):
    • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX Procyte Dx) may show a band indictator.
    • Comparison of patient WBC dot plot to species-specific normals may show pattern changes consistent with the presence of bands.
      • For example, in the IDEXX ProCyte Dx, the WBC dot plot shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population if bands are present.
    • Blood film review
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophils have toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
          • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases: 
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced leukocytosis
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • +/- increased platelets, plateletcrit, MPV, PDW
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review, absence of a left shift
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response 
    • CBC:
      • Increased neutrophils and lymphocytes
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • White blood cells encompass five different cell lines found in the blood: neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • The lifespan of most white blood cells in blood is short: half-lives are only several hours, so total white blood cell counts and the ratio of cell lines can change very quickly. This makes the white blood cell count potentially an early detector of disease.
  • White blood cells are activated and increase in number in response to a myriad of stimuli, such as infecting agents (viral, bacterial, fungal, parasitic, etc.), foreign substances, tissue damage, necrosis, and cancers.
  • Although activation and increase in numbers of white blood cells occur in response to such stimuli, actual measured white blood cell numbers in the blood may vary due to the relative numbers in the bloodstream compared to numbers that have left the bloodstream and entered tissues and body cavities.
  • White blood cells may destroy infectious agents, damaged tissue, and foreign substances, recruit other white blood cells, and in some cases wall off the abnormal area.
  • Ratio of specific types of white blood cells that are activated may depend on the type or location of the stimulus.
  • Neoplastic transformation of white blood cells typically involves abnormal unchecked production of a single cell line.
       

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The white blood cell (WBC) count is the total number of white blood cells contained in a cubic millimeter (mm3) or microliter (µL) of whole blood.
  • Neutrophils, band neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils are included in the white blood cell results.
  • Some automated counting instruments will also count nucleated red blood cells (nRBCs) causing a falsely increased WBC count.  Most laboratories provide a corrected WBC count on CBC reports.
  • Evaluation of the WBC dot plot can provide valuable information about the presence of immature neutrophils (bands), platelet clumping or morphologic abnormalities which may impact the automated white blood cell differential.
  • Morphology evaluation can provide valuable clues as to potential cause of WBC abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

  

    References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott, Williams, and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
WBC01:
Description:  White blood cells in the urine are an indicator of inflammation, infection, or neoplasia in the urinary tract.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm. 

  

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/BloodCellImages.

 

Increased White Blood Cells

   

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Bacterial cystitis
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Prostatitis
  • Urinary tract inflammation
    • Feline idiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract inflammation [FLUTD])
    • Urolithiasis
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma, prostatic carcinoma)
  • Vaginitis (voided sample)
     

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased White Blood Cells

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.

 

Decreased White Blood Cells

  • Absence of white blood cells in the urine is a normal finding
  • Artifact (e.g. cell lysis, leukocyte clumping, dilute urine)
  • Poor inflammatory response despite urinary tract infection
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Anti-inflammatory medications

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Evaluation for the presence of leukocytes is performed during the microscopic examination of the urine sediment.
  • The number of detectable leukocytes in urine is affected by multiple factors
    • Method of sample collection
    • Preservation of cellular components
    • Sample volume and concentration (specific gravity)
    • Technique of leukocyte detection
  • Methodologies
    • Microscopic examination of urine sediment is recommended for veterinary species
    • Leukocyte esterase detection (dipstick test) is not recommended for veterinary species

 

   References

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds. Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
WBC_BLD:
Description: White blood cells (WBC) are the sum of various types of circulating immune cells (neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils and basophils). Changes in any individual cell line can affect the total WBC count, however, changes in WBC most commonly reflect increases or decreases in the neutrophils. See the separate Differentials summary for the affected cell type for a detailed summary specfic to that cell line.

 

Decreased White Blood Cells    

   

  • Decreased white blood cell production
    • Infection
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Immune-mediated (targeting white blood cell precursors) 
    • Idiopathic
  • Excessive tissue demand and/or destruction of neutrophils
    • Endotoxemia/sepsis
    • Inflammation
    • Bacterial infection
  • Immune-mediated neutropenia 

  

Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased White Blood Cells

 

  • CBC may show decreases in other cell lines:
    • Non-regenerative anemia
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Assess for history or possibility of exposure to drugs that may suppress bone marrow, e.g.: 
      • Chemotherapy
      • Estrogen (endogenous or exogenous)
      • Azathioprine
      • Chloramphenicol
      • Trimethoprim sulfadiazine/sulfonamide
      • Methimazole 
    • Bone marrow cytology or biopsy to assess for decreased cellularity, neoplastic infiltration, fibrosis, immune-mediated destruction of myeloid cell line or other changes
    • Next steps to evaluate for infectious causes:
      • CBC:
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
        • Blood film review - toxic neutrophils, band neutrophils or reactive lymphocytes 
      • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
      • Serology or PCR tests - positive for infectious diseases (e.g. parvovirus, panleukopenia, FeLV, FIV, ehrlichiosis)
    • Idiopathic neutropenia is a diagnosis of exclusion.
      Decreased white blood production
  • Excessive tissue demand (and destruction) of neutrophils
    • Migration into tissues in response to endotoxin, inflammation or infection where the rate of migration exceeds the rate of replacement from the bone marrow.
    • CBC:
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Blood film review:
        • Neutrophil bands may outnumber mature neutrophils, toxic neutrophils may be seen 
        • Red blood cell fragments (e.g. schistocytes, poikilocytes) may be seen with secondary disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP) 
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for evidence of effusion, localized inflammation or infection where neutrophils may be sequestered
    • Positive bacterial culture (e.g. of urine, blood, body cavity effusion, etc.)
    • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
      • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria

 

Increased White Blood Cells 

 

  • Inflammation
    • Infection
    • Immune-mediated disease
    • Tissue necrosis
    • Neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced neutrophilia (stress leukogram)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
    • Exogenous steroids
    • Stress
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
  • Chronic or acute leukemia

  

Related Findings and Next Steps for Increased White Blood Cells

 

  • Evaluate for the presence of immature neutrophils (bands):
    • Some analyzers (e.g. IDEXX Procyte Dx) may show a band indictator.
    • Comparison of patient WBC dot plot to species-specific normals may show pattern changes consistent with the presence of bands.
      • For example, in the IDEXX ProCyte Dx, the WBC dot plot shows overlapping clusters with the neutrophil population shifting upwards into the lymphocyte population if bands are present.
    • Blood film review
  • Inflammation
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia may be seen with chronic inflammation.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram:
        • Neutrophils have toxic changes +/- band neutrophils 
        • Increased monocytes
        • Decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes 
      • Leukemoid responses with extreme neutrophilia (50K-100K/ul) and left shift can be seen with some causes (e.g. pyometra, peritonitis, Hepatozoon spp. infection, paraneoplastic response, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia [IMHA] or thrombocytopenia [ITP]).
    • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
    • Coagulation profile - variably abnormal with secondary DIC:
      • Increased prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), d-dimer and fibrin degradation products
      • Decreased fibrinogen and platelets
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of inflammation:
      • Systemic infection:
        • Serology, PCR or antigen tests - positive for infectious diseases
        • Blood culture or urine culture - positive with systemic bacterial infections
      • Localized inflammation or infection:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for localized inflammation or infection
          • Cytology (e.g. of effusion, affected organ or mass):
          • Suppurative or pyogranulomatous inflammation +/- bacteria
        • Culture of affected site variably positive
        • Pancreatitis:
          • Spec cPL or Spec fPL Test increased
          • Amylase and lipase variably increased
        • Pyelonephritis:
          • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
          • Urinalysis - active sediment (pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, casts)
          • Urine culture - positive
      • Immune-mediated diseases: 
        • CBC:
          • Regenerative anemia with spherocytosis or RBC agglutination (if IMHA)
          • Severe thrombocytopenia (if ITP)
        • Coombs - positive if IMHA
        • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) tests - variably positive
        • Joint fluid cytology - neutrophilic inflammation if immune-mediated polyarthritis
      • Neoplasia:
        • Diagnostic imaging (radiographs and/or ultrasound) to assess for neoplasia
  • Corticosteroid-induced leukocytosis
    • May be a transient stress response or reflect exogenous steroid exposure or endocrine imbalance (hyperadrenocorticism)
    •  CBC shows stress leukogram:
      • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
      • +/- increased platelets, plateletcrit, MPV, PDW
      • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review, absence of a left shift
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP (dogs)
      • Variably increased glucose
    • Urinalysis - inappropriate concentration (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses)
    • Assess for history of recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical).
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation test
  • Epinephrine-induced physiologic leukocytosis
    • Seen commonly in young animals as a transient stress response 
    • CBC:
      • Increased neutrophils and lymphocytes
      • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • White blood cells encompass five different cell lines found in the blood: neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • The lifespan of most white blood cells in blood is short: half-lives are only several hours, so total white blood cell counts and the ratio of cell lines can change very quickly. This makes the white blood cell count potentially an early detector of disease.
  • White blood cells are activated and increase in number in response to a myriad of stimuli, such as infecting agents (viral, bacterial, fungal, parasitic, etc.), foreign substances, tissue damage, necrosis, and cancers.
  • Although activation and increase in numbers of white blood cells occur in response to such stimuli, actual measured white blood cell numbers in the blood may vary due to the relative numbers in the bloodstream compared to numbers that have left the bloodstream and entered tissues and body cavities.
  • White blood cells may destroy infectious agents, damaged tissue, and foreign substances, recruit other white blood cells, and in some cases wall off the abnormal area.
  • Ratio of specific types of white blood cells that are activated may depend on the type or location of the stimulus.
  • Neoplastic transformation of white blood cells typically involves abnormal unchecked production of a single cell line.
       

    Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Automated analyzers use a variety of proprietary techniques to count and differentiate white blood cells including flow cytometry and laser systems, with selective staining for optical fluorescence.
  • The white blood cell (WBC) count is the total number of white blood cells contained in a cubic millimeter (mm3) or microliter (µL) of whole blood.
  • Neutrophils, band neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils are included in the white blood cell results.
  • Some automated counting instruments will also count nucleated red blood cells (nRBCs) causing a falsely increased WBC count.  Most laboratories provide a corrected WBC count on CBC reports.
  • Evaluation of the WBC dot plot can provide valuable information about the presence of immature neutrophils (bands), platelet clumping or morphologic abnormalities which may impact the automated white blood cell differential.
  • Morphology evaluation can provide valuable clues as to potential cause of WBC abnormalities (inflammation, infection, neoplasia, etc.).

  

    References

 

  • Feldman BF, Zinkl JG, Jain NC, eds.  Schalm's Veterinary Hematology, 5th ed.  Philadelphia, PA:  Lippincott, Williams, and Wilkins; 2000.
  • Harvey JW.  Atlas of Veterinary Hematology:  Blood and Bone Marrow of Domestic Animals.  Philadelphia, PA:  WB Saunders; 2001.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 7/1/2018
WHIP:
Description: Whipworms, including Trichuris vulpis and Trichuris felis (formerly Trichuris serrata), are intestinal parasites infecting the large intestine of the dog and cat. The Fecal Dx® Test detects a whipworm-specific antigen which is secreted by adult whipworms, allowing detection during the pre-patent period.

For routine testing, the Companion Animal Parasite Council (CAPC) recommends combining fecal antigen tests with microscopic examination of feces for eggs to ensure the widest breadth of intestinal parasite detection.

Quick Links:

  • Learn more about fecal antigen testing at idexx.com/fecal.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of whipworm infections at www.idexx.com/FecalGuide.

 Negative Whipworm Antigen

 

  • Absence of infection
  • Infection with only early larval stages, prior to the development of mature worms.
  • Low worm burden with antigen below level of detection of the immunoassay
  • An egg flotation positive result and antigen negative result may occur due to:
    • Spurious eggs due to ingestion of feces (coprophagy) without the presence of worms in the intestinal lumen
    • Low worm burden with antigen below level of detection of the immunoassay

 

Positive Whipworm Antigen

 

  • Whipworm infection
  • An egg flotation negative result and antigen positive result may occur due to:
    • Pre-patent infection
    • Intermittent shedding of eggs
    • False negative fecal flotation: the density of whipworm eggs makes them more challenging to detect by fecal flotation

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Whipworm Antigen

 

  • Clinical signs:
    • Asymptomatic
    • Clinical signs and laboratory abnormalities are more common with heavy infections
      • Colitis with mucus and/or fresh blood in the stool
      • Weight loss, dehydration and occasionally death (severe cases)
  • CBC:
    • Mild to moderate, stable anemia
    • +/- microcytosis
    • Hypochromasia (uncommon)
    • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Inflammatory leukogram
  • Chemistry:
    • Laboratory abnormalities confusing for Addison's disease can develop rarely with severe infections.
    • Increased potassium
    • Decreased sodium and Na:K ratio
    • Metabolic acidosis (decreased TCO2)
    • Increased BUN, creatinine and SDMA with severe dehydration accompanied by decreased GFR
  • Adrenal tests normal:
    • Resting cortisol
    • ACTH stimulation test

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Trichuris vulpis infections occur primarily in canids (dog, fox and coyote) and are rarely detected in felids. 
  • Trichuris felis infections in cats occur primarily in the southern regions of the US.
  • Whipworms have a direct lifecycle
    • Suitable hosts ingest embryonated eggs from infected feces or environment. 
    • Larvae hatch from the embryonated eggs in the small intestine.
    • The prepatent period is 74-90 days before maturation into adult worms and shedding of eggs.
    • Adult worms reside in the cecum and adjacent large intestine producing eggs which are shed in the feces
  • In the environment, the unembyonated eggs may survive for years and are very resistant to desiccation, extremes in temperature, and ultraviolet radiation making it a challenging parasite to eradicate from contaminated areas. 
  • The prevalence of whipworm infections ranges from 0.8 to 12.3%.
  • Whipworms have a worldwide distribution.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

  • In 1,626,104 samples submitted for fecal screening during wellness visit testing of dogs, the whipworm antigen immunoassay detected whipworms in 0.9% of dogs, while fecal flotation detected whipworm in 1.0%. Combining fecal flotation with the whipworm antigen immunoassay increased the detection to 1.4% of samples.
  • Traditionally, diagnosis of whipworms is made by fecal flotation.
    • Whipworm eggs are ovoid in shape, brown coloured and have prominent bipolar plugs.
      • Size: 72-90 x 32-40 µm
    • The eggs are dense compared to other intestinal parasites so passive flotation methods may not efficiently recover the eggs.
    • The lengthy pre-patent period may allow infections to go undetected on fecal flotation for a longer period of time than other nematodes, thus increasing the chance for the appearance of clinical signs prior to evidence of eggs in the stool. 
  •  Whipworm antigen immunoassay detects whipworm-specific antigens secreted from the Trichuris vulpis ﻿and ﻿Trichuris felis﻿ parasites.
    • The whipworm-specific antigen is secreted from adult whipworms and is not present in whipworm eggs or early larval stages.

   References

 

  • CAPC Guidelines: Whipworms. Companion Animal Parasite Council. capcvet.org/guidelines/trichuris-vulpis. Accessed July 27, 2022.
  • DiBartola SP. Clinicopathologic findings resembling hypoadrenocoticsm in dogs with primary gastrointestinal disease. JAVMA. 1985; 187(1): 60-63.
  • Elsemore DA, Geng J, Flynn L, Cruthers L, Lucio-Forster A, Bowman DD. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of Trichuris vulpis in dogs. J Vet Diagn Invest. 2014;26(3):404-411.
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 7th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders Elsevier; 2010.
  • Geng J, Elsemore D, Ketzis J. ELISA detection of Trichuris serrata corproantigen in cats. presented at American Association of Veterinary Parasitologists- 59th Annual Meeting; July 26-29, 2014; Denver, CO.
  • Graves TK, Schall WD, Refsal K, Nachreiner RF. Basal and ACTH-stimulated plasma aldosterone concentrations are normal or increased in dogs with trichuriasis-associated pseudohypoadrenocorticism.  J Vet Intern Med. 1994. Vol 8 (4): 287-289.
  • Little SE, Johnson EM, Lewis D, Jakilitsh RP, et al. Prevalence of intestinal parasites in pet dogs in the United States” Vet Parasitology. 2009; 166: 144-152.
  • Sweet S, Hegarty E, McCrann DJ, Kincaid D, Szlosek D. A 3-year retrospective analysis of canine intestinal parasites: fecal testing positivity by age, U.S. geographical region and reason for veterinary visit. Parasite Vector, 2021;14(10):173.
  • Zajac AM, Conboy GA, eds. Veterinary Clinical Parasitology, 8th ed. Ames, IA, Wiley-Blackwell; 2012.

mBIL:
Description:  Bilirubinuria is an indicator of conjugated bilirubin in the urine.  Excessive bilirubinuria in a dog or any bilirubinuria in a cat is an indication to evaluate serum bilirubin concentrations.

 

Positive Urine Bilirubin 

  

  • Mild increases may be normal in some dogs with concentrated urine (especially males)
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis 
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocoele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia)
  • False positive reactions due to medications
    • Phenothiazines  (e.g., chlorpromazine)
    • Etodolac

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Urine Bilirubin

 

  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic of biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL/Spec fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocoele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)

 

Negative Urine Bilirubin

  

 

  • Negative urine bilirubin is a normal finding
  • Artifact - False negatives
    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Centrifugation of urine prior to analysis
    • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Conjugated bilirubin passes freely through the glomerular filtration barrier and is excreted in urine.
  • Unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin and does not normally pass through the glomerular filtration barrier. Therefore, it is not detectable in urine (unless albuminuria or glomerular disease is present).
  • Bilirubinuria usually precedes hyperbilirubinemia and icterus
  • Dogs:  Clinically normal dogs may have detectable bilirubinuria in concentrated urine due to a low renal threshold for bilirubin. 
    • Canine renal tubular epithelial cells can also produce conjugated bilirubin from resorbed hemoglobin (hemoglobinuria).
  • Cats:  Normally do not have detectable bilirubinuria so any positive result is significant

 

  Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Bilirubin is detected with a diazonium salt reagent
    • More sensitive for conjugated bilirubin; insensitive to unconjugated bilirubin
  • Dipstick (reagent strips)
    • False positives and false negatives are possible
  • Ictotest reagent tablets
    • Higher sensitivity compared to dipstick
      • Often used to confirm dipstick results
    • False positives and false negatives are possible

 

   References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
