mKET:
Description:  Ketonuria indicates a derangement in energy metabolism that usually occurs in states of negative energy balance. The presence of ketones in the urine is most commonly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis in dogs and cats.

 

Positive Ketones
   

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged fasting or starvation
  • Low carbohydrate diet
  • Strenuous exercise, e.g. endurance racing
  • Exposure to severely cold environment
  • Lactation (in dogs)
  • Genetic diseases
    • Mitochondrial myopathy
    • Glycogen storage disease
  • Persistent fever
  • Artifact - false positive with dipsticks
    • Highly pigmented urine
    • Urine containing
      • Phthalein dyes
      • Compounds with sulfhydryl groups (captopril, valproic acid, d-penicillamine, tiopronin, cystine)
      • Salicylates (e.g. aspirin)
      • Levodopa metabolites
           

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Ketones

 

  • Diabetes mellitus with diabetic ketoacidosis
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL® or Spec cPL® test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administation

 

Negative Ketones
   

  • The absence of ketones is a normal finding
  • False negative
    • Aged urine sample
    • Improper storage of reagent strip (exposed to moisture, heat, or light)

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Ketones, such as beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone, are produced by lipolysis and are filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Normally, ketones are completely resorbed by the proximal tubules.
  • Ketonuria is present before ketonemia can be detected.
  • The severity of ketoacidosis cannot be correlated with the degree of ketonuria.

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Nitroprusside reaction
    • Detects acetoacetate (primarily) and acetone (to a lesser degree)
    • Does not detect beta hydroxybutyrate (the major intermediate in ketosis)

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman SC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine: diseases of the dog and the cat, 8th ed., St, Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA: Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE, Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St. Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO: Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
mPRO:
Description:  Protein in the urine can be an indicator of renal disease (interpret in conjunction with urine concentration) or lower urinary tract disease, when pre-renal causes of proteinuria have been ruled out.

 

 

Positive Urine Protein

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Glomerulonephritis
        • Idiopathic (primary)
        • Immune-mediated/infectious (secondary)
      • Renal amyloidosis
    • Tubular proteinuria
      • Acute and chronic kidney disease
      • Defects in proximal renal tubular function
      • Congenital disorders
    • Functional – transient
      • Fever, shock, cardiac disease, exercise (horse), seizures
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Overflow/overload pre-glomerular proteinuria
      • Bence Jones proteins, hyperglobulinemia
      • Post-colostral proteinuria (foals)
      • Hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Transient mild proteinuria
      • Shock
      • Fever
      • Increased physical exercise
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Inflammation or infection of the upper or lower urinary tract (or reproductive tract in voided specimen)
    • Hemorrhage into the urinary tract or reproductive tract
    • Neoplasia of the urinary tract
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
  • False positives
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Prolonged contact of dipstick reagent pad with alkaline urine
      • Quaternary ammonium or chlorhexidine contamination
      • Pigmenturia
        • Myoglobin
        • Hemoglobin
        • Recent administration of certain blood substitutes (e.g. Oxyglobin)
    • Sulfosalicylic acid test
      • Turbid urine
      • Radiographic contrast media
      • High doses of antibiotics (penicillin, cephaloridin, sulfisoxazole)
      • Co-precipitation of urinary crystals due to low pH of reagent

   

 

Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Urine Protein

 

  • Renal proteinuria
    • Small amounts of protein (trace to 1+) can be normal in urine, especially if urine is concentrated.
      • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Urine protein: creatinine (UPC) ratio - increased
    • Chemistry:
      • Decreased albumin
      • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • In primary glomerular disease, decreased renal function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore, azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoeitin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Ascites/pulmonary edema may be present with severe nephrotic syndrome
    • Consistent renal biopsy and electron microscopy results
    • Glomerular proteinuria
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes:
        • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
        • Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP)
  • Pre-renal proteinuria
    • Chemistry - increased globulins
    • Positive Bence Jones proteins in urine
    • Hemoglobinuria
      • CBC - anemia
      • Chemistry - increased bilirubin
    • Myoglobinuria
      • Chemistry - increased CK, AST
  • Post-renal proteinuria
    • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts or crystals
    • Urine culture - positive with urinary tract infection
    • Transitional cell carcinoma:
      • Urine cytology consistent with neoplasia
      • Positive bladder tumor analyte test
      • Mass visualized on ultrasound
    • Urinary calculi may be visualized on radiographs and ultrasound
  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s Disease)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP
      • Normal SDMA and creatinine
    • Urinalysis - urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • ACTH stimulation
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression

 

Negative Urine Protein

 

  • Clinically normal animal
  • False negatives:
    • Bence Jones protein unreliable
    • Highly buffered alkaline urine (when measuring by sulfosalicyclic acid test)

 

 

Additional Information

 

   Proteinuria Resource Quick Links:

  • View the Urine Protein Diagnostic Algorithm at www.idexx.com/UrineAlgorithm for guidance on when a UPC is indicated based on a positive urine protein result.
  • Learn more about the diagnosis and management of renal proteinuria at www.idexx.com/UrineProtein.

   Physiology

  • When proteinuria is detected, its potential clinical significance must be established.
  • Localization of proteinuria as pre-renal, renal or post-renal is the first step in determining its clinical significance.
  • If it is renal in origin, then the magnitude of proteinuria needs to be quantified and determined to be persistent or not.
  • A UPC ratio can be performed to quantify the degree of renal proteinuria to determine its clinical significance. The UPC ratio is a quantitative measure of all urine proteins. By measuring both the urine creatinine along with the urine protein, the UPC ratio normalizes for variations in urine concentration.
  • The presence of renal proteinuria is a negative prognostic indicator in chronic kidney disease. The greater the magnitude of proteinuria, the greater the risk for progression of renal disease and possible death.
  • Treatments can decrease proteinuria, slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease and improving survival.

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Semiquantitative
    • Colorimetric reagent strip/dipstick
      • Sensitive screening test
      • Primarily detects albumin; does not reliably detect globulins or Bence Jones proteins associated with multiple myeloma.
      • Reported as negative, trace, and 1+ to 3+ or 4+ reaction
    • Acid precipitation tests (includes sulfosalicylic acid test - SSA)
      • Detects albumin and nonalbumin proteins, including Bence Jones paraprotein
      • Historically used to confirm positive dipstick results
      • High specificity, but relatively low sensitivity
  • Quantitative
    • Colorimetric, spectrophotometric
    • Electrophoresis, immunoelectrophoresis
       

   References

  • Feldman EC, Nelson RW.  Canine and Feline Endocrinology and Reproduction, 3rd ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
  • IDEXX Reference Labs. Comparison of automated colorimetric reagent strip method and sulfosalicylic acid (SSA) precipitation method for detection of urine protein. Internal study available at www.idexx.com/SSAstudy.
  • Jacob F, Polzin DJ, Osborne CA, et al. Evaluation of the association between initial proteinuria and morbidity rate or death in dogs with naturally occurring chronic renal failure. J Am Vet Med Assoc 2005;226: 393-400.
  • Jepson RE, Elliot J, Brodbelt D, et al. Effect of control of systemic blood pressure on survival in cats with systemic hypertension. Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 402-409.
  • Kaneko JJ, Harvey JW, Bruss ML.  Clinical Biochemistry of Domestic Animals, 6th ed.  San Diego, CA:  Academic Press; 2008.
  • King JN, Tasker S, Gunn-Moore DA, et al. Prognostic factors in cats with chronic kidney disease. J Vet Intern Med. 2007;21: 906.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Lees GE, Brown SA, et al. Assessment and management of proteinuria in dogs and cats: 2004 ACVIM Consensus Statement (small animal). J Vet Intern Med 2005;19: 377-385.
  • Nabity MB. Re-evaluating urine dipstick protein in dogs: when should you be concerned? Adv Small Anim Med Surg. 2011;24(11): 1-3.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Syme HM, Markwell PJ, Pfeiffer D, et al. Survival of cats with naturally occurring chronic renal failure is related to severity of proteinuria. J Vet Intern Med. 2006;20: 528-535.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.
     

Last updated 12/1/2018
mSG:
Description:  Urine specific gravity (USG) is a measurement of the concentration of the urine. USG is influenced by several factors including: hydration status, presence of protein or glucose, and underlying disease states.   

 

Inappropriate Urine Concentration (in light of hydration status, USG<1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) 

 

  • Resistance to ADH (secondary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus)
    • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Pyometra
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Liver disease
    • Leptospirosis
    • Drug administration (e.g. glucocorticoids, phenobarbital)
    • Hypokalemia
    • Polycythemia
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Acromegaly
  • Osmotic
    • Kidney disease
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Renal tubulopathies (e.g. Fanconi syndrome)
    • Drug administration (e.g. furosemide, hydroxyethyl starch solution)
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Post-obstructive diuresis
    • High salt diet
  • Lack of medullary concentrating ability
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
    • Liver disease
    • Portosystemic shunt
    • Low protein diet
  • Increased water consumption (primary polydipsia)
    • Liver disease
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Urinary tract infection
    • Hypokalemia
    • Psychogenic water drinking (dog)
    • Gastrointestinal disease
  • Central or primary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Inappropriate Urine Concentration

  • An unconcentrated urine specific gravity may be a normal finding in a well-hydrated patient with no other evidence of disease. This is less common in cats.
    • Confirm that the history is consistent with persistently unconcentrated urine (polyuria, polydipsia, changes in urinary habits, weight loss, etc)
    • Confirm that the lack of urine concentration is persistent on multiple samples, especially on a first morning sample, and evaluate in light of hydration status.
    • Dogs can have a USG as low as 1.000 if engaging in water-based games (e.g. pool play, water hunting). 
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoic enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status, but generally not hyposthenuria (<1.008) except in some cases of pyelonephritis or leptospirosis.
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • If ketoacidotic:
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, anion gap
        • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucose and variable ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection.
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis with DKA
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL or Spec cPL test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administration
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubinuria
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - increased with diffuse or severe disease causing decreased liver function or acquired shunts
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
      • Vascular anomaly
        • Portosystemic shunt (PSS)
          • May be congenital or acquired secondary to end-stage liver disease
          • CBC:
            • Decreased MCV
            • Blood film review - variably abnormal RBC morphology (poikilocytosis)e.g. target cells in dogs and keratocytes in cats, ovalocytes, acanthocytes
          • Chemistry:
            • Mild to moderately increased ALP, GGT and AST
            • Decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose
            • Creatinine may be decreased (cats)
          • Urinalysis - ammonium biurate crystalluria
          • Protein C - decreased to <70% of baseline
          • Ammonia - increased
          • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - markedly increased
          • Abdominal radiographs - microhepatica
          • Ultrasound - decreased hepatic and portal veins, subjectively small liver, anomalous vessel may be detected, variable urolithaisis
          • Liver biopsy - microscopic bile duct proliferation, arteriolar proliferation, hypoplasia of intrahepatic portal tributaries, hepatocellular atrophy
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction >60-80%
        • Microvascular dysplasia (portal vein hypoplasia)
          • CBC - usually normal
          • Chemistry:
            • Variably decreased ALT, ALP and AST (typically mild)
            • Variably decreased albumin, BUN, cholesterol and glucose (usually only decreased with severe disease)
          • Urinalysis - usually normal
          • Bile acids - variably increased, usually less severe than with portosystemic shunt
          • Protein C - typically > 70% of baseline
          • Abdominal radiographs - typically normal
          • Abdominal ultrasound - typically normal appearing liver and vasculature, variable secondary urolithiasis
          • Liver biopsy - unable to differentiate from changes seen with portosystemic shunt. Changes may be present in only some liver lobes.
          • Nuclear scintigraphy - calculated shunt fraction < 60%
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol and albumin
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
  • Hypercalcemia
    • Chemistry - increased total calcium
    • Evaluate for underlying causes of hypercalcemia
      • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
        • Assess for evidence of neoplasia (e.g. lymphoma, multiple myeloma, plasma cell tumor, anal gland adenocarcinoma, thymoma) on physical examination with lymph node palpation, abdominal palpation and rectal exam
        • Chemistry:
          • May have increases in SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary kidney damage when both phosphorus and calcium are increased
          • Phosphorus decreased if parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) increased
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - low normal or decreased
        • Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) - variably increased
      • Primary hyperparathyroidism
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased or low normal phosphorus
          • SDMA, creatinine and BUN usually normal unless concurrent dehydration or kidney disease
        • Ionized calcium - increased
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
      • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
        • Adrenal function tests:
          • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
          • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)
      • Evaluate for possible exposure to toxins (e.g. vitamin D)
      • Chronic kidney disease (renal secondary hyperparathyroidism)
        • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
        • Ionized calcium - normal
        • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) - increased
  • Hyperthyroidism
    • CBC - mild increase in RBC, hematocrit and PCV
    • Chemistry - variably increased ALP, phosphorus and glucose
    • Total T4 and Free T4 increased

 

 

Decreased Urine Specific Gravity (hyposthenuria; USG<1.008) 

 

  • Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease)
  • Pyometra
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Atypical leptospirosis
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
  • Central diabetes insipidus

 

  Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased Urine Specific Gravity

 

  • The presence of hyposthenuria (urine specific gravity < 1.008) indicates that the kidneys retain the ability to actively dilute the urine, but are unable to concentrate the urine. There are many overlapping causes of inappropriate urine concentration and hyposthenuria.
  • An unconcentrated urine specific gravity may be a normal finding in a well-hydrated patient with no other evidence of disease. This is less common in cats.
    • Confirm that the history is consistent with persistently hyposthenuric urine (polyuria, polydipsia, changes in urinary habits, weight loss, etc)
    • Confirm that the decreasead urine concentration is persistent on multiple samples, especially on a first morning sample, and evaluate in light of hydration status.
    • Dogs can have a USG as low as 1.000 if engaging in water-based games (e.g. pool play, water hunting). 
  • Hyperadrenocortism
    • CBC:
      • Stress leukogram:
        • Increased neutrophils and monocytes
        • Decreased lymphocytes and eosinophils
        • Normal white blood cell morphology on blood film review
      • Increased platelets, +/- plateletcrit, MPV and PDW
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALP typically higher than ALT or GGT
      • Glucose variably increased
    • Urinalysis - variable proteinuria
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio may be mildly increased
    • Assess history for recent glucocorticoid administration (including topical)
    • Abnormal adrenal function tests:
      • Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
      • ACTH stimulation
    • Ultrasound shows enlarged adrenals and diffusely hyperechoid enlarged liver with smooth margins.
    • Liver cytology/biopsy - vacuolar hepatopathy
  • Pyometra
    • History of recent heat in an intact female
    • CBC:
      • Variable nonregenerative anemia with chronicity
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Urinary casts
      • Variable glucose, proteinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Urine culture with MIC susceptibility - variably positive (may be negative if infection isolated to kidneys)
    • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Atypical leptospirosis
    • Leptospirosis may rarely present with polyuria as the only clinical sign accompanied by minimal changes on minimum data base
      • Chemistry:
        • Increased SDMA
        • Variably mildly increased creatinine and BUN
      • Urinalysis:
        • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria
        • Proteinuria, variable glucosuria
        • Urinary casts (cellular most common, granular casts may also be seen)
      • Confirm infection:
        • A combination of serology and PCR on both peripheral blood and urine is recommended for the highest sensitivity
        • Leptospira antibody by ELISA:
          • Positive in an unvaccinated dog with clinical signs - consistent with infection
          • Negative antibody may be seen in early infection prior to seroconversion
          • Vaccination also results in a positive antibody test
        • Leptospira microagglutination antibody test (MAT) - paired acute and convalescent tests may show a rise in titer consistent with infection. A single titer result less than 1:1600 may be difficult to interpret in a vaccinated dog.
        • Leptospira PCR - positive in peripheral whole blood in early infection, prior to seroconversion. Urine becomes PCR positive 7-14 days after infection (at which point, detection in peripheral blood may be intermittent)
  • Psychogenic polydipsia
    • CBC unremarkable
    • Chemistry:
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • Decreased sodium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment exam
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Serum osmolality - decreased
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • Leptospirosis screening - negative
    • Ability to concentrate with water restriction is variable secondary to medullary washout and loss of concentrating gradient. 
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient.
  • Central diabetes insipidus
    • Rule out other causes of dilute urine prior to investigating for central diabetes insipidus.
    • CBC - variably increased hematocrit, RBC and hemoglobin with secondary dehydration
    • Chemistry - often normal
      • Normal SDMA, creatinine, phosphorus and liver enzymes
      • BUN variably decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity consistently <1.012
      • Negative protein and glucose
      • Inactive sediment
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - negative
    • Serum osmolality variably high, especially with limited access to water
    • Urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg
    • Daily water consumption >100 ml/kg/day
    • Bile acids (pre and post-prandial) - normal
    • Adrenal testing - normal
    • Diagnostic imaging - no evidence of disease
    • ADH or DDAVP therapeutic trial results in the ability to concentrate urine
    • Note: modified water deprivation tests are considered controversial due to high risk of hyperosmolar syndrome and death. They are contraindicated in a dehydrated or azotemic patient.
    • CT or MRI may show pituitary tumor

 

Increased Urine Specific Gravity (hypersthenuria; USG > 1.030 in dogs; > 1.035 in cats; > 1.025 in horses)
     

  • Dehydration
  • Concentrated urine may be a normal finding (especially in cats)
  • Artifact - significant glucosuria or proteinuria may increase urine specific gravity
       

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Urine Specific Gravity

 

  • Dehydration
    • Evaluate for evidence of dehydration on physical exam (skin tent, tacky mucous membranes)
    • CBC:
      • Mild to moderate increase in hematocrit and RBC
      • Normal red blood cell indices (RDW, MCV, MCHC, MCH)
      • Normal reticulocytes and reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased total protein, albumin and globulin
      • Increased sodium and chloride
      • Increased SDMA, BUN and creatinine +/- increased phosphorus (only with severe dehydration)

 

Additional Information

 

   Diagnostic Methodology

 

  • Specific gravity is the ratio of a solution's weight to the weight of an equal volume of water and is a reflection of solute concentration and osmolality.
  • Refractive index is an estimate of urine specific gravity
    • Determined by refractometry
    • Highly dependent on three factors
      • Solute concentration
      • Chemical composition of solute
      • Temperature
  • The refractive index of urine should be measured using a properly calibrated veterinary refractometer since calbration scales are different for human urine.
  • Use of dipsticks for measurement of urine specific gravity of veterinary species is unrelable, and is therefore not recommended
  • Specific gravity of randomly collected urine may indicate adequate concentrating ability by the renal tubules
    • Canine:  >1.030
    • Feline:  >1.035
    • Neonates (dogs and cats < 12 weeks of age) and foals on milk do not have efficient urine concentrating ability
  • The amount of other substrates in the urine should be interpreted with consideration of the specific gravity and vice versa
    • Significant glucosuria and proteinuria can falsely increase the urine specific gravity
  • Interpretation of specific gravity requires knowledge of the patient's hydration status, diet, and medications
    • Diuretics, glucocorticoids, anticonvulsants, excessive thyroid hormone supplementation, fluid therapy, low-protein diet, or administration of radiographic contrast media may lower the USG.
  • Specific gravity indicative of adequate renal tubule concentrating ability does not rule out the presence of diseases associated with polyuria/polydipsia, including hepatic insufficiency, hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s disease), hyperthyroidism or diabetes mellitus.

 

  References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Sykes JE. Canine and Feline Infectious Diseases, 1st ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2014.
  • Toulsa O, Center SA, Brooks MB, et al. Evaluation of plasma protein C activity for detection of hepatobiliary disease and portosystemic shunting in dogs. J Am Vet Med Assoc 2006; 229: 1761-1771.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds. Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
mUBG:
Description: Urobilinogen can be an indicator of increased serum bilirubin.  However, there is a poor correlation between increased levels of urobilinogen and either hepatobiliary disease or hemolysis in dogs and cats.

 

Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis
    • Immune-mediated red blood cell destruction
    • Increased red blood cell destruction (non-immune; e.g. Heinz body anemia)
  • Liver disease
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis
    • Pancreatitis
    • Biliary disease (e.g. mucocoele, gall bladder stones, cholecystitis, biliary cancer)
  • Artifact - False positives due to medications
    • Aminosalicylic acid
    • Sulfonamides
    • Aminobenzoic acid

 

 Next Steps and Related Findings for Positive Urobilinogen

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemia
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes +/- nucleated RBCs
      • Platelets decreased if concurrent immune-mediated thrombocytopenia (Evan's syndrome)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Spherocytosis (in dogs) and/or blood parasites may be seen on blood film review
    • Positive Coombs or saline agglutination test
    • Chemistry - increased serum bilirubin
    • Urinalysis - variable hemoglobinuria
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of secondary IMHA:
      • Assess for history of recent vaccination or medication
      • Serology, PCR or antigen testing positive for infectious causes (e.g. anaplasmosis, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, hemotropic Mycoplasma, babesiosis, cytauxzoonosis)
      • Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
      • Assess thoracic and abdominal imaging for neoplasia
    • Primary IMHA is a diagnosis of exclusion of secondary causes.
  • Heinz body anemia (oxidative injury)
    • CBC:
      • Decreased hematocrit, RBC, hemoglobin, MCHC and MCH
      • Increased MCV and RDW
      • Increased reticulocytes
      • Increased nucleated RBCs
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Blood film review: Heinz bodies, target cells, basophilic stippling, polychromasia +/- mild spherocytosis
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased serum bilirubin
      • Increased ALP, AST, +/- GGT, ALT
      • Intravascular hemolysis noted (red color to serum)
    • Urinalysis:
      • Hemoglobinuria
      • Proteinuria
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of Heinz body anemia:
      • Increased zinc concentration
      • Abdominal radiographs may reveal gastrointestinal metallic foreign body
      • History of exposure to drugs or dietary causes of Heinz body anemia, e.g.:
        • Onions
        • Garlic
        • Propylene glycol
        • Acetominophen (dogs and cats)
        • Phenothiazine (horses)
  • Liver disease
    • CBC:
      • May have regenerative anemia due to secondary gastrointestinal bleeding and/or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
      • Decreased RBC, hematocrit
      • Initially increased MCV and RDW with regeneration, then developing microcytosis (decreased MCV) and hypochromasia (decreased MCHC) with severe or continued blood loss.
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Reticulocytes initially increased, but then decreased as iron deficiency or anemia of chronic inflammatory disease develops
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • ALT increases with severity, may be increased >100-fold in acute disease, reducing with chronicity and/or loss of functional hepatic mass
      • AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin variably increased
      • With loss of liver function, albumin, BUN, glucose and cholesterol may be decreased
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine specific gravity often inappropriate in light of hydration status due to low BUN and/or altered thirst
      • Variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent elevated serum bilirubin
    • Coagulation panel - PT and PTT may be prolonged with severe disease
    • Abdominal imaging - abnormal liver size, structure or echogenicity
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Infectious liver diseases
        • CBC - variable mild to moderate thrombocytopenia (especially with leptospirosis)
        • Urinalysis - proteinuria, glucosuria and casts may be seen with leptospirosis
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Consider infectious disease testing:
          • Aerobic and anaerobic culture on fresh liver biopsy or aspirate
          • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (e.g. leptospirosis, toxoplasmosis, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP])
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - neutrophilic inflammation
      • Inflammatory 
        • Increased C-reactive protein (CRP)
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - variable, lymphocytic/plasmacytic inflammation most common
        • Copper quantification or staining - may have secondary mild to moderate increases in copper in the liver
        • Evaluate for extrahepatic diseases which may cause secondary liver inflammation
          • Spec cPL/fPL test positive with pancreatitis
          • Abnormal cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate with inflammatory bowel disease
      • Toxic insult
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially hepatotoxic drugs (e.g. NSAIDs, phenobarbital, corticosteroids, methimazole/carbimazole, mushroom, sago palm, aflatoxin, ragwort (horses), xylitol, tetracycline, heavy metals, idiosyncratic drug reactions)
        • CBC - low white blood cell count with methimazole or phenobarbital toxicity
        • Urinalysis - Fanconi-like syndrome (glucosuria, ketonuria, aminoaciduria) may be seen with jerky treats or heavy metals
        • Phenobarbital concentrations may be predictive of toxicity, but some animals may have toxicity with therapeutic levels
        • Liver cytology/biopsy - liver cell necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation
      • Hepatic lipidosis (cats)
        • CBC- nonregenerative anemia of chronic inflammatory disease
        • Chemistry:
          • Increased ALP>GGT; GGT usually normal to only mildly increased unless concurrent inflammatory disease
          • Decreased BUN
          • Increased ALT
          • Variable cholesterol and albumin
        • Radiographs - enlarged liver with smooth margins
        • Ultrasound - diffusely hyperechoic liver; abdominal effusion may be present if secondary to pancreatitis
        • Liver cytology or biopsy consistent with severe vacuolar hepatopathy
        • Investigate for underlying causes:
          • Spec fPL test increased with pancreatitis
          • Cobalamin (vitamin B12) and folate variably abnormal with inflammatory bowel disease
          • History of stress or household changes
      • Neoplasia
        • Abdominal ultrasound - enlarged or irregular liver, mass(es) within liver or diffuse infiltration may be seen
        • Chest radiographs - evaluate for metastasis to lungs
        • Liver biopsy or cytology consistent with primary neoplasia (e.g. hepatic adenocarcinoma, adenoma) or secondary metastasis
  • Extrahepatic cholestasis (pancreatic of biliary disease) 
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia (decreased RBC, hematocrit, normal reticulocytes)
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Inflammatory leukogram
      • Platelets mildly to moderately decreased
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased ALT, AST, ALP, GGT and bilirubin
      • Amylase and lipase variably increased with pancreatitis
      • Cholesterol and triglycerides variable
    • Urinalysis - variable bilirubin or ammonium biurate crystalluria
    • Bile acids - not helpful if concurrent increased serum bilirubin
    • Next steps to evaluate for causes of extrahepatic cholestasis:
      • Spec cPL/Spec fPL test - increased with pancreatitis
      • Abdominal imaging:
        • Radiographs may reveal gall bladder stones or mineralization of the biliary tract
        • Abdominal ultrasound may show evidence of mucocoele, gall bladder stones, bile duct distention, biliary masses or pancreatitis.

 

Negative Urobilinogen

 

  • A negative urobilinogen is a normal finding
  • Artifact - False negative
    • Exposure to UV light or room air
    • Delayed analysis
    • Formalin

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Intestinal bacteria convert conjugated bilirubin to urobilinogen (a colorless compound)
  • Most is excreted in the feces.  The remainder is delivered back to the liver via portal blood, recycled, and excreted in the bile. 
  • A small amount of urobilinogen passes through the glomerular filtrate into urine.
  • Diagnostic utility is limited.

 

  References

 

  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds.  Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Osborne CA, Stevens JB.  Urinalysis:  A Clinical Guide to Compassionate Patient Care.  Shawnee Mission, KS:  Bayer Corporation; 1999.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
mpH:
Description:  The pH of urine is an index of acid-base balance but is not a reliable indicator of blood pH.

 

Decreased pH (Acidic)
   

  • Metabolic acidosis
    • Ethylene glycol intoxication
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Kidney failure
    • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
    • Lactic acidosis
  • High protein or milk-based diet
  • Paradoxical aciduria (acid urine pH with metabolic alkalosis) due to severe vomiting
  • Drugs/toxins (e.g. urinary acidifiers, furosemide, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, salicilates, paraldehyde, methanol)
  • Respiratory acidosis
  • Vomiting with chloride depletion or severe diarrhea
  • Proximal renal tubular acidosis with bicarbonate depletion
  • Fever, starvation or prolonged exercise
  • Decreased serum potassium
  • Hydrogen production by bacteria

   

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Decreased pH

 

  •  Ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2 (bicarbonate) and calcium
    • Urinalysis
      • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses. Inappropriate urine concentration in light of hydration status
      • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals most common
    • Serum and urine ethylene glycol concentrations - may be increased or normal (testing must be done within 12 hours of exposure with most tests)
    • Radiographs or ultrasound may show mineralization of kidney tissue
  • Diabetes mellitus with diabetic ketoacidosis
    • CBC - variable nonregenerative anemia (with chronic disease) or increased RBC, hematocrit and hemoglobin with dehydration
    • Chemistry:
      • Increased glucose, ALP, ALT and cholesterol
      • ALP increases typically greater than ALT
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and anion gap
      • Decreased TCO2, sodium and potassium
    • Urinalysis:
      • Glucosuria, ketonuria
      • Bacteriuria and increased white blood cells may be seen with secondary urinary tract infection
    • Fructosamine - increased
    • Blood gas - metabolic acidosis
    • Evaluate for predisposing or secondary conditions:
      • Spec fPL® or Spec cPL® test - increased with concurrent pancreatitis (especially cats)
      • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive with secondary urinary tract infection (common)
      • History of recent glucocorticoid administation
  • Kidney disease
    • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate a complete urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria and/or active sediment.
    • Urinalysis: urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status
    • Chemistry: 
      • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
      • Electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic acidosis, hypo- or hypercalcemia
    • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
    • Increased blood pressure
    • Abdominal imaging shows abnormal kidney size and structure or evidence of pyelonephritis.
    • Investigate for underlying causes:
      • Toxic insult:
        • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
        • Urinalysis: urinary casts, proteinuria and/or glucosuria
      • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
        • Increased urine protein: creatinine ratio
        • Chemistry:
          • Decreased albumin
          • High cholesterol with nephrotic syndrome
      • Infectious kidney diseases:
        • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
          • Positive urine culture with pyelonephritis
          • Positive PCR or serology for infectious diseases (Leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, FIP, toxoplasmosis)
      • Evaluate for evidence of inflammation (may be localized to the urinary system or systemic with more severe infectious disease)
        • Complete urinalysis with sediment:
          • Urinary casts
          • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria with pyelonephritis
        • CBC:
          • Inflammatory leukogram
          • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin
        • C-reactive protein (CRP): increased with systemic inflammation
    • Assess for confounding conditions:
      • Hydration status, blood pressure, urine protein: creatinine ratio, thyroid status
  • Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's disease)
    • CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Normal to increased lymphocytes and eosinophils
    • Chemistry:
      • Variably decreased sodium and chloride
      • Variably increased potassium and calcium
      • Decreased cholesterol, albumin and albumin:globulin ratio
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine and BUN with secondary decreased renal perfusion and GFR
    • Urinalysis - urine concentration inappropriate in light of hydration status; urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses
    • Adrenal function tests:
      • Decreased resting serum cortisol (screening test)
      • Lack of response on ACTH stimulation test (diagnostic test)

 

Increased pH (Alkaline)
   

  • Recent meal (postprandial alkaline tide)
  • Artifact
    • Delayed sample analysis (spontaneous degeneration of urea)
    • Pigmenturia
  • Urinary tract infection (UTI) with urease-producing bacteria
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Respiratory alkalosis
  • Proximal renal tubular acidosis (early) or distal renal tubular acidosis
  • Diets rich in vegetables and cereals (e.g. horses)
     

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased pH

 

  • Urinary tract infection
    • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyenephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Struvite crystalluria common
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - positive for urease-producing bacteria (e.g. Staphylococcus spp. or Proteus spp.)
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Abdominal radiographs- variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Abdominal ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Urine pH is a measure of the hydrogen ion concentration in urine.
  • Urine pH is determined by the kidney's ability to regulate hydrogen ion and bicarbonate concentrations within the blood.
  • Normal urine pH in dogs and cats: 6.0-7.5
  • Normal urine pH in horses is typically alkaline.
  • Urine pH is variable based on diet
    • Cats and dogs usually have acidic urine
    • Anorexia can cause an acidic urine
    • Cats and dogs on vegetable-based diet may have an alkaline urine

 

  References

 

  • Latimer KS, Mahaffey EA, Prasse KW, eds.  Duncan and Prasse's Veterinary Laboratory Medicine:  Clinical Pathology, 4th ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2003.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
  • Willard MD, Tvedten H, eds.  Small Animal Clinical Diagnosis by Laboratory Methods, 4th ed.  St. Louis, MO:  Saunders; 2004.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
nhCST:
Description:  Non-hyaline casts form from cells within the renal tubules and include cellular (epithelial cells, WBCs, RBCs), granular and waxy casts. Non-hyaline casts most commonly indicate renal injury, primarily tubular in nature. However, fine granular casts may be seen in low numbers in the urine of clinically healthy dogs and cats.

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm.

The images represent (from left to right) cellular casts, granular casts and waxy casts

  

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/CastImages. 

 

Increased Non-Hyaline Casts

 

  • Epithelial or WBC cellular casts
    • Acute kidney injury or failure
      • Toxicity (e.g. NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, ethylene glycol)
      • Renal ischemia/shock/hypoperfusion
      • Infection (e.g. leptospirosis)
      • Renal infarction
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Glomerulonephritis
  • Erythrocyte (RBC) cellular casts
    • Vasculitis
    • Renal hemorrhage
  • Granular casts
    • Low numbers (0-2/lpf) of fine granular casts may be a normal finding
    • Fever/exercise (low numbers of fine granular casts)
    • Acute kidney injury or failure (fine or coarse granular casts)
      • Toxicity (e.g. NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, ethylene glycol)
      • Renal ischemia/shock/hypoperfusion
      • Infection (e.g. leptospirosis)
      • Renal infarction
  • Waxy casts
    • Chronic kidney disease (e.g. tubulointerstitial disease, amyloidosis)

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Non-Hyaline Casts

 

  • Confirm that there is other evidence of kidney disease such as supportive history (weight loss, decreased appetite, polyuria, polydipsia), abnormal kidney palpation and/or abnormal imaging. Evaluate the urinalysis for inappropriate urine specific gravity, proteinuria or active sediment.
  • CBC - variable abnormalities depending on underlying cause
  • Chemistry:
    • Increased SDMA, creatnine, BUN and phosphorus
    • May have increased total calcium and decreased ionized calcium
  • Urinalysis:
    • Urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.205 in horses; inappropriate concentration in light of hydration status.
    • Variable proteinuria
    • Variable active sediment
  • Investigate for underlying causes:
    • Protein-losing nephropathy (glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis)
      • CBC - mild to moderate nonregenerative anemia with chronic kidney disease (due to decreased erythropoietin)
      • Chemistry
        • Decreased albumin
        • High cholesterol in nephrotic syndrome
        • Increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus
          • In primary glomerular disease, decreased kidney function is seen when protein loss results in secondary tubular damage. Therefore azotemia may not be present in early stages of primary glomerular disease.
      • Urinalysis:
        • Hyaline or cellular casts more common
        • Proteinuria
        • Otherwise inactive sediment
      • Urine protein: creatinine ratio - increased
      • Blood pressure - variably increased
      • Evaluate for infectious or immune-mediated causes of glomerular proteinuria:
        • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, feline infectious peritonitis [FIP], toxoplasmosis)
        • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer
    • Toxic insult:
      • History/possibility of exposure to toxins or potentially nephrotoxic drugs
      • Urinalysis:
        • Granular or epithelial casts more common than hyaline casts
        • Proteinuria and/or glucosuria
        • Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals with ethylene glycol toxicity
    • Infectious kidney diseases:
      • CBC:
        • Inflammatory leukogram
        • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
      • Urinalysis:
        • Variable pyuria, hematuria and bacteriuria
        • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria
        • Urinary casts (granular or epithelial cellular casts more common)
      • Consider urine culture with MIC susceptibility and infectious disease testing:
        • PCR or serology for infectious diseases (leptospirosis, Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis, FeLV, FIV, toxoplasmosis)
        • Urine culture with MIC susceptibility - variably positive with pyelonephritis (may be negative if infection is localized to kidneys)
      • C-reactive protein (CRP) - increased
      • Ultrasound - dilation of the renal pelvises may be seen with pyelonephritis; enlarged kidneys with hyperechoic cortices may be seen with other infectious causes.

 

Additional Information

 

   Physiology

 

  • Casts are cylindrical concretions formed within the renal tubules from proteins, intact cells, or cellular debris.
  • Cellular casts are made up of renal tubular epithelial cells +/- RBCs and WBCs. These often occur when renal tubular epithelial cells degenerate, necrose and then slough into the lumen of the tubules.
  • Granular casts (fine or coarse) represent degenerated cellular casts.
  • Waxy casts are the final stage of cast degeneration and have typically been within the tubule lumen for a prolonged period of time. Waxy casts indicate prior tubular injury +/- urine stasis. They are readily observable due to smooth appearance, no internal texture and high refractibility. Waxy casts are always of pathologic significance.
  • Some casts (typically hyaline or fine granular) may be seen in healthy animals from normal turnover of tubular epithelial cells or following physical activity or fever. 
    • These are less than approximately 1-2 per low power field in moderately concentrated urine of otherwise normal patients.
  • RBC casts are thought to be the result of leakage of RBCs through the glomerular membrane or by bleeding into the tubules. 
  • Hemoglobin casts are the result of degradation of RBCs in the cast matrix.
  • WBC casts are usually composed of neutrophils.
  • Some casts are shed intermittently (or in showers), so the absence of casts does not preclude active renal tubular disease
  • Casts can deteriorate rapidly, especially in dilute, alkaline, or aged samples.
  • Agressive centrifugation (>250g) may distort casts.
  • The number of casts is not a reliable index of the severity, duration, or reversibility of the underlying disease.

 

   References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Ringsrud KM. Casts in the urine. Laboratory Medicine, 32(4): 2001; 191-193.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed. Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.

 

Last updated 12/1/2018
nsEPI:
Description:  Epithelial cells may be a normal finding in the urine (especially in voided or catheterized samples) but may also indicate inflammation, infection, or neoplasia in the urinary tract. The most common non-squamous epithelial cells are transitional cells which line the urinary tract from the renal pelvis to the mid-urethra.  

 

Images are provided by IDEXX SediVue Dx Urine Sediment Analyzer. Reference Bar = 20 µm. 

Images represent transitional epithelial cells.

   

To view additional SediVue Dx Reference images, visit www.idexx.com/EpithelialCellImages.  

 

Increased Non-Squamous Epithelial Cells

 

  • May be a normal finding (especially in voided or catheterized samples)
  • Urinary tract infection
    • Bacterial cystitis
    • Pyelonephritis
    • Prostatitis
  • Urinary tract inflammation
    • Feline indiopathic cystitis (feline lower urinary tract disease [FLUTD])
    • Urolithiasis
  • Neoplasia
    • Transitional cell carcinoma (nonsquamous epithelial cells)
    • Urinary/prostatic carcinoma

 

   Next Steps and Related Findings for Increased Non-Squamous Epithelial Cells

 

  • Confirm whether there are clinical signs (polyuria, polydipsia, change in urinary habits) or physical exam findings that suggest active urogenital disease.
  • Urinary tract infection
    • Evaluate urinalysis findings in light of clinical signs, CBC and chemistry results to localize infection and determine clinical significance and treatment plan. Learn more at www.idexx.com/UrineBacteria. 
    • CBC:
      • Often normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Inflammatory leukogram with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB) with pyelonephritis or prostatitis
    • Chemistry:
      • May be normal with simple bacterial cystitis
      • Variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN and phosphorus with pyelonephritis
    • Urinalysis:
      • Urine concentration variable; may be inappropriate in light of hydration status (urine specific gravity <1.030 in dogs; <1.035 in cats; <1.025 in horses) due to increased water intake, pyelonephritis and/or endotoxins released by certain bacterial strains (e.g. E. coli)
      • Active urinary sediment: pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria
      • Variable glucosuria and proteinuria (with pyelonephritis)
      • Variable urinary casts (with pyelonephritis)
      • Neutral to alkaline urine pH
      • Struvite crystalluria (typically with urease-producing bacteria)
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility positive
    • Abdominal imaging
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound:
        • Bladder wall thickening (cystitis) with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
        • Dilation of the renal pelvises and ureters may be seen with pyelonephritis
  • Feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Significant struvite crystalluria common  
      • Hematuria with equivocal pyuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - no growth
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - variable radiopaque urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Ultrasound - bladder wall thickening with variable urinary calculi or sand/sludge
      • Contrast studies may reveal obstruction
  • Urolithiasis
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary urinary obstruction
    • Urinalysis: 
      • Active urinary sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Bacteriuria with secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
      • Variable crystalluria. Crystal type may not match stone composition
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs - radiopaque stones may be visible (struvite, calcium oxalate)
      • Ultrasound - calculi visualized, bladder wall thickening and sand/sludge may be present
      • Contrast studies may reveal ureteral or urethral obstruction
      • Double-contrast studies may be required to visualize radiolucent uroliths (e.g. cystine, xanthine and urate uroliths)
  • Neoplasia (e.g. transitional cell carcinoma [TCC], prostatic carcinoma)
    •  CBC:
      • Nonregenerative anemia
      • Variable inflammatory leukogram
      • Decreased reticulocyte hemoglobin (RETIC-HGB)
    • Chemistry - variably increased SDMA, creatinine, BUN, phosphorus and potassium with secondary obstruction
    • Urinalysis:
      • Active urine sediment - pyuria, hematuria
      • Atypical transitional cells or carcinoma cells may be seen
        • Cytology must be performed to confirm neoplasia
      • Bacteriuria due to secondary infection common
      • Proteinuria
    • Urine culture and MIC susceptibility - variably positive with secondary infection
    • Abdominal imaging:
      • Radiographs:
        • Prostate neoplasia - enlarged prostate with or without mineralization and sublumbar lymph node involvement
      • Abdominal ultrasound:
        • Transitional cell carcinoma - mass seen in bladder or proximal urethra
        • Prostate carcinoma - abnormal or enlarged irregular mixed echogenicity prostate
    • Cytology - required to confirm diagnosis of neoplasia; performed on urine sediment cytology preparation or following traumatic catheterization (best for TCC) or fine needle aspirate of prostate if prostatic neoplasia is suspected.

 

Additional Information

 

  Physiology

 

  • Three types of epithelial cells can be found in the urine:  transitional epithelial cells, squamous epithelial cells, and (rarely) renal epithelial cells.
  • The type of epithelial cells seen will depend on the method of collection.  Transitional or squamous epithelial cells may be seen in voided or catheterized samples. Transitional cells, but not squamous epithelial cells, may be seen in a cystocentesis sample.
  • Transitional epithelial cells line the mucosa from the renal pelvis through the proximal/middle urethra. 
    • Cellular appearance - larger than RBC's and WBC's, round in shape and variably-sized with medium-sized round eccentric nuclei, 1 or 2 uniform nucleoli, if seen, and moderate amount of amorphous to finely granular cytoplasm with smooth to occasionally slightly angular cell margins.  Their nuclear to cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio is moderate.
  • Squamous epithelial cells line the distal urethra and external genitalia. 
    • Cellular appearance - larger than RBC's and WBC's, flat and polygonal in shape with small and round or oval, slightly eccentric nuclei if present, mostly indistinct nucleoli, and abundant amount of amorphous cytoplasm with angular and sometimes folded cell margins. Their N:C ratio is low. Squamous epithelial cells may be keratinized or non-keratinized.
  • Renal epithelial cells line the renal tubules. 
    • Cellular appearance - 3-5 times the diameter of a RBC, cuboidal to round in shape with round central nuclei, 1 or 2 uniform nucleoli, if seen, and mild amount of granular cytoplasm with smooth cell margins.  Their N:C ratio is moderate to high.
  • Increased numbers of squamous cells can be seen in voided or catheterized samples in intact dogs during estrus.
  • In cases of inflammation and infection, changes in epithelial cells can be difficult to characterize as hyperplastic (reactive to inflammation) versus neoplastic.
  • Cells can deteriorate in urine and should be evaluated on a fresh sample (or using air-dried smear made from fresh sample if analysis delayed).

  

  References

 

  • Bartges J, Polzin D, eds. Nephrology and Urology of Small Animals, 1st ed. Ames, IA: Wiley-Blackwell; 2011.
  • Cowell RL, Tyler RD, Meinkoth JH and DiNicola DB.  Diagnostic Cytology and Hematology of the Dog and Cat, 3rd ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier Saunders; 2008.
  • www.eclinpath.com (Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine)
  • Ettinger SJ, Feldman EC, Cote E, eds. Textbook of Veterinary Internal Medicine, 8th ed. St. Louis, MO:  Elsevier; 2017.
  • Stockham SL, Scott MA.  Fundamentals of Veterinary Clinical Pathology, 2nd ed.  Ames, IA:  Blackwell; 2008.
